title: A Harlem Mans First Steps Toward Self-Reliance

title: Scope of National Security Inquiry Is Revealed
description: After a decade of court battles, the Internet entrepreneur who filed the first legal challenge to a type of secret administrative order known as a national security letter revealed on Monday the breadth of an F.B.I. demand in 2004 for information about a customer.

title: Narendra Modi Could Make or Break Obamas Climate Legacy
description: LE BOURGET, France  Since Prime Minister Narendra Modi came to power, President Obama has not missed many opportunities to convey what a warm rapport he has forged with the Indian leader.

title: Giants Lose Geoff Schwartz for Season as Injuries Pile Up
description: For the banged-up Giants, Mondaysinjury news was not uplifting. Guard Geoff Schwartz, who was considered a key acquisition during the 2014 off-season but missed 14 games because of foot and ankle problems last year, was lost for the rest of the season with a broken left leg sustained in Sundays loss to the Washington Redskins.

title: Mayor de Blasio Promotes Smoother Ride on F.D.R. Drive
description: A few months after moving into Gracie Mansion, Mayor Bill de Blasio approached his transportation commissioner with a question: How do we fix the Franklin D. Roosevelt Drive?

title: Syrian Family of 7 Is Settled in New Jersey Against Christies Opposition
description: Despite the vow by Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey not to accept any more Syrian refugees and withhold state financial support, another Syrian refugee family arrived in the state on Monday night.

title: Senate Confirms Gayle E. Smith as Head of U.S.A.I.D.
description: WASHINGTON  The Senate on Monday voted to confirm Gayle E. Smith, a former national security aide to President Obama, to lead the United States Agency for International Development, the federal agency responsible for overseas humanitarian issues like feeding refugees, building clinics and distributing foreign aid.

title: The I.M.F.s Tool, and What It Means for World Trade
description: The United States dollar was once the standard reserve currency for the International Monetary Fund. But in the 1960s and early 70s, as the Vietnam War dragged on and the United States ran persistent trade deficits, the dollar came to be seen as overvalued.

title: U.S. Tightens Visa-Waiver Program in Bid to Deter Militants
description: PARIS  The White House announced changes Monday to the governments visa-waiver program to try to stop those who have visited conflict zones from easily boarding American-bound commercial flights, a move intended to prevent an attack in the United States similar to the ones that struck Paris.

title: Judge Sets Next Proceedings in Suit by Redstones Former Companion
description: A California judge decided on Monday to go forward with proceedings in a lawsuit filed by a former companion of the 92-year-old media mogul Sumner M. Redstone who has challenged his mental competence, but rejected a petition to treat the case as urgent.

title: Saving a Vital Patch of Olmsteds Staten Island Eden
description: After Christine Kaasmann died at 100 this year at her beloved Swiss-chalet-style home on Staten Islands South Shore, her three children decided it was time to sell.

title: Four Charged in Shooting of Minneapolis Protesters
description: MINNEAPOLIS  A white man accused of shooting five Black Lives Matter protesters in Minneapolis apparently had racist views and identified with the antigovernment sovereign citizen movement, according to criminal complaints filed Monday charging him in the shooting. Three others were charged with related crimes.

title: Guilty Verdict Is a Spur to Would-Be Reformers of Albanys Political Culture
description: The political culture of Albany was wielded as a shield in Sheldon Silvers defense: If Mr. Silver, the former State Assembly speaker, wrapped himself in financial conflicts of interest and collected millions of dollars in outside income, his lawyers argued, that did not make him a criminal.

title: Facing Giants, Jets Focus on Playoffs, Not Rivalry
description: Jets quarterback Ryan Fitzpatrick asked center Nick Mangold a crucial question on Monday. He wanted to know what a regular-season game against the Giants was like  if it felt different. So Mangold told him.

title: Yankees Chris Young Reportedly Joining Red Sox
description: When Yankees General Manager Brian Cashman was discussing Chris Young, his only free agent of any real consequence, at the general managers meetings last month, he could not have been more complimentary.

title: Pope Francis Ends African Trip With Visit to a Mosque
description: On his maiden visit to Africa, Pope Francis went where most other dignitaries would not  and he went in ways that won him applause from ordinary people.

title: Pfizers Long War on Taxation
description: Long before Pfizer conceived of merging with Allergan in a $150 billion deal to rid itself of what its chief executive called an an uncompetitive tax rate in the United States, the company was deploying various tax avoidance strategies dating back to at least 1976.

title: Love and Disbelief FollowDonald Trump Meeting With Black Leaders
description: It seemed like a powerful counterpoint to the perception of Donald Trump as intolerant: A hundred black ministers and religious leaders would endorse him at his offices in Manhattan, vouching for his sensitivity and broad-mindedness.

title: How the Organizer of the Paris Attacks Slipped Through Authorities Hands
description: Abdelhamid Abaaoud, who organized the Nov. 13 terrorist attacks in Paris, crisscrossed Europe and the Middle East, even though he was on a Belgian watch list.

title: How the Paris Attackers Honed Their Assault Through Trial and Error
description: PARIS  The gunfire had still not subsided, and those who could were running for their lives. But one man was crossing Paris to get close to the scenes of death.

title: Jordan Zimmermann, Like Other Aces, Bets on Himself and Wins Big
description: The Opryland Resort & Convention Center in Nashville is a sprawling wonderland with rivers, waterfalls, plant life and glass ceilings that make you feel like a cast member in The Truman Show, a reality series that is actually just make-believe. Next week, the subject is baseball, back for an encore presentation.

title: The Children Left Behind After Mass Shootings
description: Since no amount of dead bodies seems enough to spur lawmakers to rein in access to guns, lets focus on the living  the children gun violence leaves behind.

title: Iraqi Forces Prepare Next U.S.-Backed Attack on ISIS, With Mosul on Horizon
description: WASHINGTON  In Sinjar, Iraq, fighters from the Islamic State carved a network of tunnels. To defend Hawija, Iraq, they erected a 10-foot sand wall. And virtually everywhere they have surrounded their positions with dense minefields of I.E.D.s, backed by machine guns, mortars and suicide bombers.

title: Gen. Sir Robert Ford Is Dead at 91; British Commander on Bloody Sunday
description: Gen. Sir Robert Ford, the most senior army front-line commander in Northern Ireland when British paratroopers fatally shot 13 unarmed Roman Catholic civil rights protesters in 1972 on what became known as Bloody Sunday, died on Nov. 24. He was 91.

title: Turnover at Alabama Would Give Rivals a Rare Opportunity to Pounce
description: ATLANTA  Alabamas football team does not slog through the rebuilding process like most programs. It just emerges every fall as a national championship contender. Coach Nick Saban, who is in his ninth season with the Crimson Tide, has led them to three Southeastern Conference championships and three national championships, and they will play for a fourth SEC title on Saturday in the Georgia Dome here against Florida.

title: As a Deadline Looms, Paul Ryan Finds Himself in a Boehner-Like Spot
description: WASHINGTON  Remember that big budget deal hatched about a month ago, the one that was going to prevent all those recurring fiscal showdowns for the next two years? Well, it didnt. Now the need to finish the job is putting the House speaker, Representative Paul D. Ryan of Wisconsin, in a tight spot early in his tenure.

title: Ted Cruz Defends Conservatives Views on Contraception
description: Senator Ted Cruz of Texas, dismayed at liberal criticisms of the restrictive reproductive policies favored by some Republicans, mused on Monday that there was not a rubber shortage in America.

title: Cloud of Corruption and Doping Hangs Worldwide
description: The blows to sports credibility keep coming.

title: Eldar Ryazanov, Russian Film Director Known for His Satire, Dies at 88
description: Eldar Ryazanov, whose rueful satires puncturing the absurdities of everyday life in the Soviet Union and the Russia of the post-Gorbachev era made him one of Russias most popular film directors and screenwriters, died on Monday in Moscow. He was 88.

title: Become Hardened
description: TUESDAY PUZZLE  One of the issues that constructors have with creating a quip or quote puzzle is that not all quips or quotes break into chunks that scan well. For solvers, working a puzzle that has a quip or quote that is broken up into weird or partial phrases is not as much fun as one that reads beautifully. For an editor like Will Shortz, who has seen his share of quip or quote puzzles, it can become tiresome to run this type of theme on a regular basis, because repeating themes is boring and because they probably need a lot of work before theyre ready for prime time.

title: Hillary Clinton Email Released by State Department
description: The emails made public on Monday included one that an inspector general had said contained classified information. The State Department said the contents of the email were no longer classified.

title: Clinton Email Is Released After Security Concern Is Dismissed
description: WASHINGTON  A trove of Hillary Clintons emails released by the State Department on Monday shows efforts by aides to solicit advice for a concussion she sustained in 2012 and illustrates Mrs. Clintons personal difficulty with technology. The department also made public one email after rejecting concerns from an inspector general that it contained classified information.

title: Taiwan: Old Enemies Exchange Spies
description: China and Taiwan have engaged in rare exchange of spies, the office of Taiwans president announced on Monday. The exchange, while made public now, actually took place in mid-October, Taiwans Ministry of National Defense said in a statement. China released two officers from Taiwans Bureau of Military Intelligence, and they were returned to Taiwan. The men, Chu Kung-hsun and Hsu Chang-kuo, had been arrested in Vietnam near the border with China in 2006 and given life sentences, which were later reduced to 20 years, according to the Taiwanese newspaper China Times, which first reported the exchange. A Chinese spy imprisoned in Taiwan, Li Zhihao, was given early parole as part of the exchange, Charles Chen, a spokesman for Taiwans presidential office, said in a statement. The exchange of spies, Mr. Chen said, was a sign of improved relations between China and Taiwan.

title: Russia: Turkey Returns Pilots Body
description: The body of Lt. Col. Oleg A. Peshkov, the Russian Air Force pilot killed after his warplane was shot down by Turkey on Nov. 24, was returned to Russia on Monday. Turkey secured the release of his body from inside Syria, and it was flown from Ankara to a military airfield near Moscow, according to Russian news reports. Defense Minister Sergei K. Shoigu and Gen. Viktor N. Bondarev, the commander in chief of the Russian Air Force, met the plane. After his Sukhoi Su-24 bomber had been shot by a Turkish F-16, Colonel Peshkov parachuted from the plane and was killed by ground fire as he floated into Syrian territory. Turkey insisted that the plane had briefly violated its airspace, a claim Russia denied.

title: Baruch Fraternity Leader Says He Knew Rite That Turned Fatal Was Banned
description: STROUDSBURG, Pa.  As the president of the Pi Delta Psi fraternity at Baruch College, Daniel Li acknowledged that he knew the rules forbidding hazing. He also found the rituals that stood between a pledge and membership in a fraternity to be degrading.

title: As Trial Began, a Humble Assemblyman Didnt Appear Guilty to Several Jurors
description: To Arleen Phillips  or, as the rest of the courtroom knew her, Juror No. 6 in the corruption trial of a former State Assembly speaker  Sheldon Silver, the man sitting at the defendants table, did not look guilty of anything but being a politician.

title: Russia: Moscow Delays Enforcing Ban on Turkish Produce to Avoid Inflation
description: Although Russia has said it would ban fruits and vegetables from Turkey in response to the shooting down of a Russian warplane, it will wait several weeks to enforce the sanctions to avoid creating sudden shortages that could fuel inflation, Arkady Dvorkovich, a deputy prime minister, said Monday. The delay will enable Russian importers to identify alternative suppliers, he said. Officials are not considering a ban on industrial imports at this time, said Igor Shuvalov, another deputy prime minister. The list of banned items might be expanded in the future, officials said. Among the measures already announced are limits on travel and tourism between the two countries. Russia has spent almost $750 million on importing Turkish fruits and vegetables so far this year, according to government statistics, and Turkey accounted for about 4 percent of all foodstuffs purchased abroad in 2014. About 90 percent of all lemons sold in Russia come from Turkey, as well as significant amounts of tomatoes, grapes and apricots. About 1,250 Turkish trucks are now stacked up along Russias southern border, Interfax reported.

title: Lawyer Is Refused Boarding on La Guardia Flight After Revolving-Door Mix-Up
description: A prominent Texas lawyer was not allowed to board a Virgin America flight home from New York on Monday because of an encounter with a crew member at La Guardia Airport in Queens, he and the airline said.

title: Fargo Season 2, Episode 8: A Man Without a Country
description: Last week, the critic Alan Sepinwall wrote a persuasive defense of the individual TV episode in the age of serialization. A key part of his argument is that satisfying, distinct episodes neednt be the enemy of novelistic storytelling: Hours like the brain-shredding trip inside Kevin Garveys head in The Leftovers or last weeks Rio Bravo/Assault on Precinct 13-inspired siege in Fargo are stand-alone pleasures that can give a show texture and variety without seeming like a detour. It was nice to see Mr. Sepinwall cite the latter in his piece, because Fargo had been a counterexample all season, a 10-episode narrative juggernaut that seemed entirely of a piece until last week.

title: Donald Trump Tells Georgia Crowd His Critics Cant Take a Joke
description: MACON, Ga.  Donald J. Trump was in full insult mode at a campaign rally here on Monday night as he egged on a man who called President Obama a dumbass and lit into Senator Bernie Sanders of Vermont  may he rest in peace  as well as Hillary Clinton and several fellow Republican candidates.

title: Burkina Faso Elects First New Leader in Decades
description: OUAGADOUGOU, Burkina Faso  A former prime minister who has served in several high-ranking government positions emerged early Tuesday as the winner of the presidential election here, the first time the nation has had a new leader in nearly three decades.

title: Yo La Tengo to Appear in Ecstatic Music Festival
description: The sixth annual Ecstatic Music Festival will bring Yo La Tengo, Rachel Grimes and the Bang on a Can All-Stars to Merkin Concert Hall next year. The collaborative new-music festival will open on Jan. 29 and run through March 19.

description: The pledges that countries have signaled they will make in Paris over the next two weeks to cut emissions will inevitably fall short of what is needed to solve the problem of climate change.

description: By snapping their jaws onto the ground, trap-jaw ants can flip backward and escape threats. Now researchers report that these ants can also jump forward.

description: EUTAW, Ala.  After decades of relentless rise, the number of new cases of diabetes in the United States has finally started to decline.

title: The Dubious Carbon Budget
description: Berlin  OVER the last few years, the concept of a global carbon budget has established itself as a key element of the international climate policy debate. The budget defines the total amount of carbon dioxide we can emit into the atmosphere and still keep warming below 3.6 degrees Fahrenheit, or 2 degrees Celsius, the goal set by the United Nations.

title: Tell Consumers What They Are Eating
description: In approving genetically engineered salmon as safe to eat and safe for the environment, the Food and Drug Administration rejected petitions from environmental and food safety groups asking that companies selling this salmon be required to label it as genetically engineered. Congress should overturn that decision. Consumers deserve to know what they are eating.

I was sad to be reminded that he doesnt actually talk in hip-hop, but he still had some interesting things to say.

title: Sheldon Silvers Albany, Guilty on All Counts
description: Sheldon Silver, one of the most powerful politicians in New York State, was convicted in federal court on Monday on seven counts of corruption, including fraud, extortion and money laundering. That verdict, coming at a time when Dean Skelos, the former State Senate majority leader, is also on trial on federal corruption charges, should sound a loud alarm to all the players in Albany who have become so accustomed to the abuse of power  that they cant see how it infects every aspect of lawmaking. Or perhaps they have been perfectly happy to live with criminality because it suits them politically and financially.

title: Addressing Homelessness in High-Cost Cities
Parenthood and the Problem of Objectivity
description: Does a mothers love obscure her objectivity? One would think that it must, almost by definition. Primal by nature, love for ones children is far from the language of science. What do we do, as doctors and as parents, when the aims of this love run counter to the aims of empirically evidenced treatment?

title: Amid the Buying, a Tuesday Devoted to Giving
description: Every man takes the limits of his own field of vision for the limits of the world, wrote the philosopher Arthur Schopenhauer. That field has been pretty narrow lately, with so much of the news focused on murderous violence  from Paris to Colorado Springs. So lets take note: today is #GivingTuesday, the fourth anniversary of a day that offers a glimpse of the world beyond the pathological extremes: a view of the commonplace generosity and social concerns of millions of people.

But when this season ends, Russell Wilson, the star quarterback for the Seattle Seahawks, may well be judged by an unusual metric: whether his public declaration of celibacy affected his on-field play.

When the women arrived, the lawyer told them that he had received some photographs during his recent trip to Munich but that he did not think they should view them. When they insisted, he urged them to let him call a doctor who could be present when they did.

title: Google Cultural Institute Puts Us All Onstage
description: Stand, virtually, on the stage of the Palais Garnier, among the dancers of the Paris Opera Ballet. Use your mouse to manipulate a 360-degree video that allows you to see them from many angles as they perform Benjamin Millepieds Clear, Loud, Bright, Forward. Or journey to Stratford-upon-Avon, where you can try to keep up with a frenetic Alex Hassell of the Royal Shakespeare Company as Henry V, exhorting his troops to go once more unto the breach.

title: Making Sense of a Fathers Death (With Baudelaires Help)
description: Opium loomed large when Charles Baudelaire wrote The Double Room in the 1860s.

description: Andrew Carnegie supported public libraries, universities and the arts. Bill Gates and Warren Buffett support global health and development and United States education reform.

title: Statement Suits at a White-Shoe Law Firm
description: The men of Skadden Arps update the image of the staid litigator.

title: Statement Suits at a White-Shoe Law Firm
description: As far as modern white-shoe law firms go, few are as prestigious as Skadden, Arps, Slate, Meagher & Flom. For the last 15 years, Skadden Arps has also shared its New York headquarters at 4 Times Square with the fashionable editors of Cond Nast (before the magazine giant relocated to 1 World Trade Center). The editors highfalutin style may have rubbed off on the firms well-compensated associates and partners.

title: Map: Exploring the World, The Curious Map Book and More
description: What is it about maps that we find so fascinating? Ever since the Babylonians scratched two parallel lines and a circle  representing the Euphrates River and their walled capital  on a clay tablet almost 3,000 years ago, we humans have been producing flat spatial imagery to locate our place in the world. Maps anchor us, give coherence to our environment, help make visual sense of otherwise intangible realities. The most skillfully done maps, moreover, can be thrilling to look at, elevating cartography into art. Renaissance mapmakers filled the borders of their works with beautifully rendered dragons and wind-puffing gods; the modernist painter Jasper Johns playfully reimagined the standard road-atlas depiction of the continental United States in his 1961 work Map. Maps can solidify national identity, expose societal problems, illuminate trends and whip up jingoistic emotions in wartime. The map as a concept is complex and ever changing, the Library of Congress cartography expert John Hessler writes in his introduction to Map: Exploring the World. But it is the cartographic images intricate and abstract visual element that is the locus of its strength and lasting appeal.

title: Hollywood: Debbie Reynolds, Mickey Rooney, David Lynch and More
description: Hollywood means so many things to so many people: a town where deals and dreams are made and broken, a crazy place in which to grow up all wrong and yet turn out all right, an abstract Eden whose soil has yielded all kinds of flora, from rapturous Greta Garbo silents to weedlike Star Wars sequels and reboots. And no matter what we think of it today, it has been forever since Hollywood was all its cracked up to be. As Marlene Dietrich once wrote, When I came to Hollywood, the great era of silent films was over and done with. The village was not gay and reckless anymore. The studios operated like any other establishment  one had to clock in at a certain hour and heaven help you if you failed to do so. It remained like this all through the rest of the 30s until I left to join the Army.

title: The Book Cover in the Weimar Republic and Graphic Passion
description: Last week I brought Taschens gorgeous new collection The Book Cover in the Weimar Republic to the art department of the publishing house where I work. I left the book out on a table and watched as my colleagues drifted over, crowded around and riffled through it.

title: Michael Riedels Razzle Dazzle: The Battle for Broadway
description: Could it be that there were saints walking among us in 20th-century Manhattan? And could it be that those saints were a couple of Jewish lawyers? Who lunched at Sardis?

title: Photography: Carl Van Vechten, Cecil Beaton and More
description: Carl Van Vechten (1880-1964) was a big white man with big white teeth who came from Cedar Rapids, Iowa. He cuts an odd figure as portraitist of the Harlem Renaissance and its successors. He was a culture vulture and party-giver who liked to be in on the latest thing, and maybe his friendships with African-American artists and intellectuals represented nothing more than a kind of cultural tourism. Certainly W.E.B. Du Bois mistrusted him, and Ralph Ellison despised his photography, and he alienated many with his sensational 1926 roman  clef, Nigger Heaven. But he got Langston Hughes published, and furthered the careers of others; Walter White, head of the N.A.A.C.P., named his son Carl. And whatever the motivations behind them, his portraits are extraordinary  lapidary and noble and often majestic  and it is clear that he had a genuine rapport with many of his subjects.

description: JAKARTA, Indonesia  The crash of an AirAsia passenger jet off Indonesia last year was caused by a technical fault and a failed attempt by the crew to deal with it, not by bad weather, investigators said on Tuesday.

title: Looking for Charities That Inspire Kids and Families
description: In 2013 and 2014, Ron Lieber and I declared a Motherlode Week of Giving from Dec. 25 to Jan. 1. He had been writing about ways to involve children in giving as well as getting over the holiday season, and we were inspired to ask: What charities have inspired your children to give of their own time or money, and why?

description: Senator Marco Rubio of Florida will make a pair of campaign stops on Tuesday in Alabama and South Carolina, part of his attempt to make inroads in important Southern states that could play decisive roles in determining the Republican presidential nominee.

title: Comedian Jim Gaffigan on How to Travel With Five Kids
description: The comedian Jim Gaffigan shares a two-bedroom apartment in New York City with his wife, Jeannie, and five children. If that sounds like the start of a joke, its because his TV Land comedy series, The Jim Gaffigan Show, is loosely based on his life and informs much of his standup act.

title: Spoiler Alert: This Island Appears in Star Wars
description: On Irelands windswept west coast, the rare day of fine weather finds a few dozen intrepid tourists descending on the tiny fishing village of Portmagee. There, they board boats to one of the countrys most mystical places  Skellig Michael, an uninhabited pinnacle of rock some 50 minutes west through the rough swells of the Atlantic.

title: The Profound Emptiness of Resilience
description: There are many versions of the birds death, but in each, it rises the same way  out of its own ashes and into the sun. The myth of the phoenix, that symbol of endurance, began in Arabian and Egyptian folklore and was brought to the West by Herodotus 2,500 years ago.

title: The Last Dalai Lama?
description: On a wet Sunday in June at the Glastonbury Festival, more than 100,000 people spontaneously burst into a rendition of Happy Birthday. Onstage, Tenzin Gyatso, the 14th Dalai Lama, blew out the solitary candle on a large birthday cake while clasping the hand of Patti Smith, who stood beside him. The worlds most famous monk then poked a thick finger at Smiths silvery mane. Musicians, he said, white hair. But the voice and physical action, he added in his booming baritone, forceful. As Smith giggled, he went on: So, that gives me encouragement. Myself, now 80 years old, but I should be like you  more active!

title: Theres a Formula for Deciding When to Extract Fossil Fuels
description: Drill, Baby, Drill became a popular campaign mantra back in the 2008 election cycle. But now were hearing the opposite call: Leave It in the Ground.

title: Amid Smog Wave, an Artist Molds a Potent Symbol of Beijings Pollution
description: Beijing has been swamped for days in a beige-gray miasma of smog, bringing coughs and rasping, hospitals crowded from respiratory ailments, a midday sky so dim that it could pass for evening, and head-shaking disgust from residents who had hoped the city was over the worst of its chronic pollution.

description: Have you been following this weeks news? Take our quiz to see what you know and to learn more.

title: Uncertainty. Frenzy. And Then Donald Trump Appeared.
description: Donald J. Trumps campaign aides may have canceled his news conference announcing endorsements from black pastors. But he rarely lets an opportunity to speak to the news media go to waste, and he did not disappoint on Monday afternoon.

title: Digital Report Singles Out Fashions Gifted and Challenged
description: L2, the New York-based think tank that tracks brands digital competency across platforms and rates their annual performance, just released its 2015 Fashion Index, and it makes for some pretty eye-opening reading. Not just because, as my colleague Mark Scott noted in a piece for our special luxury report, 10 brands drive 65 percent of site traffic (though that is a kind of astonishing fact in itself) but because it contradicts some pretty widely held beliefs about which brands are good at this digital stuff, and which brands are not.

title: The Best Teams? Look at the Big Games
description: In this world of data-driven precision, weve come to expect everything to the fifth decimal place. Tuesday Morning Quarterback says theres still room for totally unscientific back-of-a-cocktail-napkin thinking. Enter my Authentic Games Index.

title: Holiday Favorites and a Celebration of the New
description: Ailey at City Center

title: A Lineup of Missteps
description: This weeks grab bag of grammar, style and other missteps, compiled with help from colleagues and readers.

title: Mantle on Commerce Street
description: Dear Diary:

title: It Might Be a Young Mans Game, but These Three Are Still Winning
description: Indianapolis quarterback Matt Hasselbeck, who turned 40 in September, is the oldest quarterback in the N.F.L. San Diego tight end Antonio Gates, 35, is the active leader in career touchdowns. Adrian Peterson, 30, ranks second among all active players in both career rushing yards (behind Frank Gore) and career touchdowns (behind Gates). On Sunday, all three players showed they still have something left in the tank.

title: Small News On The Yuan
description: So the IMF has included the renminbi in the SDR, adding a world of hurt to newspaper reports; now everyone will have to deal with Chinas awkward currency nomenclature. (As I understand it, you should use renminbi and yuan more or less as you use sterling and the pound; the RMB is the term for Chinese money in general, the yuan a denomination of its notes.) Its a symbolic event  the first developing country to achieve that status. And if you ask me, it was a bit rushed: China is big, but it still has capital controls, so that its currency really isnt freely negotiable the way the other currencies in the basket are.

title: Out of Danger, After 48 Years
description: How does an endangered species get out of danger?

title: Russians Unlikely to Attack ISIS in Syria, Obama Says
description: LE BOURGET, France  President Obama said Tuesday that despite repeated meetings with President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia on efforts to defeat the Islamic State, no one should be under any illusions that Russian forces would now start attacking the extremist groups positions in Syria.

title: At the Gothams, Spotlight and Spontaneity Win the Night
description: Is it humble to publicly propound the virtues of humility? The Bagger cant quite decide (leaning toward a no). But humility is what Robert Redford said was his equalizer amid the gale force winds of stardom  so I wouldnt take myself too seriously  while accepting a tribute award at the IFP Gotham Independent Film Awards at Cipriani Wall Street on Monday night.

title: A Conversation With Black Women on Race
description: In this short documentary, black women talk about the challenges they face in society.

title: A Conversation With Black Women on Race
description: This latest installment of our Conversation on Race Op-Doc video series highlights the negative emotional impact of racist attitudes on black womens lives. Everyone we reached out to for this project was eager to tell her most intimate stories of pain and discrimination, from childhood, to work, to profiling by the police. We hope that in sharing them, we are helping to complicate the public representations of black women and girls  highlighting the unique challenges they face, as well as experiences and feelings that are universal.

title: Browns Find a New Way to Lose
description: Browns fans are used to losing. Twelve seasons without a playoff spot, 21 years without a playoff win, 51 without a championship.

title: 1915: German Spy School At Antwerp
description: GENEVA  The trial of Philipponat, charged before the court-martial at Geneva with espionage in the interests of Germany, brought to light the fact that the German Headquarters Staff has installed at Antwerp a school for spies. The methods of this school are as follows: The individuals, brought to Antwerp by the recruiters whom the German information service maintains in neutral or occupied countries, follow for a month a course of lessons, which are given by staff officers, police commissaries, and a professor of chemistry, who teaches the elements of cryptography. The New York Herald, European Edition, December 2, 1915

title: Should You Update to Apple OS X El Capitan?
description: Q. My MacBook has been nagging me to update to OS X El Capitan for the last few months, but I have read a lot of negative feedback about the system. How bad is it and is it worth upgrading?

title: BlueCrest to Close Hedge Fund and Refund Outside Investors
description: Less than three years ago, BlueCrest Capital Management was one of the biggest hedge funds in Europe, managing $37 billion of investor money.

title: Spains Prized Ibrico Hams Cant Cure Fast Enough for China
description: JABUGO, Spain  On a vast farm dotted with oak and cork trees, about 350 pigs are enjoying the final weeks of a short but blissful life. They roam freely, sleep outdoors or shelter in spacious pigsties. Above all, autumn is when they get to feast all day on acorns recently fallen from the trees.

title: Daily Report: Tech Culture Across Continents, From Hacker to Satire
description: The techie culture of coders and coding has spread across the globe as Internet companies have become ascendant and usage of computers and mobile devices has become an everyday habit for many. Yet that culture is far from uniform and has evolved differently in different places.

title: U.S. Still in Danger of Losing War on AIDS, C.D.C. Director Says
description: Despite major medical advances and more than 30 years of effort, the United States is still in danger of losing the war on AIDS, according to the countrys top disease-control official.

title: ISIS Followers in U.S. Are Diverse and Young
description: WASHINGTON  American authorities this year have arrested nearly five dozen people in the United States for helping to support or plot with the Islamic State, according to a new study, the largest number of terrorism-related arrests in the country in a single year since September 2001.

title: The Man in the High Castle: Watched It All? Lets Talk About It
description: Spoilers for the full first season of Amazons The Man in the High Castle follow.

title: Rushing to End Mass Shootings, Police Face Greater Danger
description: Even before teams of armed terrorists struck Paris last month, briefly holding hostages in a theater, officials in New York had been altering their approach to school shootings and other murderous attacks that erupt and are frequently over within minutes.

title: 1940: Avila Camacho Is Inaugurated in Mexico
description: MEXICO CITY  Gen. Manuel Avila Camacho, soldier and rancher, became Mexicos President today [Dec. 1], succeeding Lazaro Cardenas, and as he took office demonstrated that his government stood shoulder to shoulder with the United States and other sister American republics in the defense of democracy. The forty-three-year-old former Minister of War was inaugurated soon after 11 a.m. in the presence of special envoys from thirty-one foreign nations. Henry A. Wallace, Vice-President-elect of the United States, received a standing ovation when he entered the hall.New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, December 2, 1940

title: Rudolph Giuliani Cites 9/11 Celebrations, but Disputes Donald Trump
description: Rudolph W. Giuliani weighed in on the question of Muslims cheeringin America after the attacks of Sept. 11, 2001, and concluded that while he recalled some pockets of celebration in New York City, Donald J. Trumps claim about thousands of revelers in New Jersey was an exaggeration.

title: Tahir Elci, Human Rights Defender
description: It is not often that I encounter someone who makes me think that peace and justice in the hardest of contexts can be more than just quixotic ambitions. Tahir Eli, the president of the Diyarbakir Bar Association, was one of those rare people for me.

title: Steve Jobs 2
description: excerpt

title: Steve Jobs 3
description: excerpt

title: AirAsia Flight 8501 Crash Findings
description: An AirAsia passenger jet plunged into the Java Sea in late 2014 because of a faulty component coupled with the crew's response, a crash investigator said on Tuesday.

title: Submit Questions for Damon Lindelof of The Leftovers
description: Damon Lindelof answered the questions here.

title: Life in a Japanese-American Internment Camp, via the Diary of a Young Man
description: NEW HAVEN  Until recently, Yonekazu Satoda says, he did not recall the diary he had written in neat cursive in the laundry building of an internment camp in Arkansas. He would eke out his entries at night amid the washboards and concrete sinks, the only private space in the camp with light.

title: Bronx Woman, 28, Fatally Shot Inside Her Apartment
description: A 28-year-old woman was fatally shot on Tuesday inside her Bronx apartment during an argument with her former boyfriend, while the couples 6-year-old son was in the home, the police said.

title: The Curious Incident of the Duct-Taped Dog on Facebook
description: People with pets are discovering that their private treatment of animals can easily make them the targets of a social media manhunt, and, in some cases, formal police inquiries.

title: Supreme Court Says Woman Injured in Austria Cant Sue in U.S.
description: WASHINGTON  The Supreme Court ruled on Tuesday that a California woman injured in a train accident in Austria cannot sue in an American court. It was the Supreme Courts first decision of the term in an argued case, and it was unanimous.

title: VW Argued for Easing New E.U. Tests on Emissions
description: LONDON  Volkswagen successfully lobbied to remove two key parts of Europes forthcoming auto emissions tests, an internal email shows, including a provision to measure the significant pollution released when an engine is started but hasnt yet warmed up.

title: Vaucluse
description: A new French restaurant on the Upper East Side from Michael Whites Altamarea Group.

title: At Vaucluse, Michael White Takes a Step Toward France on the Upper East Side
description: A critic could run out of new ways to express disappointment in Altamarea Group restaurants if Altamarea didnt keep coming up with new ways to disappoint.

title: Discontent Over Migrants Takes a Toll on East German City
description: DRESDEN, Germany  More than one year later, they are still here, the thousands of people who rally every Monday under the banner of the Pegida movement to vent their rage against Muslims, migrants and especially the government of Chancellor Angela Merkel.

title: Mayor Rahm Emanuel Fires Chicago Police Superintendent
description: CHICAGO  A week ago, Mayor Rahm Emanuel and Police Superintendent Garry F. McCarthy stood together, shoulder to shoulder, as this city released long-sought video of a white police officer shooting a black teenager 16 times along a Chicago street last year. But after nights of demonstration that followed the videos release and growing calls for changes at the citys Police Department and beyond, Mr. Emanuel stood alone at a lectern on Tuesday to say that he had dismissed Mr. McCarthy.

title: Folk Hero Furniture by Brazilian Brothers
description: The Brazilian furniture designers the Campana Brothers are known for elevating humble materials such as rope, scraps of wood and even stuffed animals: In one memorable work, a patchwork of teddy bears became a comfy chair. Their latest collection, unveiled by the So Paolo gallery Firma Casa at Design Miami, is inspired by the Cangao, nomadic bandits who roamed northeastern Brazil in the 19th century. Intricate leatherwork recalls the elaborately embellished hats, boots and vests worn by the swashbuckling thieves.

title: Jerry Seinfeld Gets a Regular Gig at the Beacon Theater
description: At this point in his career, Jerry Seinfeld is a comedian who can work as often or as little as he wants to. And now this popular stand-up performer, sitcom star and digital host is offering New York audiences the opportunity to see as much of him as they can take.

title: Rye Adds an Authentic Touch to the Holidays
description: Three men sitting in a Midtown Manhattan restaurant one recent afternoon represented three generations of the Kentucky clan whose hand has been on the tiller of the Wild Turkey distillery for more than half a century. There was Jimmy Russell, the legendary distiller; Eddie Russell, his son, a veteran distiller in his own right; and Bruce Russell, Eddies 26-year-old son, a relatively new addition to the firm.

title: Puerto Rico Begins Choosing Which Debt Payments to Make
description: WASHINGTON  Puerto Rico avoided its first major default by making payments of $354 million on its debt on Tuesday, but the islands governor said that he had already taken steps to halt certain payments on other debt coming due on Jan. 1.

title: David Letterman, Even Retired, Keeps On Interviewing
description: MUNCIE, Ind.  Six months into retirement, David Letterman stepped onstage here at Ball State University looking much the way he did as host of Late Show: suit and tie, loafers and white socks. But he has grown the kind of beard a man wears when he doesnt have to get up for work every morning  looking not so much like Santa Claus but, as he said, like Charles Darwin.

title: Race in America: Your Stories
description: As part of a series of Op-Docs videos about race, we are featuring personal stories that reflect the breadth of experiences in the United States.

title: Coaching Carousel Spins Ever Faster
description: Before the 1987 season, Virginia Tech hired a new football coach. The new boss was 2-9 in his first season. A half-dozen recruiting classes later, he finished his sixth season with a record that was, on paper, only microscopically improved: 2-8-1.

title: Airbnb Releases Trove of New York City Home-Sharing Data
description: Airbnb has had a rough history with regulators in New York City. Now the company is playing nice.

title: Young Palestinian Women Join the West Bank Turmoil
description: NEW ASKAR REFUGEE CAMP, West Bank  The 16-year-old gave clear warning that she was up to something days before she swapped her schoolbooks for a knife and headed to a nearby Israeli military checkpoint. If I am killed, Ashrakat Qattanani told her father, Dont cry for me, cry for Palestine.

title: Chicago Mayor on Firing of Police Chief
description: Mayor Rahm Emanuel of Chicago said that the police superintendent, Garry F. McCarthy, had been "excellent" in his role but that the public trust in the department's leadership had been shaken.

title: Jimmer Fredette Steps Back, but Scores 37, in D-League Debut
description: WHITE PLAINS  Tony Hammel, who coached Jimmer Fredette for four years at Glens Falls High School, still connects with him every couple of weeks. They text or chat on the phone, even as Fredette continues to hopscotch the country on a seemingly endless basketball odyssey.

title: Adele on Love, Fame, Ego and 25
description: Adele has everyone talking. Drake has offered to do her laundry. Britney Spears has professed her love for Hello. But conversation about Adele has mostly focused on numbers  and her (ultimately lucrative) decision not to make her new album, 25, available to streaming services  rather than her music.

title: Lin-Manuel Miranda Contributing  Music to Star Wars
description: Lin-Manuel Miranda is still performing on Broadway, but he also has a gig in a galaxy far, far away. J.J. Abrams, the director of Star Wars: The Force Awakens, revealed on the Tonight show that Mr. Miranda helped write the music for the movies cantina scene.

title: U.S. Special Operations Force in Iraq to Grow, Pentagon Says
description: WASHINGTON  The Pentagon will expand its Special Operations force in Iraq as part of a ramped-up war effort against the Islamic State in Iraq and Syria, Defense Secretary Ashton B. Carter told a House hearing on Tuesday.

title: Student Activism and Free Speech at Amherst
description: To the Editor:

title: Jessica Jones Episode 8: This Power Was Forced on Me
description: Episode 8 is a welcome corrective to the pity parties that were Episodes 6 and 7. Here, Jones returns to her childhood home, now renovated by Kilgrave, and confronts her guilt directly. Jones may not have been in control of her actions before but thats not the case here, as the episodes writer, Scott Reynolds, reminds us immediately, by having Kilgrave tell Jones: I was serious when I said I wanted you to choose. Joness free will makes all the difference in AKA WWJD, a thoughtfully focused episode that swims around the idea that some people just dont feel remorse about their actions.

title: Luke Walton, With 0-0 Record, Is Named an N.B.A. Coach of the Month
description: Settling the debate once and for all, the N.B.A. issued a statement on Tuesday clarifying that it would not alter its policy of not crediting wins and losses to interim coaches in most instances. Golden State Coach Steve Kerr will receive credit for the Warriors record under Luke Walton, who has been running the team in Kerrs absence.

title: Wary of Donald Trump, G.O.P. Leaders Are Caught in a Standoff
description: WASHINGTON  For months, much of the Republican Partys establishment has been uneasy about the rise of Donald J. Trump, concerned that he was overwhelming the presidential primary contest and encouraging other candidates to mimic his incendiary speech. Now, though, irritation is giving way to panic as it becomes increasingly plausible that Mr. Trump could be the partys standard-bearer and imperil the careers of other Republicans.

title: While U.S. Car Sales Jump, VWs Plunge
description: DETROIT  While other automakers were reporting gains in a strong market for new vehicles in November, Volkswagen said on Tuesday that the impact of a widening emissions scandal caused its sales in the United States to plunge nearly 25 percent during the month.

title: Two New York City Workers Charged With Stealing $2.1 Million From Benefits Programs
description: The New York City employees plan, as described by investigators, was elaborate but efficient. She had people pay welfare recipients for access to their benefits cards and directed money to their accounts. Then an associate used some of the fraudulent benefits to buy Red Bull in bulk and resold the energy drink to bodegas. Some of the cash then made its way back to the city employee, the authorities said.

title: A Twist on the Traditional Challah
description: Bread  shaping it, baking it, blessing it and sharing it  is part of almost every Jewish holiday.

title: N.H.L. This Week: Rangers and Isles Meet in Brooklyn
description: Every Tuesday, The New York Times will look at the week ahead in the N.H.L., highlighting hot  or not so hot  teams and players.

title: Challenging the Oligarchy
description: I review Robert Reichs new book in the New York Review of Books. Things have changed a lot since 1991.

title: An Artist and a Poet on Lifes Little Mysteries
description: For Ts ongoing series, the poet Carl Phillips and the painter Howard Hodgkin make tangible the most fleeting of lifes daily wonders.WHAT I SEE IS THE LIGHT FALLING ALL AROUND US

title: Chartreuse: Holiday Greenery in a Cocktail Coupe
description: In the French Alps, aprs-ski, a mug of verte chaude often awaits. This regional warmer (the name means hot green) consists of hot chocolate revved with a generous splash of Chartreuse, the strong, verdant spirit that is made nearby. The drink may also come crowned with a pouf of freshly whipped cream.

title: Jeb Bushs Strange New Ad
description: All Americans should be grateful to those who have earned the Medal of Honor, an award of valor often granted posthumously because of the high degree of personal sacrifice it represents. But individual acts of bravery dont confer any special knowledge of what it takes to be the commander in chief.

title: Avars, Arabs, and History
description: The historian David Potter had a great letter published in the Financial Times, correcting the really bad history of the Dutch president, who suggested that migrants brought about the fall of Rome. (Bad history is all the rage these days.) Potter:

title: For Robert Dear, Religion and Rage Before Planned Parenthood Attack
description: CHARLESTON, S.C.  The man she had married professed to be deeply religious. But after more than seven years with Robert L. Dear Jr., Barbara Micheau had come to see life with him as a kind of hell on earth.

title: Paul Ryan Pushes Changes in Mental Health Care After Colorado Shooting
description: WASHINGTON  Efforts to overhaul the nations approach to mental illness gained momentum on Tuesday as the House speaker, Paul D. Ryan, urged lawmakers to do more to protect people after the deadly shooting last week at a Planned Parenthood clinic in Colorado.

title: Wanted: More Women on the Slopes
description: Ski resorts have spent considerable resources in recent years making sure they nurtured the next generation of skiers and boarders by creating innovative and fun classes for children. Now their mothers and older sisters are increasingly getting attention as women-only programs multiply across the Rocky Mountain range.

title: Broad Effort Aims to Expand Financial Services to Low-Income Consumers
description: WASHINGTON  The Obama administration, teaming with private partners including the Gates Foundation and JPMorgan Chase, announced initiatives on Tuesday to expand banking services to millions of Americans and others worldwide who lack essentials like checking or savings accounts and access to credit.

title: Joba Chamberlain Returns to the Land of the Midges
description: The signing of a journeyman pitcher to a minor league contract does not ordinarily raise much interest in the hot stove league.

title: At Home, Chris Christie Hears a Dissenting Newspaper Voice
description: Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey is riding high after a coveted endorsement from The New Hampshire Union Leader, but he is not winning such accolades at home.

title: A New Sports Company Serves Up Wellness, and Sunglasses
description: Sports culture tends to revolve around competition, victory and defeat. So its a bit strange at first to hear the terms Tom Daly and Max Vallot use when talking about their new athletic company, District Vision: community, participation, inclusiveness, meditation.

title: New York City Aims for Vast Electric Car Fleet by 2025
description: By 2025, New York City is planning to employ the largest municipal fleet of electric vehicles in the country, along with a sprawling network of charging stations to go with it.

title: Nocino, an Italian Walnut Liqueur, Is Also Made in America
description: The holidays are shot through with nuts. We stuff them inside our turkeys, cookies and fruitcakes. Without them, decorative nutcrackers are just garish tchotchkes.

title: Helen Mirren, Robert De Niro and More at the Gotham Independent Film Awards
description: Luminaries of the film world gathered in New York for the unofficial kickoff to awards season.

title: Imagining a World Without Growth
description: Could the world order survive without growing?

title: Gotham Independent Film Awards Red Carpet
description: See what Maggie Gyllenhaal, Julianne Moore and Dascha Polanco wore to the award show.

title: On Hanukkah, the Latke Road Less Traveled
description: Each year before Hanukkah, which begins this year at sunset on Sunday, I wonder why I labor so over potato latkes. I grate the potatoes and onions by hand, often skinning my knuckles. I squeeze out the water so the potatoes fry crisper and wont discolor  but sometimes they still do.

title: Why the Pro-Life Movement Opposes Violence
description: In the wake of the Robert Dear shootings at a Planned Parenthood facility in Colorado, the tendency from pro-choice writers has been to get the pro-life movement coming and going on the one hand accusing pro-lifers of at least semi-deliberately fomenting violence, on the other accusing them of being inconsistent for abjuring the violence that their own premises seem (to pro-choice eyes) to inevitably justify.

title: Charlie Savages Power Wars
description: When Paris was attacked last month, politicians and pundits fell all over themselves rushing to proclaim what Washington should do next in the war on terror. The vast majority of them would have done better to keep quiet and read Charlie Savages new book, Power Wars, instead. It offers a master class in how to think seriously about crucial aspects of the subject.

title: Votes in Congress Move to Undercut Climate Pledge
description: WASHINGTON  Hours after President Obamapledged Tuesday in Paris that the United States would be in the vanguard of nations seeking a global response to climate change, Congress approved two measures aimed at undercutting him.

title: A Powerful Curators Idiosyncratic Genius
description: Carolyn Christov-Bakargiev has worked with the biggest names in contemporary art and organized its most prestigious exhibitions, including the Sydney Biennale and the 13th edition of Documenta. Next month, she will become director of Turins two major contemporary art museums, which are merging. She has the power to influence artists work and to sculpt artists careers  and yet she rejects the idea that she selects artists for her shows. Selects reminds me of 1943, she recently told the press.

title: Leader of Taliban Splinter Group Allied With ISIS Is Killed
description: KANDAHAR, Afghanistan  After months of Taliban infighting that has left hundreds dead, the prominent head of a splinter faction allied with the Islamic State has been killed, government officials and Taliban commanders said on Tuesday.

title: Steve Jobs 1
description: excerpt

title: Helen Mirren, Robert De Niro and More at the Gotham Independent Film Awards
description: Luminaries of the film world gathered in New York for the unofficial kickoff to awards season.

title: Facts & Figures: Attacks on Muslims in America
description: Attacks and threats against mosques and individual Muslims in the United States have surged since the Paris attacks, according to a report by the Council on American-Islamic Relations. ThinkProgress has a breakdown of some of the incidents cited in the report, including these:

title: New Rules on Reporting Brokers Dismissals to Begin Dec. 12
description: New rules significantly shorten the window of time brokerage firms have to report the details of a brokers departure from their firm  an effort by securities regulators to make background information about brokers more accessible to consumers.

title: Gotham Independent Film Awards Red Carpet
description: See what Maggie Gyllenhaal, Julianne Moore and Dascha Polanco wore to the award show.

title: Leap of Faith, by Bruce Weber
description: The latest volume of the iconic photographers annual cultural anthology collects stories that might not otherwise be told.

title: Around the World With Bruce Weber
description: In Leap of Faith, the 15th installment of his annual cultural anthology, All-American, the legendary photographer Bruce Weber collects stories, both historical and contemporary, that might otherwise not be told. Here, a snapshot of images from the books wide roam, from a dance for incarcerated fathers and their daughters in Richmond, Va., to the reportage of war photographer Lynsey Addario.

title: Ex-President of Argentina Is Sentenced in Embezzlement Case
description: BUENOS AIRES  Carlos Sal Menem, the former Argentine president, was convicted and sentenced on Tuesday to more than four years in prison for overseeing the embezzlement of public funds to pay bonuses to government officials during his presidency in the 1990s.

title: A Foundation Says the Joffrey Ballet Owes Licensing Fees of $373,000
description: A foundation which says it owns the rights to the ballets created by the founders of the Joffrey Ballet, Robert Joffrey and Gerald Arpino, said this week that the ballet company owed it more than $373,000 in back payments for performing the works in recent years.

title: New Options Abound in the Former Macys Cellar
description: Chef Street and Rowlands Bar & Grill The pots, pans and blenders from the former Macys Cellar have been moved upstairs, replaced by clothing for millennials. But there are new places to eat, starting with a food court where four Airstream-style trailers dispense name-brand dishes: Theres Taquitoria, serving Marc Forgiones tacos; Crumb on Parchment, with salads, grain bowls and sandwiches from the Miami chef Michelle Bernstein; ramen, bao buns and dumplings by Takashi Yagihashi of Chicago; and Rollies, for sandwiches on rolls. Nearby is a new pub, Rowlands (Rowland is the R in R. H. Macy), with bar, banquette and table seating for shrimp salad, fried chicken, burgers, grilled fish and steaks. (Chef Street opens Wednesday; Rowlands opens later this month): Chef Street, Macys lower level, 151 West 34th Street; Rowlands Bar & Grill, 212-868-3001.

title: G.O.P. Candidates Viewing Economys Past Through Gold-Colored Glasses
description: WASHINGTON  Republicans unhappy with the Federal Reserve are circulating an idea that long ago lost currency with most economists: a gold standard.

title: Kobes Poem to Basketball
description: From The Players Tribune

title: Pfizers Deal for Allergan Is a Dubious Milestone
description: Pfizers $160 billion takeover of Allergan reached a few milestones in the mergers and acquisitions trade.

title: Before Giving, Check Out Charities and Their Policies on Privacy
description: As the year draws to a close, many people are considering charitable donations. But before writing a check or clicking to make an online donation, its best to do some homework.

title: The Sober Proprietor of a Bar on Avenue B
description: True artifacts of the East Villages punk heritage are few and far between these days. One of the few is Manitobas, on Avenue B.

title: Students Protests May Play Role in Supreme Court Case on Race in Admissions
description: WASHINGTON  As student protests over racial injustice are exploding at campuses across the nation, the Supreme Court is preparing to hear a major case that could put an end to racial preferences in college admissions.

title: Volkswagens Software Was Illegal Defeat Device, German Regulator Says
description: LONDON  German regulators said on Tuesday that the software Volkswagen used in many of its diesel vehicles constituted illegal cheating on emissions tests, deepening the companys problems.

title: Mark Zuckerberg Vows to Donate 99% of His Facebook Shares for Charity
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Mark Zuckerberg, the co-founder and chief executive of Facebook, announced on Tuesday that he and his wife would give 99 percent of their Facebook shares during our lives  holdings currently worth more than $45 billion  to charitable purposes.

title: New Peace Talks on Syria Could Be Held This Month
description: UNITED NATIONS  The world powers that met in Vienna for landmark talks aimed at ending the war in Syria could meet next in New York in mid-December, diplomats here said, as long as the latest tensions between Russia and Turkey can be calmed.

title: On the Hunt for Gluten-Free Holiday Cookies
description: You dont have to shop for gluten-free all-purpose flour to make great gluten-free Christmas cookies. Every holiday season, in addition to the sables that I always make but that my sister, who has celiac, cant eat, I make coconut macaroons and regular macarons, cookies that dont call for flour. This year I wanted to expand my repertoire. So I solicited ideas for cookies that dont require any wheat flour from a few pastry chefs around the country.

title: Columbia Disputes Exxon Mobil on Climate Risk Articles
description: The dean of Columbias Graduate School of Journalism published a letter on Tuesday strongly disputing accusations by Exxon Mobil that journalists from the school had produced inaccurate and misleading articles about the companys knowledge of the risks of climate change.

title: Inside Art Basel Miami Beachs Most Anticipated Collaboration
description: On Monday evening, a crowd filed out of the Prez Art Museum Miami (PAMM) after a private dinner toasting Jorge M. Prez. At the same time, a steady stream of dancers, musicians and stage handlers flowed in for a different kind of spectacle  the first rehearsal of the artist Ryan McNamara and the musician Devont Hyness collaborative, one-night-only performance, Dimensions. Commissioned by PAMM as part of its annual multimedia series, which partners artists with musicians, Dimensions has been in the works since the last Art Basel Miami Beach  but with three days until showtime, last night was the first time the full cast had been assembled. I hadnt even seen the stages until today, laughed McNamara, who stole the show at last years fair with ME3M, his hybrid, Internet-themed ballet at Miamis Grand Theater. I think Dev said it best when he described it as a two-hour dance/soul/opera experience.

title: Iranian Diaspora in California
description: Iranian Diaspora in California by Javad Parsa

title: Research Group Funded by Coca-Cola to Disband
description: A group called the Global Energy Balance Network, led by scientists and created by Coca-Cola, announced this week that it was shutting down after months of pressure from public health authorities who said that the groups mission was to play down the link between soft drinks and obesity.

title: Response From Steve Coll to Exxon Mobil
description: The dean of Columbias Graduate School of Journalism rebuts suggestions that journalists from the school had produced inaccurate and misleading articles on Exxon Mobil.

title: Pictures of the Day: Greece and Elsewhere
description: Greece and More  Pictures of the Day

title: Jeb Bush Says He Would Have Probably Skipped Climate Conference
description: WATERLOO, Iowa  Jeb Bush on Tuesday belittled President Obamas trip to Paris for the global climate conference, saying that if he were president, he most likely would have skipped the meeting, where officials from nearly 200 nations are seeking to avert potentially catastrophic damage to the environment.

title: Crimean Residents Still Dont Have Power
description: Residents in the Crimean peninsula have been living without electricity since Nov. 22, when protesters blew up the power lines.

title: Lands End Updates Its Image
description: There were days as a kid when I was so bored, I organized my entire day around the mail delivery.

title: Dec. 1, 2015  Pictures of the Day
description: Photos from Greece, Burkina Faso, South Korea and Nepal.

title: How to Cook American
description: Have questions about recipes, cooking and food? My job is to answer them. Ask me anything: foodeditor@nytimes.com.

title: Mother: Televisions Favorite Role
description: Mothers are all over the small screen, both in high-profile prime-time spots and on more obscure outlets. Good mothers, indifferent mothers, confused mothers, condemnable mothers  take your pick.

title: Review: The Fiery Angel, Devilishly Tough Prokofiev
description: MUNICH  Occultism and masochistic obsession; demons, orgies and writhing nuns. These were some of the topics Prokofiev was wrestling with in 1923 when, deep into work on his opera The Fiery Angel, he married his first wife, Lina, in southern Bavaria.

title: Washingtons Shaw Neighborhood Is Remade for Young Urbanites
description: WASHINGTON  Over time, neighborhoods rise and fall and then rise again.

title: Pop-Up Bars Proliferate During the Holidays
description: Pop-up stores trading in Christmas trappings are commonplace in shopping malls across the country in December. Now, urban mixology has added its own peculiar twist: the seasonal cocktail bar.

title: Scholars Unveil New Edition of Hitlers Mein Kampf
description: BERLIN  Not since 1945, when the Allies banned the dubious work and awarded the rights to the state of Bavaria, has Hitlers manifesto, Mein Kampf, been officially published in German. Bavaria had refused to release it. But under German law, its copyright expires Dec. 31, the 70th year after the authors death.

title: In Chinatown, A Busy Day
description: In New Yorks Chinatown, Thanksgiving is a day to celebrate a marriage. The holiday allows more family members to attend because they already have a day off from work.

title: For Some Chinese-Americans, Thanksgiving Is for Wedding Receptions
description: To many immigrants from Fujian Province in southeastern China, Thanksgiving does not mean turkey, stuffing and football. It is instead a rare day off that many use to give or attend wedding receptions.

title: A Tour of Joel Chens Antiques
description: The Los Angeles design dealer favors an unpredictable mix.

title: A Conversation With J. D. Parker
description: Mr. Parker, 34, is a senior vice president at Marcus & Millichap and the district manager of its tristate region. He joined the 44-year-old brokerage firm, which specializes in commercial real estate investment sales and advisory services, in 2004.

title: How Chicagos Police Superintendent Lost His Job
description: Mayor Rahm Emanuel of Chicago fired Superintendent Garry F. McCarthy following days of protests in the city after the police released footage of the shooting of 17-year-old Laquan McDonald.

title: Inside a Celebrity Antique Dealers Favorite Room
description: Joel Chen

title: Bookshelf: Here Come the Robots
description: In new picture books, children and robots join forces.

title: Your Tuesday Evening Briefing: Mark Zuckerberg, Paris, H.I.V.
description: (Want to get this briefing by email? Heres the sign-up.)

title: Whistle-Blower Complaint Directed at Whistle-Blower Group
description: When Lindsey Williams lost her job, the news arrived abruptly, in a voice mail message from her boss. A co-worker, Richard Renner, said he was given just an hour to hand in his keys, collect his personal effects and leave.

title: After Passing Up David Price, Yankees Will Face Him With Red Sox
description: David Price made his major league debut at the old Yankee Stadium, in the final month of its final season. Some hitters he faced were Xavier Nady, Wilson Betemit and Ivan Rodriguez. Yes, Price goes back a long way with the Yankees, and he will go forward against them for many years, too.

title: Review: In Robin Coste Lewiss Voyage of the Sable Venus, Poems on Race
description: One of the poems in Robin Coste Lewiss first book, Voyage of the Sable Venus, has a title that resembles a gift label:

title: Your Evening Briefing
description: Heres what you need to know at the end of the day.

title: Hillary Clinton Calls for Overhaul of Justice System
description: MONTGOMERY, Ala.  In the church here where, 60 years ago, the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. inspired residents to boycott the local bus network, Hillary Clinton on Tuesday called for overhauling the criminal justice system, saying there is something profoundly wrong when black men are disproportionately stopped and searched by the police, arrested or killed.

title: Shigeru Mizuki, Influential Japanese Cartoonist, Dies at 93
description: TOKYO  Shigeru Mizuki, an influential and widely popular Japanese cartoonist with a talent for humanizing mythical monsters and dissecting the monstrous side of humanity, died here on Monday. He was 93.

title: Verdict Sheet From Sheldon Silver's Trial
description: A jury found the former Assembly speaker guilty on all seven counts, including fraud and extortion.

title: Review: Commedia Rapunzel, With a Bit of Seasonal Spice
description: The Spaghetti and Meatball Players have folded a lot of camp and not much Christmas into their new family show, The Commedia Rapunzel: Holiday Extravaganza Pumpkin Spice Latte Edition. Although this production has its inspired moments, it often resembles the heroines hair: too tangled, too long and simply too much.

title: Clinton Pays Tribute to Rosa Parks
description: Hillary Clinton saluted Rosa Parks in Montgomery, Ala., on the 60th anniversary of Mrs. Parkss refusal to give up her seat on a public bus.

title: How Would You Give Away Your Fortune?
description: If you were Mark Zuckerberg and Priscilla Chan, how would you give away $45 billion, and why?

title: Review: Lena Hall Barrels Through Her Musical Career at Feinsteins
description: Lena Hall wasnt even born when Jefferson Airplanes White Rabbit marched onto the airwaves on a bolero strut just in time for the Summer of Love. But her parents, artists living in the Haight Ashbury district of San Francisco, were charter members of the hipoisie in the emerald city of groovy enlightenment. And as Ms. Hall recalls in The Villa Satori Growing Up in Haight Ashbury, her show at Feinsteins/54 Below, the neighborhood was still a bohemian mecca when she came along in 1980.

title: The Questionable Ways of Albany, Exposed at Sheldon Silvers Trial
description: Assemblywoman Amy Paulin had finished testifying for the government at the corruption trial of Sheldon Silver, offering a primer on how New York State government works, when one of Mr. Silvers lawyers caught her by surprise.

title: What Were Reading
description: Get recommendations from New York Times reporters and editors, highlighting great stories from around the web. What Were Reading emails are sent twice a week. Sign up

title: The Toll of Violent Anti-Abortion Speech
description: HERE are some things abortion opponents have said about Robert L. Dear Jr., the shooter accused of killing three and wounding nine at the Planned Parenthood clinic in Colorado Springs last Friday. He was just a lunatic. He wasnt attacking Planned Parenthood, he ran in there after trying to rob a bank. My personal favorite, from the Republican presidential candidate Sen. Ted Cruz: He is reported to be a transgendered leftist activist.

title: Review: Hitchcock/Truffaut Revisits the Master of Suspense
description: Psycho (1960) was the first film I saw in a movie theater, an experience that my 7-year-old self was ill-equipped to parse. Surrounded by jittery adults, I puzzled over everything, and not just the frantic screaming that mimicked Bernard Herrmanns devilishly clever musical cues. Why, I wondered, was Janet Leigh wandering around in her bra in the middle of the afternoon?

title: Ted Cruz Mocks Clintons Condom Police
description: At a town hall meeting in Iowa, the Republican presidential candidate Ted Cruz derided Hillary Clinton. He said the G.O.P. was not waging a war on women, calling that made-up nonsense.

title: Ex-Citigroup Construction Executive Admits Taking $500,000 in Bribes
description: The bribes were sometimes delivered as cash-stuffed envelopes to the Citigroup executive. Other times, contractors seeking business sent checks to a fake company that the executive ran from his house. One electrical company bought him a lavish hunting trip in Alaska. Another contractor built a patio and barbecue at the executives home.

title: Review: Sound of Redemption Traces Frank Morgans Route From Jazz Musician to Prisoner and Back
description: In the 1950s, some jazz musicians believed they couldnt get that Charlie Parker happy-sad feeling without using drugs. So says a friend of the saxophonist Frank Morgan in Sound of Redemption, a documentary that revels in the happy despite some seriously sad events.

title: Negative News May Alter Statin Users Behavior
description: A Danish study has found that news articles that focus on the risks or adverse effects of statin drugs may lead people to stop taking the medicines, and probably contribute to increases in heart attacks and deaths.

title: Recent Commercial Real Estate Transactions
description: RECENT SALE

title: Amy and Hunting Ground Lead Documentary Shortlist
description: The Oscar race for best documentary feature came into sharp focus on Tuesday when the Academy released its shortlist of the 15 nonfiction films in contention.

title: Romanias Dancing, Drinking Bears
description: In a corner of Romania, the holiday season is ushered in by troupes of bearskin-clad revelers dancing, singing and drinking.

title: Months After Russian Annexation, Hopes Start to Dim in Crimea
description: SHCHYOLKINO, Crimea  When residents in this typical Soviet factory town voted enthusiastically to secede from Ukraine and to become Russians, they thought the chaos and corruption that made daily life a struggle were a thing of the past.

title: Protection Bureaus Stormy Path to Reform the Auto Finance Industry
description: House Republicans are trying to shut down the Consumer Financial Protection Bureaus attempt to regulate the $900 billion auto finance industry. Its a political battle that just might lead to the end of the fledgling agencys mission to regulate every nook and cranny of consumer finance.

title: Cleveland Officer Says He Shot Tamir Rice After Fake Gun Was Pulled
description: Officer Timothy Loehmann, the rookie Cleveland patrolman who fatally shot 12-year-old Tamir Rice last year, saw the boy reaching into his waistband and pulling the gun out before firing his own weapon, the officer said in a statement released Tuesday by the local prosecutors office.

title: The Hard-Working Italian Origins of the Rockefeller Center Christmas Tree
description: Dressed in overalls and jackets, wearing work boots and hats, the men lined up five dozen strong on Christmas Eve 1931 for that weeks pay at a Midtown Manhattan construction site.

title: A Young Islander Gears Up for the Rangers
description: SYOSSET, N.Y.  The Islanders have found lineup stability leading into Wednesdays first game against the first-place but struggling Rangers at Barclays Center.

title: Economic Report Adds to Brazils Mounting Woes
description: RIO DE JANEIRO  It keeps getting messier.

title: Student Protesters Self-Absorbed and Narcissistic, Oklahoma College President Says
description: The president of an evangelical college has jumped into the latest campus culture wars with a complaint about a student who said he felt victimized by a sermon on love, and should not have had to listen to it.

title: Janet DiFiore, Westchester Prosecutor, Is Nominated as New Yorks Chief Judge
description: ALBANY  Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo on Tuesday nominated Janet DiFiore, an experienced prosecutor and fellow Westchester County resident, to New Yorks highest judicial post.

title: ISIS Promise of Statehood Falling Far Short, Ex-Residents Say
description: SANLIURFA, Turkey  After the Syrian government stopped paying him, a technician who had spent two decades pumping the countrys oil received an enticing offer: do the same work for the jihadists of the Islamic State  starting at three times the salary.

title: Receding Waters in California Expose Artifacts to Plundering
description: CLEARLAKE, Calif.  Along cracked-mud shorelines and beneath tangles of weeds on parched riverbanks, artifacts and archaeological sites that have rested in peace beneath the water for hundreds and even thousands of years have become increasingly visible as the states drought has lingered, leaving them susceptible to plunder by opportunistic looters.

title: Replacing a Green Card, and a Home
description: When Elda M. Kriss was released from the hospital in September 2013, she hoped to return to the life she had built over more than three decades in the United States. Instead, she found that everything was gone.

title: In Philadelphia, a Feel-Good Moment for Kobe Bryant, if a Brief One
description: PHILADELPHIA  Kobe Bryant was feeling nostalgic Monday night, so he drove around and visited some of his favorite childhood haunts, including the playgrounds where he honed his game. He recalled how he went scoreless one summer in the Sonny Hill League. He was 11 years old.

title: Dave Roberts, Dodgers New Manager, Reflects on Teams Ties to Breaking Barriers
description: LOS ANGELES  When Waymon Roberts moved his family around Marine bases, from Okinawa to California, Hawaii and North Carolina, he knew it was not easy, especially for his children. So he regularly repeated a mantra that can be useful for military families.

title: Bipartisan Talks Yield $300 Billion Highway Bill
description: WASHINGTON  Congressional negotiators clinched a deal on Tuesday for a five-year, roughly $300 billion transportation bill that would inject badly needed investments into the nations deteriorated highways and other infrastructure and also reopen the Export-Import Bank.

title: Maurice Strong, Environmental Champion, Dies at 86
description: Maurice Strong, a former industrialist and confessed ecological sinner who was in the vanguard of placing environmentalism on the worlds agenda as a high-ranking United Nations official, died on Saturday. He was 86.

title: Bronx Man Stabs Wife and Flees With Their Daughter, Police Say
description: A Bronx man stabbed his wife several times on Tuesday, then fled with their 3-year-old daughter, the police said, prompting the authorities to issue an Amber Alert.

title: Worldwide Support for Ending AIDS
description: World AIDS Day celebrations around the globe.

title: The Marshall Islands Are Disappearing
description: Most of the Marshall Islands rise less than six feet above sea level. For the residents, the destructive power of the rising seas is already an inescapable part of daily life.

title: California: State Falls Short of Water Goal
description: For the first time since emergency drought regulations took effect this year, Californians failed to meet the 25 percent water reduction target set by Gov. Jerry Brown. Residents reduced their water used in October by 22.2 percent compared with 2013, the states lowest conservation rate since mandatory water reductions began in the summer. Over all, residents remain on a pace to meet the 25 percent goal, having saved 27.1 percent over 2013 in the five months from June to October. State water officials have said saving water will be more difficult during the winter because Californians used less water during the winter in years past. They said they expected conservation rates to remain lower during the colder months. I was relieved at the numbers, Felicia Marcus, chairwoman of the State Water Resources Control Board, said of Octobers 22 percent figure. The emergency drought regulations will be in effect through February, but officials are considering a new set of emergency regulations if the drought continues.

title: U.S. Plans to Counter Arms Breach by Russia
