description: WASHINGTON  Frustrated by Russias refusal to address the Obama administrations concerns that it has violated a landmark arms control accord, the Pentagon is moving ahead with plans to strengthen defenses in Europe against Moscows military programs, including the threat posed by cruise missiles, a senior Defense Department official told Congress on Tuesday.

title: The Chicago Police Scandal
description: The cover-up that began 13 months ago when a Chicago police officer executed 17-year-old Laquan McDonald on a busy street might well have included highly ranked officials who ordered subordinates to conceal information. But the conspiracy of concealment exposed last week when the city, under court order, finally released a video of the shooting could also be seen as a kind of autonomic response from a historically corrupt law enforcement agency that is well versed in the art of hiding misconduct, brutality  and even torture.

title: Judge Gives Push to Deadlocked Jury in Massey Mine Safety Trial
description: CHARLESTON, W.Va.  On its seventh full day of deliberations, a federal jury said Tuesday that it was at an impasse in the trial of Donald L. Blankenship, the West Virginia businessman who led Massey Energy Company when 29 people were killed in a coal mine.

title: Luc Bondy, Swiss-Born Theater and Opera Director, Dies at 67
description: Luc Bondy, a Swiss-born stage director whose productions, known for their shrewd probing of human behavior and attention to acting subtlety, were featured in Europes most prestigious theaters and opera houses, died on Saturday. He was 67.

title: Review: Jane Martins H2O Explores the Interdependence of the Sacred and the Profane
description: Jake Abadjian became famous overnight playing the big-screen superhero Dawnwalker  as Jake describes him, an ordinary cabdriver born without a tongue. Yes, Dawnwalker is mute; no, Jake didnt toil for years onstage before stumbling into stardom. But his three blockbusters did make many millions for DreamWorks.

title: Fabulous Deli Delicacy
description: Administrivial Stocking Stuffer Alert! St. Martins Press has released a new book of puzzles from Will Shortzs favorite constructors, just in time for you to start thinking about what to get your favorite solver. You can read more about the book here.

title: American Convicted in Peru Plot Plans to Return to U.S.
description: LIMA, Peru   Lori Berenson, an American who has completed a 20-year sentence for aiding a rebel group that planned to take members of Perus Congress hostage, could be deported as early as Wednesday, a government official here said.

title: Yemen: Red Cross Worker Is Held by Kidnappers
description: The International Committee of the Red Cross said that two of its staff members were abducted by gunmen as they drove to work on Tuesday in Sana, Yemens capital. One of the workers, a Yemeni man, was later released, but the second, a Tunisian woman, was still being held, the group said in a statement. It was the latest in a series of attacks in Yemen against the Red Cross, one of the few international humanitarian organizations that has continued operations in Yemen since a civil war started in March. The Red Cross said it did not know who was responsible for the kidnappings.

title: CuomoTempers Hopes for Tougher Ethics Laws
description: For those advocating ethics reform in New Yorks scandal-sullied capital, the  conviction of Sheldon Silver, the once-untouchable State Assembly speaker, on corruption charges should have marked a permanent change in the tides  the beginning of the end for public officials who used their posts for private gain.

title: On Tape at Skeloses Trial, Son Talks of Senators Pull
description: Senator Dean G. Skeloss son sounded as if he thought he had a pretty good plan.

title: Kean University Graduate Accused in Threats Against Blacks
description: A black graduate of Kean University in New Jersey was accused on Tuesday of fabricating threats on Twitter against black staff members and students that led officials to heighten security on campus, the authorities said.

title: Scream Queens Season 1, Episode 11: Unbreakable Dean Munsch
description: Did anything of substance happen on this weeks episode of Scream Queens? Of course, using the word substance in connection with this show is an incongruity, but you know what I mean. We learned that Dean Munsch, whom the Chanels tried to kill several times, is apparently immune to puffer fish venom and to being frozen to death in a cryotherapy chamber. We learned that Pete has apparently murdered someone. But did the story move forward much? Did any major characters or even minor ones die? Did the episode have some redeeming value, like being amusing? No. Maybe this should have been a 10-episode series. (Two more to go.)

title: Yahoos Board Is Said to Weigh Selling Off Core Business
description: SAN FRANCISCO  The board of Yahoo will discuss potentially selling off the beleaguered Internet companys core business during a series of meetings this week, people briefed on the plans said on Tuesday.

title: Word of the Day + Quiz | percussion
description: percussion  \pr-k-shn\  noun

title: Boston Consultings Most Innovative Companies: Lessons From a Decade of Ranking
description: Innovation is an essential yet elusive ingredient in corporate success, and one that is notoriously difficult to measure.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: It does not make sense for us to go to Paris and come back with something that says, In a few years time, your country is going to be underwater.

title: Singapore Police Again Arrest Suspect Accused of Fixing Soccer Matches
description: The Singapore police have again arrested a man accused of running one of the worlds largest soccer match-fixing rings, just days after a court in the city-state had ordered his release.

title: What to Watch Wednesday
description: Gather round, viewers, as Rockefeller Center flips the switch on its big, beautiful Christmas tree. Then get out your tissues as you watch animals fight for their lives. And there are apparently no words for the season finale of Empire.

title: Corrections: December 2, 2015
description: INTERNATIONAL

title: Romanias Dancing, Drinking Bears
description: What is your perfect childhood holiday memory? For New Yorkers, it might be seeing the Rockettes at Radio City Music Hall, going to midnight Mass, large family gatherings or braving the crowds in Times Square for the New Years ball drop.

title: Affordable, Reliable Coal
description: To the Editor:

title: Sheldon Silvers Conviction on Corruption Charges
description: To the Editor:

title: Putins Syrian Misadventure
description: When President Vladimir Putin of Russia announced he was setting up an air base in the middle of Syria to take on the Islamic State and bolster President Bashar al-Assad, more than a few analysts and politicians praised his forceful, game-changing, strategic brilliance, suggesting that Putin was crazy like a fox. Some of us thought he was just crazy.

title: Domestic Abuse Policy
description: To the Editor:

title: Pfizer-Allergan: A Drug Merger With Tax Benefits
description: To the Editor:

title: An Opening in the War Against AIDS
description: International health agencies continue to lose ground in the struggle against H.I.V., the virus that causes AIDS. Each year the number of people who become infected outpaces the number of people starting treatment for the virus. That is discouraging given that the opportunities to control the spread of the virus have never been better, scientifically and financially. It is imperative to move aggressively to change the trajectory of this epidemic.

title: The G.O.P.s Worst Budget Riders
description: The short-term spending bill that is financing federal government operations will expire on Dec. 11, and unless Congress and President Obama agree on another extension or a final bill, there will be a shutdown.

title: Anyone but Ted Cruz
description: Youre evaluating candidates for an open job in your company, and you come across one who makes a big impression.

title: Donald Trumps Appeal
description: The continuing strength of Donald J. Trumps bid for the Republican presidential nomination has dumbfounded his own party, the media, political scientists, donors and pollsters.

title: The Real Problem With Police Video
description: A CHICAGO police officer shot and killed a teenager named Laquan McDonald in October of last year, but most of us learned about Mr. McDonald only last week, after a judge ordered the release of police video footage of his death. That is also when prosecutors finally brought first-degree murder charges against the officer. Clearly, such footage has considerable power.

title: A Fight Over Fish
News Qs | Even Ballet Dancers Are in Awe of Stephen Currys Moves
description: Before Reading Even Ballet Dancers Are in Awe of Stephen Currys Moves:

title: China Calls Hacking of U.S. Workers Data a Crime, Not a State Act
description: HONG KONG  China has acknowledged for the first time that the breach of the United States Office of Personnel Managements computer systems, which the Obama administration said exposed the personal information of more than 21.5 million people, was the work of Chinese hackers. But China insisted that the breach was the result of criminal activity, not a state-sponsored cyberattack.

title: Evan Ross Trains for The Hunger Games and Fatherhood
description: The actor and singer Evan Ross, 27, shares workout tips from the driveway of his Sherman Oaks, Calif. home.

title: Amid Dominant No. 1s in Tennis, More Fluidity on Womens Tour
description: The big gaps at the top of the rankings speak for themselves at the official end of the tennis season, which is not quite the real end of the tennis season, with the International Premier Tennis League relaunching in Japan on Wednesday.

title: Adrien Brodys Five Favorite Things
description: Adrien Brody is best known for having won an Oscar in 2003 for The Pianist. But now the 42-year-old Queens native is making his mark in another genre: fine art. This week, as part of Art Basel Miami Beach, Mr. Brody will be showing his first series of paintings at Domingo Zapatas pop-up gallery at the Lulu Laboratorium. Titled Hotdogs, Hamburgers and Handguns, the series, according to Mr. Brody, accounts for pop culture obsessions, including fast food and violence. Below, he shares five of his favorite things.

title: Once Embraced by Chris Christie, New Jerseys Muslims Feel Betrayed
description: The invitation arrived by email, bearing the seal of the State of New Jersey and the name of its new governor, Chris Christie. It asked a select group of Muslim leaders to break the daily Ramadan fast at Mr. Christies home, and began with a traditional Muslim salutation.

title: How Real Are You on Social Media?
description: How much thought and effort do you invest in making sure you look good, popular and happy on Facebook or Instagram?

title: U2, Preaching Defiance, Heads Back to Paris
description: Near the midway point of every recent U2 show, a simulated bomb goes off. The sound of the explosion, which along with the song Raised by Wolves commemorates 1974 terrorist car bombings in Dublin, is meant to mark the end of innocence on the bands autobiographical Innocence and Experience tour.

title: A Wall Street Landmark Seen by Millions, but Often Overlooked
description: One of New Yorks greatest historical landmarks, Federal Hall National Memorial, can be defined by what it is not. It is not widely enough known. It is not well enough visited. And it is not Federal Hall.

title: Living in Clinton Hill
description: Rich with historic residential architecture, the north-central Brooklyn neighborhood is growing in popularity, and home prices show it.

title: Clinton Hill, Brooklyn, a Neighborhood in Transition
description: After Amelie Wisniak moved to Manhattan from Paris four years ago, a friend told her, Never leave the island  Manhattan was the epicenter. At first Ms. Wisniak, an entrepreneur and a founder of SportChaser, a search engine that connects sports fans to bars, heeded that advice  I never went to Brooklyn, she said.

title: On a Paris Street, a Mix of Peoples and Borders
description: With bars and cafes toward one end and a Muslim enclave at the other, Rue Jean-Pierre Timbaud is a microcosm of Paris.

title: Street Spared in Paris Attacks Embodies What Terrorists Targeted
description: PARIS  For reasons that may never be known, maybe just by chance, the Nov. 13 assaults here, which killed 130 people, skipped over the shops, outdoor cafes and theaters along Rue Jean-Pierre Timbaud. The Bataclan theater is just around the corner; the Caf Bonne Bire, where five died, is a short walk the other way.

title: The Only Street in Paris, by Elaine Sciolino
description: Elaine Sciolino, a former Paris bureau chief for The New York Times, has lived in that city long enough to know its not only the Gothic spires of Notre Dame or the opalescent gray light known as grisaille that makes the city unique. Paris is beautiful; the food is delicious, the shoe shopping world class. But its the people who make Paris Paris. And in her latest book, Sciolino celebrates this idea, bringing her favorite street to life through the stories and histories of its residents and merchants.

title: And Still I Rise: Black America Since MLK, by Henry Louis Gates Jr. and Kevin M. Burke
description: And Still I Rise: Black America Since MLK, a companion to a coming PBS special, makes for brisk and emotionally uncomplicated reading. No writing that claims such a focus can truly be dispassionate, but Rise aims to be more comprehensive than rousing. Thats not to say that the authors, Henry Louis Gates Jr. and Kevin M. Burke, are without their prejudices  more on those in a moment. But in these times when race so sizzles at the forefront of the public consciousness, Rise, particularly in its earlier chapters, can feel encyclopedically bland  and thats probably the books most refreshing trait. The surprisingly objective telling somehow lends itself to an enjoyably subjective experience.

title: Mary-Louise Parkers Dear Mr. You
description: Dear Ms. Editor,

title: Gardens: Rescuing Eden, The High Line and More
description: Surely the planting of gardens shares kinship with the making of sand mandalas, those vibrant patterns, painstakingly laid down by Tibetan Buddhist monks over long, backbreaking days only to be ritualistically brushed away when theyre completed. Life is ephemeral; we are in eternal transit. Every dawn, gardeners the world over stroll outside, view the depredations of the nights creatures and learn to accept impermanence. Gardens are among the most evanescent of our arts. But we dig in anyway, making what we can of our plots  and resisting any thought of their unmaking.

title: 15 More Cookbooks
description: Cookbooks demand their own real estate in the kitchen, where they tend to acquire the sort of greasy finger tracings and residues of spills unlikely to find their way onto the pages of the latest Ferrante novel. This, along with some essentially practical considerations, guides the categorization of the books listed below.

title: Cooking: Asian-American, Women Chefs of New York and More
description: What qualifies these days as an extraordinary recipe and do any of us really need another cookbook to find it? I know I dont require even one more traditional recipe for summer rolls, chicken curry or mushroom risotto. As Dale Talde writes in ASIAN-AMERICAN: Proudly Inauthentic Recipes From the Philippines to Brooklyn (Grand Central Life & Style, $32), we used to want food to be a pat on the back, not an uppercut to the chin. Today, the best recipes communicate a rebellious spirit and a back story amounting to more than a fill-in-the-blank: I went to X and fell in love with Y. Whether its Thailand and green papaya salad, Israel and lemon-mint couscous, or France and sole meunire (if youre Julia Child), these stories have grown tiresome if not precious. I gravitate toward lawless recipes that fall under the admittedly loose rubric of what Talde calls an immigrants cuisine. This is food undergirded by a strong tradition of regional home cooking overlain by the potent influence of diners, gyro shops, Polish delis, taquerias, burger joints, Chinese spots and other food meccas. This food is defined as much by meat loaf and hot dogs as it is by shawarma and roti, tacos and yakitori.

title: Morning Agenda: Yahoo Said to Weigh Selling Core Business
description: YAHOO SAID TO WEIGH SELLING CORE BUSINESS | The board of Yahoo will discuss selling the companys core business during meetings this week, Michael J. de la Merced and Vindu Goel report in DealBook. People briefed on the plans who were not authorized to discuss them publicly said the board would also discuss whether to go ahead with plans to spin off Yahoos stake in Alibaba.

title: The Jemima Code, by Toni Tipton-Martin
description: The suggestion that one could begin to excite a meaningful fact-finding conversation about the foodways of the African-American experience  of black men and women from the advent of slavery through the Industrial Revolution, the Civil War and the resulting Emancipation, not to mention Jim Crow or the struggle for the right to vote  is remarkable. In The Jemima Code, her inspiring account of the stories of our unsung and unrewarded history, Toni Tipton-Martin has made such a claim and has served up a slice of history with bold flavors, cultural enlightenment and real-life images of the people of color whose culinary contributions are realized in these pages. Gifted pioneers, they were creating recipes, managing plantations and running commercial kitchens in a world that regarded them as less than full partners, and often invisible ones.

title: Keeping an Eye Open, by Julian Barnes
description: What is the point of reading biographies of artists? Critics have frequently come down hard on them. They contend that the details of a life are helpless to explain the majesty of art. What matters are not the despairing childhoods and difficult relationships, the question of whether a particular artist was altruistic or plainly cruel  but the object that emerged in the end, an object unburdened by life, succeeding or failing on the basis of its appeal to the eye.

title: Hotel and Tour News: Reindeer in New York, Art in France
description: ART IS CENTER STAGE IN NEW TOUR IN FRANCE

title: The Close Ties Between Exercise and Beer
description: For many people, working out and alcohol are closely linked. Sports teams and training partners celebrate victories, bemoan defeats or mark the end of training sessions with a beer or three. Beer, in fact, provides a substantial portion of some exercisers fluid intake after workouts.

title: Looking for a Hero
description: During a panicked Internet search, I found out my dads surgeon held an excellent track record at his hospital, and was also a singer-songwriter. An Irish ex-pat, I phoned Dad in Ireland from my home in San Francisco, hoping to lift his spirits. He had a risky surgery ahead.

title: Your Wednesday Briefing: Mark Zuckerberg, British Parliament, Yahoo
description: (Want to get this briefing by email? Heres the sign-up.)

title: Your Wednesday Briefing
description: Here is what you need to know to start your day.

title: New York Today: A Sidewalk Forest
description: Updated 7:45 a.m.

title: Donald Trump and Hillary Clinton Endure as Ben Carson Recedes, Poll Says
description: Two months before the Iowa caucuses, Donald J. Trump and Hillary Clinton are showing no signs of losing steam.

title: With Evangelical Support Slipping, Ben Carson Prepares a Pastor Rollout
description: Ben Carson, whose widespread support among evangelical voters has shown some signs of slipping, will hold a news conference in South Carolina on Wednesday that his campaign has called an Evangelical Rollout.

title: Highway Bill Offers a Seasonal Display of Congressional Unity
description: Lo and behold, Congress has delivered a long-term highway bill. It is practically a holiday miracle.

title: Kobe Bryant the Bard Earns Mostly Positive Reviews
description: The students in Nick Twemlows college poetry workshop could be surprised this week to be reading the debut work of an enigmatic new voice: Kobe Bryant of the Los Angeles Lakers.

title: White Debt
description: The word for debt in German also means guilt. A friend who used to live in Munich mentioned this to me recently. I took note because Im newly in debt, quite a lot of it, from buying a house. So far, my debt is surprisingly comfortable, and thats one quality of debt that Ive been pondering lately  how easy it can be.

title: Judge John Hodgman on Star Wars Collectibles
description: Julie writes: My fianc and I love Star Wars. Im fine with buying posters, action figures and even Star Wars-themed groceries, but my fianc has started keeping the mac-and-cheese boxes and soup cans with the Star Wars characters on them. Even after Ive thrown them away, he fishes them out of the trash.

title: Letter of Recommendation: Falling
description: For my 41st birthday, an especially sadistic buddy gave me a video of me falling off my skateboard nearly 160 times. Its a humbling 8 minutes 43 seconds, made all the more cutting by the soundtrack: Nine Inch Nails playing Something I Can Never Have and Hurt. The video charts my four-year quest to land something called a 360 varial, in which you launch above the lip of a ramp, spin the board a full rotation, catch it with your lead hand and pull it back under you before re-entry.

title: Should I Marry the Son of a Crook?
description: I have been dating someone for quite some time, and we have been discussing getting married. I love him dearly, and I can see spending the rest of my life with him. But a lingering issue has recently been causing me some doubt about our future. His father spent time in jail for stock manipulation and embezzling money from his company. I have always considered myself to be an ethical person (perhaps to a fault), and his fathers criminal history makes me uncomfortable. I am not sure that I want to be associated with someone like that, and I certainly would not be able to accept anything from him in the form of gifts or contributions to a wedding reception. If we were to get married, I would have to take the name of and otherwise associate with someone I find morally reprehensible. Would it be wrong to break off a relationship that is going well because of his fathers criminal past? Name Withheld

title: Four Bodies in Elmhurst
description: On the Saturday morning of Labor Day weekend in 2014, an 82-year-old man named Frank Stack hobbled out of his house in Elmhurst, Ill., a quiet suburb of Chicago, and drove 15 minutes northwest to the group home where his 48-year-old son, Francis, lived with five other men with developmental disabilities. David Clark, the supervisor on duty, knew the whole family well and was friendly with Stack. Youre here on Saturday, Clark said, surprised. Stack normally took his son home for dinner on Sundays. Mom wants to see Slugger, Stack said. It was a holiday weekend, so a change in plans was no big deal. Stack promised to have his son back by 5.

title: The Human Flock
description: There are 12 of us by the lake. Some have set out spotting scopes on tripods upon the grass; others carry binoculars. Silently we stand and wait for the Hungarian dusk. The sun slips behind an expanse of steely water, and the air grows colder. Then we hear a faint noise like baying hounds or discordant bugles, at first hardly discernible through the wind rattling the reeds. It grows into an unearthly clamor. Here they come! someone whispers. Overhead, a long, wavering chevron of beating wings is inked across the darkening sky. Behind it flows others, and there are others behind them, all passing overhead in ever-increasing waves, filling the air with an astonishing barrage of noise and beauty.

title: How Mark Zuckerbergs Example Helps Fight Stigma of Family Leave
description: Theres growing political support for some sort of paid family leave, and its clear that many mothers use it when its offered. What has been less clear is whether it would make a difference for fathers. A new study shows how it would.

title: Aung San Suu Kyi and Myanmar General Meet, Taking Steps Toward Sharing Power
description: YANGON, Myanmar  She is the former political prisoner whose party triumphed in elections last month. He is the commander in chief of the military that jailed her for the better part of two decades.

title: G.O.P. Candidates, Feeling Rush to Raise Funds, Turn to Unlikely Source
description: The leading Republican presidential prospects are descending on Thursday on the city they all love to hate  the nations capital.

title: How I Learned to Hunt
description: At the end of Day 1 of wing-shooting school, I stood before the bathroom mirror, gently poking the tender spot on my shoulder that resembled a Gothic window in dull red.

title: Claim That Video Backs Donald Trumps  Assertion of Mass 9/11 Celebrations Is Debunked
description: Reporters who have searched for, and failed to find, any trace of the video Donald J. Trump claims to have seen on Sept. 11, 2001, showing thousands and thousands of American Muslims cheering in New Jersey as the World Trade Center collapsed, have been repeatedly assured by the candidates supporters on social networks that such footage does exist.

title: Voters, Worried About Terrorism, Look for Leaders at Home on Silver Screen
description: Get off my plane, growls the president of the United States to a terrorist hijacker in the 1997 movie Air Force One, before snapping the enemys neck and shoving him out the cargo door.

title: A Dogs West Side Prey
description: Dear Diary:

title: 1940: U-Boats Trap British Convoy
description: Another large convoy of British cargo vessels carrying war supplies and food to England was attacked yesterday, presumably by German submarines, about 400 miles west of Ireland. At least eight ships were attacked, six of which were torpedoed. No ships are known to have been actually sunk. The only reports of the attack on the convoy were pieced together from distress signals. For a period of twenty hours, the U-boats apparently picked off merchantmen isolated from the convoy as they tried to make their way around the north of Ireland.New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, December 3, 1940

title: Terrors Nameless Victims in Nigeria
description: LAGOS, Nigeria  WITH the worlds attention focused on the Nov. 13 attacks in Paris that killed 130 people, there was a flurry of debate about how much more media coverage France had received than Beirut, where, a day earlier, suicide bombers sent by the Islamic State killed 43 people. In Nigeria, we expect most terrorist attacks to go unnoticed by the world.

title: A Five-Bedroom Country House Outside Prague
description: Built in the 1930s and renovated in 1999, the home, which has an indoor heated pool, is on the market for $1.17 million.

title: House Hunting in ... the Czech Republic
description: A FIVE-BEDROOM VILLA OUTSIDE PRAGUE

title: NATO Unveils Plans to Grow, Drawing Fury and Threats From Russia
description: LONDON  For the first time in six years, NATO on Wednesday invited a new member to join the military alliance, prompting a heated response from Russia and further underscoring escalating tensions between the Cold War adversaries.

title: If Readers Had $45 Billion to Donate, This Is What They Would Support
description: Mark Zuckerberg, the co-founder and chief executive of Facebook, and his wife, Dr. Priscilla Chan, made a bold statement on Tuesday: In honor of the birth of their daughter, they said they would give 99 percent of their Facebook shares to charitable purposes. That amounts to about $45 billion.

title: The Murky Origins of the Largest Dinosaur Museum in the World
description: PINGYI, China  Here are a few quirky and little-known facts about this industrial backwater some 300 miles southeast of the Chinese capital: Locals have a fondness for fried cicadas, and the city, a major processor of fruits and nuts, bills itself as the China Foodstuff Canned City.

title: Daily Report: The Zuckerbergs Give Away Their Facebook Fortune
description: Many billionaires turned to philanthropy late in their lives. In Silicon Valley, some are turning to it much earlier.

title: The War Within Tonya Pinkins
description: As the artistic director of Classic Stage Company since 2003, Brian Kulick, who steps down at the end of this season, making way for John Doyle, has had a knack for persuading great actors to challenge themselves in classic roles (like Peter Sarsgaard in Hamlet and F. Murray Abraham in Gallileo). So its fitting that one of his last productions at the intimate gem of a theater pairs Tonya Pinkins with one of the mightiest roles in the canon, the title character in Brechts Mother Courage and Her Children. In playing the canny survivor ground down by a war-torn world, Ms. Pinkins will be following the likes of Fiona Shaw and Meryl Streep. Ms. Pinkins often seems to elevate her material, but when she sinks into a complex role worthy of her gifts  Caroline, or Change is perhaps the best example  the results can be thrilling. Thats what makes this show such a downtown event. Duncan Sheik, the composer behind Spring Awakening, wrote new music. Mr. Kulick directs. (Performances start Wednesday, Dec. 9, classicstage.org.)

title: Choosing a Desktop Drive
description: Q. I can see the advantages of getting a laptop with a flash storage drive, since these drives are lighter weight and more durable, but is it worth the extra money to get an internal flash drive for a desktop computer?

title: Hari Nef Adds Another Layer to Transparent
description: Some women really know how to make an entrance. Consider Hari Nef, who had been in The New York Times offices for about 10 minutes before the Twitterverse issued an alert: its been rumored that @harinef is on the fourth floor wearing those fuzzy gucci loafers.

title: Multiplier Evidence and Multiplier Denial
description: One of the overwhelming lessons of the post-2008 crisis has been that fiscal multipliers are large when monetary policy cant offset the effects of spending cuts  which is what basic macroeconomics told us should be true, and is. But its a lesson many people dont want to learn, and theres very obviously a market for papers that claim to undermine that evidence.

title: 1965: Ten Years for Alabama Slayer
description: ANNISTON, Ala.  A white male jury today [Dec. 2] convicted a white man of second-degree murder in the slaying of a Negro. It was the first murder conviction of a white man for the slaying of a Negro in recent Alabama history. The jurors sentenced Hubert Damon Strange, 25, a garage attendant, to ten years in prison. The tall, blond youth stood with hands on his hips as the verdict was read. Defense Attorney J.B. Stoner, a militant segregationist, who had predicted an acquittal or at worst a mistrial, was stunned. Later, he said: I was surprised that a jury of 12 so-called white men would convict an innocent person on such a flimsy case. New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, December 3, 1965

title: Twyla Tharp on Tour:The Wrap Up
description: Twyla Tharp is writing about rehearsing, touring and creating new work, 50 years after her first dance concert. This is her final post.

title: Below the Line: Scoring Steve Jobs
description: What should the soundtrack be to the life of a tech visionary? In the Danny Boyle film Steve Jobs, there is no simple answer. The film captures the life of the co-founder of Apple in an unusual way, focusing on three product launches during Mr. Jobss career, in 1984, 1989 and 1998. We stay behind the scenes at these launches, with the tensions and emotional beats of the movie played out in hallways and dressing rooms. And the score, by Daniel Pemberton, aims to capture Mr. Jobss mood as well as set up the stakes of his involvement with Apple and beyond.

title: Jennifer Hudson, Without a Safety Net, Prepares for The Color Purple
description: A year ago, the producers of The Color Purple, the Broadway musical adapted from the Alice Walker novel, called the singer and actress Jennifer Hudson and asked if she would consider joining the cast of the shows revival. Ms. Hudson did not hesitate.

title: Jay Zs Tidal Service Gets a New Chief
description: The music streaming service Tidal has named a new chief executive, its third since Jay Z unveiled his plans for the service with much fanfare in the spring. Taking on the role will be Jeff Toig, a former SoundCloud executive.

title: Wages Up, Prices Low: Shake Shacks Food for Thought for the Fed
description: When Federal Reserve officials meet in two weeks to decide whether to raise interest rates, they will probably eat catered food at their Foggy Bottom headquarters. If they want to get some fresh air, though, they might consider heading to the nearest Shake Shack, where they could find both tasty burgers and insight that will make their decision smarter.

title: Homeless and Mentally Ill, a Former College Lineman Dies on the Street
description: HAINES CITY, Fla.  About an hour after sunset recently, Ryan Hoffman rode his bike, a hot pink Huffy, into oncoming traffic on an unlit stretch of Highway 17-92 here.

title: Frankenthaler Foundation Grant for Visual Arts at Yaddo
description: With James Baldwin, Saul Bellow, John Cheever and Alice Walker on the roll call of writers who had residencies at Yaddo, the artists retreat founded in Saratoga Springs in 1900, its literary history has often eclipsed awareness of the visual artists who worked there, among them Helen Frankenthaler, the abstract painter who died in 2011.

title: Grindr Polls Users on H.I.V. Prevention Pill
description: Since it was rolled out in 2012, Truvada, a pill that vastly reduces the risk of contracting H.I.V., has been hailed by some gay men as a game changer in the battle against the disease and condemned by others who argue that it encourages unsafe sex.

title: Family of American Killed in Benghazi Awaits Promised Funds
description: WASHINGTON  Family members of Glen Doherty, a C.I.A. contractor and a former Navy SEAL who was among four Americans killed in the 2012 terrorist attack in Benghazi, Libya, said they felt a sense of closure when they were told last December that the agency had finally agreed to pay Mr. Dohertys death benefits.

title: Pepper Fajans Makes Brooklyn Studios for Dance a Blessed Refuge
description: Pepper Fajans is a dancer, a puppeteer, a choreographer and a carpenter, but when he was a child he performed magic. Extensively, he said. I went out on the street in downtown Seattle and passed a hat. He may have been mastering misdirection, but what he was really learning was how to engage an audience.

title: Baking Season
description: Sam Sifton emails readers of Cooking five days a week to talk about food and suggest recipes. That email also appears here. To receive it in your inbox, register here.

title: Chanels Mtiers dArt show at Cinecitt
description: Karl Lagerfeld themed his pre-fall collection around Paris-meets-Rome.

title: Chanels Big Roman Spectacle
description: Karl Lagerfeld has been known to stage his pre-fall shows in far-flung locations: Salzburg, Edinburgh, Dallas. But this season, he brought the fashion crowd to Italy  mounting his mtiers dart collection in the iconic Cinecitt film complex on the outskirts of Rome. Guests were whisked into the sprawling studio on golf carts and transported to a cocktail-hour in the middle of a movie set of Ancient Rome (the complex was home to everything from Ben Hur to Spartacus). From there, Chanel screened a Lagerfeld-directed short film starting Kristen Stewart (who was also in the crowd) as a young actress playing Coco Chanel.

title: In Double It, Going for That Circus Atmosphere
description: Like whirring blades, they fly through the air, vanquishing dozens of opponents single-handedly. Others can balance on one hand more steadily than many people can balance on one leg. They are Chinese acrobats, or the body doubles for the stars of martial arts movies, and they have the skills of superheroes. But have you ever wondered what theyre like at a party?

title: Samuel Berger, Adviser to Clinton Who Shaped Foreign Ties, Dies at 70
description: Samuel R. Berger, a political confidant of President Bill Clinton who became his national security adviser and helped manage a period of fundamental transition in American foreign policy, died on Wednesday in Washington. He was 70.

title: Crazy Like a Box: Going Public Can Give Start-Ups Outsize Power
description: In early 2014, when the cloud storage company Box filed for an initial public offering, many on Wall Street looked at its numbers and laughed. Boxs revenues were soaring, but its losses were growing nearly as quickly. It was pouring vast sums into sales and marketing, it had less than a year of cash remaining, and executives did not anticipate making a profit for years.

title: A Math Teachers Critique of New Yorks Algebra Exam
description: To the Editor:

title: Donald Trump Says Terrorists Families Should Be Targets
description: Donald J. Trump said Wednesday that in the battle against the Islamic State, the families of terrorists should be targets, saying they were using their relatives as shields.

title: Six Screenwriters Leaving Their Mark on Hollywood
description: Screenwriters have been habitually overlooked by critics and a moviegoing public that hallows directors and A-list actors. But the glory of great films is, in no small part, great writing. Here, some of the year's best.

title: Analyzing the Elements of Art | Five Ways to Think About Line
description: Welcome to the third piece in our Seven Elements of Art series, in which Kristin Farr of KQED Art School helps students make connections between formal art instruction and our daily visual culture.

title: Video Review: Honda Pilot Is Useful Like a Van, but No Longer Square
description: SINCE its debut as a 2003 model, the Honda Pilot has pretty much looked like the box it was shipped in. But now, Honda throws a curve with the third generation  theres no square anywhere. Squinted eyes will see a vague resemblance to the CR-V. Smart move on Hondas part; the Pilots little sister is the best-selling crossover in the United States.

title: Historical Photos of Persia Through the Eyes of a Shah
description: In 1844, the 13-year-old heir apparent to the Qajar dynasty throne in Persia had his first portrait photograph taken by a traveling European, and a lifelong shutterbug was born. A few years later, when the prince inherited the crown as Naser al-Din Shah Qajar, he not only hired a resident court photographer but also learned to take pictures himself, turning a royal building into a darkroom and training court eunuchs to print the pictures he took of his wives.

title: Sofia Coppolas Muse? Bill Murray, of Course
description: Hes made his list and checked it twice, and its now that time of year when, if youve been good, a certain jolly, silver-haired gentleman might show up to spread a little extra holiday cheer: Were talking, of course, about Bill Murray. That mischievous actor and star of Rushmore, Groundhog Day and Olive Kitteridge adds another surprising credit to his already unpredictable rsum with the release of A Very Murray Christmas, a Netflix special that casts Mr. Murray as himself, more or less, as he tries to make things merry and bright on an unusual day at the Carlyle Hotel.

title: Dev Hynes as Blood Orange: A Force of Motion
description: Blood Orange is the recording and performing name for Dev Hynes, who grew up in London and became an excellent New Yorker about 10 years ago. Hes become semi-popular for his songs  the curious and elegiac tracks on the albums Coastal Grooves and Cupid Deluxe  but beyond the recorded evidence, Blood Orange represents a force of motion, aggregation, reclamation and scholarship. In his own work and through his collaborations with female singers  Carly Rae Jepsen, Solange Knowles, FKA twigs, Sky Ferreira  hes been creatively juxtaposing the sounds of 80s and 90s R&B and dance music against changing contemporary aesthetics. He has never fully committed to becoming a touring act, but its not a stretch to predict that Blood Orange and Friends, at the Apollo on Dec. 12, will be a memorable scene. Guests include the rappers Le1f and Junglepussy; the hip-hop trio Ratking; and a D.J. set by Kindness, a.k.a. the singer Adam Bainbridge. (3 and 8 p.m., bowerypresents.com.)

title: Melting: Last Race to the Pole, an Adventure Way Up North
description: A good preparation for winter is to watch one of the many cold-weather reality shows on cable, and this year Animal Planet has a particularly dramatic offering, a special at 9 p.m. Wednesday, Dec. 9, called Melting: Last Race to the Pole. It follows two adventurers, Eric Larsen and Ryan Waters, as they try to make their way unaided across the Arctic Ocean to the North Pole, a journey few have completed and now made all the more treacherous by the Arctic ice melt.

title: Starkly Different Accounts of Freddie Grays Death as Trial of Officer Begins
description: BALTIMORE  After civil unrest, outrage and months of heated debate over how and why a 25-year-old black man named Freddie Gray suffered a broken spine in police custody, prosecutors and defense lawyers offered starkly different accounts here Wednesday as the trial of Officer William G. Porter, one of six Baltimore police officers charged in Mr. Grays death, began.

title: Counterculture Flicks at Anthology Film Archives
description: No Hollywood studio ever understood the teenage audience better than American International Pictures, which was founded in the mid-1950s and quickly cranked out double features for the drive-in, heavy on schlock horror, juvenile delinquents and hot rods. In the 60s, production expanded into psychedelia; led by the subversive indie-film master Roger Corman, this period also served as an apprenticeship for a new wave of moviemakers.

title: Diana Damrau and Joyce DiDonato, Bel Canto Divas, Return to New York
description: New York welcomes back two bel canto divas this week, both known for the warmth and dexterity of their singing and for their likability and down-to-earth humor. On Sunday, Dec. 6, the German soprano Diana Damrau presents a song recital at Carnegie Hall with the pianist Craig Rutenberg that draws on Schubert, Strauss and Dvorak as well as a sprinkling of artful ridiculousness in the form of Poulencs Fianailles Pour Rire and Manuel Rosenthals survey of weighty themes  elephants, grammar  seen through a childs eyes. (Stern Auditorium, 2 p.m. carnegiehall.org.)

title: British Jets Hit ISIS in Syria After Parliament Authorizes Airstrikes
description: LONDON  The British Parliament on Wednesday authorized airstrikes in Syria against the Islamic State, in a vote that became a wider test of British willingness to play an active role in international affairs, and British warplanes made their first attacks hours later.

title: BTG Pactual Partners Take Control From Former Leader
description: RIO DE JANEIRO  Andr Esteves, long the force behind BTG Pactual, ceded financial control in the firm he founded to a group of seven partners, the Brazilian investment bank said in a regulatory filing on Wednesday.

title: Larry Keigwin & Company at the Joyce Theater
description: The more the merrier: The choreographer Larry Keigwin may well agree with that. He likes moving lots of people who crowd and jostle one another and thoroughly enjoy the bustle. His troupe, Keigwin & Company, is offering two of his works for dancers on the move at the Joyce Theater. Sidewalk celebrates city folk on a busy street, with steps that range from pedestrian activities to explosions of athleticism. And in Exit Like an Animal, dancers behave like herds, but their patterns suggest theyre also acquainted with fashion shows and night spots. Although Mr. Keigwin loves ensembles, his new 3 Ballads is a solo  his first in more than a decade. But hes still filling the stage with energetic steps. In addition, this company presents premieres by two up-and-coming choreographers, Loni Landon and Adam Barruch.

description: LEAWOOD, KAN.

description: Two young designers find space to create in a family-owned postmodernist monument in Spain.
