The cleanest of the many ways to skin a cat begins with a so-called dorsal cut. Start at the bottom of the skull, and cut a straight line to the base of the tail along the spine. Always use a sharp blade, says Eddy, who prefers a carbon steel scalpel. Peel the skin back as you would an orange. Trim carefully around the paws, mouth, nose and eyes. This is obviously not work for the squeamish, but to make a lifelike remembrance of an animal means doing things that make its death inescapable.

title: In Other Countries, Youre as Likely to Be Killed by a Falling Object as by a Gun
description: Two young campers were sleeping in Yosemite Valley this August when a tree branch snapped and fell on their tent, killing them both. We dont know what caused the limb to fall, said the parks spokeswoman, Jodi Bailey. It seems like just a freak accident.

title: The Legend and Lore of Notre-Dame de Reims
description: The story goes that in the 13th century, when three great French cathedrals were being built  Notre-Dame de Paris, Notre-Dame de Chartres and Notre-Dame de Reims  the builders of Notre-Dame de Reims, determined to achieve primacy over the other two and perhaps employing a bit of industrial espionage, managed to make their massive edifice just a little bit more massive than the other two. As in, a few extra feet.

title: FIFA Charges Have Ring of Familiarity
description: The impertinence is so terribly uncouth.

title: Teenagers in The Times | November 2015
description: Welcome to the November edition of Teenagers in The Times, a monthly feature that rounds up recent articles about young people that have appeared in the paper.

title: On Chinas Constitution Day, Book on Constitutionalism Largely Disappears
description: BEIJING  China held its second-ever National Constitution Day on Friday, when citizens are supposed to renew their loyalty to the Constitution that both enshrines the Communist Partys power and promises freedom of expression and other rights  so long as that power is not challenged.

title: San Bernardino Shooting Divides Party Narratives
description: To listen to the Democratic and Republican presidential candidates describe the mass shootings in San Bernardino is to hear two separate realities.

title: The Importance of a Leaf
description: Dear Diary:

title: Benicio Del Toro on What Sicario Got Right (and Wrong)
description: Natural-born brooder and a man in possession of Hollywoods slinkiest pair of bedroom eyes, Benicio Del Toro fits seamlessly into characters who at a moments notice might either pull a shiv or erupt into twitchy, maniacal laughter. In Denis Villeneuves drug war opus, Sicario, it is hard to fathom any other actor as Alejandro, a tormented Mexican ex-prosecutor turned avenger who alternately menaces and protects the F.B.I. agent played by Emily Blunt. Mr. Del Toros performance has foisted him into Oscar contention for best supporting actor, a category he won in 2001, for his role in Traffic. He was nominated again in 2004 for 21 Grams.

title: Hotel and Tour News: Hollywood History in Puerto Vallarta
description: IN MEXICO, A BOUTIQUE HOTEL WITH A HOLLYWOOD HISTORY

title: 1890: King William Laid in His Grave
description: THE HAGUE  The Hague is teeming to-night [Dec. 4] with joyous crowds after the burial of the last of its Orange Kings, which was, in point of fact, a brilliant pageant. The population, amounting to 183,000, reached this morning to 400,000 by the influx of foreign Princes and their suites, crowds of Belgians, Germans, Luxemburgers and Dutch provincials; 25,000 visitors came from Amsterdam alone, and many spent the night in the streets, finding no lodgings. Many of the streets were decked with tricolor flags, and the balconies and windows were decorated with black hangings. Wooden stands for sightseers were erected in all the streets, in the shop fronts and even on the decks of the barges on the canals, and places were paid for at extraordinary prices. An Englishman gave 300 florins for a window. The procession formed, one mile long, and taking seventy-five minutes to pass a given point, the principal features were the muffled drums, the military bands playing Chopins and Handels funeral dirges. The New York Herald, European Edition, December 5, 1890

title: Norfolk Southern Rejects $28 Billion Bid From Canadian Pacific
description: Canadian Pacific has been rebuffed in an another ambitious attempt to buy a large railroad operator, showing again the regulatory hurdles to rail-carrier consolidation.

title: What I Love | Nick Sandow
description: The actor, of Orange Is the New Black, and his partner, Tamara Malkin-Stuart, live in a Brooklyn townhouse.

title: Nick Sandow, of Orange Is the New Black, at Home
description: The free-standing soaking tub is the scene-stealer in the 19th-century townhouse in Carroll Gardens, Brooklyn, that belongs to the actor and director Nick Sandow. Set in front of a window wall overlooking the neighbors backyards, the tub is the focal point of a sight line running from the second-floor living room at the front of the house, through the stair landing, to the master bedroom and the open bathroom.

title: A Grim News Playbook in Repeated Mass Killings
description: On Wednesday at 2:28 p.m., the CNN anchor Brooke Baldwin was in a split-screen conversation with a network legal correspondent on a story about Guantnamo Bay when her producer started talking into her earpiece. There had been another shooting, this time in San Bernardino, Calif., he said. There was not much information, but she would have to break away and relay it to viewers immediately.

title: The Economy Is Growing, but Not Fixed Yet
description: The economy is performing almost exactly as the people paid to predict these things thought it would.

title: Daily Report: Mark Zuckerberg Explains His Use of Limited Liability Company
description: Since the Facebook chief executive Mark Zuckerberg and his wife, Dr. Priscilla Chan, revealed their plans this week to give away 99 percent of their Facebook shares over their lifetimes toward philanthropic purposes, the couple has faced plenty of heat.

title: Using Card and Board Games to Keep Minds Sharp
description: MARK A. WIEDER began playing chess at age 8. Now the owner of a consulting firm in New Jersey, Mr. Wieder, 65, played competitively throughout high school and college. According to the United States Chess Federation, he is among the top 5 percent of federation members age 65 and older.

title: The Spectacle of Skill: Selected Writings of Robert Hughes
description: Robert Hughes was a large, ruddy, passionate man with a mordant, propulsive prose style, an acid sense of humor and a keen appreciation for the ridiculous in American culture, a quality that is never in short supply. He was also an art critic for Time magazine for 30 years; the author of more than a dozen books, including a best-selling history of Australia, The Fatal Shore; host of a television tour of modern art, The Shock of the New; and an avid fisherman. I knew the man, and I liked and admired him, although I did not always share his opinions about art and artists.

title: G.O.P. Field Continues to Chase Donald Trump, New Poll Says
description: Donald J. Trump continues to widen his lead for the Republican Partys presidential nomination, according to a new national CNN/ORC poll that shows the billionaire businessman in his most dominant position since entering the race last summer.

title: Stuff We Liked: Whimsical Charts and Colorful Books
description: This article was initially published as a letter to subscribers of The Upshots newsletter. You can sign up for the email here to get this and all of the best of The Upshot.

title: Anchors Away (Slightly Wonkish)
description: Last week I wrote about what in our macroeconomic models has and hasnt worked since 2008. As I said, demand-side events have been very much what people using IS-LM would have predicted (and did). But on the supply side, not so much. For one thing, the accelerationist doctrine that has dominated economic discussion of inflation and unemployment for 40 years has fallen flat. If inflation had responded to the Great Recession and aftermath the way it did in previous big slumps, we would be deep in deflation by now; we arent.

title: Whats on This Week Around the World
description: Paris

title: Packers Hail Mary to Beat Lions Evokes Other Crazy Plays
description: The game was over.

title: In Paris, Negotiators Trim a Draft Climate Agreement, Climate Scientists Press for Nuclear Energy, Activists Prepare for Failure
description: In theory, the goal of the Paris talks over a new global climate agreement is to create a more sustainable human relationship with the climate system by curbing emissions of greenhouse gases and boosting poor countries capacity to withstand climate shocks.

title: Portraits: John Berger on Artists
description: Has John Berger mellowed? Apparently not. In his new book, the passionately wayward and contentious English writer, who once shared his Booker Prize money with the Black Panther Party, recalls being ejected from the National Gallery in London. You have insulted one of my men, the security chief tells Berger. You have shouted obscene words in a public institution. You will now walk in front of us to the main exit. Bergers crime? He refused, after a quarrel with a guard, to put his bag on his shoulder while drawing from a favorite painting, Antonello da Messinas Crucifixion. Now almost 90, Berger still has the deep devotion to pictures, not to mention the reflexive anti-authoritarianism, that you might associate with a first-year art student.

title: In Greece, Shift From Cash to Plastic Could Undercut Shadow Economy
description: ATHENS  In the central market here recently, hanging above the trays of cod and the slabs of pink meat, was evidence that Greeces near bankruptcy last summer was having an unexpected impact  shiny new placards advertising that, at least in some stalls, customers could now pay with debit and credit cards.

title: 1940: War Prisoners to Be Sent Food
description: WASHINGTON  The American Red Cross announced today [Dec. 4] that war prisoners in European camps will receive 5,000 packages of food before the end of the year as a result of an urgent request of the International Committee of the Red Cross in Geneva. The shipment will be the first of what is to be known as a prisoners-of-war package service, the Red Cross said. The Red Cross announced that food would be sent first because of the great need, but that later shipments would include clothing also. The food now is being purchased and will be packed by a merchandising firm for the Red Cross. The parcels will weigh eleven pounds each, will cost approximately $2.75 and will contain evaporated milk, oatmeal, cheese, sardines, oleo margarine, dried fruit, corned beef, orange juice, sugar, cigarettes and vitamized dry beverages requiring only the addition of water.New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, December 5, 1940

title: Dont Assume a Fed Action Will Move the Market
description: Humans dont behave like computers. That makes life interesting, but it has a serious downside for economists: It is exceedingly difficult to predict the short-term directions of major markets, even when events seem to be entirely predictable.

title: The Uncollected David Rakoff
description: In his foreword to The Uncollected David Rakoff, a book that understandably, if ultimately ill-advisably, attempts to squeeze and preserve every last drop out of the late essayist, humorist and performer, Paul Rudnick calls Rakoff my favorite breed of artist, because his work promises pleasure. Remembering the delicious experience of encountering Rakoffs name in a magazine, Rudnick writes, Id either catapult right to his words or Id save them for last, as an earned dessert.

title: Live and Kicking: Soccer Games to Watch This Weekend
description: This week is full of cup matches in Europe  lots and lots of cup matches  but if thats not your thing, start looking ahead to the weekend.

title: Comics Task: Get Young Germans to Log Off, Tune In and Laugh Out Loud
description: COLOGNE, Germany  Jan Bhmermann, a 34-year-old comic, has two of the toughest assignments in Germany.

title: A New Crisis of Cuban Migration
description: Washington  A standoff in recent weeks that has trapped hundreds of Cuban migrants at Costa Ricas border with Nicaragua as they try to reach the United States is a graphic demonstration that Washingtons migration policy toward Cuba is no longer sustainable. Left unchanged it could produce a crisis on the scale of the 1980 Mariel boatlift or the 1994 balsero (rafters) crisis  if one hasnt begun already.

title: Lady Byron and Her Daughters, by Julia Markus
description: Annabella Milbanke has historically gotten bad press. During their uneasy courtship, her future husband, Lord Byron, christened her the princess of parallelograms: a backhanded accolade to bestow on even the most mathematically inclined 19th-century bride. By September 1816, a few months after the end of their short and disastrous marriage, he had labeled his wife a moral Clytemnestra.

title: Death Takes No Holiday
description: Just call me Bad Santa, lugging a sack of holiday cheer: this years outstanding books about homicidal children, psychopaths and coldblooded murderers. Tuck the kids into bed and forget the milk and cookies. Make mine Belgian chocolates and a snifter of brandy. Now stop yelling for the cops and open your gifts.

title: F.B.I. Treating San Bernardino Attack as Terrorism Case
description: WASHINGTON  On the day she and her husband killed 14 people and wounded 21 others in San Bernardino, Calif., a woman pledged allegiance to the Islamic State in a Facebook post, officials said Friday, as the F.B.I. announced that it was treating the massacre as an act of terrorism.

title: As Marco Rubio Speaks of Faith, Evangelicals Keep Options Open
description: At a dinner with Iowa religious leaders recently, Marco Rubio opened up about his relationship with Jesus. He described what he had learned from studying the Bible, especially the Apostle Peter, and spoke of the importance of self-sacrifice as illustrated in the story of Abraham.

title: The Bold Idea Behind a Small Brooklyn School
description: The widely publicized letter that Mark Zuckerberg and his wife, Priscilla Chan, wrote to their newborn daughter this week  a letter that might have attempted to preclude any anxiety on the childs part with a clause like dont worry, therell always be money for Cheddar Bunnies  pledged 99 percent of the couples Facebook shares to charity.

title: Leases and Lengthier Loans Can Reduce Car Payments
description: CAR shoppers are increasingly favoring financial arrangements like leases and longer-term loans that allow them to buy costlier vehicles but with more manageable monthly payments.

title: Alfonse DAmato in Rare Role: Testifying Against Friend at Skelos Trial
description: In his three terms as a United States senator from New York and his decades of influence as a Republican power broker, Alfonse M. DAmato has seen and done just about everything.

title: 1901: An Icy Deluge From the South Pole
description: In 1901, the European edition of The New York Herald published the work of the scientist Leon Lewis, who predicted the break-up of the so-called continent of Antarctica. A glacial flood was sure to follow, he claimed, one that would wipe out the entire human race. Below, an excerpt from our archives:

title: Enter My Contest!
description: Its time for a contest! My email newsletter is one year old, and to celebrate were going to try to reward old subscribers and new ones alike.

title: Europes Most Indulgent Trek
description: The epicurean pleasures of the Tour du Mont Blanc.

title: Reported Gains in Afghan Maternal Health Are Found to Be Implausible
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  One of the best ways to measure improvement in a nations health is the maternal mortality rate, and American officials have long held out Afghanistans striking improvement there as an important legacy of Western aid.

title: Keep Feasting!
description: Sam Sifton emails readers of Cooking five days a week to talk about food and suggest recipes. That email also appears here. To receive it in your inbox, register here.

title: 100 Miles, 10 Days, Three Countries and a Lot of Cheese
description: The quest story that enjoys the greatest currency in America, aside from the postapocalyptic road trip, is the grueling distance hike. The genre is capacious, and can be inspirational (Cheryl Strayeds Wild) or slapstick (Bill Brysons A Walk in the Woods), but the plot doesnt vary much: Out of a sense of profligacy or shame, one takes to the long narrow path as a kind of purgatory, stripping off various regrettable excesses  drugs, sex, food, Internet. At the trails end one emerges remade: chaste, humble and slender.

title: FIFAs Message Is at the Mercy of the Wrong Messengers
description: ZURICH  The FIFA officials tried hard. They did. On Thursday afternoon, the acting president and the acting secretary general and the permanent reform committee chief (who just seems to like acting) wanted desperately to talk about change. About progress. About the future.

title: On Guns, Obama Cannot Easily Sidestep Congress
description: WASHINGTON  In the hours after the San Bernardino rampage, President Obama reiterated the plea for common sense gun safety laws that he has made after virtually every mass shooting during his presidency.

title: Charlotte Rampling Through the Years
description: For more than five decades, the actress has seduced men and women alike with her cool, distant beauty.

title: Rare King James Bible First Edition Discovered at Drew University
description: Drew University, founded in Madison, N.J., in 1867 as a Methodist seminary, is known for its unusually rich collection of rare books and manuscripts, including hundreds of historic Bibles, a 1493 Nuremberg Chronicle and extensive holdings relating to Willa Cather.

title: Homes for Sale in New York and New Jersey
description: Click on the slide show to see this weeks featured properties in the New York region:

title: On the Market in the New York Region
description: This weeks homes include a four-bedroom in Croton-on-Hudson, N.Y., and a five-bedroom in South Amboy, N.J.

title: Jessica Jones Episode 10: 1,000 Cuts
description: One of the things that instantly distinguished Jessica Jones from other live-action Marvel TV adaptations was its forward momentum and sense of mystery. Integral characters like Luke Cage, Will Simpson and Dorothy Walker were introduced quickly in order to set up the urgency of Joness hunt for Kilgrave. And until Episode 10, the shows creators had done a fine job of making Joness search for Kilgrave feel genuinely urgent, which is pretty impressive given how many times shes caught him, lost him, then reluctantly rendezvoused with him, and back again. AKA 1,000 Cuts is the first episode that has an arrhythmic pace and a generally messy structure.

title: Judge in FIFA Scandal Arrested When Cruise Ship Docks in Florida
description: Federal agents boarded an international cruise ship as it docked in Florida before dawn on Friday and arrested one of the world soccer officials who had yet to be captured in a broad corruption investigation, the F.B.I. said.

title: Letters: Questioning the Gods
description: To the Editor:

title: Charlotte Ramplings Unknowable Truth
description: For more than 50 years, the actress has seduced men and women alike with her cool, distant beauty. But what if all that time we were wrong?

title: Water as a Climate-Change Gut Punch in a City Defined by an Ocean
description: MIAMI  The ordinary man settled into his ordinary ritual.

title: Hotel in Nicaragua Offers Secluded Luxury
description: Standard rooms start at $245.

title: China Pledges $60 Billion to Aid Africas Development
description: JOHANNESBURG  China pledged $60 billion in development assistance to Africa on Friday, promising to help nations industrialize and elevate its relationship with the continent beyond one centered on the extraction of raw materials.

title: Paperback Row
description: PUTINS KLEPTOCRACY: Who Owns Russia?, by Karen Dawisha. (Simon & Schuster, $18.) Vladimir Putin and his associates have merely used democracy for decoration during his tenure as president, Dawisha argues. She presents the scope of his corruption in damning detail, cataloging cases of money laundering, bribery and election fixing, all designed to benefit the countrys elite. (More than half of the $50 billion earmarked for the Sochi Olympics ended up in the pockets of Putins allies.)

title: Healing Together
description: In his wife, Mr. Barkley, a three-time boxing champion, has found a happy, healing and loving influence.

title: Iran Barkley and Pamela Graham: A Boxer Marries His Champ
description: The comeback of Iran Barkley began five years ago at a nightclub in the South Bronx, a short jog from the gang-infested neighborhood where he first learned to use his fists. It was a skill that would eventually help him earn three world boxing titles and what he estimated to be more than $5 million.

title: Homes for Sale in Brooklyn and Manhattan
description: Click on the slide show to see this weeks featured properties in New York City:

title: On the Market in New York City
description: This weeks properties are in Hells Kitchen, SoHo and Bedford-Stuyvesant, Brooklyn.

title: Editors Choice
description: THE COMPLETE WORKS OF PRIMO LEVI, edited by Ann Goldstein. (Liveright, three volumes, $100.) Twenty-eight years after Levis death, this collection of everything he published brings into focus the breadth and coherence of his genius.

title: Despite Climate Concerns, OPEC Plans to Keep Pumping Oil While It Can
description: VIENNA  Even as United Nations climate-conference delegates met near Paris on Friday seeking ways to reduce the globes dependence on high-carbon fuels like oil, some of the worlds biggest petroleum producers vowed to keep pumping flat out.

title: A Hanukkah Treat (No, Not Latkes) With a Sweet Reminder of Sicily
description: Latkes may be ubiquitous at Hanukkah here in the United States, but almost anything deep-fried is fair game, from Israeli jelly doughnuts to Spanish cheese fritters to whatever other tidbits one feels like browning in a good amount of bubbling oil.

title: Cartoon: Chappatte on Climate Change
description: Someday, people may provide a new energy source.

title: San Bernardino Shooting: The Investigation So Far
description: The investigation into the shooting at San Bernardino, Calif., that killed 14 people and wounded 21 continued Friday.

title: Fusing Flamenco and Krump
description: This adaptation of Sophocles Antigone being performed in New York City fuses flamenco dancing and krump, a style of hip-hop dance.

title: An Excerpt from Sophocles Antigone
description: Soledad Barrio, the lead performer in Noche Flamencas Antigona, practices the scene El Entierro de Polineices in which she buries her brother.

title: A Renowned Dance Couple Keeps Flamencos Flame Burning in New York
description: Flamenco is clandestino, said Soledad Barrio, the star of the renowned company Noche Flamenca, who moved with her family from Madrid to Washington Heights two years ago. In a flamenco studio, she continued, you dont need big windows  or beautiful space.

title: What the Eye Hears and America Dancing
description: To an extent that seems counterintuitive from the quaint, straw-hat soft shoe typically associated with it, tap-dancing  like so much of American popular culture  owes its very essence to black people. Like the jazz it evolved alongside, tap blends the European and the African to a near-indissoluble degree, with origins only dimly reconstructable. Brian Seiberts authoritative What the Eye Hears illuminates those beginnings  along with what happened afterward  as well as anyone ever will.

title: Manhattan Prosecutors Will Not Retry Former Dewey Chairman
description: Prosecutors in Manhattan have decided not to retry Steven H. Davis, the former chairman of Dewey & LeBoeuf, the once-prominent New York law firm that collapsed in bankruptcy in 2012, a person briefed on the matter said on Friday.

title: High Line Living
description: A spacious duplex penthouse at the High Line-hugging HL23 condominium, perched directly above the elevated park and with a wraparound terrace offering far-ranging vistas that include the Hudson River, the Empire State Building and the World Trade Center, is about to enter the market for $22.95 million.

title: Exclusive | 515 West 23rd Street
description: The 3,554-square-foot duplex penthouse cantilevers over the High Line.

title: Purdue Fires a Champion of Athletes Rights
description: John Shoop, the offensive coordinator for the Purdue football team, was called into the office of Darrell Hazell, the teams head coach, and fired. It was 12:45 p.m. Sunday.

title: Inside the List
description: Elephant in the Room: Cross Justice, the latest thriller in James Pattersons long-running Alex Cross series, enters the hardcover fiction list at No.1. This has been, as usual, a very good year for Patterson: Cross Justice is his ninth novel to hit the adult hardcover list in 2015 (seven of them written with other people, but still), and since January he has appeared on that list, or the extended version, for all but four weeks. Patterson was at the National Book Awards ceremony last month, at Cipriani Wall Street, to accept the Literarian Award for his efforts to promote reading. I feel uncomfortable, he told the crowd, because, well, I am the elephant in the room, the bull in the china shop, the stranger in a strange land, the Big Mac at Cipriani. He went on to discuss his early love of fiction  hes partial to the terrific novels Mr. Bridge and Mrs. Bridge, by Evan S. Connell  and to praise school libraries and independent bookstores, encouraging his listeners to help those institutions if they could: Lets all be literarians, whatever the hell that means. He also revealed that his debut mystery, The Thomas Berryman Number, had been rejected 31 times before finding a home. I keep a list of all the editors who turned down my first novel, he said. Sometimes they send me books and ask for blurbs. Mostly, though, theyre dead.

title: Barry Bondss Return to Baseball Will Be Compelling to Watch
description: The hitting coach is the busiest person on a baseball team. If you see him in the pregame hours, he is almost always scurrying somewhere  bouncing over to the video room to study swings on a laptop, ducking into a conference room to share scouting reports, wheeling a cart of baseballs into a batting tunnel under the stands. Pitchers, with their delicate arms, cannot throw constantly to shake a slump. But hitters can swing as often as they like.

title: Climate Change and Choosing Where to Invest
description: CLIMATE change has finally gotten the attention of world leaders, who convened in Paris this week for a conference on how to combat global warming.

title: Mets Sandy Alderson Needs Treatment for Cancer
description: Members of the news media gathered in a conference room at Citi Field on Friday for the annual off-season luncheon with Mets executives, including the chief operating officer Jeff Wilpon, the assistant general manager John Ricco and the top front-office aide J. P. Ricciardi.

title: In Long Island City, Now Arriving in No Mans Land
description: On a recent Saturday night, more than a dozen people found themselves in the industrial wilds of Long Island City, Queens, looking for a line of yellow paint.

title: Central Park Views for $45 Million
description: A penthouse on the 18th and 19th floors of 15 Central Park West, the exclusive twin-tower limestone condominium where another apartment held the record until recently for the citys most expensive single-family residence, sold at a $3 million loss, for $45,000,000, according to city records. But an eighth-floor apartment in the building closed at its full $35,000,000 asking price and yielded a hefty profit. The two transactions were the priciest of the week.

title: The Illustrated Interview: Judd Apatow
description: The Emmy-winning writer, director and comedian, who is one of the producers of the upcoming Netflix film Pee-wees Big Holiday, sketched his answers in a dressing room with a Uni-Ball Vision Elite Liquid Ink Rollerball pen.

title: Landlord Lets Reporters Into San Bernardino Suspects Home
description: REDLANDS, Calif.  There was the can of baby formula left on the counter, and the dishes stacking up in the kitchen sink. A cookies-and-cream ice cream cake sat in the freezer, half-eaten. And upstairs, in one of the bedrooms, a white crib had been piled high with pillows, blankets and toys for a baby.

title: Inside The New York Times Book Review: The 10 Best Books of 2015
description: This week, editors at the Book Review discuss the years best books; Alexandra Alter has news from the literary world; Matthew Schneier discusses facial hair and a treatise on mens style; Bee Wilson talks about First Bite; and Gregory Cowles has best-seller news. Pamela Paul is the host.

title: Mortgage Approval Entirely Online
description: Progress toward moving the entire mortgage approval process online made an apparent leap forward last month with the introduction of Quicken Loans Rocket Mortgage.

title: Resistance Is Futile
description: Theres no data on this, but Id guess that most self-help books are purchased in the depths of a bad mood. When were happy, we idle and play. When were not, we buy books that promise a fix. And when those books fail to deliver, we feel wronged. The market has responded accordingly, with a crop of new books seemingly aimed at people who have grown cynical about self-help. These books have profane titles, saucy premises and, in one case, a cover photo of the author posing nearly nude and oiled and aiming a weapon. Their tone is belligerent. Much like their intended readers, these books could be credibly described as having an attitude problem.

title: A Neurotics Guide to Small Talk
description: As a lifelong neurotic, I sympathize with the daily struggle to conquer human-to-human small talk. Parties, weddings, bars, offices, public transportation: Small talk is all around us. Holiday party season makes it worse.

title: Home Sales Around the New York Region
description: Information on sales in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

title: Suffocation Described as Likely Cause of Death inFreddie Gray Case
description: BALTIMORE  Freddie Grays spinal cord was so severely injured that he most likely lost his ability to breathe and suffocated, a state medical examiner testified here Friday on a tense day of testimony and video evidence that evoked an issue and a phrase  I cant breathe  intimately associated with another contentious case of a black mans death after a rough encounter with the police.

title: Thinking Chowder? Try an Iberian-Inspired Soup
description: Publishing a new recipe for chowder seems like asking for trouble, since everyone has a different idea about what makes a true one.

title: The Fashion News to Know This Week
description: The future is female

title: How Jamie Hodari, Workplace Entrepreneur, Spends His Sundays
description: Would you eat a fish caught in Prospect Park? Neither would Jamie Hodari. But that doesnt stop Mr. Hodari, 34, whose business is creating shared office spaces, from getting out there with bait and rod and letting the prospect of catching a largemouth bass transport him to another place. Mr. Hodari is a founding partner of Industrious, which has been constructing its first outpost in New York. Its a little ironic, he said in late October, because my work is devoted to saying that working at home inhibits your creativity and makes it harder to be productive. But our first New York location doesnt open for three weeks, so I do work from home relatively frequently. Home is an apartment in Cobble Hill, Brooklyn, where Mr. Hodari lives alone.

title: Gun Violence and Fear in America
description: To the Editor:

title: Union Square Cafe, Danny Meyers Flagship Bistro, Is About to Set Sail
description: Like certain insects or figures from Greek mythology, New York eats its own. You know how it works: A restaurant moves into an underserved area, attracts attention, then a crowd, and then other restaurants and larger crowds. Before you know it, the original restaurant can no longer afford to remain in the very neighborhood it helped create. Thats exactly what happened to Union Square Cafe, Danny Meyers flagship bistro. After 30 years, the restaurant is relocating from its perch on East 16th Street to the other side of Union Square. In celebration of the move, Mr. Meyer created the 12 Nights of Union Square Cafe, a three-course menu for $85 available through Dec. 12.

title: In Miami, a Trio of Minimalist Paintings
description: Its undeniable that figuration stands tall in todays art market  bodies of all shapes and sizes are in evidence throughout the Miami art fairs and are the subject of one of the most buzzed-about pop-up exhibitions in town, Unrealism, at the Design Districts Moore Building, curated by the heavyweight double bill of Jeffrey Deitch and Larry Gagosian. However, as soon as a trend hits a saturation point, the window opens wide for a counterpoint. Throughout Art Basel Miami Beach, there are a number of strikingly spare paintings whose minimal, monochromatic brushstrokes bear uncanny superficial resemblances, despite originating from very different times and places. The 78-year-old Swiss painter Niele Toroni is known for applying short, squarish acrylic streaks of a prescribed size in strict patterns; he has new works on offer at a number of booths, including Alfonso Artiaco. On offer at Greene Naftali is a historical work by the recently deceased German painter Gunther Forg  who, though prolific like Toroni, is known for constant variation rather than repetition. Finally, the Paris-based South Korean artist Lee Ufans canvas of two blocky gray smears at Galerie Nchst St. Stephan Rosemarie Schwarzwlder is discreetly rooted in the natural origin of its materials, which combine oil with pigments of stone.

title: Greg Abbotts Stern Commandments
description: HOUSTON  IF Ive learned anything living in Texas, lo, these many years, it is that actions that seem nuts or cruel on the surface usually have some rational basis down below. But Im struggling to see this one.

title: The Wiz Live! Scores Strong Ratings
description: The Wiz Live!, NBCs latest live musical, scored strong ratings on Thursday night, easily beating last years live rendition of Peter Pan. The broadcast brought network televisions highest Thursday-night ratings in the key 18- to 49-year-old demographic, for a nonsporting event, in more than a year.

title: The Green Lady of Brooklyn
description: Elizabeth Sweetheart, 74, is known in her area of Brooklyn as the Green Lady of Carroll Gardens for her evergreen approach to life.

title: Fantasy Football Week 13: Rankings and Matchup Analysis
description: Fantasy football analysis for N.F.L. Week 13 games, including Mondays matchup between the Dallas Cowboys and the Washington Redskins. You can also follow the Sablich brothers on Twitter at @5thDownFantasy and see their complete Week 13 player rankings.

title: Think Like a Doctor: Limp as a Baby Solved
description: On Thursday we challenged Well readers to solve the real-life case of a 28-year-old woman who had a long history of abdominal pain and constipation who suddenly started seizing and having hallucinations. It was a pretty classic presentation of a rare disease, and lots of you figured it out.

title: Thanksgiving's Over, Let's Fill Some Bowls
description: With several conference championships on Saturday, heres a look at how the College Football Playoff might shake out.

title: Puerto Ricos Debt Relief to Get Supreme Court Hearing
description: WASHINGTON  The Supreme Court on Friday agreed to decide whether Puerto Rico, which is in the midst of a financial crisis, may allow public utilities there to restructure $20 billion in debt.

title: Russian Truckers, Irate Over New Tolls, Block Roads Near Moscow
description: MOSCOW  Hundreds of long-distance truckers blocked a lengthy section of the ring road circling the capital on Friday to protest a new national toll, in the first sign that Russias economic woes might be eroding the broad support for President Vladimir V. Putins government.

title: The End of Social Security Loopholes: What Now?
description: For years, retirees have been able to squeeze tens of thousands of extra dollars from Social Security using two special tactics. Though they went by gimmicky names like claim benefits now, claim more later, these strategies were perfectly legal.

title: Inside a Redecorated 17th-Century Palace
description: What to do when inheriting a family castle filled with battle weapons, dusty heirlooms and family portraits? For Giovanni and Lucia Guarini, it started with paint.

title: Shanice Williams on Her Road to Dorothy and The Wiz Live!
description: Shanice Williams had big sparkly slippers to fill when she stepped into the role of Dorothy for NBCs broadcast of The Wiz Live! on Thursday night. By most accounts, she more than pulled it off, earning accolades from many critics, fans and celebrities following along on Twitter. They were all the more impressed because shes making her professional debut at only 19, and she had to hold her own with a cast that included Mary J. Blige, Queen Latifah, and Ne-Yo. (Your world is about to change its face but I know where youre goingas far and as high as you want, Audra McDonald tweeted to her.)

title: The Vibrant Makeover of a 17th-Century Palace
description: Giovanni and Lucia Guarini inherited a castle filled with battle weapons, dusty heirlooms and family portraits. And then they got some paint.

title: Yahoos Spinoff Plan Could Be Risky Business
description: The Yahoo board is reconsidering ways to increase its languishing stock price, including a possible sale of the core platform and advertising business. Most of the value of Yahoos stock is locked up in its $32 billion stake in Alibaba, and for almost a year, the board has focused on trying to dispose of those shares without paying taxes.

title: Avon Opts for New Playbook in Fight With Activist Investor
description: Avons fading beauty is in the eyes of two different financial beholders.

title: Is Gollum Good or Evil? Jail Term in Turkey Hinges on Answer
description: A Turkish mans freedom may hang on a question put to a panel of Lord of the Rings experts: Is Gollum evil?

title: Now I Am With the Protesters: Readers on a Police Shooting in Chicago
description: The videotaped shooting of 17-year-old Laquan McDonald by a Chicago police officer prompted readers to call for systemic change to restore public trust in law enforcement in Chicago and around the country.

title: When a New Mother Is Accused in a Shooting
description: The reported accounts of Tashfeen Maliks life sound so ordinary. She met her husband, Syed Rizwan Farook, online, through a dating site. She moved to the United States from Pakistan on a K-1 visa as his fiance, and they married two years ago. After she became pregnant, the couple registered at Target, inviting friends and family to give them familiar things, a car seat, diapers, safety swabs.

title: Whats Hot in Miami This Week  Outside the Basel Tent
description: Prioritizing is key for the collectors, artists and onlookers who descend upon Miami Art Week. Alongside the fairs  Art Basel, plus 22 satellites  theres an international influx of events and exhibitions in the realms of design, fashion, art and everything in between scattered across diverse venues in the city. While some ambitious participants touched down over the weekend, Monday night offered the first round of previews, beginning at the Shelborne Wyndham Grand, where the artist Bosco Sodi has installed six gold, site-specific sculptures with an almost extraterrestrial shine. Across the water in the up-and-coming neighborhood of Little Haiti, the recently moved Gallery Diet opened its doors for Ann Cravens new painting show  giving visitors the opportunity to get better acquainted with the local talent.

title: Bookshelf: Holiday Tales
description: New picture books include When Santa Was a Baby and Miracle on 133rd Street.

title: From Jordan to Hummus, Looking Back at Ben Carsons Tough Week
description: Ben Carson is taking a break from the campaign trail on Friday, which he may need after a particularly rough week that saw him stumbling in polls amid questions about his command of foreign policy.

title: Popcast: Sophie and Grimes
description: Ben Ratliff and Jon Pareles discuss their approaches to music.

title: A Meal-Delivery App Claims Turf in Seamlesss Own Backyard
description: When Seamless and GrubHub merged in May 2013, they formed a meal delivery juggernaut that seemed certain to dominate in New York City. But two years later, a new player has begun to compete, even outpacing Seamless, a New York native, in some of the citys neighborhoods.

title: Delhi to Limit Use of Cars in an Effort to Control Pollution
description: NEW DELHI  The notoriously polluted air in the Indian capital has become so bad that the local government is planning to limit the use of private cars to alternate days, among other measures.

title: College Football Games to Watch on Saturday
description: No. 5 Michigan State vs. No. 4 Iowa

title: Changing Strategies for Social Security
description: Some people near full retirement age can still increase the total amount they get from Social Security using provisions recently eliminated by Congress.

title: Lyric Opera Seeks to Reassure Patrons Over a Work that Mirrors the Terror Out There
description: It is not just television networks that have had to grapple since the Paris attacks with when and how to present scenes of terrorism, but the Lyric Opera of Chicago as well. Bel Canto, a much-anticipated opera that will have its world premiere there on Monday, opens with an unexpectedly resonant scene: a musical performance interrupted by gun-toting terrorists.

title: M. Roland Nachman, Lawyer in Times v. Sullivan Libel Case, Dies at 91
description: M. Roland Nachman, an Alabama lawyer who opposed The New York Times in a libel case that resulted in a landmark Supreme Court decision establishing greater leeway for newspapers and individuals to criticize government officials and other public figures, died on Nov. 24 at his home in Montgomery, Ala. He was 91.

title: Sara Hyltons Images Depict Little Pakistans Quiet Conflicts
description: Last summer, Sara Hylton, a Canadian photojournalist who splits her time between New York and New Delhi, came to Brooklyn in search of a way to tell the story of the boroughs Muslims, religious profiling and police surveillance.

title: New Yorks Little Pakistan
description: Sara Hylton sought to tell the stories of Little Pakistan, at the center of which is Midwood, Brooklyn.

title: Popcast: Grimes and Sophie Cut Across Subgenres
description: Listen to this weeks podcast | Subscribe: iTunes | RSS | Stitcher| Audioboom

title: Caregivers Sometimes Must Sacrifice Their Careers
description: Her supervisors empathized. They knew why Marcy Sherman-Lewis, a customer service agent, was missing workdays: Both her parents, who lived an hour away, had Alzheimers disease.

title: La Bonne Bire, Cafe Hit in Paris Attacks, Is Back in Business
description: PARIS  Jacqueline Bouley used to go regularly to La Bonne Bire, a sprawling cafe in Pariss 10th Arrondissement, to linger over a drink on the long terrace. Her routine came to an abrupt halt after the night of Nov. 13, when Islamic State gunmen drove up and massacred five people in a hail of gunfire before continuing their deadly assault around town.

title: University Negotiates to Return Pissarro to Jewish Family
description: After fighting for years, the University of Oklahoma is now negotiating the terms under which it will return a Pissarro painting to a Jewish family whose relatives had their artworks looted by the Nazis.

title: China Creates a World Bank of Its Own, and the U.S. Balks
description: BEIJING  As top leaders met at a lush Bali resort in October 2013, President Xi Jinping of China described his vision for a new multinational, multibillion-dollar bank to finance roads, rails and power grids across Asia. Under Chinese stewardship, the bank would tackle the slow development in poor countries that was holding the region back from becoming the wealth center of the world.

title: Learning From Ebola: Was Quarantine Too Extreme a Response?
description: Sometimes journalists take a hard look at questions that survive after an immediate crisis has passed. In that spirit, my most recent article for The Times was about Ebola  yes, Ebola, last years frightful threat.

title: Big City Book Club
description: The Big City Book Club is seeking the wisdom of readers to help select a book for our meeting in early January. What is the best New York-centric book you read in 2015?

title: My 10 Favorite Books: Michael Pollan
description: For his bookshop installation, One Grand, the editor Aaron Hicklin asked people to name the 10 books theyd take with them if they were marooned on a desert island. The next in the series is Michael Pollan, author of many titles including The Omnivores Dilemma and In Defense of Food. He shares his picks exclusively with T.

title: Worlds Converge in Deadly Crash on New Jersey Highway
description: In one vehicle there were 13 immigrant workers, men and women commuting home in a van after a long Saturday shift at a Chinese restaurant. In another was a young data analyst heading home after mentoring a teenager. And in another, two farmers hauling a truckload of Kentucky cattle back to Maine.

title: Restoring a Connecticut Farmhouse
description: For 22 years, Suni Munshani, a technology entrepreneur who lives in Easton, Conn., with his wife, Tina, and daughter, Saira, dreamed of owning a country home. He had in mind a particular place, set on 10 rolling acres with farm buildings, paddocks and a pair of Asian katsura trees that gave off the odor of caramelized sugar in the fall.

title: On Location | Easton, Conn
description: Suni Munshani, a technology entrepreneur, restores a farm and renovates a 1935 house.

title: The Economy Doesnt Need Higher Interest Rates
description: An interest rate increase this month may be the only way for Janet Yellen, the chairwoman of the Federal Reserve, to quiet the increasingly insistentcalls for a rate hike by some Fed policymakers.

title: Inquiry Into Paris Terror Attacks Widens to Eastern Europe
description: BRUSSELS  The investigation into the Paris terrorist attacks, previously focused on jihadist networks in France and Belgium, has widened to Eastern Europe, with a Belgian federal prosecutor announcing Friday that one of the people suspected of terrorism traveled in September by car to Hungary, where he picked up two men now believed to have links to the carnage of Nov. 13.

title: The Arithmetic of Compassion
description: WE all can relate to the saying One death is a tragedy; a million deaths is a statistic. Our sympathy for suffering and loss declines precipitously when we are presented with increasing numbers of victims. In the 1950s, the psychiatrist Robert Jay Lifton studied survivors of the atomic bombs dropped on Hiroshima and Nagasaki and discovered that a condition he labeled psychic numbing enabled them to withstand the psychological trauma of this experience.

title: A Film About Anthony Weiner Is Coming Out Next Month
description: The saga of Anthony D. Weiner has been out of the headlines for a while, but it will be on the silver screen in January, just in time for the Iowa caucuses.

title: Shaking Up the Banking Establishment
description: The World Bank, I.M.F. and Asian Development Bank compared.

title: Tenant Set Fatal Brooklyn Explosion, Official Says
description: An explosion that killed two women and leveled a building in Brooklyn in October was intentionally set by one of them using gasoline that had been poured on the stairwell, a New York City official said on Friday.

title: Saudi-Led Coalition to Investigate Bombing of Clinic in Yemen
description: CAIRO  A military coalition led by Saudi Arabia said Friday that it would form a fact-finding committee to investigate allegations that coalition warplanes had bombed a clinic in Yemen operated by Doctors Without Borders earlier in the week, injuring nine people, according to a statement carried by the official Saudi Press Agency.

title: Louis Stettner and the Glories of Penn Station
description: Images of New Yorks grand  and long-gone  Penn Station recall an era when the daily commute was more akin to passing through an art museum.

title: Inside The New York Times Book Review: The Years Best Books
description: Listen to this weeks podcast | Subscribe: iTunes | Stitcher

title: Fresh, Simple Looks for an Ingnue
description: Brie Larsons fashion choices.

title: Brie Larsons Gowns, From Calvin Klein to Wes Gordon
description: At 26, Brie Larson is already a veteran of the independent film circuit. But shes still an ingnue on the red carpet.

title: Art Basels Chicest, Most Colorful Getups
description: At the annual fair, the characters navigating the booths are often as eye-catching as the artworks inside them.

title: Top Jeb Bush Donor Plans Full-Page Ads Against Donald Trump
description: Its a case of the billionaire versus the BULLYionaire.

title: Not Even Catharsis Is Seen in Senate Vote to Repeal Health Law
description: WASHINGTON  Senate Republicans have finally fulfilled their long quest to pass legislation repealing President Obamas landmark health care law, and Congress will soon send the measure to the White House, where it might have a chance of being folded into origami or a fleet of paper airplanes, but no possibility of being signed into law.

title: Scott Weiland, a Symbolic Voice of the Shifting 90s Rock Scene
description: Scott Weiland, who died in his sleep Thursday night on tour in Minnesota, was a rock singer precisely of his time, the early 1990s: a vulnerable peacock with a fraught, hyper-masculine baritone, self-destructive but confident.

title: Getting BuzzFeed Clicks by Drinking and Whining
Review: Stars Pay Tribute to Frank Sinatra
description: Everything that was good and bad about Lincoln Centers underwhelming fund-raising gala timed to Frank Sinatras centennial, Sinatra: Voice for a Century at David Geffen Hall on Thursday, converged late in the evening in a moment of disturbing clarity. As the mighty New York Philharmonic orchestra, conducted by Alan Gilbert, played the funereal opening chords from Nelson Riddles original arrangement of Whats New? from the 1958 album, Frank Sinatra Sings for Only the Lonely, an emotional chasm opened up.

title: Pictures of the Day: Syria and Elsewhere
description: Syria and More  Pictures of the Day

title: Dec. 4, 2015  Pictures of the Day
description: Photos from Syria, Greece, England and Nicaragua.

title: Your Friday Evening Briefing: San Bernardino, OPEC, Scott Weiland
description: (Want to get this briefing by email? Heres the sign-up.)

title: The Lowrider Car Scene Finds a Home
description: Thanks to social media, the subculture has taken root in Tokyo, So Paulo and Jakarta, among other places.

title: Your Evening Briefing
description: Heres what you need to know at the end of the day.

title: Wally Lambs Latest Novel to Be Released Exclusively as Book App
description: In 1992, two debut novelists gave a joint reading at a Manhattan bookstore. One of them was Ken Siman, whose novel, Pizza Face, sold decently, but was hardly a blockbuster. He eventually went on to pursue a career in publishing.

title: Lowriding Culture Goes Global
description: In the Southern California lowrider scene, there are some clashes as to which country has adopted the Mexican-American culture with the most swag.

title: Undersea Treasure Hunt
description: To the Editor:

title: Senator Dick Durbin, on Sentencing Reform
State Retirement Plans
description: To the Editor:

title: The Paris Talks and the Scale of the Climate Challenge
description: To the Editor:

title: Smooth Visa Process for Woman in Attack Is Focus of Inquiry
description: The woman involved in the shootings in San Bernardino, Calif., on Wednesday passed through two rounds of criminal and national security background checks as she obtained a fianc visa and later a resident green card to live in the United States, federal officials said.

title: Gad Elmaleh: Talking Funny in French and English
description: As stand-up comedy becomes an increasingly global phenomenon, international stars are starting to emerge, like the South African Trevor Noah, who played to huge audiences in Africa before taking over The Daily Show. Now Gad Elmaleh, a Moroccan-born stand-up comedian often called the Jerry Seinfeld of France, is hoping for crossover success here as well. Hes embarking on his first significant run of shows in English beginning Sunday at Joes Pub, part of a national tour and later New York residency.

title: Review: The Paris Opera Ballet, Under New Management
description: PARIS  The new triple bill of ballets at the Paris Opera  named, after its choreographic auteurs, Christopher Wheeldon, Wayne McGregor, Pina Bausch  demands three thoroughly unalike styles from its dancers. Yet the companys dancing in each is a tremendous pleasure: three-dimensional in texture, keen in dynamics and, most welcome of all, proceeding through long, multifaceted phrases.

title: Evening Hours | Bright Nights
description: A festive benefit, a street festival and more.

title: Launch of Cargo Rocket to Space Station Is Postponed
description: A rocket packed with 7,700 pounds of cargo destined for the International Space Station remained on the ground Friday after bad weather again halted the countdown.

title: Its Turner Time, When British Artists Win Cash and a Skewering
description: GLASGOW  The voices of three singers dressed in black slide from impossibly high notes down to gruff growls. Nearby is a reading room stocked with books, papers, magazines and television monitors broadcasting interviews with people discussing alien abduction and conspiracy theories. In yet another room, fur coats are stitched into the backs of chairs. Elsewhere, a small house has been assembled and filled with furniture, doorknobs, sinks and lampshades, all for sale.

title: Samsung to Pay Apple $548 Million in Patent Dispute
description: Samsung agreed to pay Apple $548 million to settle a smartphone patent dispute, but the payment wont put an end to the long-running legal battles between the two companies.

title: Review: Kissin and Friends at Carnegie Hall
description: Carnegie Halls Perspectives series give major artists the chance to show audiences the breadth of their musical lives. This season, the pianist Evgeny Kissins series is happily varied  most interesting, an evening of Yiddish poetry and piano works by Jewish composers, coming later this month. A few weeks ago, he again proved his solo credentials with a rare repeated recital, and theres Rachmaninoff to come with the Metropolitan Opera Orchestra in the spring.

title: What Were Reading
description: Get recommendations from New York Times reporters and editors, highlighting great stories from around the web. What Were Reading emails are sent twice a week. Sign up

title: No More Thoughts and Prayers
description: We never had enough time to rationalize, in the uniquely American way, why that middle-aged white man killed a cop, a mother of two and an Iraq war veteran in Colorado Springs, when the latest slaughter of human life intruded. He was  what, pro-life? Screaming something about baby parts while he unloaded in a Planned Parenthood clinic?

title: Review: Gigantic Takes On a Ton of Teenage Angst
description: There are no fat suits in Gigantic, the new musical set at a weight-loss camp for bulky teenagers. For its characters, the end of the summer will bring no magical transformation from round to svelte.

title: Review: Riverside Symphony Offers Nostalgia and Tibetan Tones
description: The Riverside Symphony, founded in 1981 by George Rothman and Anthony Korf, has built a solid reputation for varied, sometimes challenging programs. So Time Travel, its season-opening concert on Wednesday evening at Merkin Concert Hall, proved something of a disappointment from the start.

title: Draghi Says No Limits on European Stimulus Measures
description: In a speech to Wall Street investors, the president of the European Central Bank, Mario Draghi, reinforced his promise to do all in his power to push Europes stagnating economy toward a full recovery.

title: Review: Pavel Zustiaks Custodians of Beauty
description: The door to the theater at New York Live Arts was within arms reach, but we were taken on a detour, directed to walk down a staircase, which veered into a pitch-black corridor. In an instant, the quotidian was washed away, replaced by a strange, uncomfortable feeling: displacement.

title: Review: In Badolos Yimbgr, Men Jesting and Ranting
description: In the program note to his new dance, Yimbgr, the choreographer Souleymane Badolo tells a story about taking French friends to a funeral in his native country, Burkina Faso. When they think they see dancing, he tells them it is not the dancing they know but instead a codified language of movement that must be known to appreciate the messages within.

title: Lawmakers Near Deal on Billions in Tax Cuts
description: WASHINGTON  Republican and Democratic negotiators closed in Friday on a major package of tax cuts for businesses and individuals that could exceed $700 billion in forgone revenues over a decade, and planned to work through the weekend in hopes that Congress can approve it before quitting for the year.

title: Bill Cunningham | The Biker Jacket
description: The biker jacket has now replaced the tailored sports jacket. It seems to reflect  in its most rugged, sinister black  the mood of the world today. Even if the fashion world tries to lighten it up with a rainbow of colors, the black jacket remains the most popular, and the statement of autumn. Below, veterans in club-insignia-covered jackets.

title: U.S. Presses for U.N. Resolution to Fight ISIS Financing
description: WASHINGTON  The United States and Russia are negotiating a new resolution at the United Nations Security Council intended to strengthen international efforts to cut off revenues that  the Islamic State raises to govern territory and spread its ideology.

title: New Name for Roosevelt Hospital
description: The Mount Sinai Health System renamed the Manhattan hospital in November.

title: Mount Sinai Sheds Roosevelt Name as Hospital Moves On
description: Roosevelt. Love it or hate it, the name resonates in American history.

title: Facing Resistance in Texas, Syrian Refugees Find Temporary Sanctuary in New York
description: Though Texas has sued to keep Syrian refugees out, a dozen of them found temporary respite on Friday in New York City, where Mayor Bill de Blasio said he welcomed them with open arms to the city of immigrants.

title: Yahoo Board Is Quiet on Any Shake-Up Plans
description: SAN FRANCISCO  With a crucial deadline looming next week, Yahoo shareholders still do not know how  or if  the board plans to restructure the technology giant.

title: Giants Dealing With New Injuries
description: The Giants offensive lineup appears to be getting healthier, but defensively, the Giants lost two more starters to injury this week.

title: Melvin Williams, an Inspiration for The Wire, Dies at 73
description: Melvin Williams, whose exploits as a drug kingpin in Baltimore informed the plot and character details of the HBO series The Wire, and who, after emerging from prison, played a role on the show, died on Thursday in Baltimore. He was 73.

title: Justin Trudeau Outlines Sweeping Agenda for Canada
description: OTTAWA  Getting down to work after a whirlwind global tour, Justin Trudeau, Canadas new Liberal prime minister, presented Parliament with a sweeping legislative agenda on Friday.

title: A Victory for Women at War
description: THE announcement this week by Secretary of Defense Ashton B. Carter that all combat roles in the United States military would officially be open to women is, without question, a victory. News of the decision was a thrill for me and thousands of other women who have served and continue to serve over the past 14 years in support roles in Iraq and Afghanistan, many of whom enthusiastically volunteered, as I did, for positions that put us in the middle of conflict.

title: Chipotle Stock Tumbles After E. Coli Outbreak
description: Chipotle Mexican Grills stock took a hit on Friday, falling about 8 percent in after-hours trading, when the company rescinded its 2016 forecast after an E. coli outbreak that has sickened dozens of people across the United States.

title: New Officers Add to Hope for Reform at Rikers Island
description: Why would someone want to work at Rikers Island?

title: G.M. Will Import Buicks Made in China to the U.S.
description: DETROIT  General Motors said on Friday that it would sell its first Chinese-made vehicle in the United States next year in an effort to expand the product lineup of its struggling Buick brand.

title: Cuba and U.S. to Discuss Settling Claims on Property
description: MIAMI  Representatives of Cuba and the United States will meet on Tuesday in Havana to begin negotiations on settling decades-old outstanding property claims for the thousands of American citizens and companies whose assets were confiscated after Cubas revolution, according to several people briefed on the coming talks.

title: A Defense of Sugary Soda That Fizzled for Coke
description: The Coca-Cola Company has finally been shamed into backing away from a research program that sought to deflect attention from the role of sugary soft drinks in the nations obesity crisis.

title: Venezuelas Economic Woes Buoy Opposition Before Election
description: CARACAS, Venezuela  On a sunny afternoon, Jorge Milln, an opposition candidate for congress, walked through the narrow streets of a lower-middle-class neighborhood, pressing the flesh in what was once a no mans land for people like him.

title: Robert Loggia, Rugged but Versatile Character Actor, Dies at 85
description: Robert Loggia, an Oscar-nominated actor who had a durable career in television and movies, notably in Brian De Palmas gangster film Scarface and Penny Marshalls comedy Big, died on Friday at his home in Los Angeles. He was 85.

title: Muslims in America Condemn Extremists and Fear Anew for Their Lives
description: Only hours after news broke that a suspect in a mass shooting in San Bernardino, Calif., had a Muslim name, the well-practiced organizations that represent American Muslims to the broader public kicked into action, as they routinely do after each terrorist attack attributed to Muslim extremists.

title: Gun Debate Yields Page One Editorial
description: The New York Times ran an editorial on its front page on Saturday, the first time the paper has done so since 1920, calling for greater regulation on guns in the aftermath of a spate of mass shootings.

title: Review: In Whale, Gallim Dance Takes On Love
description: Since 2007, when the ambitious young choreographer Andrea Miller founded her company, Gallim Dance, her work has often seemed desperate to grow up fast. The telltale signs were heavy borrowings from established choreographers and a general sense of struggling to appear mature. So it comes as a relief  and possibly even a sign of maturation  that her new piece, Whale, begins with young dancers behaving like young dancers.

title: End the Gun Epidemic in America
description: All decent people feel sorrow and righteous fury about the latest slaughter of innocents, in California. Law enforcement and intelligence agencies are searching for motivations, including the vital question of how the murderers might have been connected to international terrorism. That is right and proper.

title: The Senate Goes Gaga on Guns
description: Would it be absolutely cynical to say the Senate responded to what appears to be a terrorist mass shooting by declining to ban the sale of guns to people on the terrorist watch list?

title: Fed Might Not Have the Luxury of Slow and Steady Rate Increases
description: After seven years of keeping United States interest rates at rock bottom, the Federal Reserve has signaled that Dec. 16 could be D-Day for a long-awaited increase. That was the message Janet L. Yellen, chairwoman of the Federal Reserve, conveyed in two public presentations last week.

title: After San Bernardino Attack, Republican Candidates Talk War
description: The Republican candidates for president angrily demanded on Friday that the United States face up to a new world war, one that has breached its borders, threatened the safety of Americans and brought the menace of Islamic terrorism deep into the homeland.

title: In Net Neutrality Hearing, Judge Signals Comfort With F.C.C.s Defense
description: Reading the tea leaves from a court hearing is a dangerous endeavor. But standing out from a hearing on Friday over net neutrality regulations were comments from an influential judge who seemed to indicate more comfort with the Federal Communications Commissions legal defense of the rules.

title: A Mother Kept Her Cancer Secret, So Her Sons Focused on the Future
description: To conceal that she had breast cancer, Matilde Perez told her two sons that she was getting breast implants. She believed it would be more palatable to cast her operation as vanity-inspired than lifesaving.

title: Fear Ignorance, Not Muslims
description: As the country continues a long and dangerous campaign to root out and prevent terrorist threats, it is concerned but not helpless. Federal investigators are starting a terrorism investigation in the California mass shooting, and more facts will emerge about the background of the killers and their links to the Islamic State.

title: A Gift From Congress, to Congress
description: Congress is getting ready to give itself loads of extra campaign dollars again this holiday season.

title: The Knick Season 2, Episode 8: Victims All Around
description: Things got weird and morbid right away this week on The Knick. A patient on the addiction ward sneaked into the morgue, pulled a needle out of the neck of a corpse and chugged embalming fluid like a drunk inhaling Malibu rum in a dentists chair. He was the first victim in an episode that would see two deaths, a wife committed to an asylum, a wife abandoned and kicked out of her house and a father locked in silent paralysis.

title: Kristaps Porzingis Flourishes Again as Knicks Beat Nets
description: Forty years ago, Lionel Hollins was a rookie on the Portland Trail Blazers, a highly touted point guard out of Arizona State picked sixth in the 1975 draft.

title: Diamondbacks Are Said to Agree to Deal With Zack Greinke
description: The Arizona Diamondbacks improved by 15 games last season, to 79-83, but their progress was easy to miss. The Los Angeles Dodgers, with marquee talent and the games highest payroll, won the National League West. The San Francisco Giants, with three recent championships, finished second.

title: Step Forward for Two Suits Filed Against the N.C.A.A.
description: Two lawsuits filed for college athletes, one of which seeks to eliminate limitations on N.C.A.A. scholarships, cleared a hurdle Friday when a federal judge, Claudia Wilken, found that the suits, known as the Jenkins and Alston cases, could proceed as class actions.

title: At Donald Trump Rally in North Carolina, the Protesters Just Keep Coming
description: RALEIGH, N.C.  The calls for Security! rang out through the crowd near the podium 15 minutes before the event even began.

title: What to Watch Saturday
description: Saturday night, and on the couch? Live vicariously through Noah Baumbach and Greta Gerwigs Mistress America. Roll with Will Ferrell and Kevin Hart. Then fall asleep while gazing into Ryan Goslings eyes on S.N.L.

title: Corrections: December 5, 2015
description: FRONT PAGE

title: Quotation of the Day
description: Theres a number of pieces of evidence which has essentially pushed us off the cliff to say we are considering this an act of terrorism.

title: China Hits Another Box-Office High
description: BEIJING  Chinas film market, currently the worlds second-largest, shows no signs of slowing down.

title: Obama Calls for Stronger Gun Laws After California Shooting
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama edged closer Saturday to declaring the shooting in San Bernardino, Calif., that killed 14 people a terrorist attack, but stuck to his prescription that the answer to preventing such tragedies was gun limits.

title: Our (Bare) Shelves, Our Selves
description: When I was 13, in the early 1990s, I dug through my parents cache of vinyl records from the 60s and 70s. We still had a phonograph, so I played some of them, concentrating on the Beatles. Their bigger hits were inescapably familiar, but a number of their songs were new to me.

title: The Post-Binge-Watching Blues: A Malady of Our Times
description: Bathed in the light of my laptop, green in its glow, I finished another episode of Master of None, Aziz Ansaris Netflix comedy. It was after midnight, but not long after, and I reasoned that one more couldnt hurt; the screen was already inclining in that direction, offering helpfully to auto-start the next episode in the queue.

title: Small-Town Boy Makes Good, One Celebrity Hairdo at a Time
description: One day in 1955, when Maury Hopson was a teenager in dusty Fort Stockton, Tex., he stopped in at the beauty shop, where his mother was getting her hair done, and he overheard some ladies gossiping about Elizabeth Taylor, who happened to be in nearby Marfa, filming the George Stevens picture Giant. One of the beauty-parlor busybodies said she had visited the movie set, and she took special delight in relaying to the other women that she saw the actress wearing a dirty bra.

title: Pete Wentz Checks Out Art in Chelsea
description: On late Tuesday, Pete Wentz, bassist for the rock n roll punk band Fall Out Boy, was at the Mary Boone Gallery in Chelsea examining Two Napoleons Crossing the Alps, a 2015 painting by Peter Saul. Mr. Saul, 81, is a father of the Pop Art movement, and for the gallery show, he copied old masters in his familiar Day-Glo style.

title: Her Films May Flop, but Kate Hudson Remains a Fashion Star
description: Flanked by a pair of zealous escorts, Kate Hudson was trotted like a show horse onto a makeshift red carpet at the Standard High Line hotel in the meatpacking district.

title: Nigerias Comics Pull Punch Lines From Deeper Social Ills
description: LAGOS, Nigeria  The thieves were having a field day, the comedian Ali Baba exclaimed to a large auditorium of lawyers. It was so bad that they struck every car along a deeply potholed road  that is, until a former governor came along.

title: On Tether to Fossil Fuels, Nations Speak With Money
description: As representatives of nearly 200 countries gathered in Paris to discuss ways of reducing emissions from fossil fuels, many pointed to what they consider a simple and obvious way to change behavior: Stop widespread subsidies that encourage the use of fossil fuels.

title: The Week on Instagram
description: Photos posted this week on @nytimes took Instagram followers from San Bernardino, Calif., to Paris.

title: Saturday Morning Music
description: Whoops. I spent all day in a room full of serious men in dark suits, not one of whom had green hair, a man-bun, or a nose ring  which are all, to be clear, perfectly fine things in the right context  and forgot all about matters musical. So here, belatedly, is the right context:

title: Farhad and Mikes Week in Tech: Ride-Hailing Competition Heats Up
description: Each Saturday, Farhad Manjoo and Mike Isaac, technology reporters at The New York Times, review the weeks news, offering analysis and maybe a joke or two about the most important developments in the tech industry.

title: Cultural Corridor Proposed for Northern Berkshires
description: Thomas Krens, who once directed the Guggenheim Museum in New York and its overseas satellites, on Saturday joined with the former Massachusetts governors William Weld and Michael Dukakis to announce an ambitious plan to establish a cultural corridor between North Adams and Williamstown, Mass.

title: Holiday Bonuses for Building Staff
description: Ask Real Estate is a weekly column that answers questions from across the New York region. Submit yours to realestateqa@nytimes.com.

title: Venezuelas Economic Pain Gives Opposition a Lift
description: Venezuelans go to the polls on Sunday for elections that could change the political balance.

title: Guns and The Times: Other Voices
description: To the Editor:

title: Ted Cruz Vows to Kill the Terrorists in Ad Timed to Big Football Game
description: Senator Ted Cruz will begin airing a new ad in Iowa on Saturday in which he vows to kill the terrorists, the latest indication of how national security is emerging as the dominant issue in the Republican presidential race.

title: 1955: Rosa Parks Bus Legacy
description: Sixty years ago, on Dec. 1, 1955, Rosa Parks made history by refusing to sit in the segregated area of a bus in Montgomery, Ala. A few months later, Robert S. Bird, writing in The New York Herald Tribune, recalled how her arrest led to the Montgomery bus boycott:

title: Tar Heels Football Adopts a Winning Pattern (It Has Diamonds)
description: The North Carolina football team won 11 of 12 regular-season games and made it to the Atlantic Coast Conference championship game this year, all while wearing uniforms that include the argyle pattern made famous by the U.N.C. mens basketball team.

title: Martin Shkreli, the Bad Boy of Pharmaceuticals, Hits Back
description: Martin Shkreli was trying to explain himself, so he turned to YouTube.

title: In Scotland, Unlike America, Mass Shooting Led to Stricter Gun Laws
description: DUNBLANE, Scotland  It is a simple plaque for the 16 children gunned down that day in March 1996, set on a small, stone column outside the primary school that continues to educate this towns young. Built on a slope between trees and overgrown shrubs, it is easy to miss.

title: Variety Puzzle: Split Decisions
description: VARIETY PUZZLE  Boy, I tore through this one. Talk about a puzzle being in ones wheelhouse. Normally, I get bogged down in certain spots in a Split Decisions, but not today.

title: In FIFA Inquiry, Switzerland Aids U.S. but Is Wary of Being Eclipsed
description: BERN, Switzerland  As Swiss authorities again carried out the wishes of United States law enforcement early Thursday, arresting two global soccer officials in Zurich who had been indicted in Brooklyn federal court, American prosecutors praised Switzerland as a critical partner in the Justice Departments corruption case.

title: Cant Put Down Your Device? Thats by Design
description: Greg Hochmuth was one of the first software engineers hired at Instagram. He worked on a team in 2012 that developed the first Android app for the slick photo-sharing service. In its first 24 hours, the app was downloaded more than one million times.

title: How Donald Trump Talks
description: Mr. Trumps word choices differ markedly from those of Americas last five presidents, according to a review of his public utterances over the past week.

title: For Trump, We Are Good and They Are Bad
description: Donald J. Trump led cheering supporters through a landscape of foes that must beaten, sent away or discredited.

title: 95,000 Words, Many of Them Ominous, From Donald Trumps Tongue
description: Something bad is happening, Donald J. Trump warned New Hampshire voters Tuesday night, casting suspicions on Muslims and mosques. Something really dangerous is going on.

title: The G.O.P. Spectrum
description: To the Editor:

title: For San Bernardino Survivors, a Day of Screams and Chaos
description: SAN BERNARDINO, Calif.  The noise was deafening. The blast of gunshots. The piercing shriek of a fire alarm, and the torrent of water gushing from the sprinkler system, mixing with the blood on the floor.

title: In N.F.L., Never Have So Many Been So-So
description: Come one, come all to MetLife Stadium on Sunday. The C students. The 12-handicap golfers. The middle managers.

title: With Odell Beckham Jr. Playing Role of King, the Jets Try to Keep Him in Check
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  Week after week this season, players on teams preparing to face the Giants have braced themselves for a distinctive line of questioning from reporters. Compelled to appraise the Giants incandescent Odell Beckham Jr., opponents have responded with a mixture of genial regard, passive-aggressive reluctance or outward irritation.

title: All the Product Reviews Money Can Buy
description: The holiday online shopping season has begun, and that means reading lots of online product reviews. Some of these reviews are helpful, others are not. And many are fakes  raves or pans from people who have never actually used the product. Where do fake reviews come from? In this column, a close-up look at one notable source.

title: China Steps Up, but Its Currency Still Has Dues to Pay
description: The dollar lost a bit of its exalted status last week and the Chinese renminbi gained some luster. That was the straightforward meaning of an announcement in Washington by the International Monetary Fund, which decided to admit the renminbi to an exclusive group of elite currencies.

title: Your Weekend Briefing
description: Heres what you need to know about the weeks top stories.

title: Dont Change the Legal Rule on Intent
description: Congress is achingly close to passing broad, bipartisan legislation that would reform the federal criminal justice system. There is widespread agreement among liberals and conservatives that many parts of the system  particularly federal drug sentencing laws  are overly harsh and fall disproportionately on minorities.

title: The Unfair Treatment of Ebola Workers
description: American health care workers contributed enormously to the successful effort to stop the Ebola epidemic in West Africa that flared up in 2014, but they were treated horrendously when they came home. The reason: Irrational fears and politicians eager to show toughness in protecting constituents led to needless quarantines on doctors, nurses and other workers, even when they had no symptoms of the disease and no chance of infecting others.

title: Sundays Matchup: Jets at Giants
description: 1 p.m. Eastern, CBS

title: A Friendship That Comes With a Toll
description: Chinese trade and investment in Nigeria have made goods cheaper and spurred infrastructure projects, but the relationship has also exacted a cost.

title: In Nigeria, Chinese Investment Comes With a Downside
description: Emeka Ezelugha was excited to open a computer training center. He could teach his countrymen some skills and earn a living.

title: Liberalisms Gun Problem
Hysteria About Refugees, but Blindness on Guns
