Skelos, the former majority leader of the New York Senate, and his son were found guilty of federal corruption charges on Friday, a quick and devastating follow-up punch to the State Capitol, which has seen two entrenched leaders convicted and removed from office in less than two weeks.

title: Who Said Game of Thrones Wasnt for Kids?
description: Mom, can we talk about Game of Thrones? my 4-year-old daughter asks at the dinner table, looking up at me hopefully. My 6-year-old son nods vigorously.

title: Popcast: Joe Casey of Protomartyr
description: Listen to this weeks podcast | Subscribe: iTunes | RSS | Stitcher| Audioboom

title: Giving Directions? Start With a Landmark
description: There are many ways to give directions, but some formats are more effective than others, according to a new study.

title: How Hope Boykin, Alvin Ailey Dancer, Spends Her Sundays
description: Hope Boykin, who recently completed her 15th anniversary with the Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater, has been called a force of nature on stage. Matthew Rushing, the companys rehearsal director and a choreographer, created a lead role for her in his dance Odetta, a tribute to the singer and civil rights activist. Ms. Boykin, 43, who lives in Harlem, teaches, choreographs and continues to coach rising dancers. On Sundays, when she isnt dancing (Ailey is currently performing at City Center through Jan. 3), Ms. Boykin lowers the volume, making church the main event. Though it is rare for dancers to perform into their 40s, Ms. Boykin said, Were not dancing late, were dancing just right.

title: What If We Could Redesign Our DNA?
description: How would people redesign their bodies, if they could? The Brazilian illustrator Roger Mello has fancifully envisioned the results.

title: Facts & Figures: Most Oppose Barring Muslims from America
description: Nearly sixty percent of Americans oppose Donald Trumps plan to bar Muslims from entering the country, according to a CBS News poll. Sixty-seven percent believe such a ban goes against the founding principles of this country.

title: Memorable Sinatra Moments
description: Frank Sinatra was was born on Dec. 12, 1915. A hundred years on, the Voice resonates still.

title: San Bernardino Attackers Friend Spoke of Sleeper Cells Before Rampage
description: RIVERSIDE, Calif.  The regulars did not take it seriously when Enrique Marquez mused about terrorism at Morgans Tavern, a dank dive bar where Mr. Marquez hauled ice, cleaned bathrooms and checked IDs at the door. After a few drinks, he would just start talking  about his money woes, trying to lose weight, wanting to join the Navy. News reports about terrorism were just fodder for more bar talk.

title: Why Brussels Is the New Berlin
description: For decades, Europes buttoned-up political center had a reputation for stodginess and chilliness. No longer: Brussels has quietly emerged as one of the continents most exciting creative hubs.

title: A Decade of Kickflips and Ollies
description: Images from the book T.F. at 1: Ten Years of Quartersnacks, which examines the vibrant culture of skateboarding in New York.

title: A Downtown Skateboard Blog Turns 10
description: One Friday last month, a few dozen skateboarders had gathered at the baseball diamond at Tompkins Square Park in the East Village, an area known to local skaters as the T.F. (short for training facility).

title: Fantasy Football Week 14: Rankings and Matchup Analysis
description: Fantasy football analysis for N.F.L. Week 14 games, including Mondays matchup between the Miami Dolphins and the Giants. You can also follow the Sablich brothers on Twitter at @5thDownFantasy and see their complete Week 14 player rankings.

title: In Mark Rothko: From the Inside Out, a Son Writes About His Father
description: Christopher Rothko doesnt look much like his father, the painter Mark Rothko, who took his own life when his son was 6. The father was rotund and jowly, with a high bald pate and a world-weary demeanor (at least in the best-known portraits.) The son, now 52, is lean and reedy, with a head of just-graying hair and a ready smile.

title: With Its Focus on Air Travel, U.S. Leaves Trains Vulnerable to Attack, Experts Say
description: WASHINGTON  The day before Thanksgiving, with the country on high alert for terrorist threats, dozens of armed guards from the Department of Homeland Security and local law enforcement patrolled Union Station here as hundreds of passengers emerged from commuter and Amtrak trains.

title: A Holiday Wish List (as in I Wish I Never Got This)
description: Its holiday time, but you dont want to give your loved ones the same old boring sweaters or fruitcake everyone else is offloading. Heres your guide to gifts that will stand out:

title: Stan Fischler, Hockey Maven, at Home
description: Nearly a decade ago, when Stan Fischler and his wife, Shirley, determined that market conditions were ripe for selling their condo on West 110th Street, they were sure of two things: They wanted to rent and they wanted to stay in the neighborhood. After winnowing the field, they carefully considered the merits of the finalists, a two-bedroom apartment right around the corner on West 109th and a two-bedroom on 86th and Central Park West.

title: Books About New Yorks Restrictive Grid, and Mutable Castes
description: Rem Koolhaas applauded the two-dimensional discipline that allowed for undreamed of freedom for three-dimensional anarchy. Henry James hated it as a primal topographic curse. Gerard Koeppel also approaches Manhattans transformation into the City of Angles skeptically in his prodigiously researched City on a Grid: How New York Became New York (Da Capo Press).

title: Democrats Revoke Debate Sponsorship of WMUR, New Hampshire TV Station
description: The Democratic National Committee has revoked the sponsorship of WMUR, New Hampshires most influential television station, of the partys presidential debate next week because of a labor dispute involving the station.

title: What I Love | Stan Fischler
description: Stan Fischler, the hockey expert for MSG Networks, lives in a two-bedroom rental on the Upper West Side.

title: A Fragrant Shrub That Smells Like Winter
description: For those who enjoy hiking shoreline trails, bayberry is as familiar and comfortable as a favorite hat. It is a touchstone species, a plant with an unpretentious beauty you can count on seeing along a favorite trail. Bayberry is also delightfully fragrant, but only up close. You cant find bayberry by following the fragrance to its source as you might a rose, wild grapes or even witch hazel. You must crush one of its berries in your fingers or rub one of its leaves under your nose to appreciate its peppery scent. Set against the cold, salty air of the Atlantic coast, it is nature at its most intimate and memorable.

title: Burundi Military Sites Raided by Gunmen, Renewing Fears of Chaos
description: KAMPALA, Uganda  Coordinated attacks by gunmen struck Burundis capital before dawn on Friday, the most significant act of violence since a failed coup attempt in May, causing stores to shutter and jittery residents to bolt themselves indoors even as the government sought to assure the incredulous population that daily life was continuing as normal.

title: Holographic Studios and Kalustyans Cafe in Kips Bay
description: Kips Bay, north of Gramercy Park in Manhattan, was named for an early Dutch farmer, Jacob Kip, and an East River inlet now masked by landfill. Bellevue is its anchor, the oldest continuously operating hospital in the United States, which happens to be two blocks from what is thought to be the oldest continuous gallery of holography in the world, Holographic Studios.

title: National Front Faces Tougher Climb to Victory in France
description: PARIS  After a week in which she and her far-right National Front party seemed ascendant, Marine Le Pen is heading into Sundays second round of French regional elections facing a new and more challenging political equation that will test the appeal of her nationalist, anti-immigrant message.

title: Spain Arrests Terrorism Suspect in Plot Against Swedish Artist
description: MADRID  Spain on Friday announced the arrest of a suspect wanted by the United States in connection with terrorism activities, including a failed attempt to kill a Swedish cartoonist who had depicted the Prophet Muhammad with a dogs body.

title: Plum Islands Pink House Inspires a Real Estate Fantasy
description: Several years ago, I called a real estate agent in my hometown, Newburyport, Mass., with (as one tends to bring to agents) a fantasy. I wanted to buy the Pink House.

title: How Do You Talk to Your Children About Being Muslim?
description: It is not an easy time in the United States, or in much of the world, to be Muslim. There are organizations like the Islamic State and Al Qaeda that are committing horrendous acts of terrorism in the name of Islam. At the same time, there are right-wing and nationalist politicians who are scapegoating all Muslims and playing on public fears and anxiety. Donald J. Trump in the United States and Marine Le Pen in France are lashing out at Muslim immigrants and calling them a threat to public safety and cultural identity.

title: Frank Sinatra: A Hundred Years On, the Voice Resonates Still
description: Frank Sinatra gave pop music a beating heart.

title: Protesters Ejected From Donald Trump Event in Manhattan
description: Protesters angry at Donald J. Trumps call to ban foreign Muslims from entering the United States disrupted his appearance on Friday in midtown Manhattan, and security guards forcibly ejected several of the demonstrators.

title: Review: Saltaire Oyster Bar in Port Chester Offers the Unexpected
description: Port Chesters beautiful old granary warehouse, last occupied by the Willett House restaurant, has been repurposed once again, this time into Saltaire Oyster Bar and Fish House, a stylish, bustling restaurant and bar. The dcor is uncluttered and smart, with nautical maps on one wall and heavy loading ropes with serious hooks filling in a corner or two, all leaving room for the luxury of well-spaced tables.

title: Knicks Porzingis Nails the Charm but Aims for Consistency
description: SACRAMENTO  Minutes before the Knicks and the Kings tipped off Thursday night, Vlade Divac, joking with reporters, said that he had some advice for Kristaps Porzingis, the Knicks rookie big man from Latvia.

title: Murder Charges Filed Against Previously Imprisoned Russian Oligarch
description: MOSCOW  Russian investigators filed new criminal charges on Friday against Mikhail B. Khodorkovsky, the onetime oil oligarch, critic of President Vladimir V. Putin and former prisoner who lives in exile.

title: Review: At South End Uncorked, Clever Dishes in a Casual Setting
description: During a recent dinner at South End Uncorked, which opened in July in downtown New Canaan, the volume seemed to be set at 11, making me feel as though I had to shout to be heard.

title: Trumpism After Trump
description: On Monday, Donald Trump stood aboard the U.S.S. Yorktown before a sprawling crowd. Earlier in the day, he had introduced a proposal that, in a candidacy notable for its bombast, was his most bombastic yet: a total and complete shutdown of Muslims entering the United States. The reaction in the media was instantaneous, enormous  the eyes of the world were on Trump. And yet the man, that night, struck me as far less important than the roar of the crowd that greeted him.

title: Review: Indian Kitchen in Allendale Leaves the Butter Behind
description: The dal was the first hint that Nirvana Indian Kitchen wasnt your typical generic curry joint. Fragrant with ginger and cilantro, the soupy yellow lentil stew with peas and bits of diced okra was a recipe from Indias Gujarat region, where my husband Mahir is from. After a few skeptical spoonfuls, he declared it to be as good as his mothers.

title: Sexy Fish Caters to Londons Stateless Super-Rich
description: LONDON  It is like being punched in the face by Abu Dhabi, said a reviewer from The Spectator, the weekly journal of the old British establishment.

title: Share Their Stories
description: As part of the magazines annual Lives They Lived issue, we invite you to contribute a photograph and a story of someone close to you who died this year.

title: Pictures of the Day: Gaza City and Elsewhere
description: Gaza City and More  Pictures of the Day

title: Fearing a Missions Betrayal as Union Theological Seminary Plans to Sell Its Air Rights
description: For nearly two centuries, Union Theological Seminary has brought together scholarship and faith on behalf of social justice. But recently the religious institution has found itself pursuing a more earthly occupation: trying to navigate New York Citys brutal real estate market without doing damage to its soul.

title: Dec. 11, 2015  Pictures of the Day
description: Photos from Gaza City, Turkey, Afghanistan and the United States.

title: Wrangling Appears to Give Way to a Deal in Paris Climate Talks
description: Agence France-Presse is reporting that a deal has been struck on final text for a climate agreement after two weeks of talks, with the draft to be presented to ministers late morning on Saturday. Sometimes, such early reports can fizzle, so stay tuned.

title: Long Island Sports Bars Get a Menu Upgrade
description: On any given Sunday at Brixx & Barley, a pub in Long Beach that has been open for almost two years, every N.F.L. game is carried live on one of 27 televisions. But the 80-inch screen presiding over the bar is reserved for New York teams.

title: Give It Up for Pluto
description: IN science, as in other realms, the great and the mighty command our attention and dominate the headlines. See, for example, the recent discoveries of Dreadnoughtus schrani (the biggest dinosaur) and EGS-zs8-1 (the farthest galaxy). But this year, as NASAs New Horizons spacecraft sped through the outskirts of the solar system, a cherished underdog stole the show: the dwarf planet Pluto.

title: Artificial-Intelligence Research Center Is Founded by Silicon Valley Investors
description: A group of prominent Silicon Valley investors and technology companies said on Friday that they would establish an artificial-intelligence research center to develop digital intelligence that will benefit humanity.

title: Finding Refuge for Salmon, Cold Water Preferred
description: PORTLAND, Ore.  When Lewis and Clark first encountered the Columbia River in 1805, they wrote about nearby streams so thick with salmon that you could all but walk across on their backs.

title: One-Thing Shops: Indie Magazines, London
description: Yesterday afternoon, Jeremy Leslie sat at a makeshift table behind rows of empty shelves, trying to get the music started. Apart from putting the mags out, he said, staring halfway between a laptop and a portable speaker, this is probably the best job. Leslie was in Londons Clerkenwell neighborhood to prepare for the unveiling of his new shop, a brick-and-mortar extension of magCulture.com, the magazine review site hes been running since 2006.

title: What Were Reading
description: Get recommendations from New York Times reporters and editors, highlighting great stories from around the web. What Were Reading emails are sent twice a week. Sign up

title: The Woman Who Dresses Hollywoods Leading Men
description: The stylist Ashley Weston moved quickly around the eighth-floor suite of the London West Hollywood hotel the other day, pinning and tucking the folds of an eggplant-colored Zegna suit.

title: World on Fire: Unquiet Art After 1965 at Purchase
description: Six oversize panels of Robert Rauschenbergs 1970 Currents series, which hang in a gallery in the Neuberger Museum of Art in Purchase, capture the volatility of an era.

title: Jeremy Scott Adds Fashion Sparkle to Baby Strollers
description: On a brisk night in Milan last month, the chic concept store 10 Corso Como was packed with Italian fashion journalists and socialites young and old.

title: After Skelos and Silver, How to Save Albany
description: Albany  AFTER just a day of deliberation, a jury found former State Senate majority leader Dean G. Skelos and his son guilty on Friday of federal corruption charges. The decision came less than two weeks after another jury handed down a similar verdict against former Assembly Speaker Sheldon Silver.

title: Viola Davis and Edie Falco Talk Race, Sex and Life Before Stardom
description: It takes 20 years to make an overnight success, as Eddie Cantor, the old vaudevillian, put it. And judging by the acclaimed careers of Viola Davis and Edie Falco, he wasnt far off. Interestingly, neither of the actresses would have had it any other way.

title: Street Life at the Heckscher Museum of Art
description: A few years ago, a painting of a young man hurtling toward a subway car with an Olympians athleticism caught the eye of Lisa Chalif, the curator of the Heckscher Museum of Art in Huntington. The painting, a 1987 oil on canvas by Don Perlis called Leaper, had been donated to the museum in 2002 but had never been put on display, she said, at least not in the 10 years she has been with the museum.

title: The Global Face of Student Protest
description: Johannesburg  NOT long after I moved from the United States to South Africa six years ago, I took a walk in a city called Bloemfontein. The scale of the downtown is huge, reflecting the ambitions of South Africas white settlers. The avenues feel as wide as highways, the department stores soar. Statues of military leaders and politicians from South Africas white-ruled past keep watch over the street corners.

title: Review: Measure for Measure, a Comedy of Contradictions
description: The six-singer a cappella harmony that opens Fiasco Theaters Measure for Measure, now at the Long Wharf Theater in New Haven, is a prayerful and fitting opening to this Shakespeare play. Its elegant as a whole but complicated as all get-out under the surface.

title: Creating a Constellation of Stars in Virtual Reality
description: Earlier this year, The New York Times Magazine followed three displaced children in a documentary-style virtual reality experience. For our next major foray into VR, we wanted to push to the other end of the spectrum and see if we could create something fictional. It seemed a natural fit to fold these efforts into our annual Great Performers portfolio, which celebrates the best performers of the year in photo, video and for the first time, virtual reality.

title: Too Cool for School: Class Pictures Turn Into Photo Shoots
description: The school photo is getting a modern makeover in New York, just in time to mail the grandparents their yearly glossies.

title: Egypt Is Intensifying Its Crackdown on Journalists, Rights Group Warns
description: CAIRO  The Egyptian government has intensified its crackdown against members of the news media in recent weeks, arresting one prominent journalist and preparing to bring another to trial, as the number of reporters detained in Egypt has hit its highest level in decades, according to human rights campaigners and press freedom groups.

title: Review: The Expanse, a Syfy Space Opera Laced With Parables
description: In its 23 years, the cable channel now known as Syfy has had exactly one series that became required viewing: Battlestar Galactica, which ended in 2009. In the six years since, while AMC, FX, HBO, Netflix and others have defined the parameters of peak TV, Syfys most recognizable show has probably been Ghost Hunters, the reality series about plumbers turned paranormal private eyes.

title: Paterson Joseph Brings Charles Ignatius Sancho to Life
description: He was an actor, a composer, a writer and a grocer. He was painted by Gainsborough and corresponded with the novelist Laurence Sterne. He was Charles Ignatius Sancho  black, born on a slave ship and believed to be, in 1774, the first black Briton to cast a vote.

title: Review: Childhoods End, a Syfy Adaptation of Arthur C. Clarkes Chilling Futurist Tale
description: Imagine theres no countries, John Lennon sang in that dreamy anthem that gets people all wistful about world peace. It isnt hard to do. Nothing to kill or die for, and no religion, too.

title: Review: The Robot Chicken Christmas Special: X-Mas United, on Adult Swim
description: Its possible that you will find yourself snared in a pit of sweet, sticky goo this weekend, because the television schedule is jammed with movie titles like A Dogwalkers Christmas Tale (Saturday on Up TV) and Wish Upon a Christmas (Sunday on Lifetime).

title: Evening Hours | Winter Spirit
description: Parties for animals, artisans, Sinatra and more.

title: Parable on Bigotry and Citizenship Plays Out in a Supermarket
description: NORTH BRUNSWICK, N.J.  In these days of controversy about Muslims in America, a time when the national attitude is being torn between compassion and condemnation, there is a real-life parable to be shared. You know it must be true because it took place at a supermarket in New Jersey, a place too prosaic to sustain any fantasy.

title: Your Evening Briefing
description: Heres what you need to know at the end of the day.

title: Your Friday Evening Briefing: Refugees, Dean Skelos, Frank Sinatra
description: (Want to get this briefing by email? Heres the sign-up.)

title: Review: Andrew Normans Split, a Teeming Premiere From the New York Philharmonic
description: Can the young American composer Andrew Norman keep this up? Im not just referring to the career roll hes been on: This week the recording of Mr. Normans breathless orchestral work Play was nominated for a Grammy Award in the contemporary classical composition category.

title: Review: Take Care, With Audience Participation for All
description: Anyone with inflamed performance-anxiety issues may want to think twice before attending Take Care, a willfully weird, highly interactive theater piece that uses a series of playful but ominous sketches and games to explore nervous-making aspects of the world today.

title: A More Trustworthy Santa, and a Citi Bike Rider Going Nowhere
description: Q. What protections, if any, have been put in place following the Operation Santa fraud at the James A. Farley Post Office on Eighth Avenue? Weve been participating for years, but are really considering other options as it is difficult to have confidence that our time, effort and money are reaching the children we are trying to bring a little holiday cheer to.

title: Qaddafis Son Hannibal Is Said to Be Abducted in Lebanon
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  The youngest son of Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi, the Libyan leader deposed and killed four years ago, was abducted in Lebanon and then handed over to security forces by militants seeking to avenge a prominent Lebanese Shiite cleric who disappeared in Libya in the 1970s, the state-run National News Agency said on Friday.

title: For Republicans, Contested 1976 Convention Looms Over 2016 Race
description: Donald J. Trumps dominance in the polls, combined with a cluster of second-place candidates looking to topple him, has Republicans thinking their convention next summer could be a nerve-racking get-together reminiscent of 1976.

title: A Columbia County Nest That Came Fully Feathered
description: A farmhouse tucked along the serpentine roads of Columbia County in upstate Ghent, Elizabeth and Michael Walterss dream home came with a sort of caveat: On the eastern edge of the property sat a dilapidated barn, loaded with years of detritus. The Walterses had no money for a down payment, so the owner agreed to sell on the condition that they would be the ones to empty the barn.

title: Cate Blanchett Struts Through Awards Season
description: An occasional Armani model, shes in Chanel one night, Yacine Aouadi the next.

title: Bill Cunningham | Pot of Gold
description: The streets and parks of New York are paved in gold  not coins, but ginkgo leaves. It has been the most fantastic prolonged autumn in years, and this week they were still sweeping the golden leaves from the trees around 19th-century Gramercy Park, where there are gas lanterns in front of The Players, the social club. Carriages in Central Park had golden ostrich plumes. Fashion reflected this magical autumn.

title: Women in Ukraine Walk a New Beat
description: In a country where gender equality is a distant dream, female police officers could be a first step toward changing attitudes.

title: Review: Jory Vinikour, Playing Bach on the Instrument for Which It Was Written
description: Only a few decades ago, purists argued that Bach should be played not on the modern piano, but on the harpsichord. But for listeners now accustomed to hearing this composers work rendered with the elaborate expressive capabilities of the modern piano, its predecessors sound can seem dry and monochromatic.

title: Review: Creating Contrasts With yMusic, Marcos Balter and Dance
description: New York Live Arts, as its longtime visitors know, has changed. Once a destination almost exclusively for dance  in a previous life, it was Dance Theater Workshop  it has opened its doors, under shifting leadership, to a wider range of disciplines and cross-disciplinary programs, for better and for worse.

title: Review: Im With Her, Three Americana Virtuosos
description: The harmonies couldnt have been purer, or the picking more precise, when the trio Im With Her  an alliance of Americana virtuosos  performed at the Bowery Ballroom on Thursday night.

title: Supreme Court to Review Laws Criminalizing Refusal of Body Substance Tests
description: WASHINGTON  The Supreme Court agreed on Friday to decide whether states can make it a crime for motorists suspected of drunken driving to refuse breath, blood or urine tests. Thirteen states have such laws.

title: Mobilizing Voters in New Yorks Housing Projects
description: Located in a stretch of Long Island City, in Queens, close to but psychologically distant from new glass apartment towers that offer rock-climbing walls and in certain instances call themselves clubs, the Queensbridge Houses make up the largest public housing project in the country. Built near the East River in the late 1930s, they contain 96 low-rise buildings and more than 7,000 people. Music critics have noted that, on a per-capita basis, Queensbridge  at various points home to Nas, Capone, Tragedy Khadafi, Marley Marl  is responsible for unleashing more hip-hop talent than any other location in the world.

title: The Flip Side of Mr. Trump's Appeal
description: A group gathered near the Trump International Hotel and Tower in Manhattan to protest the presidential candidates statements on Muslims.

title: Attack Spurs New Chapter in History of Dread in the U.S.
description: The handsome Washington townhouse where Wayne Hickory practices orthodontics is a landmark of terrorism in America.

title: Inside The New York Times Book Review: Recording Pride and Prejudice
description: Listen to this weeks podcast | Subscribe: iTunes | Stitcher

title: Ted Cruz Sees Boon to His Campaign in Donald Trump
description: Senator Ted Cruz has long cheered Donald J. Trumps presence in the Republican presidential field, thanking him for focusing national attention on issues like border security.

title: Martin Shkrelis Latest Plan to Sharply Raise Drug Price Prompts Outcry
description: Martin Shkreli is once again provoking alarm with a plan to sharply increase the price of a decades-old drug for a serious infectious disease. This time the drug treats Chagas disease, a parasitic infection that can cause potentially lethal heart problems.

title: Cubs Add Jason Heyward, and Optimism Is Multiplying
description: Jason Heyward hit a home run on his very first swing in the major leagues, in 2010, when he was 20 years old. Since that moment, it has been easy to project dreams onto him. Heyward can do it all  hit, run, field  yet he has somehow not made an All-Star team since his rookie season and has never come close to winning a Most Valuable Player Award.

title: Ohio: Objection to Disposal Practices at Planned Parenthood Clinics
description: An investigation into whether three Planned Parenthood clinics had improperly sold fetal tissue found that they had not, but said that they disposed of aborted fetuses improperly by turning them over to disposal companies that take the remains to landfills, the state attorney general, Mike DeWine, said Friday. Mr. DeWine said that sending aborted fetuses to a landfill was callous and completely inhumane and violated a state administrative code requirement that fetuses be disposed of in a humane manner. He referred his findings to the Ohio Department of Health, which oversees abortion clinics. Stephanie Kight, the president and chief executive of Planned Parenthood of Greater Ohio, issued a statement calling the accusations inflammatory and baseless. She said Planned Parenthood handles medical tissue like any other quality health care provider. Our agreements with vendors all require them to follow state law, and dispose of tissue accordingly. If they are not, then I will take swift action. Ms. Kight said she was concerned that the attorney generals report was not the result of meaningful investigation, but instead yet another attack on womens access to health care in the state of Ohio.

title: Minnesota: Man Is Accused of Making Death Threats to F.B.I. Agents
description: The federal authorities on Friday arrested a 19-year-old Minneapolis manwho they said threatened to kill F.B.I. agents after another Minnesota resident was charged with trying to join the Islamic State. The man, Khaalid A. Abdulkadir, was accused in court documents of posting on Twitter that he would kill them FEDS for take my brothers shortly after Abdirizak M. Warsame was arrested Wednesday. Mr. Warsame was charged with conspiring to provide material support to the Islamic State, making him the 10th person from the Minneapolis area to face federal charges of attempting to support the group. Mr. Abdulkadir, who federal agents said has contacted terrorism suspects on Twitter, is accused of impeding and retaliating against a federal law enforcement officer. The Minneapolis area, which has a large Somali population, has been a center of jihadist recruiting in America for years, with several young men from there leaving the country to join terrorist organizations abroad.

title: Best Sellers
description: All the lists: print, e-books, fiction, nonfiction, childrens books and more.

title: Cuba: Mail Flights From U.S. to Begin
description: The United States and Cuba have agreed to re-establish direct postal service, officials of both countries said Friday, the latest progress in President Obamas push to normalize relations with the island nation after more than a half-century of estrangement. The process will begin within weeks with the launch of a pilot program, which will facilitate mail flights between the two countries several times a week. Mail between the United States and Cuba currently must be routed through a third country, in line with the American embargo and a complex web of Treasury and Commerce Department sanctions that tightly restrict what kinds of materials may be sent, to whom, and under what circumstances. American and Cuban officials struck the agreement to begin allowing direct service on Thursday in Miami.

title: Wall Street Slips on Oils Big Drop
description: The fall in oil prices showed little sign of slowing as crude futures in New York continued their slide on Friday, falling for the sixth straight day and settling near a seven-year low.

title: What Italian Drone Pilots See as They Scan Iraq for Militants
description: At first glance, the aerial surveillance video of suspected Islamic State militants moving around Iraq released by the Italian Air Force seems familiar.

title: Judge Denies Bail for Ex-Suffolk County Police Chief: He Still Has the Power
description: CENTRAL ISLIP, N.Y.  A federal judge ordered the former police chief of Suffolk County held without bail on Friday, saying he had orchestrated such far-reaching corruption in the department that there was a risk he would continue meddling in the inquiry into his misconduct even after his arrest this week.

title: Draft of Climate Pact Is Ready, U.N. Officials Say
description: LE BOURGET, France  After almost two weeks of marathon negotiations, the lines for food and coffee on Friday night snaked through the temporary tent city here that has been home to the global climate talks. People made final bets in a five-euro pool on the precise hour the talks might conclude.

title: Decline in Stop-and-Frisk Tactic Drives Drop in Police Actions in New York, Study Says
description: The overall number of arrests, stops, moving violations and criminal summonses issued in New York City has fallen substantially over the past four years, according to a study released on Friday.

title: Defender Is Swiftly Waived by Giants
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  Giants defensive end Damontre Moore, who was drafted two years ago to rejuvenate the teams flagging pass rush but whose inconsistent play and erratic practice habits frustrated Giants coaches, was unexpectedly waived by the team.

title: A Junk Bond Fund Freezes Out Investors, and the Chills Spread
description: Two months ago, Thomas Lapointe, lead portfolio manager of the Third Avenue Management junk bond fund, delivered a bullish presentation at a conference at the Waldorf Astoria hotel.

title: Fewer Young People Are Drinking and Driving, Study Says
description: Far fewer young Americans are drinking and driving than they once did, according to a new survey, even as vehicle accidents remain their No. 1 killer.

title: Best-Seller Lists: Nov. 29, 2020
description: All the lists: print, e-books, fiction, nonfiction, childrens books and more.

title: Uber Is Said to Be Shaking Up Policy and Communications Team
description: Uber is cutting about 20 jobs in its policy and communications department, a move that insiders describe as an overhaul of those teams.

title: In Besieged Syrian City, a Pastry Chef Turned Activist Fears a Truce
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  A Syrian pastry chef turned antigovernment activist, Bebars al-Talawy, has spent nearly three years in besieged rebel enclaves, growing ever more gaunt, exasperated and sick of the one red jacket he has worn month after month.

title: Arson Is Suspected at a California Mosque
description: SAN BERNARDINO, Calif.  A fire that tore through part of a Southern California mosque just before a prayer service on Friday afternoon appears to have been arson, the authorities said.

title: Doris Matsui, Congresswoman Born in Internment Camp, Responds to Trump
description: WASHINGTON  Click on the About Doris button on the congressional website of Representative Doris Matsui, and you will learn that she grew up on a farm in Californias Central Valley. You will not learn that she was born in the Arizona desert, in a desolate internment camp where Japanese-Americans were imprisoned in former stables during World War II.

title: Charles S. Moffett, Curator Who Focused on Impressionists, Dies at 70
description: Charles S. Moffett, a curator who reframed scholarly understanding of the Impressionists and their era in exhibitions at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, the National Gallery and other major museums, died on Thursday at his home on Fishers Island, N.Y. He was 70.

title: John Williams, Versatile N.B.A. Player Known as Hot Rod, Dies at 53
description: John Williams, a versatile sixth man for the Cleveland Cavaliers who briefly earned more than Michael Jordan after renegotiating a contract during the summer of 1990, helping to establish the modern era of free agency and huge salaries, died on Friday in Baton Rouge, La. He was 53.

title: Special Education Provider in Brooklyn Improperly Billed State $2.6 Million, Audit Finds
description: A Brooklyn preschool special education provider, Starting Point Services for Children, improperly billed New York State for $2.6 million in expenses during recent fiscal years, according to an audit that the state comptroller released on Friday.

title: Should Labels Be Required on Genetically Modified Foods?
description: To the Editor:

title: Job Tester
description: SATURDAY PUZZLE  Remember when I said that it was totally worth it to push yourself and try the Saturday puzzles, even though you were convinced that they would be way too hard for you?

title: Battered and Blind, and Finding a Home in the Bronx
description: For Seana Cromitie, the surest sign of a new problem in a life full of them came in the place that had always been her sanctuary: the kitchen. There, in the Applebees restaurant in East Harlem where she worked, she would slice vegetables and miss, scarring her hands with small wound after small wound.

title: Why Are So Many Black Women Dying of AIDS?
description: THE injustices caused by racial profiling in law enforcement, and bias in criminal prosecution and sentencing, are now a subject of significant public attention. And they should be. The loss of life and liberty from these practices is shameful and tragic. But it is critical that we do not overlook the significant evidence showing that the end result of these practices  the mass incarceration of nonwhite men  may also be fueling an urgent public health crisis among some of the most disadvantaged members of our society.

title: Assemblyman Who Urged Reform Takes Job With Consulting Firm
description: In Albanys freshman class of reform-minded legislators, State Assemblyman Michael Blake, a charismatic Bronx Democrat, has been among the most vocal in calling for the cleanup of a capital known for corruption.

title: Bryony Brind Dies at 55; Nureyev Lifted Ballerinas Career
description: Bryony Brind, who at 22 startled audiences when Rudolf Nureyev plucked her from the ranks of junior Royal Ballet dancers to be his partner in a Covent Garden production in London, putting her on a path to become a principal dancer for the company, died on Dec. 2. She was 55.

title: Argentina Abandons Pact With Iran to Investigate 94 Attack at Jewish Center
description: BUENOS AIRES  Argentinas new government will not try to revive a voided pact with Iran to jointly investigate the 1994 bombing of a Jewish center here, Justice Minister Germn Garavano said Friday night.

title: Why Poland Is Turning Away From the West
description: Sofia, Bulgaria  DURING the recent electoral campaign in Poland, a constant question raised by pundits and politicians was not whether the country would go right, but whether it would go wrong.

title: Canadas Warm Embrace of Refugees
description: Many of the indelible images of the Middle East refugee crisis this year are haunting. There was the heart wrenching photo of Aylan Kurdi, a lifeless 3-year-old boy who drowned at sea and washed up ashore on a beach in Turkey in early September. A photographer in Greece captured the moment Laith Majid, an Iraqi refugee, walked off a deflating boat in Greece in tears, tightly clutching his son and daughter. And its hard to forget the spiteful Hungarian journalist who tripped a Syrian refugee carrying a child, making them stumble.

title: Ted Carpet-Bomb Cruz
description: This would have been an instructive Senate hearing for Ted Cruz to attend: U.S. Strategy to Counter the Islamic State of Iraq and the Levant and U.S. Policy Toward Iraq and Syria.

title: Gov. Cuomos Burden on Ethics
description: Two of the three most powerful political leaders in New York State are now convicted felons. This places an immediate burden on the third member of that club, Gov. Andrew Cuomo, to radically transform a political culture that has made the word Albany virtually synonymous with legislative self-dealing.

title: Cocaine and Alcohol Caused Death of Tommy Hanson
description: Tommy Hanson, a former major league pitcher, died from delayed complications of cocaine and alcohol toxicity, according to autopsy results released Friday.

title: The Knick Season 2, Episode 9: Origin Story
description: The Knick took a 2,000-mile detour at the beginning of this weeks episode, opening  disconcertingly  not on 1900s New York but on a somnolent jungle landscape that was soon identified as 1894 Nicaragua. There John Thackery, hired to stop a smallpox outbreak, first met the shipping magnate Capt. August Robertson, handcuffed to a post and accused of causing the outbreak.

title: Falling Bricks Cause Concern and Delays on the Upper East Side
description: Nick Alexopoulos jumped from his couch and dropped his Xbox controller when he heard the sound outside his Upper East Side apartment on Monday night.

title: Michael Cuddyer Calls It a Career, and the Mets Gain Some Flexibility
description: Michael Cuddyer, a respected veteran in the Mets clubhouse during the 2015 season but a disappointment on the field, has decided to retire with one year left on his contract. His decision, which was confirmed Friday by a person in baseball with knowledge of the situation, could allow the Mets some additional financial flexibility as they continue to put together their 2016 team.

title: Celtics Work Overtime, Twice, but the Warriors Go to 24-0
description: BOSTON  No team has pushed the Golden State Warriors this season the way the Boston Celtics did on Friday at TD Garden. The Celtics had a 5-point lead with two minutes left in regulation. They had chances to win the game at the end of regulation and the first overtime. They held leads in both overtimes.

title: What to Watch Saturday
description: Feeling rebellious? Stream Mad Max: Fury Road. Or turn on the tube as Mary Poppins produces a spoonful of sugar in the Disney classic, while Selena Gomez and Vanessa Hudgens leave their Disney pasts behind in Spring Breakers.

title: France Replies to Worlds 50 Best Restaurants List With 1,000 of Its Own
description: PARIS  The last thing the food universe seems to need these days is another restaurant guide.

title: Fighting in Kabuls Diplomatic Quarter Ends, Afghan Officials Say
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  The Talibans overnight siege of a guesthouse near the Spanish Embassy in the diplomatic quarter of Kabul ended on Saturday as the police killed the final attacker, officials said.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: Climate change is about ecosystems. Climate change negotiations are about ego-systems.

title: Corrections: December 12, 2015
description: NATIONAL

title: Debt and Demographic Debt Spirals
description: Im in Portugal  sorry, too jet-lagged to post music this week  where I am attending a conference in memory of Jose da Silva Lopes. (No, Im not doing interviews  Im spending my spare time with friends.) And I have been doing some homework about the terrible times Portugal has recently suffered. What especially caught my eye was this:

title: Nations Approve Landmark Climate Accord in Paris
description: LE BOURGET, France  With the sudden bang of a gavel Saturday night, representatives of 195 nations reached a landmark accord that will, for the first time, commit nearly every country to lowering planet-warming greenhouse gas emissions to help stave off the most drastic effects of climate change.

title: Hollywoods It Kid: A Blast of Fresh Air on the Oscar Trail
description: LOS ANGELES  Here is the impolite truth about a lot of child actors: They are unbearable little creatures. Theyve been media trained within an inch of their young lives. (Dimples and jazz hands, activate!) They usually come accompanied by narcissistic, fame-hungry parents. Their career role model is Miley Cyrus.

title: Text Me? Ping Me? Communications Overload in the Digital Age
description: There was a period last summer when my 25-year-old sister, Willa, decided to start communicating with me through comments on the rapper Drakes Instagram feed.

title: At 69, Charlotte Rampling Knows What You Look Amazing Really Means
description: Old age was the subject on many minds at a screening Dec. 3 for 45 Years, a movie starring the 60s It girl, Charlotte Rampling.

title: Dog Owners Wondering if Fido Needs a Flu Shot
description: Last spring, veterinarians in Chicago became overwhelmed by dogs with high fevers, hacking coughs, copiously dripping noses, runny eyes, lethargy and loss of appetite. Over nearly two months, at least 1,500 dogs fell ill, many for as long as three weeks. At least eight died from secondary infections like pneumonia.

title: Los Angeles Churches Make Worship...Hip?
description: LOS ANGELES  Just before 10 a.m. on a sunny Sunday in November, a crowd gathered in front of a white modernist building here on Hollywood Boulevard. An inscription on its side, H/N, short for Here and Now, stood out from a block away.

title: Presentation to Treasury on Fannie and Freddie
description: Documents show that as early as June 2011, the Treasury Department had been told that Fannie and Freddie were on the road to recovery and that their tax assets would most likely generate significant value.

title: Fannie and Freddies Government Rescue Has Come With Claws
description: On May 9, 2012, the executives of Fannie Mae, the beleaguered mortgage finance company, finally went public with good news: After three and a half years as a ward of the state, it was profitable again.

title: The Week on Instagram
description: Photos posted this week on @nytimes took followers from Jackson Hole, China, to a quiet Hanukkah scene in Brooklyn.

title: Becoming Kricket
description: After moving to New York, Kricket Nimmons started getting regular health checkups and counseling, and adhering to a new antiretroviral medication regimen for her H.I.V. Before long, she was able to contemplate the idea of a future.

title: A Whole New Being: How Kricket Nimmons Seized the Transgender Moment
description: Perched on a gurney at dawn, Kricket Jern Nimmons, 40, kicked her feet giddily, like a girl on the edge of a pool, preparing to take a plunge. She wore a hospital gown and purple socks with paw prints. Her face was clean-scrubbed  no lash, no makeup, just me  and she looked at peace.

title: Transcript of Testimony by Kricket Jern Nimmons
description: Ms. Nimmons, formerly Jerome, testified in a Georgia federal court against the prison guard who was convicted of sexually assaulting her.

title: Doctors Without Borders Raises Death Toll in Kunduz Strike to 42
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  The number of those killed in an American airstrike that destroyed the Doctors Without Borders hospital in the northern city of Kunduz was much higher than previously thought, the medical group announced Saturday.

title: The Paris Climate Accord
description: A group of nations in Paris reached a landmark agreement to cut back planet-warming emissions of greenhouse gas.

title: Farhad and Mikes Week in Tech: Tempering Walmarts Digital Ambitions
description: Each Saturday, Farhad Manjoo and Mike Isaac, technology reporters at The New York Times, review the weeks news, offering analysis and maybe a joke or two about the most important developments in the tech industry.

title: North Korean Band Abruptly Leaves China, Its Concerts Canceled
description: BEIJING  The favorite pop band of North Koreas young leader abruptly boarded a plane to return home on Saturday, just hours before an important concert here. The concert would have been the bands first one overseas and was one of three in the Chinese capital intended to improve relations between the nations.

title: When a Tree Encroaches
description: Ask Real Estate is a weekly column that answers questions from across the New York region. Submit yours to realestateqa@nytimes.com.

title: The Graying Thieves Who Nearly Got Away With a Record Heist in London
description: LONDON  On Friday nights for three years, they met over pints at the Castle, a pub in Islington, in North London. The four men were getting on in years, but they were not there just to talk about retirement plans or the aches and pains of aging.

title: The Rise of Hate Search
description: HOURS after the massacre in San Bernardino, Calif., on Dec. 2, and minutes after the media first reported that at least one of the shooters had a Muslim-sounding name, a disturbing number of Californians had decided what they wanted to do with Muslims: kill them.

title: Negotiations Break Down Between Two Koreas
description: SEOUL, South Korea  Two days of marathon talks between North Korea and South Korea broke down without agreement Saturday, as negotiators failed to agree on how to bring about a thaw in their long-strained relations.

title: Protesters Are in Agreement as Well: Pact Is Too Weak
description: PARIS  Several thousand climate activists from across Europe and many from farther afield gathered peacefully near the Arc de Triomphe on Saturday to protest the outcome of the COP 21 climate conference about 12 miles away.

title: Alan Dershowitz, From the Death Penalty to Roman Polanski
description: Over a five-decade career, Mr. Dershowitz has represented some of Americas most prominent criminal defendants, including O.J. Simpson, Leona Helmsley, Mike Tyson and Claus von Bulow.

title: Alan Dershowitz on the Defense (His Own)
description: Last month, demonstrators at Johns Hopkins University interrupted Alan M. Dershowitz as he was giving a fiery speech defending Israel. The disruption normally would not have fazed Mr. Dershowitz, a former Harvard Law School professor who thrives on controversy and relishes taking on opponents in and out of the courtroom.

title: Lives in Balance, Texas Leads Scrutiny of Bite-Mark Forensics
description: FORT WORTH, Tex.  Steven Mark Chaney, who was freed from prison in October after 28 years, had to fight back tears as he watched forensic dentists argue here, before the Texas Forensic Science Commission, whether bite patterns on the skin of murder, rape and child abuse victims can offer valid clues to the perpetrators identity.

title: Jessica Herrin of Stella & Dot: Put the Culture Over the Quarter
description: This interview with Jessica Herrin, founder and chief executive of  Stella & Dot Family Brands, was conducted and condensed by Adam Bryant.

title: Dennison Tsosie: Bearing the Torch, and Using It, Too
U.S. Visa Process Missed San Bernardino Wifes Online Zealotry
description: WASHINGTON  Tashfeen Malik, who with her husband carried out the massacre in San Bernardino, Calif., passed three background checks by American immigration officials as she moved to the United States from Pakistan. None uncovered what Ms. Malik had said online about her views on violent jihad.

title: Variety: An Upside Down Acrostic
description: VARIETY PUZZLE  Most people who solve crossword and other types of puzzles also have a fondness for math and number-based puzzles, so I hope I am preaching to the choir when I remind readers that we also offer a math puzzle blog on Mondays called Numberplay. Written in a charmingly approachable way by Gary Antonick, Numberplay explores the different ways a problem can be solved, and it is worth a gander. You might even see some familiar Wordplayers there.

title: Inside the Paris Climate Deal
description: Highlights from the final draft text of a climate agreement submitted to the delegates in Paris.

title: Moms and Daughters Debate Gender Factor in Hillary Clintons Bid
description: Barbara Schierenbeck, a 59-year-old nurse in Brooklyn, is swept up in the excitement of potentially electing Hillary Clinton the first female president. She cannot understand why her 19-year-old daughter, Anna, does not feel the same way.

title: Donald Trumps Latest Feud Is With a Prince
description: Its a spat between two heirs to fortunes, one that traverses billions of dollars, millions of Twitter followers, an ocean or two, and an increasingly caustic presidential campaign.

title: With Heisman Trophy Tucked Away, Spotlight Falls on Look-Alikes
description: When the winner of the Heisman Trophy was announced Saturday night on ESPN, the hefty bronze statue that was lifted in joy was not the original one first awarded in 1935.

title: Todays Butlers Are Trading Silver Trays for iPads
description: When Graham Lefford started working as a butler in 1989, his daily tasks usually involved planning formal dinners and carefully arranging the daily breakfast tray with coffee and a newspaper.

title: Man Charged With Arson in California Mosque Fire
description: SAN BERNARDINO, Calif.  A 23-year-old man was booked Saturday on arson and hate-crime charges in connection with a fire that burned through part of a Southern California mosque just before a prayer service on Friday.

title: Saudi Elections Are First to Include Women as Voters and Candidates
description: RIYADH, Saudi Arabia  There were no public debates, few campaign posters and no scandals. Candidates did not promote their platforms or undermine their rivals on television. And they risked disqualification for speaking to journalists.

title: Smart Car Standoff Pits Social Progress Against Global Competition
description: HAMBACH, France  On a drizzly afternoon in October, Mathis Cdric buzzed around the kitchen of his small Alsatian restaurant in Hambach, France, a bucolic town near the German border. It was lunchtime, and workers from a nearby Smart car factory would soon be filtering in to grab the daily special of sauerkraut and sausages before heading to their afternoon shift.

title: Morgan Lloyd
description: Morgan Lloyd is a co-creator of You Me Bum Bum Train, an immersive and somewhat surreal theater experience in London put on by an all-volunteer cast and crew that subjects passengers to a series of scenarios in which they must improvise a part without any preparation  if they can get one of the nearly impossible-to-obtain tickets.

title: How Well Do You Know Religion?
description: This is a time that tests our fundamental values.

title: Get Home Safe, My Rapist Said
description: I WANT to make sure you get home safe, my rapist said, as he walked me to my car. It was after 2 a.m., the Sunday before Christmas, and snow was falling. In some ways, in the very visceral, physical, rape way, it was all over. In more important ways, it was just beginning.

title: The Strip
description: A weekly comic strip featured in the Sunday Review.

title: The Lie About College Diversity
description: THE Supreme Court listened anew last week to arguments about affirmative action in higher education, and we heard yet again about the push by colleges to assemble diverse student bodies.

title: Where Is the Cure for the Migraine?
description: AT least 36 million Americans suffer from migraines, and while more and more medical professionals are on the case, they have never found satisfactory answers for why the pain starts, let alone how to make it end.

title: Your iPhone Is Ruining Your Posture  and Your Mood
description: THERE are plenty of reasons to put our cellphones down now and then, not least the fact that incessantly checking them takes us out of the present moment and disrupts family dinners around the globe. But heres one you might not have considered: Smartphones are ruining our posture. And bad posture doesnt just mean a stiff neck. It can hurt us in insidious psychological ways.

title: The Islamic Dilemma
Keep the Flame Lit for Investigative Journalism
description: This is the second part of a look at the threatened state of local investigative reporting.

title: Opening All Military Jobs to Women
description: Readers hail and condemn a Pentagon plan to open all military jobs to women.

title: Haiti Deserves a Legitimate Election
description: There is an electoral crisis in Haiti. An election in October to choose a successor to President Michel Martelly was so marred by reports of ballot tampering, illegal voting and other abuses that the result has been widely denounced as illegitimate.

title: Exploring the World on Foot
description: BAKU, Azerbaijan  ITS an odd feeling: being aware of the Earth rotating beneath your feet.

title: Despair Over Gun Deaths Is Not an Option
description: After months of grief and depression, parents who lost children in the 2012 schoolhouse gun slaughter in Newtown, Conn., turned to the courts last year for a modicum of justice and only then discovered the full power of gun manufacturers: The industry marketing the weapons that killed 20 children and six adults at the school enjoys an extraordinary immunity from civil damage suits  a customized shield from Congress that the makers of autos, drugs and other American industries are not given.

title: Paul Ryan Says Inclusive House Agenda Must Counter Polarizing Campaign
description: WASHINGTON  Concerned about the harshly negative presidential campaign dominated by Donald J. Trump, the nations highest-ranking Republican says Congress must confront polarizing populism by promoting an inclusive policy-focused agenda to counter any personality-driven run sure to cost his party the White House.

title: A College Basketball Player Who Is Also a Law School Student
description: NEWARK  The circulation desk was still closed early on a recent Monday morning in the Peter W. Rodino Jr. Library, on the fourth level of the Seton Hall School of Law, where Braeden Anderson settled by a desk in the corner. He flipped an accordion-size textbook to Page 563.

title: Groups Converge for Mock Shooting Near University of Texas
description: AUSTIN, Tex.  Only a handful of gun-rights advocates and those supporting Texas new, less restrictive campus-carry law showed up near the University of Texas campus here on Saturday for a highly publicized but divisive demonstration and mock shooting in favor of ending gun-free zones.

title: Marjorie Lord, Actress on The Danny Thomas Show, Dies at 97
description: Marjorie Lord, an actress who achieved success as the comedian Danny Thomass wife on the Emmy-winning comedy series The Danny Thomas Show, but to her frustration found herself being typecast as a housewife for years afterward, died on Nov. 28. She was 97.

title: The Climate Path Ahead
description: At the Earth Summit in Rio de Janeiro 23 years ago, the worlds nations adopted a treaty that pledged, but ultimately failed, to cut the emissions driving global warming. In Paris over the last two weeks, negotiators from around the world met for the 21st time since then in an effort to move from aspiration to action.

title: Auston Matthews, 18, Blazes a New Route to the N.H.L.
description: ZURICH  When Auston Matthews was asked to consider the most substantial challenge he faced as an 18-year-old prodigy from Arizona spending a year playing professional hockey in Switzerland, one particular obstacle came to mind quickly.

title: John Eaton, Composer and Electronic Innovator, Dies at 80
description: John Eaton, an avant-garde composer of operas both grandiose and chamber-size and an early proponent of synthesizer music, died on Dec. 2 in Manhattan. He was 80.

title: In Reversal, Governor Cuomo Moves to Support Faster Action on Information Requests
description: ALBANY  As the state capital reels from the convictions of two of its most powerful leaders and as calls for substantive reforms rise to a fever pitch, Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo issued an executive order on Saturday effectively reversing his own veto from the day before of a bill intended to speed appeals under the states Freedom of Information Law.

title: Karl-Anthony Towns Is Revealing His Secrets, One Game at a Time
description: MINNEAPOLIS  Shabazz Muhammad was well aware of Karl-Anthony Towns when the Minnesota Timberwolves made the 7-foot Towns the first overall pick in Junes N.B.A. draft, having watched him patrol the post as a key member of John Caliparis talent-laden team at Kentucky.

title: Haitian Migrants in Limbo Along the Border
description: Now stateless, the refugees exist in the space between Haiti and the Dominican Republic, two nations that, along with their island, share a history steeped in hostility.

title: Forced to Flee Dominican Republic for Haiti, Migrants Land in Limbo
description: PARC CADEAU 2, Haiti  Along this arid strip of borderland, the river brings life. Its languid waters are used to cook the food, quench the thirst and bathe the bodies of thousands of Haitian migrants who have poured onto its banks from the Dominican Republic, fleeing threats of violence and deportation.

title: You Cant Put Ice Over a Migraine, a Lurking Malady in the N.F.L.
description: FLORHAM PARK, N.J.  When he woke last Sunday morning, Jeremy Kerley sensed trouble already coming on. Fitful sleep is often his trigger, he said. The migraine eventually hit him like an anvil late in last weeks game against the Giants.

title: Titans at Jets Matchup
description: 1 p.m., CBS

title: Paris Accord Considers Climate Change as a Factor in Mass Migration
description: LE BOURGET, France  The two-week United Nations climate conference outside Paris that drew to an end on Saturday focused on many of the physical dangers associated with climate change: extreme weather, severe drought, the warming of oceans, rain forest destruction and disruptions to the food supply.

title: An N.F.L. Season of Bitter (or Sweet) Comebacks
description: The desperate last-minute comeback in an N.F.L. game, a harried march downfield with one eye on the countdown of an unrelenting scoreboard clock, has always produced some of the sports most memorable moments.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: Praise For Leader At Purdue

title: Bands Together
description: SUNDAY PUZZLE  Well, this is a treat. Monday queen Andrea Carla Michaels meets up with Tracy Gray and greets us with a Sunday puzzle. After reading the byline, it took me a while to adjust to the fact that this wouldnt be a smooth solve like Ms. Michaelss Monday grids because it is Sunday but, once I got over that hump, I was fine.

title: Ted Cruz Surges Past Donald Trump to Lead in Iowa Poll
description: DES MOINES  Senator Ted Cruz of Texas surged to a 10-point lead in a new poll released Saturday of likely Republican caucusgoers in Iowa, signaling that his campaign is gathering momentum and suggesting that a long nominating fight is ahead.

title: 15 Years After Vicious Attack, Planning a Return to the Ring
description: Before he awoke from a three-week coma, Viktor Sinyuts swears that he knew the extent of his injuries. He had been hospitalized after a brutal assault that cost him his right leg.

title: The Destination in Paris Climate Talks Was a Journey That Begins Now
description: Between the tumultuous breakdown in Copenhagen in 2009 and the cheers and bubbly in Paris on Saturday, climate change diplomacy underwent a grand metamorphosis.

title: Political Violence in Burundi Exacts Growing Toll
description: KAMPALA, Uganda  Dozens of bodies, some with their hands tied behind their backs, were strewn across the streets of Bujumbura, the capital of Burundi, on Saturday, a day after coordinated strikes by unidentified gunmen on military camps shook the country.

title: Senegal, a Peaceful Islamic Democracy, Is Jarred by Fears of Militancy
description: GUDIAWAYE, Senegal  Raids for suspects in the Paris attacks flashed across the television at the Sow family house in this small village along Senegals coastline.

title: AsMichael Cuddyer Walks Away, He Cites Aches and Pains
description: Four days after the Mets season ended, Michael Cuddyer had surgery to repair a core muscle injury, and in the following days he started thinking about retirement. His first season with the Mets had been marred by knee and wrist injuries. Over the last four years, he had missed nearly 40 percent of his teams regular-season games because of injury.

title: Empire State Pride Agenda to Disband, Citing Fulfillment of Its Mission
description: ALBANY  In a surprise announcement, the Empire State Pride Agenda, a leading state group that advocates gay, lesbian, bisexual and transgender issues in New York, will disband next year, citing the fulfillment of a 25-year campaign for equality.

title: Obama, Once a Guest, Is Now a Leader in World Talks
description: WASHINGTON  Six years ago, President Obama came away from a round of global climate talks bitter and frustrated, having been reduced to personally chasing other world leaders around a Copenhagen conference center and bursting uninvited into a meeting with them to salvage a pact that left many disappointed.

title: Climate Accord Is a Healing Step, if Not a Cure
description: LE BOURGET, France  After the stomping and cheering died down, and the hugs and toasts ended, a question hung in the air as the climate conference came to a close: What does the new deal really mean for the future of the Earth?

title: What Does a Climate Deal Mean for the World?
description: A group of 195 nations reached a landmark climate agreement on Saturday. Here is what it means for the planet, business, politics and other areas.

title: Nets Rally Falls Short Against the Clippers
description: For three and a half quarters, the Los Angeles Clippers traversed the air above the court at Barclays Center to create a crowd-pleasing abundance of above-the-rim plays.

title: Chris Christie Attacks Marco Rubio for Being Hard to Find in New Hampshire
description: Chris Christie, who is enjoying a bump in popularity in New Hampshire, mocked Marco Rubio on Saturday for not visiting the state more often.

title: Derrick Henry Captures Alabamas Second Heisman
description: Derrick Henry, the workhorse Alabama running back, caught his breath at the podium Saturday night after winning the Heisman Trophy as he began to thank his mother, whom he would awaken with late-night calls when he struggled; his father, my No. 1 fan; and his grandmother, who made me what I am today.

title: Indianapolis Police Kill Man Who Had Knife
description: Indianapolis police officers shot and killed a man on Saturday after he lunged at an officer with a knife following an unsuccessful effort to subdue him using nonlethal force, the department said in a statement.

title: Warriors Fall to Bucks, Ending Perfect Start
description: The Golden State Warriors are perfect no more. Their 24-game winning streak to start the 2015-16 N.B.A. season came to end on Saturday night in Milwaukee, where they lost to the Bucks, 108-95.

title: Rand Pauls Advisers Argue for Main-Stage Appearance
description: Aides to Senator Rand Paul of Kentucky indicated that they would fight any decision by CNN to move him to the so-called undercard stage for the Republican debate on Tuesday in Las Vegas, butdismissed a report that he was considering dropping out of the race if he were not on the main stage.

title: Erin Yavener, David Gise
description: Erin Brooke Yavener and David Ian Gise were married Saturday evening at the Wilshire Caterers in West Orange, N.J. Rabbi Steven Bayar officiated.

title: Peter Foley and William Gaden II
description: Peter Terence Foley and William Starr Gaden II were married Saturday in New York. The Rev. Kate Parker-Burgard, a United Methodist minister, officiated at the Harvard Club of New York City.

title: Dareema Jenkins and Travis Hughes
description: Dr. Dareema Jenkins and Travis Dubois Hughes were married Saturday by the Rev. Michael A. Bird, an Episcopal priest, at Christ Church Bronxville in Bronxville, N.Y.

title: Alexandra Mizels, Logan Sembler
description: Alexandra Jessica Mizels, the daughter of Nancy J. Mizels of Fort Lauderdale, Fla., and David B. Mizels of Weston, Fla., was married Saturday evening to Logan Nye Sembler, a son of Debbie N. Sembler and Brent W. Sembler of St. Petersburg, Fla. Rabbi Michael Torop officiated at the Vinoy Renaissance Resort & Golf Club in St. Petersburg.

title: Naomi Karp, Howard Tilman
description: Naomi Leah Karp, the daughter of Sharon Rosenfeld Karp and Elliot B. Karp of Cincinnati and Aventura, Fla., is to be married Sunday to Rabbi Howard Jonah Tilman, a son of Ellen Rosenberg Tilman and Cantor David F. Tilman of Elkins Park, Pa. Rabbi Joel Seltzer, is to lead the ceremony at the Jacksonville Jewish Center in Jacksonville, Fla., with Rabbi Jonathan Lubliner participating.

title: Brittany Morgan and Zachary Kurz
description: Brittany Alexa Morgan, the daughter of Hilarie Lauter Morgan and Mitchell L. Morgan of Bryn Mawr, Pa., was married Saturday evening to Zachary Mitchell Kurz, a son of Sandy Mitchell Kurz and Mitchell H. Kurz of New York. Rabbi Solomon Rothstein officiated at the Breakers Hotel in Palm Beach, Fla.

title: Allison Dorman, Lee Goldfarb
description: Allison Esther Dorman, a daughter of Ellen R. Dorman and Ned N. Dorman of Jericho, N.Y., was married Saturday evening to Lee Michael Goldfarb, a son of Marjorie M. Goldfarb and Larry A. Goldfarb of Sewickley, Pa. Rabbi Michael Katz officiated, with Cantor Kalman Fliegelman assisting, at Fresh Meadow Country Club in Lake Success, N.Y.

title: Leah Rosenberg and Getzel Davis: A Hanukkah Wedding Lights Their Way Forward
description: Dr. Leah Beth Rosenberg and Rabbi George Miller Davis are to be married Sunday by Rabbi Arthur Green at Temple Israel of Boston in Massachusetts.

title: Sonia Sujanani and Matthew Soares
description: Sonia Sujanani, the daughter of Lata Sujanani and Dr. Manoj Sujanani of Lexington, Mass., was married Saturday evening to Matthew Francis Soares, the son of Linda J. Soares and Joseph F. Soares of Warren, R.I. Fernande R. V. Duffly, an associate justice of the Massachusetts Supreme Judicial Court with chambers in Boston, officiated at the Boston Cambridge Marriott in Cambridge, Mass.

title: David Taylor, David Bergad
description: David Eugene Taylor and David Franklin Bergad were married Thursday in San Francisco City Hall by Bevan Dufty, a deputy marriage commissioner.

title: Halsey Stebbins, Douglas Keller Jr.
description: Halsey Hampden Stebbins and Douglas Andrew Keller Jr. were married Saturday evening at the Womans Athletic Club in Chicago. Pastor Brian Evans, a Baptist minister, officiated.

title: Wilmary Soto Morales and Stefan Guignet
description: Wilmary Soto Morales, a daughter of Marta Elizabeth Morales Lozada and Wilfredo Soto Laborde of San Juan, P.R., was married Saturday to Stefan Patrick Guignet, a son of Kelly A. Guignet and Douglas K. Guignet of Mountain Top, Pa. Francisco Gonzlez, a minister with Rose Ministries, officiated at the W Retreat & Spa on Vieques, P.R.

title: Elizabeth Reinhard and Peter Lorimer
description: Elizabeth Simons Reinhard, a daughter of Rose-Lee S. Reinhard and Keith L. Reinhard of New York, was married Saturday to Peter Brailler Lorimer, the son of Linda K. Lorimer of New Haven and Ernest M. Lorimer of Westport, Conn. Geoffrey Reinhard, a brother of the bride who became a Universal Life minister for the occasion, officiated at the Stein Eriksen Lodge in Park City, Utah.

title: Karina Schless, Frank Andrea IV
description: Karina Holmes Schless , a daughter of Lesley I. B. Schless and Eric H. Schless of Old Greenwich, Conn., was married Saturday to Frank Albert Andrea IV, a son of Donna C. Andrea and Frank A. Andrea III of Cold Spring Harbor, N.Y. The Rev. Richard S. DenUyl Jr., a minister of the United Church of Christ, performed the ceremony at the First Congregational Church of Greenwich.

title: Yaffa Vitberg, Shaun Steigman
description: Dr. Yaffa Malka Vitberg and Dr. Shaun Allen Steigman are to be married Sunday by Rabbi Moshe Edelman at the Shelter Rock Jewish Center in Roslyn, N.Y.

title: Emily McPherson and Warren Holmes: Earning the Job of Boyfriend
description: Emily Marie McPherson, the daughter of Cynthia L. McPherson and Dr. Charles D. McPherson of Henderson, Nev., was married Saturday evening to Warren Chandler Crawford Holmes, a son of Irene S. Holmes of Ladue, Mo., and the late John A. Holmes Jr. The Rev. Roy Pfautch, a Presbyterian minister, officiated at the Colony Club in New York.

title: Corrections: December 13, 2015
description: INTERNATIONAL

title: Quotation of the Day
description: I came to the realization that if I am supporting her because she is a woman, thats equally as bad as not supporting her because of her gender.

title: Rodeos First Family at the National Finals
description: Rusty Wright, a member of a family that has produced a steady supply of saddle-bronc champions, was among those competing for a title in Las Vegas.

title: Democrat Elected Mayor of Houston
description: HOUSTON  Voters here on Saturday kept the largest city in Texas in Democratic hands, electing a longtime lawmaker as mayor in a tight race over a Republican-leaning businessman.

title: Your Weekend Briefing: Climate Talks, Donald Trump, Dupont
description: Here are the weeks top stories.

title: Your Weekend Briefing
description: Heres what you need to know about the weeks top stories.

title: How Fish Communicate, Even Using Noise
description: Q. We know that aquatic mammals communicate with one another, but what about fish?

title: With Fed Set to Lift Interest Rates, the Little Guy Feels Anxious
description: AURORA, Colo.  William Harris tapped his retirement savings to open A-Town Pizza, a Neapolitan pizzeria, in this Denver suburb three years ago. He borrowed $200,000 to open a second location this year and now employs 60 people. On a good Friday, his shops sell 1,200 pies.

title: Iraqis Oregon Jackpot Raises Questions on Lottery Sales
description: SEATTLE  The man from Baghdad showed up unannounced this month in a state office building in Salem, Ore., with a piece of paper in his hand that he said was worth $6.4 million. He politely asked that his name be kept quiet, then told state officials that he had set up a local bank account into which they should deposit money annually. And then he went away, richer and more mysterious than when he arrived.

title: 1890: Reported Battle Between Indians
description: According to reports received from Pine Ridge, a sanguinary fight took place at Badlands after the late peace conference between the followers of Short Bull and those of Two Strikes. According to the statement of Yankton Charlie, the Sioux Government scout, each chief claimed the leadership and tried to secure it forcibly. From twenty-five to fifty Indians were killed in the struggle. This report is confirmed by friendly Indians who escaped to the Agency during the fight. The depredations of the Indians now extend to the foot of the Black Hills. It is thought to be useless to talk of peace at present. There has been no attempt by the hostile Indians to move out of their entrenchments since the peace council was held. Official despatches received at Washington state that the situation in the Indian territories is favorable, and that the display of troops has demoralized the hostile Indians. The New York Herald, European Edition, December 14, 1890
