title: Kurt Geiger, British Footwear Maker, in Another Private Equity Deal
description: LONDON  The European private equity firm Cinven said on Monday that it had agreed to acquire Kurt Geiger, the British footwear and accessories company, from the New York private equity firm Sycamore Partners.

title: Adele Announces 56-Date North American Tour
description: Adele has set a 56-date North American tour, to begin July 5 and 6 at the Xcel Energy Center in St. Paul and continue through Nov. 14 and 15, at the Palacio de los Deportes in Mexico City.

title: Stephen Wolfram Aims to Democratize His Software
description: For nearly three decades, Stephen Wolfram has built software technology that has attracted an avid following among mathematicians and scientists. His Mathematica program for symbolic mathematical computation and its programming language, Wolfram Language, are favorites of the intelligentsia of the quant world in universities and corporations.

title: 1940: Laval Is Ousted
description: VICHY  Pierre Laval is out as French Vice-Premier and Foreign Minister. Premier Marshal Henri Ptain proclaimed this change in the government to the French people in a broadcast tonight [Dec. 14], declaring that he was taking a decision which I believe to conform to the interests of the country. Pierre-Etienne Flandin has been named Foreign Minister. There will be no Vice-Premier in the reconstituted government. Ptain will remain as both Chief of State and Premier. The eighty-four-year-old marshal told the French people over the radio that Frances relations with Germany would remain unchanged. It was revealed also that Ptain, before making his broadcast, had sent a personal message to Fuehrer Adolf Hitler confirming his (Ptains) intention of pursuing a policy of Franco-German rapprochement.New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, December 15, 1940

title: Thai Man May Go to Prison for Insulting Kings Dog
description: BANGKOK  Thailands strict laws making it a crime to insult the monarchy entered new territory on Monday when a factory worker was charged with disparaging the kings dog.

title: Hillary Clinton Widens Lead Over Bernie Sanders in Iowa Poll
description: Hillary Clinton is building on her lead over Senator Bernie Sanders in Iowa, according to a new poll that shows the former secretary of state gaining momentum less than two months before the states caucuses.

title: Trampolining Droplets
description: Microscopic water droplets levitate and bounce up and down, driven only by low pressure and evaporation.

title: Waters Big (and Then Bigger) Bounce
description: The behavior of very small things can surprise humans, who are used to living in a world of their own size, dominated by gravity.

title: Marco Rubios Wife: A Partner Ready to Puncture His Ego
description: The Hawaiian couples retreat was marketed as a chance to receive godly counsel on marriage, and it featured daily seminars on the art of apologizing, the perils of miscommunication and the power of expressing emotion. Admit your anger, read the slide from one presentation.

title: Daily Report: A Vote on Driver Labor Rights
description: The question of whether drivers at Uber and other on-demand companies are employees or contract workers does not yet have a firm answer. Some prominent executives and policy advocates are even arguing for a new kind of worker status, something that falls in the middle.

title: Egypts Inquiry Into Russian Jet Crash Finds No Proof of Terrorism
description: CAIRO  Egypts government placed itself directly at odds with Russian and Western allies on Monday, announcing that Egyptian investigators had found no evidence that the Russian airliner crash in Sinai on Oct. 31 was caused by terrorism.

title: Why Very Low Interest Rates May Stick Around
description: The Federal Reserve will most likely raise interest rates this week for the first time in nearly a decade. To understand what it means  and doesnt mean  consider a previous year in which interest rates were on the rise.

title: Jan. 2, 1966: When Airbags Were More Science Fiction Than Fact
description: On Jan. 2, 1966, The New York Times published a long article about American car companies response to the growing public concern about safety. At the time, cars had few safety devices  shoulder harnesses will probably not be standard on 1967 models, the article said. The automakers are convinced that scarcely anyone wants them.

title: French Teacher Lied About ISIS Stabbing, Prosecutors Say
description: PARIS  The French authorities said on Monday that a teacher who claimed to have been stabbed with scissors and a box cutter at a preschool near Paris had fabricated the story.

title: On the Verge: Charlotte Hockin
description: Looks from the designers new eponymous line of womenswear.

title: A Young London Designer Who Doesnt Want the Buzz
description: For the 33-year-old British designer Charlotte Hockin, the inside of a garment has always been more fascinating than the outside. I spend hours thinking about how things are made, she says. When I think about designing something, its an attempt to answer a lot of questions and challenge myself. What I always come back to is revealing the beauty of construction  thats my tagline.

title: 1965: U.S. Urges UN Peace Service
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y.  The United States today [Dec. 14] proposed the establishment of a United Nations peace service that would go into action to prevent outbreaks of violence anywhere. The burden of the UN fire department will become intolerable if we cannot do a better job of fire prevention, U.S. Ambassador Arthur J. Goldberg said. New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, December 15, 1965

title: West Bank Shopping Complex, a Symbol of Coexistence, Is Shaken
description: GUSH ETZION JUNCTION, West Bank  On a recent crisp afternoon, a gleaming new Israeli supermarket opened its doors at this West Bank crossroads, a once-congenial meeting spot for Israelis and Palestinians that now resembles a battleground.

title: Islamic State Gains Strength in Yemen, Challenging Al Qaeda
description: SANA, Yemen  Nine months of war between a Saudi-led military coalition and a Yemeni rebel group have left thousands of civilians dead, a nation gravely polarized and the land strewn with debris, mines and unexploded bombs.

title: In New Star Wars, John Williams Returns, Too
description: If youve watched American films, youve most likely heard the work of John Williams.

title: Bus Crash in Argentina Kills Over 40 Police Officers
description: BUENOS AIRES  A bus full of police officers veered off a bridge in northern Argentina early Monday and plunged 60 feet into a ditch, local officials said. Forty-three officers were killed and eight others were injured, according to Juan Manuel Urtubey, the governor of Salta Province, where the crash took place around 2 a.m.

title: Drone Registration Rules Are Announced by F.A.A.
description: WASHINGTON  The Federal Aviation Administration on Monday announced new rules that will require nearly all owners of remote-controlled recreational drones to register the machines in a national database, an attempt by the agency to address safety fears.

title: The Most Popular Recipes of 2015
description: Sam Sifton emails readers of Cooking five days a week to talk about food and suggest recipes. That email also appears here. To receive it in your inbox, register here.

title: Chicago Teachers Approve Call to Strike as Contract Talks Stall
description: CHICAGO  The Chicago Teachers Union has voted overwhelmingly to authorize its leaders to call a strike, a move that clears the way for the unions second walkout in four years and delivers another pressing political challenge for Mayor Rahm Emanuel.

title: Depressed Vote Shows Problems of French Banlieues
description: ST.-DENIS, France  Nearly 70 percent of registered voters in this urban enclave north of Paris stayed home during the first round of Frances regional elections on Dec. 6, a fact that didnt surprise Didier Paillard, the citys twice-elected Communist mayor.

title: What Would You Ask Martin OMalley?
description: Martin OMalley, the former governor of Maryland and a candidate for the Democratic presidential nomination, will visit the editorial board on Tuesday as the board prepares to endorse a candidate for president. These candidate interviews are off the record, but well ask Mr. OMalley one question on the record, and that question will come from you.

title: As Poland Lurches to Right, Many in Europe Look On in Alarm
description: WARSAW  In the few weeks since Polands new right-wing government took over, its leaders have alarmed the domestic opposition and moderate parties throughout Europe by taking a series of unilateral actions that one critic labeled Putinist.

title: Palestinian Rams Car Into Crowd of Israelis at Jerusalem Bus Stop
description: JERUSALEM  A Palestinian resident of East Jerusalem rammed a car into a crowd of Israelis at a Jerusalem bus stop on Monday, according to the Israeli police, injuring about a dozen of them, including an 18-month-old baby.

title: Dear Pete Rose: Its Still a No. Sincerely, Baseball
description: Rob Manfred, the commissioner of Major League Baseball, has decided not to lift the permanent ban imposed on Pete Rose more than a quarter-century ago, meaning that Rose, the player with more hits than anyone else in the sports history, will continue in an exile that has long kept him out of the Hall of Fame.

title: In Son of Saul, Laszlo Nemes Expands the Language of Holocaust Films
description: PARIS  How do you find a fresh perspective on the Holocaust? In his first feature, Son of Saul, the Hungarian director Laszlo Nemes chose to depict the enormity through the specific. For most of the 107-minute fiction film, the camera remains fixed on the face of one inmate at Auschwitz-Birkenau as he races around the death camp trying to bury a boy he believes is his son.

title: Assessing How Important a Statement Is for Securities Fraud
description: When someone asks how you are doing, the reflexive answer is often good even if it has been a horrible day. The questioner is being polite, and hardly expects a disquisition on the status of your life.

title: Alex Gansa on Homeland and Responding to Real-Life Terrorism
description: Once mostly anonymous, the producers who oversee top television series have sometimes become as well known as the actors who star in them. On occasion, The Times will pose questions from readers (and pose some of our own) to notable show runners, and post their responses.

title: Keith Devlin and the Unfinished Game
description: This weeks puzzle was suggested by Keith Devlin, a Stanford mathematician currently teaching at Princeton. Dr. Devlin has been a considerable force in making mathematics accessible to millions through his many books, talks, radio and television appearances(check outthis list).He has a remarkable gift for making mathematical concepts meaningful and relevant, with particular emphasis on historical context. Heres Dr. Devlin with a real-life challenge that generatedone of the most important concepts in mathematics today  probability theory:

title: The Steelers Are in Better Playoff Shape Than People Think
description: If the N.F.L. season ended today  as the television announcers often say  the Steelers would not make the playoffs. Theyre in the No. 7 position in the A.F.C., and only six teams make the playoffs. To add to its troubles, Pittsburgh has to play the 10-3 Denver Broncos this weekend.

title: Obama Urges Mideast Allies to Do More in Fight Against ISIS
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama called on Middle East allies on Monday to do more in the fight against the Islamic State in Iraq and Syria, signaling a growing frustration within the administration that Saudi Arabia and other allies in the region have yet to help the United States build up a Syrian Arab coalition of ground forces to push back the militant group in Syria.

title: New Research Raises More Questions about Antidepressant Use During Pregnancy
description: The pros and cons of taking antidepressants while pregnant have been hotly debated despite increasing research in the field. Each time one study highlights negative outcomes associated with antidepressant use during pregnancy, another study is published pointing toward the benefits for mother and baby. For any woman considering pregnancy and in need of antidepressants, deciding on a course of action can be agonizing. Today, research published in JAMA Pediatrics is likely to make matters even more troubling for these women.

title: A History of Fed Leaders and Interest Rates
description: The chairwoman of the Federal Reserve has begun the process of raising interest rates, a move that her predecessors have taken in recent decades as they put their own distinctive stamp on the economy.

title: Debate Offers Jeb Bush a Chance to Take the Family Gloves Off
description: From George Bush to his two political sons, the Bush family has always been squeamish about messy, personal attacks on rivals, preferring to outsource the dirty work to aides.

title: Hoverboard Safety Fears Grow as Problems Mount
description: So-called hoverboards, the two-wheeled, gliding motorized scooters that have taken over sidewalks and social media in recent months, are coming under greater scrutiny after reports of fires and explosions.

title: Glacier National Park Adds Cycling Trip
description: In time for the National Park Services centennial year, 2016, Trek Travel has added a Glacier National Park Cycling Trip, making it Treks sixth tour to incorporate national parks in the itinerary.

title: Clydesdale Bank to Pursue I.P.O. as Part of Spinoff
description: LONDON  Clydesdale Bank said on Monday that it planned to pursue an initial public offering as part of its spinoff from National Australia Bank next year.

title: How to Download a Batch of Photos on Flickr
description: Q. My hard drive died and took my photo library with it. I have most of my pictures on Flickr, though  is there a way to grab them back to my new Windows 10 PC from the website, without having to download them one by one?

title: Ed Ruschas Wonderful Christmas Present for Britain
description: LONDON  The artist Ed Ruscha will donate one copy of every print he makes for the rest of his life to Tate, the umbrella organization that oversees the Tate Museums here, the organization announced Monday.

title: Kingsley Market in San Miguel de Allende
description: A Los Angeles expat and accessories designers new shop offers Mexican minimalism  and Japanese shawls.

title: 14 Airports in Greece to Be Privatized in $1.3 Billion Deal
description: ATHENS  Greeces leftist-led government on Monday signed its first major privatization deal, granting a German company the right to lease and manage more than a dozen regional airports.

title: Jeb Bush Gets Serious
description: Jeb Bush is trying to talk seriously. Or at least hes using the word serious a lot.

title: The Top 10 Restaurant Dishes of 2015
description: Sticky buns, duck carnitas, a porchetta sandwich and pine-scented mackerel all show that the city chefs creativity is healthy.

title: Barred From Baseball: Pete Rose Is Most Famous, but He Is Far From Alone
description: It is the ultimate penalty in baseball: the lifetime ban. Pete Rose is the most famous person to pay the penalty, but many players and owners have been barred over the years for all manner of malfeasance.

title: Transparent Season 2, Episodes 2 and 3: Pool Parties and Provosts
description: Episode 2, like the season premiere directed by Jill Soloway, opens on Amy Landecker, who plays Sarah, looking decimated  puffy, no makeup, sallow, dead in the eyes.

title: Your Most Valuable Asset Is Yourself
description: Years ago, my colleagues and I conducted a fairly large-scale research project. We interviewed a bunch of high-income professionals who provided professional services. This group included doctors, dentists and lawyers, and like most of us, they earned money only when they were working. In essence, they traded their time for dollars.

title: In the Market for Mexican Minimalism
description: After a decade of spending half of every year in San Miguel de Allende, Lisa Kingsley began to dread having to return home to Los Angeles. Now, two years after moving there full-time, the accessories designer has opened Kingsley Market, a spare, sunlit, all-white space on one of the towns main shopping streets where she sells a selection of handbags, essential oils and jewelry. I wanted it to be a place where Mexican craftsmanship could meet modern design, she says. And while not all of the pieces on offer are Mexican in origin (most notably, the lightweight cotton shawls from the Japanese artisan Tamaki Niime), everything in her own collection  supple snakeskin clutches in shades of cream, persimmon and clay; earthy perfumes made with macadamia oil sourced from a small plantation in Guerrero; smoky incense sticks whose resin comes from local Copal trees; old lead bullets dating to the Mexican Revolution refashioned into pendants  is locally crafted. (A small footwear collection is next.)

title: On Princess Bride Portrayals, Mandy Patinkin Thinks Ted Cruz Doesnt Get It
description: In recent days, the actor Mandy Patinkin, who played the master swordsman Inigo Montoya in the classic 1987 film The Princess Bride, has received emails from friends alerting him to pictures on the Internet that show scenes taken from the movie with Ted Cruzs face superimposed on top of his body.

title: Chicago Police Commander Acquitted in Gun-in-Mouth Case
description: CHICAGO  A Chicago police commander accused of sticking a gun in a suspects mouth, holding a Taser to his groin and threatening to kill him was acquitted of felony charges on Monday by a circuit court judge.

title: Evelyn Witkin and the Road to DNA Enlightenment
description: For decades Evelyn M. Witkin, professor emerita at Rutgers University, has been a towering figure in genetics. Recently she was awarded the Lasker Basic Medical Research Award for groundbreaking work into how DNA responds to damage, a process essential to all living organisms.

title: Justices Favor Lesbian Adoptive Mother in Visitation Case
description: WASHINGTON  The Supreme Court on Monday  sided with an adoptive mother who had split with her former lesbian partner, who is the birth mother, staying a decision of the Alabama Supreme Court. That court refused to recognize the womans adoptions of three children, although a Georgia court granted the adoptions in 2007.

title: Polls Show Donald Trump Well-Positioned Nationally and in Iowa
description: Donald J. Trumps support among Republicans has cracked the 40 percent threshold, according to a national poll released on Monday that shows the billionaire real estate mogul pulling away from his rivals after his proposal to bar Muslim immigrants from entering the United States.

title: Rising Obesity Rates Put Strain on Nursing Homes
description: RED BAY, Ala.  At 72, her gray hair closely shorn, her days occupied by sewing and television, Wanda Chism seems every bit a typical nursing home patient  but for her size.

title: Supreme Court Upholds Arbitration in DirecTV Case
description: WASHINGTON  The Supreme Court on Monday ruled that dissatisfied customers of DirecTV in California could not band together in a class action and must instead pursue individual arbitrations.

title: Merkel Defies Conservative Critics of Her Refugee Policy
description: BERLIN  With maneuvering behind the scenes and a strong appeal to various factions in her party, Chancellor Angela Merkel on Monday muted conservative criticism of opening Germany to an estimated one million refugees this year and insisted that Germans would succeed in absorbing the intake because it is part of the identity of this country to do great things.

title: C-Sections Are Best With a Little Labor, a Study Says
description: For years, research has shown that babies born by cesarean section are more likely to develop health problems. Now, a groundbreaking study suggests that not all C-sections are equally risky.

title: New York City to Close 3 Troubled Public Schools in Brooklyn
description: The New York City Education Department announced on Monday that it planned to close three poorly performing schools at the end of the current school year. It is the first time Mayor Bill de Blasios administration has elected to shut down any noncharter public schools.

title: A Discredited Challenge to Affirmative Action
description: To the Editor:

title: Bowe Bergdahl to Face Court-Martial on Desertion Charges
description: A top Army commander on Monday ordered that Sgt. Bowe Bergdahl face a court-martial on charges of desertion and endangering troops stemming from his decision to leave his outpost in 2009, a move that prompted a huge manhunt in the wilds of eastern Afghanistan and landed him in nearly five years of harsh Taliban captivity.

title: Ridding Society of Racism
description: To the Editor:

title: Samsungs Patent Loss to Apple Is Appealed to Supreme Court
description: Less than two weeks ago, Samsung agreed to pay Apple $548 million in damages in Federal District Court, as their yearslong legal conflict seemed to be tailing off to a cease-fire.

title: Commissioners Written Decision on Pete Rose
description: Commissioner Rob Manfred determined that Rose has not presented credible evidence of a reconfigured life.

title: For Bien Cuits Zachary Golper, the Bowl Scraper Fits Like a Glove
description: Zachary Golper learned to make bread in a sheep barn, under guttering candles in the dead of night.

title: E.P.A. Broke Law With Social Media Push for Water Rule, Auditor Finds
description: WASHINGTON  The Environmental Protection Agency engaged in covert propaganda and violated federal law when it blitzed social media to urge the public to back an Obama administration rule intended to better protect the nations streams and surface waters, congressional auditors have concluded.

title: Newell Rubbermaids Merger Machine Shows Stress
description: Newell Rubbermaid is overworking its merger machine.

title: How The Times Covers the Globe
description: Michael Slackman, international managing editor of The New York Times on how the paper does international coverage.

title: Texas Plumber Sues Car Dealer After His Truck Ends Up on Syrias Front Lines
description: A Texas plumber has filed a lawsuit against a car dealership after a used truck he sold showed up on the front lines in Syria being used by Islamist fighters. The logo and phone number of his company, Mark-1 Plumbing, were still visible on the doors.

title: Will Congress Help Americas First Responders?
description: Despite bipartisan approval and popular support, a bill assisting first responders who have illnesses resulting from 9/11 has been stalled by Republican leadersin Congress. The James Zadroga 9/11 Health and Compensation Act of 2010 provides emergency medical care, monitoring and compensation programs to thousands of first responders nationwide, but will expire this monthunless Congress acts.

title: Donald Trump Releases Medical Report Calling His Health Extraordinary
description: Donald J. Trump has released a letter from his personal physician attesting that his health is extraordinary.

title: Zahn McClarnon on Fargo and What Makes Hanzee Tick
description: Throughout most of the second season of Fargo, which ends tonight, Hanzee Dent has served as a reliable tracker and enforcer for the Gerhardt crime family of North Dakota. Hes a shrewd and implacable killing machine, like a more stoic variation on Javier Bardems terrifying Anton Chigurh in No Country for Old Men (one of the many Coen Brothers films the shows creator, Noah Hawley, alludes to in the series). Yet Hanzees role has evolved and deepened down the stretch, as his own agenda has surfaced amid the chaos of a turf war with the Kansas City mob.

title: Giving Bondholders a Voice in Debt Restructuring
description: Mark J. Roe is a professor at Harvard Law School. He wrote The Voting Prohibition in Bond Workouts, published in The Yale Law Journal.

title: Nomas Story Told in a Documentary
description: The story of how the Copenhagen chef Ren Redzepi began fashioning what has come to be known as the new Nordic cuisine is told in Noma: My Perfect Storm, a feature-length film that should appeal to dedicated restaurantgoers. It includes people in Mr. Redzepis circle like Claus Meyer, who will soon open a Nordic restaurant in New York, and Tage Ronne, who rummages the forest floor for ingredients, as well as the team of cooks who spend so much time plucking tiny leaves from threadlike stems. As for the distinction of running what has been named the best restaurant in the world four times (but with two, not three Michelin stars), it provides a dramatic story line and, for Mr. Redzepi, enough angst to suit Shakespeares prince, even though he is half-Macedonian: Noma: My Perfect Storm, directed by Pierre Deschamps, produced by Documentree Films, in theaters, on demand and on iTunes on Friday.

title: In New Era for Marijuana, New York Smokers Get Bolder
description: It wafts down the pavement, an unmistakable odor more Haight-Ashbury than New York  the tang of marijuana smoke in the citys streets. If the smell (and the lightheadedness a passer-by may feel) is anything to judge by, lighting up and strolling around seems increasingly common in pockets of Brooklyn, on side streets in Manhattan and in other public spaces.

title: Andrew Hamingson to Lead Lower Manhattan Cultural Council
description: The Lower Manhattan Cultural Council  which runs downtown arts festivals and initiatives, awards grants and is currently expanding its Arts Center at Governors Island  announced Monday that its next president would be Andrew D. Hamingson, who is now the executive director of St. Anns Warehouse in Brooklyn.

title: Baltimore Trial Leaves Unanswered Question: What Happened to Freddie Gray?
description: BALTIMORE  When a young black man named Freddie Gray died of a spinal cord injury in April, after a widely circulated cellphone video showing him being dragged screaming into a police transport van, a theory emerged: He was brutalized by officers, who gave him an intentional rough ride that left him with a broken neck.

title: Chargers and Raiders Stick Together in Los Angeles Plan
description: The San Diego Chargers and the Oakland Raiders remain committed to building a stadium together in Carson, Calif., if owners of the other N.F.L. franchises approve the teams applications to move to the Los Angeles area.

title: A Global Accord on Climate Change
description: To the Editor:

title: Brooklyn Rock Lottery Taps Instant Bandmates for a Day
description: All morning, afternoon and evening in Brooklyn on Saturday, rock n roll scenes played out like demented fever dreams. As hordes of Santas stumbled around on the streets outside, the lead singer of the Rapture grabbed a guitar and was shredding alongside a revered Israeli guitarist and a Brooklyn hip-hop artist. A Sonic Youth producer traded screamed lyrics about beatniks in space with the off-kilter electro-pop artist Autre Ne Veut. A 14-year-old heavy-metal guitarist and a jazz saxophonist taught each other riffs.

title: Adeles Third Week at No. 1 Is Accompanied by Another Chart Record
description: Another week, another eye-popping sales statistic for Adele.

title: Marine Le Pen Far From Humbled by National Fronts Bruising Defeat
description: PARIS  Marine Le Pens concession speech after her National Front party lost in every region of France on Sunday was anything but conciliatory, despite more than 70 percent of voters rejecting the far-right leaders message of hostility toward immigrants and open borders.

title: Benedict Anderson, Scholar Who Saw Nations as Imagined, Dies at 79
description: Benedict Anderson, a scholar of Southeast Asia who transformed the study of nationalism by positing that nations were imagined communities that arose from the fateful interplay of capitalism and the printing press, died on Saturday night at a hotel in Batu, Indonesia. He was 79.

title: In Age of Digital Records, Paper Still Carries Weight
description: As the ancient Britons celebrated the alignment of stone and shadow at Stonehenge, as modern astronomers delight in a solar eclipse, so joy fills my personal universe during the brief intervals when my three major professional passwords converge.

title: Five Artist-Designed Objects  That Cost (Much) Less Than Canvases
description: This holiday season, thanks to some enterprising painters, sculptors and performers, giving a gallery-worthy present (or at least a comfy scarf or tee) doesnt have to cost a fortune.

title: Estela Duo to Open Branch at Met Breuer
description: The grande dame of Manhattan museums has decided to import a dash of downtown cool.

title: Times Insider Live: How The Times Covers the Globe
description: It has certainly been a head-spinning year for international news.

title: Changes Coming for Health Care in China and Cuba
description: Two countries that are models of effective public health intervention, China and Cuba, have recently embarked on important policy changes, leaving some experts wondering whether citizens will be left worse off.

title: Pictures of the Day: the West Bank and Elsewhere
description: The West Bank and Elsewhere: Pictures of the Day

title: Dec. 14, 2015  Pictures of the Day
description: Photos from the West Bank, the Philippines, Syria and Central African Republic.

title: 120 Multistate Outbreaks: Tip of Iceberg in Food-borne Infection
Proposed Move on Fed Dividend Is Troubling
description: David Zaring is assistant professor of legal studies at the Wharton School of the University of Pennsylvania.

title: Qaddafi Son Arrested by Lebanon in New Twist on Missing Imam Mystery
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  A flamboyant son of Libyas deposed leader was interrogated and formally arrested by Lebanons judiciary on Monday, accused of withholding information about the unsolved 1978 disappearance of a revered Lebanese Shiite cleric and two companions in Libya.

title: Last Days for U.N. Court Trying Suspects in Rwanda Genocide
description: ARUSHA, Tanzania  This town, near the edge of the Great Rift Valley, has long been a jumping off point for safaris. But intermingled with the zoom-lens-wielding tourists and camouflage-green safari trucks has been another common sight: buttoned-up legal staff members drawn from all over the world.

title: Craft Brewers Have to Compete for Beer Cans
description: When customers began to line up at 5 a.m. outside Scott Metzgers microbrewery in San Antonio, Mr. Metzger knew he had to start making more beer.

title: Lillian Vernon, Creator of a Bustling Catalog Business, Dies at 88
description: Lillian Vernon, who created a sprawling catalog business that specialized in personalized gifts and ingenious gadgets and made her an American household name, died on Monday in Manhattan. She was 88.

title: Review: Reviving Andy de Groats Works in New York
description: If you werent part of the postmodern dance scene in 1970s New York, you might not know about Andy de Groat, an imaginative minimalist who moved to France in the 80s, leaving behind few traces of his work. The choreographer Catherine Galasso, born in 1982, is well aware that his dances, if not performed, could be forgotten on this side of the Atlantic. During the past few years, she has been reconstructing his early repertoire, or as she calls it, live archiving. The result is get dancing, an illuminating, heartfelt program of old and new work performed at Danspace Project on Friday.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: TO THE EDITOR:

title: Opportunity Seldom Knocks for Black Football Coaches
description: Several years ago, David Williams, the athletic director at Vanderbilt, was approached by Kansas States offensive coordinator at a gathering for young minority assistant football coaches.

title: On Your Feet! and Fiddler Are Strong at Broadway Box Office
description: Immigration may be polarizing as a political issue, but on Broadway several immigrant stories are doing quite well.

title: Review: Adam Sismans John le Carr: The Biography
description: Betrayal, abandonment and the yearning to belong  these are the psychological tent poles of John le Carrs novels, driving the plots of his spy stories and lofting his best work way over the genres walls. As Adam Sismans absorbing new biography of Mr. le Carr (or, rather, of David Cornwell, the man behind the pseudonym) makes clear, these emotions were deeply rooted in the novelists unhappy childhood. His father, Ronnie, was a flamboyant and shameless con man who racked up debts and marks around the world and served prison time for fraud. His mother, Olive, abandoned the family when David was 5.

title: Mohamed Hadid, a Luxury Developer Who Shines on Instagram
description: When it comes to Instagram celebrities, few people seem to lead as glamorous a life as Mr. Hadid.

title: U.S. Calls for Inquiry Into Rights Abuses in Burundi
description: GENEVA  The United States called on Monday for an international inquiry into human rights abuses in Burundi, responding to months of escalating violence that has cost hundreds of lives and heightened concerns that it could spill over into neighboring countries.

title: Review: Met Chamber Ensemble Salutes Boulez With a Less Complicated Piece Than Planned
description: Though Pierre Boulez has been too ill to take part in the celebrations of his 90th birthday this year, James Levine and the Met Chamber Ensemble saluted him on Sunday at Zankel Hall with an incisive account of Drive 1 for six instruments.

title: A Mansion, a Shell Company and Resentment in Bel Air
description: LOS ANGELES  The most notorious new house in Los Angeles hangs from a Bel Air hillside, high above the sprawl and smog, unfinished and unloved.

title: The Church and the Jews
description: To the Editor:

title: Review: Alvin Ailey Troupe Gives Premiere of Piazzolla Caldera
description: A work like Memoria unveils a sampling of Alvin Aileys obsessions: classical ballet, jazz and the modern-dance techniques of Lester Horton and Martha Graham. Set to music by Keith Jarrett, Memoria, dedicated to Aileys friend, the choreographer Joyce Trisler, begins quietly with the lead dancer, Jacqueline Green, dressed in a pale gown with flowers in her hair.

title: The Restaurant That Got Its Name From Drake
description: When chef Susur Lees new downtown Toronto restaurant opened earlier this autumn, rumors connected the hometown hero and multihyphenate rapper Drake (born Aubrey Drake Graham) to the project. He did promote its opening via Vine, and arrive early to its September launch party to D.J. the event  attended by guests including Jaden Smith, Jada Pinkett Smith and Serena Williams. But Drakes only official connection to the upscale comfort-food-style eatery  owned by his frequent business partner, Angelo Ferraro, and by Lees family  is that he gave it its name: Frings.

title: Perfectly Reasonable Question: Was That Photo Real?
description: The photograph shows a Muslim girl at a desk doing her homework, with the television on in the background. The image on the TV screen is of Donald Trump.

title: Documenting Rape in India
description: When Smita Sharma photographs rape victims who have been shunned and ostracized in India, she connects with them by sharing her own story of sexual assault.

title: Italy Delays E.U.s Renewal of Sanctions Against Russia
description: BRUSSELS  The European Union delayed a decision on whether to renew sanctions against Russia on Monday, after Italy insisted that more discussion was needed.

title: Donald Trumps Doctor Likes Hyperbole, Too
description: Donald J. Trump appears to have hired the Donald J. Trump of doctors.

title: Panel: Your Money Matters
description: Welcome to Times Insider Events  live programming for Times Insiders and their guests.

title: Quarterback Alex Smith Provides Chiefs With Grit in a Seven-Game Tear
description: KANSAS CITY, Mo.  Alex Smith strode through the Kansas City Chiefs locker room Sunday afternoon wearing white game pants soaked through with rainwater, splotched with mud and tinted green from the paint used to make a football field look nice in December.

title: Your Monday Evening Briefing: Bowe Bergdahl, Pete Rose, Federal Reserve
description: (Want to get this briefing by email? Heres the sign-up.)

title: Instant Bandmates for a Day at the Brooklyn Rock Lottery
description: Saturday was a madcap marathon of creativity for 25 musicians who arrived at the Knitting Factory in Brooklyn to form bands that would perform that night.

title: Your Evening Briefing
description: Heres what you need to know about the days top stories.

title: McConnell Takes Credit for Resuscitating the Senate
description: WASHINGTON  Barney Frank once told me that asking Republicans to govern was like asking him, the first openly gay member of Congress, to judge the Miss America contest: He would do it, but he wouldnt enjoy it much or be very good at it.

title: After Protests, Turkey Withdraws Some Troops From Iraq
description: ISTANBUL  Turkey on Monday withdrew some troops that had been sent to the outskirts of Mosul in northern Iraq to support a training mission, a deployment that had set off an angry reaction in Baghdad, where the authorities said they had never agreed to host Turkish forces.

title: Climate Advocates See Need for Continued Activism
description: Amid all the cheering over the landmark climate agreement in Paris this weekend, there were also criticisms that it did not go far enough, including from many environmental advocates who had been working for years to push climate change onto the worlds stage and inspire collective action.

title: Leading a Nation Takes Years Off Life, Study Suggests
description: New research may offer a consolation prize for whichever presidential nominee comes up short next November: Losing could mean a longer life.

title: First-Time Director Settles In at Prez Art Museum Miami
description: MIAMI  On a recent balmy day in his new institutional home overlooking Biscayne Bay here, Franklin Sirmans should have looked haggard.

title: Seattle Will Allow Uber and Lyft Drivers to Form Unions
description: SEATTLE  The Seattle City Council voted unanimously to approve a bill allowing drivers for Uber, Lyft and other ride-hailing apps to form unions.

title: Bill Cosby Files Defamation Suit Against Women Who Accused Him
description: Demonstrating that he is still prepared to fight, Bill Cosby struck back on Monday against seven of the women who have accused him of sexual assault and defamation by, in turn, suing them for defamation and denying their allegations.

title: The Children Now Have Beds, but Home Remains a Precarious Place
description: Even before Hurricane Sandy took away all that Mabel Dunkley had, what she had was mostly trouble.

title: New York Regents Vote to Exclude State Tests in Teacher Evaluations
description: New York took another step toward removing state test scores as a component in teacher evaluations on Monday, when members of the Board of Regents voted in favor of a four-year moratorium on their use.

title: Cuomo Considers Reset for Long-Delayed Penn Station Expansion
description: Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo is considering a bold move to restart the long-stalled plan to transform Midtown Manhattans blocklong general post office into a $900 million transit and commercial hub for Pennsylvania Station: jettisoning the developers, Related Companies and Vornado Realty.

title: Rush Limbaugh Stands in Ted Cruzs Corner After Attacks by Donald Trump
description: Rush Limbaugh, the conservative radio host who defended Donald J. Trumps proposal to bar Muslim immigrants, took issue with the real-estate developer on Monday for his attacks on Senator Ted Cruz of Texas as a maniac for how he has battled with the Republican Senate leadership.

title: Dudamel Conducts Some Music for New Star Wars Film
description: Gustavo Dudamel is now a Jedi maestro.

title: In New Tack in Gun Debate, a Call to Investigate Smith & Wessons Disclosures
description: The New York City public advocate on Monday asked federal regulators to investigate whether the gun manufacturer Smith & Wesson had made adequate disclosures in its financial statements.

title: Oil Exports and Renewable Energy
description: If Congress decides to change a 40-year-old law that restricts the export of crude oil, as is likely this week, that move must be accompanied by measures like tax credits for renewable energy to help in the fight against climate change.

title: The Paris Climate Pact Will Need Strong Follow-Up
description: Paris is over. The cheering and high-fiving have died down. Now comes the hard part.

title: Silence on the Climate Pact From the Republican Candidates
description: One can describe the 2016 Republican presidential candidates in many ways, but silent is seldom one of them. Yet after 195 nations agreed on Saturday to reduce the greenhouse gas emissions that cause climate change, the Republican field remained nearly mum.

title: Court Documents in Redstone Case
description: Manuela Herzer, the former companion of Sumner M. Redstone, claimed that Mr. Redstones signature had been forged on a November document, and provided testimony from a handwriting expert in a filing with the Los Angeles County Superior Court.

title: In Petition, Sumner Redstones Former Companion Takes Aim at Viacom Chief
description: A former companion of the 92-year-old media mogul Sumner M. Redstone, who is challenging Mr. Redstones mental competence, claimed in a legal filing that a declaration provided to the court by the chief executive of Viacom was riddled with falsehoods. The declaration stated that Mr. Redstone was engaged and attentive.

title: Iran: Smog Envelops Tehran
description: Intense smog shrouded the metropolitan area of Irans capital, Tehran, on Monday in what local health authorities called the worst air pollution in months. They warned all residents of the area  roughly 14 million people  to stay indoors if possible because of the poor air quality. The semiofficial Tasnim News Agency said air contaminants were seven times the maximum level recommended by the World Health Organization. Air pollution is a chronic issue in Tehran, which is surrounded by mountains that trap atmospheric pollutants. Exhaust fumes from vehicles account for most of the problem, which typically worsens in colder weather.

title: 5% of Sothebys Workers Take Buyouts
description: The auction house Sothebys has accepted the buyouts of 80 employees, or 5 percent of its 1,600-person global work force, the company reported in records filed on Monday with the Securities and Exchange Commission.

title: Tracking of Jonathan Pollard, a Paroled Spy, Requires More Explanation, Judge Says
description: The United States Parole Commission was ordered on Monday to provide a fuller explanation of its reasons for electronically tracking the movements of the convicted spy Jonathan L. Pollard, and for monitoring his computers at work and at home.

title: Giants, Rearming for Title Run, Sign Johnny Cueto
description: While the San Francisco Giants took their annual odd-year break from the World Series, Johnny Cueto showed up there with the Kansas City Royals. Cueto, a former All-Star right-hander, twirled a two-hit complete-game victory over the Mets in Game 2.

title: Low Natural Gas Prices Squeeze Industry and Fell a C.E.O.
description: HOUSTON  Plummeting oil and natural gas prices have whipsawed the energy industry, forcing cancellations of billions of dollars of projects, late payments on loans, and over a quarter of a million layoffs worldwide.

title: Russian Pianist Receives First Cage Cunningham Fellowship
description: The Baryshnikov Arts Center announced Monday night that it had raised $1 million to establish a new Cage Cunningham Fellowship, and that the first recipient would be the Russian pianist Alexei Lubimov, who plans to use his award to commission new works.

title: Phil Pepe, Longtime New York Sportswriter, Dies at 80
description: Phil Pepe, a popular New York sportswriter who covered the Yankees for city newspapers, delivered radio commentary and wrote dozens of books with, and about, major league stars, died on Sunday at his home in Englewood, N.J. He was 80.

title: Reporters in Las Vegas Try to Crack Case of Who Owns Their Newspaper
description: Journalists at The Las Vegas Review-Journal described the newsroom as somber and confused on Monday, as a seemingly simple question remained unanswered: Who bought the newspaper for $140 million in cash last week?

title: As Health Care Act Insurance Deadline Nears, Unprecedented Demand
description: WASHINGTON  Milwaukee, Detroit and Philadelphia have done the best among 20 cities competing to sign up people for health insurance under the Affordable Care Act, while Dallas, Denver and Las Vegas are lagging, the White House said Monday ahead of Tuesdays deadline to enroll for coverage that takes effect on Jan. 1.

title: Diagnosing Yahoos Ills: Ugly Math in Marissa Mayers Reign
description: Lets do some basic math about Yahoo since Marissa Mayer took the helm over three years ago.

title: Congress Inches Toward Completed Spending Bill
description: WASHINGTON  Congressional negotiators worked Monday night to complete a $1.1 trillion spending bill for 2016, and an accompanying package of up to $750 billion in tax breaks for businesses and low-income workers.

title: Maryland Man Accused of Tapping Money From ISIS Operatives for a U.S. Attack
description: WASHINGTON  A Maryland man received at least $8,700 from Islamic State operatives overseas and planned to use the money to launch an attack in the United States as part of a pledge of loyalty to the militant group, prosecutors said on Monday.

title: N.B.A. Referee Who Was Target of Rondos Slur Says He Is Gay
description: An N.B.A. referee disclosed in a statement to Yahoo Sports that he is gay after Rajon Rondo, a Sacramento Kings guard, directed what the league called a derogatory and offensive term at him during a game this month.

title: Puerto Ricos Embattled Governor Says He Wont Run for 2nd Term
description: MIAMI  With Puerto Ricos debt-ridden economy still in crisis and his administration mired in scandal, Alejandro Garca Padilla, the islands embattled governor, announced on Monday that he would not seek re-election in 2016.

title: At Republican Debate, Candidates Are Likely to Set Sights on Ted Cruz
description: WASHINGTON  In the five weeks since the last Republican presidential debate, terrorists have struck in Paris and San Bernardino, Calif., Donald J. Trump has proposed barring Muslims from coming to America, Ben Carsons support has evaporated and Senator Ted Cruz of Texas has emerged as Mr. Trumps stiffest competition. Senator Marco Rubio of Florida has gone on the attack against Mr. Cruz, and Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey, who has less money than many senators up for re-election, has shown signs of life, at least in New Hampshire.

title: Jaroslav Halak and Thomas Greiss, a Dependable Goalie Tandem, Lift the Islanders
description: SYOSSET, N.Y.  The Islanders are winning in every possible manner of late, with points in 10 straight games, including eight victories: four in regulation, three in shootouts and one in a three-on-three overtime. Goaltenders Jaroslav Halak and Thomas Greiss have helped drive the teams climb up the standings.

title: Bernie Sanders Urges Cuomo to Raise CUNY Professors Pay
description: While the rest of the presidential field was talking about how to confront global terrorism, Senator Bernie Sanders in recent days had a very local issue on his mind: getting a raise for professors at the City University of New York.

title: Review: In MotherStruck! Staceyann Chin Chronicles Her Quest to Become Pregnant
description: Sometimes it feels like Ive spent my entire life terrified of getting pregnant, says Staceyann Chin at the top of her solo show MotherStruck! Born in Jamaica, Ms. Chin grew up in fear of becoming a statistic like her mother: young and pregnant, with no father to help support her child. But the subject of this engaging and often funny stage memoir, which opened on Monday at the Culture Project, is not, in fact, Ms. Chins valiant efforts to stave off motherhood, but her increasingly strong desire for, and her difficulty in, actually achieving it.

title: Review: In Marjorie Prime, Lois Smith Connects With the Past
description: Try to remember. Its never as easy it sounds, recalling something  anything  especially as the brain ages, and the past covers more and more years. We edit, we distort, we censor; we select, we discard, we reshape, until memory becomes myth.

title: Moves Like a Buoy in the Ocean
description: TUESDAY PUZZLE  This one tickled me, perhaps because I wasnt expecting such a fun theme and rocking fill this early in the week. Just goes to show you that you never know what Will Shortz has up his sleeve.

title: Hudsons Bay Is Said to Consider Buying Gilt Groupe for $250 Million
description: Gilt Groupe, a onetime darling of online fashion sales, is nearing a deal to sell itself  albeit at a steep discount to its once lofty valuation.

title: Evelyn Lieberman, 71, Dies; Aide Moved Lewinsky From White House
description: Evelyn Lieberman, who as the first woman to serve as deputy chief of staff to a president grew concerned about the behavior of the junior aide Monica S. Lewinsky around Bill Clinton and banished her to a job outside the White House, died on Saturday in Washington. She was 71.

title: Mass Evacuations Conducted as Typhoon Hits Philippines
description: MANILA  The Philippines conducted one of the largest mass evacuations in its recent history in preparation for Typhoon Melor, which roared through the storm-scarred central islands of the country on Tuesday, leaving floods, debris and widespread blackouts in its wake.

title: Fargo Season 2 Finale: No More Schnitzel
description: And here ya are, and its a beautiful day.

title: Woman Found Dead in Brooklyn Was Murdered, Police Say
description: More than a month after an 82-year-old woman was found dead on the kitchen floor of her Brooklyn apartment, the police said on Monday that she had been murdered.

title: China Is Leading Jailer of Journalists, Group Says
description: China was the biggest jailer of journalists in 2015 for the second consecutive year, and the number imprisoned in Egypt and Turkey also rose sharply compared with 2014, a free-press advocacy group that monitors journalist incarcerations said in an annual report released on Tuesday.

title: Word of the Day + Quiz | quibble
description: quibble  \kwi-bl\  verb and noun

title: New York City Cracking Down on Drivers Near Senior Centers

title: The Experts Were Wrong About the Best Places for Better and Cheaper Health Care
description: Do areas that spend less on Medicare also spend less on health care over all? A new study is forcing experts to rethink what they know about health costs.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: I feel like the past two months have probably been the hardest of my life.

title: Corrections: December 15, 2015
description: NATIONAL

title: In China, Diners Pay for Clean Air With Their Entree
description: BEIJING  Has clean air become such a luxury in China that restaurants can charge patrons for it?

title: Donald Trump Touches on Issues, and Poll Numbers, in Las Vegas
description: LAS VEGAS  Donald J. Trump kept his focus on multiple polls showing him leading the Republican presidential race while talking at length on Monday about immigration and the countrys economy during a speech before thousands of people.

title: Documenting Rape in India
description: At night, vivid memories of sexual abuse haunt Smita Sharmas dreams. During the day, they motivate her to document the stories of rape victims in India.

title: Gu Kailai, Wife of Fallen Chinese Official, Is Given Life Sentence
description: HONG KONG  A Beijing court has commuted to life in prison the suspended death sentence given to Gu Kailai, the wife of one of Chinas most prominent politicians, for the murder of a British business associate, according to the Chinese state-run news media.

title: The Year of Unearthed Memories
description: Childhood fears and adult traumas are stored differently in the brain than happy memories. They are buried like porous capsules deep in the primitive regions, below awareness and beyond easy reach of conscious thinking and talking. They are buried so deep that they are separated from the normal flow of life, and so time cannot work its natural healing powers.

title: What Would It Take to Integrate Our Schools?
description: EVEN though we may believe that separate but equal public schools are inherently unequal, we havent been prepared to do much about it. In recent years, weve rarely even talked about it.

title: Fixing Fannie and Freddie for Good
description: IN the longstanding debate about what should be done to overhaul Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac, the mortgage behemoths that taxpayers rescued at the height of the financial crisis, a growing number of groups, including several hedge funds and other investors, as well as civil rights groups and consumer advocates, are offering a surprising answer: Go back to the very system we just bailed out.

title: Are You Eating Frankenfish?
description: THIS month, Congress may decide whether consumers are smart enough to be trusted with their own food choices. Some lawmakers are trying to insert language into must-pass spending legislation that would block states from giving consumers the right to know whether their food contains genetically modified ingredients.

title: Is It Ted Cruzs Party  Or Marco Rubios?
description: The most interesting fight brewing in the Republican primary isnt between Donald J. Trump and the rest of the world, but between Ted Cruz and Marco Rubio, wunderkind vs. wunderkind. One is ruthless in his appeals to the Republican base, poised to ride its anger to victory, as Tea Party candidates did before him; the other is attractive to the establishment wing of the party, with the potential to draw in moderate voters, but who is sputtering in early primary states.

title: Are Americans Fears Legitimate?
How Donald Trump Could Win, and Why He Probably Wont
description: Despite controversy after controversy, Donald Trump still dominates the polls. With his seemingly impervious lead, it is tempting to declare that he is a clear front-runner for the nomination.

title: Got First-World Problems? Dont Feel Guilty.
description: At the beginning of a recent session, my client Keith seemed reluctant to start. He usually jumps right in, overflowing with thoughts and feelings from the past week. That day he was uncharacteristically reticent. After a minute or two of silence, he said, This probably sounds like a first-world problem, but

title: Advanced Semiconductor Engineering Keeps Up Pursuit of Taiwan Rival
description: HONG KONG  Advanced Semiconductor Engineering, a Taiwanese company that assembles and tests chips, is not giving up its multibillion-dollar pursuit of its local competitor, Siliconware Precision Industries.

title: Europe Approves Tough New Data Protection Rules
description: European officials approved long-awaited data protection regulations on Tuesday, the latest effort in the region to give people a greater say over how their digital information is collected and managed.

title: The Donald and the Chump Factor
description: I suppose there are still some people waiting for Trumps bubble to burst  any day now! But it keeps not happening. And its becoming increasingly plausible that he will go all the way. Why?

title: Verbatim: Follow the Chicken
description: In this dramatization of transcripts from a legal deposition, lawyers grapple with a plaintiffs bizarre testimony about the destruction of his chickens pasture.

title: Verbatim: Follow the Chicken
description: As I research legal transcripts for the Op-Doc video series Verbatim, I search for unusually worded arguments and objections that tell us something about our judicial process. The transcript dramatized for this latest episode hooked me when I read how a plaintiff explained himself to a roomful of captive lawyers, telling them simply: Because I follow the chicken.

title: News Qs | Twitters Top Hashtags, Tweets and Users for 2015
description: Before Reading Twitters Top Hashtags, Tweets and Users for 2015:

title: Do You Get Enough Exercise?
description: Teenagers have a reputation for just hanging around, whether with friends or screens or both, without doing all that much physical activity. A new study says that most adolescents arent getting enough exercise, even during the school day.

title: Holiday Updos for Tricky Hair
description: Three festive styles you can do even if you think your hair is too fine, short or curly.

title: Where the Candidates Stand on 2016s Biggest Issues
description: See what the candidates are saying about gun control, immigration and more, and how their positions align with the American people.

title: Star Wars: The Force Awakens Has World Premiere, No Expense Spared
description: LOS ANGELES  A veritable army of security guards, publicists and event staffers. Quadruple the typical number of invited guests. A lavish after-party, replete with Stormtroopers and a roaming Chewbacca, stretching for four city blocks.

title: Modi Rival Denounces Raid at Delhi State Government Headquarters
description: NEW DELHI  A longtime political rivalry in India heated up on Tuesday when federal officials raided the offices of the Delhi State government and the states chief minister, Arvind Kejriwal, reacted with fury, calling Prime Minister Narendra Modi a coward and a psychopath.

title: European Drug Makers Sanofi and Boehringer Ingelheim in Talks
description: LONDON  The French pharmaceutical company Sanofi and the German drug maker Boehringer Ingelheim said on Tuesday that they were in exclusive negotiations on a potential asset swap that would make Sanofi one of the worlds largest manufacturers of nonprescription medicines.

title: General Electric to Sell Commercial Lending Business in Japan
description: HONG KONG  General Electric agreed on Tuesday to sell its commercial lending business in Japan to Sumitomo Mitsui Finance and Leasing, one of Japans largest leasing companies, for 575 billion yen, or about $4.8 billion.

title: All Things Being Unequal
description: President Obama calls economic inequality the defining challenge of our time. Pope Francis tells us that today we also have to say thou shall not to an economy of exclusion and inequality. The French economist Thomas Piketty writes a nearly 700-page book for Harvard University Press about long-term trends in inequality and, in the wake of the Occupy movement, is rewarded with a surprise best seller. Mitt Romney, of all people, now complains that income inequality has gotten worse. Economic inequality is bad. Everybody thinks so.

title: Your Tuesday Briefing
description: Heres what you need to know to start your day.

title: Ask Well: How Often Should You Get Dental X-Rays?
description: Question:

title: Your Tuesday Briefing: Republican Debate, Bowe Bergdahl, Pete Rose
description: (Want to get this briefing by email? Heres the sign-up.)

title: Hangry? Want a Slice of Piecaken? The Top New Food Words for 2015
description: The language of food is changing at breakneck speed to reflect new menus, new mash-ups, new diets, new hashtags.

title: Hillary Clinton to Unveil Counterterrorism Strategy
description: In the weeks since the Dec. 2 attack in San Bernardino, Calif., Hillary Clinton has urged tolerance toward Muslims and reiterated her calls for increased gun control measures. What she has not done is speak extensively about what she would do to stop a terrorist attack in the United States.

title: New York Today: Our Person of the Year
description: Updated 11:23 a.m.

title: Yemen Agrees to Cease-Fire With Rebels as Peace Talks Begin
description: GENEVA  The Yemeni government and Houthi rebels called an immediate halt to hostilities on Tuesday as they started peace talks mediated by a United Nations special envoy at an undisclosed location in Switzerland, a United Nations spokesman confirmed.

title: Morning Agenda: Diagnosing Yahoos Ills
description: DIAGNOSING YAHOOS ILLS  | Over the weekend, Eric Jackson, who runs a small hedge fund called SpringOwl Asset Management and has long railed against the Yahoos missteps, sent a presentation to the board. The figures in it listed the billions spent on acquisitions of unknown companies, stock buybacks, compensation, free food and parties.

title: Ben Carsons Threat to Leave G.O.P. Packs Less Punch Than Donald Trumps
description: Republicans are gathering to debate on Tuesday with an unpleasant question lingering in the background: whether, in the long run, they will all remain Republicans.

title: PR Newswire Sold to Cision for $841 Million
description: LONDON  UBM, the British business-events organizer, said on Tuesday that it had agreed to sell the news-release distribution service PR Newswire to Cision, the owner of Gorkana Group, for $841 million.

title: House Armed Services Committee to Ban Cameras From Witnesses Feet
description: Its an iconic moment at any big congressional hearing  witnesses take their seats to testify and the whir from the cameras of photographers seated on the floor between the witness table and the committee dais confirms that the moment has been captured for posterity.

title: Aveva and Schneider Electric Terminate Plans for Complex Deal
description: LONDON  The British engineering company Aveva Group said on Tuesday that it had walked away from a complex deal with Schneider Electric that would have seen the French industrial group take a majority stake in the company.

title: AMC Entertainment Names Adam Aron Chief Executive
description: LOS ANGELES  AMC Entertainment Holdings, which operates the AMC Theaters movie theater chain, named Adam M. Aron president and chief executive on Tuesday, filling a post vacated by Gerardo I. Lopez in July.

title: Rebuilding the Middle Class the Army Way
description: A few weeks ago, I was sitting in a classroom at the United States Army War College in Carlisle, Pa. There were 16 students, all in their early 40s and most of them lieutenant colonels, who had been selected to spend a year in this rural, peaceful place learning how to think strategically about war. In modern business, thinking strategically has become a clich entirely devoid of meaning. But in the military, its meaning remains quite precise. As one person in the class told me, as a lieutenant colonel in a tank battalion, he was engaged in tactics: making sure that his tankers and their tanks were ready to fight. As a colonel, he would be concerned with strategy: advising on which enemies those tanks should engage and how.

title: Whos Really Radical?
description: For the last couple of centuries, the word radical referred to people who try to pull things up from the root. After the Civil War, Radical Republicans, as they were called, pushed Reconstruction policies through Congress on behalf of freed slaves, trying to tear down the plantation-based power structure of the antebellum South. Eugene Debs, the most prominent socialist of the early 20th century (and a hero to Bernie Sanders), ran for president five times on what was seen as a radical platform of condemning capitalist oppression.

title: Theres Joy in Working Together Again
description: Anticipation is understandably high for David O. Russells new film, Joy, about the late-blooming brainiac inventor of the dazzlingly successful Miracle Mop, and later those skinny velvet hangers. Once again, Mr. Russell rounded up his team of A-list players. Jennifer Lawrence plays the titular Joy Mangano, Robert De Niro portrays her father, and Bradley Cooper is an executive at QVC, the television-shopping network where Joy peddled her wares. The film, which opens on Christmas, traces Joys decades-long journey, from a precocious girl in the 1960s to a disgruntled housewife in the 1970s to a steely entrepreneur in the 1990s, surmounting financial woes, con artists and her meddlesome Greek chorus of a family.

title: Has Europe Reached the Breaking Point?
description: A few weeks ago, I visited the fence that made Hungary a symbol of European anxiety. Chain-link and razor wire, it slices through pastures as it traces Hungarys southern border. More than 100 miles long, it was constructed quickly this summer as refugees streamed into the country, heading toward Austria and Germany. Police officers and soldiers were stationed every few hundred yards, and they examined my passport at almost every checkpoint. They seemed bored, perhaps because the flood of refugees and migrants had mostly abated. The fence had sealed Hungary off, and that made Laszlo Toroczkai  the 37-year-old mayor of Asotthalom, a Hungarian farming town on the Serbian border, and a rising ultranationalist star of far-right European politics  very happy.

title: Poll Watch: Donald Trumps Supporters Are Not a Happy Bunch
description: Supporters of Donald J. Trump expressed two clear sentiments in the latest New York Times/CBS News poll: anger about the way things are going in Washington, and excitement about what Mr. Trump would do as president.

title: In Crucial Republican Bout, 2 Names Will Take the Middle of the Ring
description: Tonight is the last Republican presidential debate of 2015, and possibly the most consequential.

title: Cartoon: Saudi Arabian Roadblock
description: A snails pace on womens rights.

title: Qualcomm Concludes a Split Would Be Detrimental
description: Qualcomm has a message for its shareholders: Breaking up is hard to do. And in the opinion of the companys top management, it is less profitable than staying together.

title: 1940: Bermuda Defense Bastion
description: American military authorities are losing no time in pushing ahead the development of the new United States base at Bermuda. Already United States Army engineers are in the field, making a thorough survey so that construction may start within three months. Bermuda, long recognized as a paradise for American tourists, a blissful haven for wedding trips and a peaceful place never touched by actual warfare, suddenly has become one of the most important links in a chain of military bases reaching from Newfoundland to South America.New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, December 16, 1940

title: The Weekly News Quiz Is on a Short Break, but We Have a Challenge for You Instead
description: Our Weekly News Quiz is on hiatus until Jan. 5, and were running a special Farewell, 2015 Quiz in its place.

title: U.S. Navy Commander Implies China Has Eroded Safety of South China Sea
description: BEIJING  A senior American naval commander has implicitly accused China of creating so-called military zones close to artificial islands it has built in the South China Sea, declaring that such actions are eroding the security of one of the worlds busiest waterways.

title: Big Short Gains Awards Momentum but a Big Test Nears
description: The Oscar-aspiring The Big Short, a star-studded mortgage crisis comedic thriller (you probably wont ever see those words together again), opened gangbusters this weekend, averaging $90,000 per screen. Mind you, as Variety has noted, the film was only on eight screens, and Steve Jobs opened auspiciously, too, taking in $130,000 per screen in four theaters before tanking.

title: How an M.L.B. Tour of Cuba Went From a Dream to Reality
description: After Yoenis Cespedes won the Home Run Derby at the 2013 All-Star Game, he was given the opportunity to direct a charitable donation to an organization of his choosing. Cespedes immediately thought of Cuba, the country he fled in 2011, but he was not sure how to proceed. So he asked Leonor Colon, an official with the players union, for guidance.

title: Jacobs Pillow Announces 2016 Season
description: Dormeshia Sumbry-Edwards, Derick K. Grant and Jason Samuels Smith will explore the legacy of tap dance. Wendy Whelan will team up again with Brian Brooks for an evening of new solos and duets to music played by Brooklyn Rider. And troupes from around the world  including the Bereishit Dance Company of South Korea, Che Malambo of Argentina and Compagnie Herv Koubi of France  will come to the Berkshires to dance.

title: Tangled Passages
description: Long, complicated sentences can be off-putting to hurried readers, especially those reading on small screens. Of course we want to convey complex ideas, with layers of nuance, background and qualification  but we dont have to do it all in a single sentence. Whats more, overstuffed sentences are far more likely to run off the grammatical rails.

title: A New Emphasis on Fact-Checking in Real Time
description: Heres what makes readers justifiably crazy: false statements in news articles that are allowed to go unchallenged.

title: Obama Counters Anti-Muslim Talk by Welcoming New Citizens
description: WASHINGTON  Standing in a room with the original Constitution, Declaration of Independence and Bill of Rights, President Obama on Tuesday declared that the United States should never give in to fear but should continue to welcome immigrants and refugees because thats who we are.

title: A Solution for Awful N.F.L. Officiating? Simplify the Rules
description: Officiating gaffes continue to be a story line of the 2015 N.F.L. season, and the problem is not just human error.

title: Who Is a Muslim?
description: WASHINGTON  Donald J. Trumps scandalous proposal that the United States bar entry to all Muslims  though he later clarified his view that American citizens and a few others might be allowed in  raises two fundamental but largely unaddressed questions: Who and what is a Muslim?

title: Brazils Students Occupy Their Schools to Save Them
description: So Paulo, Brazil  Brazils economy, a huge corruption scandal at a state-owned oil company and, more recently, impeachment proceedings against President Dilma Rousseff have dominated the news about this country recently. But its another crisis in the state of So Paulo that has the potential to shape democracy in the country for years to come. Thats because this crisis  a huge protest in response to the states plan to close 94 public schools  involves some of the countrys youngest citizens: elementary, middle and high school students.

title: The Traveling Old-Fashioned Glasses
description: Dear Diary:

title: In North Carolina, a Town to Lift a Fork or Turn a Page
description: On the surface, theres not much to suggest there would be anything special about the central North Carolina town of Hillsborough, population around 6,000, northwest of the Research Triangle, as the area encompassing Raleigh, Durham and Chapel Hill is called. Its downtown business district, a handful of low-slung brick buildings, peters out after a block or two in any direction. After that, the space between homes quickly grows, and rural surroundings take over.

title: Airports: The Unlikely New Scene of Pop-Ups and Parties
description: For Allison Reeves, a 34-year-old actor based in Hollywood, Calif., a trip to the airport is something she dreads. I hate, hate, hate flying, she said. So she was surprised when she actually had fun at Kennedy International Airport after Thanksgiving.

title: Germany Arrests Islamic Extremist Suspected of Aiding Terrorist Groups
description: The German authorities on Tuesday detained one of the countrys most active Islamic extremists, who once tried to open a school supported by a network called Invitation to Paradise, on four counts of supporting a terrorist organization, federal prosecutors said.

title: Basketballs Birth, in James Naismiths Own Spoken Words
description: James Naismith, basketballs inventor, arrived in New York City in early 1939 with three items on his agenda.

title: Howard Stern and SiriusXM Sign New Deal for 5 Years
description: A decade ago, Howard Stern surprised the media world by leaving terrestrial radio  where he had a huge audience but faced constant headaches over censorship issues  for the relatively new and unproven world of satellite radio.

title: What to Watch Tuesday
description: Linda Ellerbee, who explained the birds and the bees and everything in between to a generation of children, bids farewell. The finalists on The Voice sing their hearts out. And a South Korean homicide detective has a very bad day.

title: Trading Sags 36% at Jefferies Group
description: Jefferies Group said on Tuesday that its sales and trading revenue fell 36 in the fourth quarter, dealing a blow to its results.

title: Mass Shootings Add Anxiety to Movie Theater Visits
description: As she sat down with her 8-year-old daughter recently in an Oakland, Calif., theater for a matinee of The Peanuts Movie, Denise Simard, 44, was surprised by her own paranoia.

title: NATO Nations No Longer Question Need for Alliance
description: LONDON  NATO is the alliance that keeps finding reasons to exist, to the surprise of some and the annoyance of Moscow.

title: Daily Report: Rules for Registering Your Drone
description: The Federal Aviation Administration on Monday laid out new registration requirements for owners of recreational drones, just in time for Christmas. The rules apply to Americans with a drone weighing between half a pound and 55 pounds  which means nearly all recreational drones.

title: Dividing the Screen in Mac OS X
description: Q. How do you turn on the split-screen mode in the new Mac system?

title: Related Companies Raises $1 Billion for Real Estate Fund
description: A few years after the recession, Related Companies  the real estate firm behind New York landmarks like Time Warner Center and Hudson Yards  started a fund to invest in distressed properties and refurbish them to sell at a higher price.

title: Britain Prunes Silly Laws on Salmon Handling and Armor Wearing
description: LONDON  It is not a great idea to carry a plank of wood down a busy sidewalk. Nor should you ride a horse while drunk, or handle a salmon under suspicious circumstances.

title: A Conservative Islam For a Liberal Society
description: My Sunday column, on Islams future in the West,tried to imagine how Western debates about faith in a pluralist society look to a devout Muslim trying to imagine how his religion might modernize and moderate without dissolvingits essentials in a relativizing/secularizing sea. At the end, I tentatively suggestedthat American evangelicalism and Mormonismoffer interesting models for a conservative Islams futurein the liberal order: The analogy in both cases is necessarily theologically inapt, but thedistinctive balances that American evangelicals and Mormons have struck between assimilation and self-segregation, between ecumenism and proselytization, between adapting to egalitarian norms and maintaining forms of hierarchy and patriarchy, all have relevance towhat lies ahead for Islam in the West.

title: E.U. Pushes to Take Over Border Security at Migrant Crossings
description: BRUSSELS  European Union authorities on Tuesday proposed taking control of border and coastal security at entry points for migrants in countries like Greece and Italy, to get a grip on a crisis that has divided the bloc and fed the rise of populist political movements.

title: The Best Songs of 2015
description: The music critics of The New York Times share their picks for the best songs of the year.

title: 1965: Peking A-Missile Peril to World
description: PARIS  Secretary of Defense Robert S. McNamara said today [Dec. 15] that Communist China will probably be able to hit cities such as San Francisco and Berlin with nuclear missiles within ten years. Mr. McNamara, in a speech to the semi-annual NATO Council meeting, said Peking would have enough fissionable material by 1967 to start producing and test-firing medium-range nuclear missiles. By 1975, he said, they would probably have operable long-range missiles. He suggested, however, implicitly, that NATO should enlarge itself into a world-wide police force to withstand Chinese aggression. New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, December 16, 1965

title: Fantastic Beasts and Where to Find Them Trailer is Released
description: Lumos maxima. With the words from that incantation, a trailer, and potentially a new franchise, begins. The first look at Fantastic Beasts and Where to Find Them, the spinoff film from the Harry Potter series, was released on Tuesday.

title: Ex-Washington Mayor Avoids Charges, but Bitterness Lingers
description: WASHINGTON  In this city of poorly kept secrets and sometimes stranger-than-fiction schemes, the identity of mayoral Candidate A, as he was formally known in a far-reaching political corruption investigation, was not even briefly a mystery. Candidate A was Mayor Vincent C. Gray.

title: Life on Mars by Way of Hawaii: Q. and A.
description: On a rocky, sloping terrain near the Mauna Loa volcano in Hawaii, Christiane Heinicke, a 30-year-old German physicist and engineer, is one of six researchers conducting a yearlong simulation of life on Mars.

title: Los Angeles and New York Differ in Their Responses to a Terrorism Threat
description: LOS ANGELES  The nations two largest school systems confronted threats of a terrorist attack on Tuesday and reacted in sharply different ways: New York City reviewed the warning and dismissed it as a hoax, but officials here abruptly shut down all public schools, upending the lives of parents, students and teachers.

title: 2 Dead Children Found in Storage Unit in Northern California
description: Police officers in Northern California who were investigating a case of torture and abuse of a child this week found the bodies of two children inside a storage unit.

title: Giants Brush Themselves Off, Still Looking to Contend
description: Chasing after a sideline pass in Monday nights game with the Miami Dolphins, Giants cornerback Dominique Rodgers-Cromartie could not hold up as the play ended and his momentum carried him full speed into his teams bench area. In an instant, the fully-padded Rodgers-Cromartie crashed into Tom Coughlin, propelling the 69-year-old Giants coach in a violent backward tumble.

title: Holidays, Uncertainty and the Extended Foster Family
description: Auntie Meghan?

title: What Happens When Mother Earth Gets Angry
description: The momentous climate accord reached last weekend in Paris recognizes three powerful and unyielding economic and ecological trends. These were prompted by the collision of the resource-abundant development approach of the 20th century with the increasingly dire environmental conditions of the 21st.

title: Prison Diversion Programs in New York Face New Scrutiny After Police Officers Killing
description: On May 6, 2013, Darrell Wright was caught with a handgun in Brooklyn, his first arrest. He was 16, and prosecutors diverted him from jail into a program intended to provide young people with a pathway out of gang life.

title: Focusing on Leadership as Marine Corps Mandate to Integrate Women in Combat Units Nears
description: Fourteen years ago, when I was a midshipman at Marine Corps Officer Candidates School, our female sergeant instructor lined us up at attention. If youre a woman in the Marine Corps, she said, youre either a bitch, a dyke, or a ho. Shocking? Perhaps.
