But she decided to participate in the film Bolshoi Babylon because after watching the filmmakers Nick Read and Mark Franchetti work, she felt she could trust them. In the documentary, she fights her way back from an injury and speaks bluntly about the state of the Bolshoi after the 2013 acid attack on its artistic director, Sergei Filin. In advance of the films HBO release, Ms. Alexandrova spoke from Moscow through a translator. Here are edited excerpts from the conversation.

title: Anastasia Meskova on the Bolshoi: I Was in the Middle
description: Anastasia Meskova isnt your ordinary Bolshoi ballerina. A first soloist, Ms. Meskova is a single mother  her son will turn 10 in January  and has a parallel career as an actress. (She appears on a Russian drama series.) In the documentary Bolshoi Babylon, which explores the state of the Bolshoi after the 2013 acid attack on Sergei Filin, she explains that she works in the Bolshoi, but not the one that she dreamed of. Lets hope, she says, its a sickness that will pass. Ms. Meskova spoke about the film, through a translator, from Moscow. Here are edited excerpts from the conversation.

title: Spains Enigmatic Leader Faces New Generation in Election
description: MADRID  In their first debate before Sundays national election, the leaders of Spains four main political parties each took their places on stage, with one exception.

title: The Knicks Needed a Hero. Enter Kristaps Porzingis.
description: In the run-up to Christmas, Kristaps Porzingis, the 20-year-old forward for the New York Knicks, spent an evening signing basketballs and T-shirts at the Brazen Fox pub in White Plains. For 90 minutes, dozens of people  mostly young men in blue-and-orange Knicks gear  approached him and shyly introduced themselves with the same excited greeting: Yo, K.P.! Many of them asked Porzingis, who is 7-foot-3, if he would mind standing up before they took their photographs and selfies. What one learns in such a situation is that there are not many ways to tell a man he is tall.

title: Scandals Web TripsPennsylvania Attorney General Kathleen Kane
description: HARRISBURG, Pa.  By themselves, the emails were arresting enough: videos, photographs, cartoons and jokes, some depicting sex acts; others mocking or demeaning blacks, gays, Muslims and even the poor and uneducated. But just as disturbing is where they were found: on Pennsylvania government computers, in email accounts whose owners included some of the states most powerful figures.

title: Three Reasons for Those Hefty College Tuition Bills
description: What should we do about the high cost of higher education? As we pick the next president, that question should feature prominently in the public debate. The economic prosperity of our children and grandchildren hinges on finding the right answer.

title: Serving Up a Raise in the Senate Cafeteria
description: In the three years since the Fight for $15 began with walkouts by fast-food workers in New York City, it has been taken up by workers in retail, home care and other low wage fields, by generally liberal cities that have lifted their minimum wages to $15 an hour or closer to it and by the Democratic presidential contenders Bernie Sanders and Martin OMalley.

title: 1965: De Gaulle Wins Second Term
description: PARIS  Charles de Gaulle, the most powerful French chief of state since Napoleon I, was reelected to a second term as president of the Fifth Republic yesterday [Dec. 18]. With more than 80 percent of the vote counted, the general led his leftist opponent, Franois Mitterrand, by a margin of 55 percent to 45. Gen. de Gaulles victory came in a runoff election, two weeks after he had failed to gain the absolute margin necessary for reelection against a field of five other candidates.

title: Where Health Care Is Better and Cheaper: Answers to 10 Questions
description: A recent article about the disparity between health care costs for Medicare vs. private insurance raised many reader questions. Here, we answer some.

title: What I Mean When I Say Chinook Salmon
description: Selected by Natasha Trethewey.

title: 12 Recipes for the Weekend
description: Sam Sifton emails readers of Cooking five days a week to talk about food and suggest recipes. That email also appears here. To receive it in your inbox, register here.

title: The Soft Power of Militant Jihad
description: Oslo  AFTER Abu Musab al-Zarqawi, the leader of Al Qaeda in Iraq, the predecessor to the Islamic State, reportedly beheaded the American hostage Nicholas Berg in 2004, he became known in jihadi circles as the Slaughterer. Few people in the West are aware that he also went by the nickname He Who Weeps a Lot. Mr. Zarqawi was known for weeping during prayer and when speaking about Muslim womens suffering under occupation.

title: Letters: Much About History
description: To the Editor:

title: Paperback Row
description: GUANTNAMO DIARY, by Mohamedou Ould Slahi. Edited by Larry Siems. (Back Bay/Little, Brown, $17.99.) Ten years ago, as an inmate in Guantnamo (where he is still held), Slahi began writing an exhaustive record of his detainment, starting with his 2001 arrest in Mauritania and including the dehumanizing torture and humiliating interrogations he has been subjected to. The resulting book was edited twice: Siems began his work only after the American government left the text rife with redactions.

title: Inside the List
description: Indefinable: Poetry doesnt hit the lists very often, but when it does, it can hit big. In 2015, Claudia Rankines Citizen stayed on the monthly race and civil rights list all year; its currently No.5. A hard-to-classify volume of prose poems, or lyrical essays, about daily encounters with racism  I wanted to replicate the sense of having these stories come at you, Rankine told The New Statesman  the book has also spent time on the paperback nonfiction list and, more counterintuitively, the monthly relationships list. (One place it hasnt appeared yet is the monthly politics list, although that may change now that a young woman in Illinois was spotted reading it at a Trump rally.) The people who compile the Times lists arent the only ones who have struggled to define Rankines book. Last winter, Citizen became the first title ever nominated for a National Book Critics Circle Award in two categories: A finalist in criticism, it won in poetry. So what is this book, exactly? And how does Rankine feel about efforts to pin it down? If we leave the structural hybridity of Citizen aside, she told me via email, I want to believe there is a recognized veracity of experience for the people categorizing the book. Each feels Citizen satisfies some truth or intention for their category. I am a poet, and I didnt fictionalize the accounts told to me or taken from my life or from the news; I simply submerged my thinking into the ethical loneliness (a phrase taken from the title of Jill Stauffers excellent book) that the sentences accumulated. The lyrical reflection of lives struggling to negotiate racism in our culture apparently feels authentic to many categories. That seems right. Then she quoted a line from Sentences and Paragraphs, by Gertrude Stein: Never ask any one what a sentence is or what it has been.

title: Editors Choice
description: TWAIN AND STANLEY ENTER PARADISE, by Oscar Hijuelos. (Grand Central, $28.) The final novel by Hijuelos, who died in 2013, is an imaginative though incomplete homage to the bond between two of the most famous men of the 19th century.

title: Cooking for Dunces
description: In his rave for John Kennedy Tooles A Confederacy of Dunces in the Book Review in 1980, Alan Friedman said the comic romp generates the city of New Orleans in hot, sharp, solid, ethnic detail. Much of that detail had to do with food. In the recently published A Confederacy of Dunces Cookbook, Cynthia LeJeune Nobles writes that its scenes unfold through clouds of doughnut sugar, rivers of Dixie 45 beer, tangles of spaghetti and mounds of empty erster (oyster) shells.

title: F.D.A. Proposes Ban on Indoor Tanning for Minors to Fight Skin Cancer
description: WASHINGTON  The Food and Drug Administration on Friday proposed barring everyone under 18 from using tanning beds, a sweeping move that medical experts say is a major step toward reducing the risk of skin cancer in the United States.

title: All American Boys, by Jason Reynolds and Brendan Kiely
description: RASHAD IS ABSENT AGAIN TODAY, cries the graffiti scrawled across the sidewalk in front of Springfield Central High School. It is both a reminder and a call to action. Rashad Butler, a 16-year-old junior R.O.T.C. member and young black man, is in the hospital after a white police officer assaulted him in a convenience store. Rashad had intended to pay for a bag of chips, but Officer Paul Galluzzo mistook him for a thief. Outraged at the injustice, Rashads fellow students rise up in protest.

title: Naughty Mabel, Lazy Dave and More
description: The suburban neighborhood where I grew up had leafy oak trees, manicured lawns and absolutely no fences. Which meant that I, walking to and from elementary school, had to traverse a terrifying half-mile of pet pooches free-ranging themselves from yard to yard, barking, drooling, tail-wagging and scaring the dickens out of me and my Barbie lunchbox.

title: Academy Narrows Foreign-Language Contenders to 9
description: Hungarys Son of Saul, a first feature set at Auschwitz during World War II, and the Franco-Turkish drama Mustang are among the nine films to make the short list for Oscar for best foreign-language film, the Academy announced Thursday.

title: Report Declares Gurlitt of Sound Mind in Leaving Art to Museum
description: BERLIN  A court-ordered report has found that the German art dealer Cornelius Gurlitt was of sound mind when he drew up a will leaving a collection of some 1,200 works to a Swiss museum, lawyers for a relative who has contested the validity of the will said Friday.

title: Popcast: Best Albums of 2015
description: Listen to this weeks podcast | Subscribe: iTunes | RSS | Stitcher| Audioboom

title: N.F.L. Week 15 Previews and Picks
description: Heres a look at the best games of N.F.L. Week 15, and who we think will win them.

title: List of Used Cars With Accident Avoidance Technologies
description: This list from Edmunds.com shows which vehicles from the 2012-14 model years had pre-collision avoidance systems, blind spot warnings and lane departure alerts. The list indicates which features were standard (S under Availability) or optional (O).

title: Katherine Carlyle, by Rupert Thomson
description: Toward the end of Frankenstein, Mary Shelleys mad scientist travels across Europe in pursuit of his monstrous creation. Guided by a slight clue, he tells us, I followed the windings of the Rhone, but vainly. His desire for revenge  and for closure  takes him across the Mediterranean and through Russia and Asia, to what may have felt like the very ends of the earth. The creature has purposely led him farther and farther astray: Sometimes, indeed, he left marks in writing on the barks of the trees, or cut in stone, that guided me, and instigated my fury. Of course, Dr. Victor Frankenstein ends up lost in the snow and ice of the distant north.

title: Gorsky, by Vesna Goldsworthy
description: Its a very clever idea: to update The Great Gatsby by making the bootlegger into a Russian arms-dealing billionaire and transplanting the action from Jazz Age New York to 21st-century London, a city increasingly shaped by global wealth. And yet the style of Vesna Goldsworthys first novel, Gorsky, owes less to F. Scott Fitzgerald than it does to one of his contemporaries, at least at the beginning. She circles her subject elegantly, like Ford Madox Ford in The Good Soldier, writing from the slant perspective of a curious, intelligent foreigner only half in love with Englishness.

title: How Much Car Do You Buy to Keep Your Teenager Safe?
description: So your teenager needs a car. Or maybe you need the teenager to have a car so you can get out of the chauffeuring business.

title: Bookshelf: Family Matters
description: New picture books include Mother Bruce and Mixed Me!

title: Ire Grows Over Marco Rubios Past on Immigration and His Campaign Tactics
description: WASHINGTON  Senator Marco Rubio made a big bet on an immigration overhaul that failed  and he has been running away from it since. Now his past is catching up with him, stoking old grievances from conservative rivals who are reopening one of the most vulnerable episodes in his past.

title: Inside The New York Times Book Review: From Movement to Mainstream
description: This week, Sam Tanenhaus discusses two new books about the history of American conservatism; Alexandra Alter has news from the publishing world; Lori Gottlieb talks about Courtney Jungs Lactivism; and Gregory Cowles has best-seller news. Pamela Paul is the host.

title: A Breakfast Casserole ThatsComfort Food at Sunrise
description: Because I grew up with bagels and lox as the centerpiece of every special-occasion brunch, the first breakfast casserole I encountered seemed exotic and exciting.

title: Inside The New York Times Book Review Podcast: From Movement to Mainstream
description: Listen to this weeks podcast | Subscribe: iTunes | Stitcher

title: Showing the Seams in Anomalisa
description: The directors Charlie Kaufman and Duke Johnson discuss the difficult work of bringing puppets to life in their stop-motion film.

title: Rwanda Votes on Extending Term of President Paul Kagame
description: NAIROBI, Kenya  Millions of Rwandans filed obediently into the polls on Friday in a constitutional referendum that seeks to extend President Paul Kagames tenure for potentially 19 more years.

title: Museum & Gallery Listings for Dec. 18-24
description: Museums and galleries are in Manhattan unless otherwise noted. Many institutions are closed on and around Christmas Day; see individual websites for schedule changes. Full reviews of recent art shows are at nytimes.com/art. A searchable guide to these and many other art shows is at nytimes.com/events.

title: Safyre Terry Has 430,000 Christmas Cards, but Arson Case Drags On
description: The story of Safyre Terry, a little girl who was badly burned when she and her relatives were the victims of a deadly arson attack in Schenectady, N.Y., has been so widely shared online that volunteers are busy helping her sort through over 430,000 Christmas cards and thousands of gifts.

title: Obama Discusses Difficulty of Detecting Terrorism at Year-End Conference
description: WASHINGTON  At the end of a week in which he has sought to demonstrate his commitment to fighting terrorism at home and abroad, President Obama on Friday acknowledged that some terrorist plots  such as those by a husband and wife or lone wolf  are difficult to detect and prevent.

title: F.H.A. Loans Preferred
description: About a year has passed since Fannie Mae introduced a mortgage program requiring only 3 percent down, an effort to put homeownership within reach of more first-time buyers. Freddie Mac introduced a similar option in March.

title: No Comment Necessary: Donald Trump Apparently Prefers Putin to Obama
description: Donald Trump is very pleased about the praise he got this week from Vladimir Putin  despite Mr. Putins questionable human-rights record.

title: Broadway Tax Benefit Approved by Congress
description: Congress on Friday approved a change in tax law sought by Broadway producers, who say it will encourage investment in commercial theater.

title: Comedy Listings for Dec. 18-24
description: For news about comedy, including critical commentary: nytimes.com/arts. A searchable guide to these and other shows is at nytimes.com/events.

title: How Santa Claus Ended Up on U.S. Militarys Radar
description: Sixty years ago this month, near the height of the Cold War, Col. Harry W. Shoup, the new chief of the combat operations center of the Continental Air Defense Command, or Conad, unwittingly started a Christmas tradition that continues to this day.

title: When White Diamonds Wont Cut It
description: IF there is a holiday gift almost guaranteed to make a recipient swoon with joy, it is a diamond. But while such stones remain appealing as jewelry, the value of certain colored diamonds has increased while traditional white diamonds have fallen.

title: American Fiction
description: GOLDEN AGEBy Jane Smiley443 pp. Knopf, $26.95.

title: Rick Moodys Hotels of North America
description: Reginald Edward Morse, the hero of Hotels of North America, Rick Moodys elaborate new skit of a novel, does get around. Milan, Spokane, London, Washington, Tulsa, Tuscaloosa, Cleveland, Des Moines, Chicago, Charlottesville: Hes crossed the deserts bare, man, hes breathed the mountain air, hes been everywhere. Morse is a motivational speaker, which accounts for his traveling, but he also moonlights as a reviewer for a website called RateYourLodging.com, which accounts for the way this novel is constructed: as a series of 37 hotel reviews. (One way we know were in a fictional universe: Morse suggests he is paid for posting his opinions online.) The hotels under review range from the Plaza in New York City (Morse, as a child, spent a night there in the early 1970s) to a Radisson in Waterbury, Conn. (an ideal place, he notes, for those in search of the loneliest night imaginable), to the Capri Whitestone in the Bronx, with its view of the Whitestone Bridge toll plaza and the overpowering reverberation of death in its communal bathroom.

title: A Just and Generous Nation: Abraham Lincoln and the Fight for American Opportunity
description: What would Lincoln do? Its the secular version of asking what would Jesus do  to which the answer tends to be: whatever Im doing, and you should be doing too. Theodore Roosevelt even kept a portrait of Abe on his desk so that when I am confronted with a great problem, I look up to that picture, and I do as I believe Lincoln would have done.

title: Beyond Measure: Rescuing an Overscheduled, Overtested, Underestimated Generation
description: In the thought-provoking Beyond Measure, Vicki Abeles offers a compelling set of arguments for reconsidering how we define success in American education and for radically altering the approach weve taken to get there. High grades, high test scores and admission to one of the nations elite colleges have long been embraced as symbols of excellence and, by extension, successful parenting. Abeles suggests that pursuit of this narrow form of success is actually harming children and families, and distorting our educational institutions. Her book is bound to be controversial, particularly to the education establishment  university presidents, the testing industry and the policy makers who support them. For many of them, Beyond Measure is likely to be regarded as a threat, if not downright subversive.

title: The Art of Grace, by Sarah L. Kaufman
description: The Art of Grace ... The Art of Grace. It is concerning when the title of a book has a wannabe whiff. Or is it just graceless me that smells it? But the alternative, in this case, is worse, and it is as precious and highfalutin as it sounds given that the author is not Thomas Aquinas or John Ruskin. It is a phrase that promotes its author as an arbiter of grace, a lofty perch indeed from which to view us mere clumsy mortals. And so, Sarah L. Kaufman, in her first book, sets the stakes perilously high, particularly since her subject is not exactly origami but grace, that fragile, exquisite, transient entity of unparalleled depth, breadth, complexity and profundity. She has taken on, perhaps to her credit, the Sisyphean task of persuading us to choose grace over ego and so revisits that epic battle where grace loses every time  though ego never wins. Such ambition! But why not? We are in can-do America, and the author, dance critic for The Washington Post for almost 20 years, has a Pulitzer Prize in her pocket.

title: Murder at a Remove
description: Why go through all the fuss and bother of committing murder when you can stalk your victims on the Internet and bully them into doing the deed themselves? Carol Jordan, the self-destructive but intensely interesting protagonist of SPLINTER THE SILENCE (Atlantic Monthly, $26) and other mysteries by Val McDermid, doesnt buy that explanation for the death of Jasmine Burton, a forceful advocate for women and children exploited by traffickers in the sex trade. The suicides of other outspoken feminists may reveal a pattern, but that still doesnt answer an important question: How could a pack of cyber-trolls persuade a strong, self-assured woman to take her own life?

title: Home Sales Around the New York Region
description: Information on sales in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

title: George W. Bush Tells Donors He Is Upbeat About Jeb Bushs Chances of Winning
description: Former President George W. Bush offered a holiday message of optimism and encouragement to donors on a private conference call with Jeb Bushs national finance team on Friday.

title: The Fashion News to Know This Week
description: Crazed and confused

title: A Prescription for Confusion: When to Take All Those Pills
description: Imagine that your doctor has prescribed you these medications, the researchers told the older adults, aged 55 to 74, who were participating in an experiment at several Chicago health centers.

title: Dance Listings for Dec. 18-24
description: Full reviews of recent dance performances: nytimes.com/dance. A searchable guide to these and other performances is at nytimes.com/events.

title: Syrias Not Funny. So Whats a Comic to Do?
description: NOTHING usually happens during a podcast where two comics sit around and have a meandering chat. Maybe thats what makes them so dreadful to listen to. Theyre very easy and fun for comedians like me to do, though. You dont have to focus or have clear opinions, you can just be like Oh yeah  I think I do remember that commercial, ha-ha, and then tell the host how many siblings you have.

title: Martin Shkreli Resigns From Turing Pharmaceuticals
description: Martin Shkreli has resigned as chief executive of Turing Pharmaceuticals after his arrest on securities fraud charges, the company announced on Friday.

title: Trying to Force the S.E.C.s Hand on High-Speed Trading
description: Robert P. Bartlett III is a law professor at the University of California, Berkeley, School of Law and faculty co-director of the Berkeley Center for Law, Business and the Economy. Justin McCrary is a law professor at the University of California, Berkeley, School of Law and the director of the Berkeley Social Science Data Laboratory.

title: On the Market in New York City
description: This weeks properties are in SoHo, the Upper East Side and Bay Ridge, Brooklyn.

title: Against the Odds, Qihoo Gets Its Buyout
description: Qihoo 360 finally got its $9.3 billion buyout, against the odds.

title: At Celsius, Skaters Are the Show
description: Midtown Manhattan swarms with people any time of year, but the crowds always thicken in December. That was certainly the case on a recent, unseasonably warm Tuesday afternoon at Bryant Park. There, locals and tourists alike can gawk at the holiday decorations, ice-skate on the 17,000-square-foot rink, shop at the 125 pop-up stores or simply take it all in while slurping a hot chocolate or soup at Celsius. The jewel-like, glass-enclosed restaurant, open from November through March, gives customers front-row seats to the seasonal spectacle, while offering casual fare like salads and burgers.

title: NoHo Mansion With Room for Some Warhols for $18.58 Million
description: The art dealer Alberto Mugrabi paid $18,583,062.50 for a pair of ground-floor triplex mansions at the Schumacher, a printing plant-turned-boutique condominium in NoHo that offers soaring ceilings and ample wall space ideal for displaying pricey artwork. The transaction was the most expensive closed sale of the week, according to city records.

title: Iran Struggles With Long-Term Drought
description: A seven-year drought shows no signs of letting up.

title: Womens Hockey Grows Bigger, Faster and Dire
description: The gold medal game at the Sochi Olympics last year represented the pinnacle of womens hockey: a captivating 3-2 overtime victory by Canada over the United States that drew almost five million viewers on NBC.

title: Incredible Bulk at a Comic Book Warehouse in Brooklyn
description: Its beginning to look a little like Christmas in Joseph Kochs Comic Book Warehouse.

title: On the Market in the New York Region
description: This weeks properties include a three-bedroom in Ridgefield, Conn., and a four-bedroom in Sea Cliff, N.Y.

title: Homes for Sale in New York and Connecticut
description: Click on the slide show to see this weeks featured properties in the New York region:

title: Homes for Sale in Manhattan and Brooklyn
description: Click on the slide show to see this weeks featured properties in New York City:

title: Thigh Bone Suggests Ancient and Modern Humans Overlapped
description: Analysis of an ancient thigh bone suggests that a species of early hominin may have survived as late as 14,000 years ago in southwest China.

title: New App Is a 21st-Century Walkie-Talkie
description: Apples iMessage has an audio-chat feature that allows you to send voice messages to friends on the same platform as text messages. Many apps have similar features, including WhatsApp and WeChat. Then there is the actual phone, which Im told is the basis of these app-filled devices we all have. If you really want to hear someones voice, you can simply call her.

title: The Rise and Rise of Misty Copeland
description: Cherry Peace stood, feet firmly planted at the stage door of the David H. Koch Theater at Lincoln Center in October. She was waiting for Misty Copeland, who had just wrapped up a matinee performance of Paul Taylors Company B at the American Ballet Theater, to kick off her toe shoes and exit.

title: After Poaching Deaths, Elephants Rearrange Families
description: Poachers target older elephants for ivory because their tusks are larger. Elephants live in groups led by older females, and their loss may drastically affect the social structures of these communities.

title: Systemic Change Needed After Faulty Times Article
description: Updated, 2:15 p.m.

title: In Fairness, Obama Commutes Sentences for 95, Mostly Drug Offenders
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama ended a tumultuous year in the nations capital by commuting the sentences of 95 federal prisoners and granting two pardons on Friday, building on his push to reorient the nations criminal justice system with a holiday season stroke of his pen.

title: Ronda Rousey, Outside the Octagon
description: When Ronda Rousey was named Best Female Athlete at the ESPY Awards in July, beating out the college basketball player Breanna Stewart, the Olympic skier Lindsey Vonn and the highly favored Serena Williams, many in the audience probably turned to each other and asked, Who?

title: America in Handbags and Glad Rags
description: Abraham Lincoln, John Philip Sousa and the fictional Jay Gatsby are the marquee names at Costume and Culture: Our Heritage, Our Fashion, an exhibition in Port Washington.

title: Spending Bills Approval Shows Need for a Republican President, Candidates Say
description: The $1 trillion spending bill that passed through Congress with bipartisan support on Friday has been hailed by Republican and Democratic leaders as a rare example of the parties coming together to get things done. But for Republican presidential candidates who are sticking to the outsider script of Washington being broken, there waslittle to celebrate.

title: Wild Fennel and Sardines Give Pasta a Fragrant Taste of Sicily
description: When I think of Sicilian cuisine, the first thing that comes to mind is aromatic wild fennel, its feathery green fronds and unmistakable anise-like scent. Sicily is covered with the indigenous herb, and it is the seasoning of choice for many a traditional dish. You have only to climb any hill to collect it.

title: Ukraine Halts Repayments on $3.5 Billion It Owes Russia
description: MOSCOW  The Ukrainian government declared a moratorium Friday on repaying about $3.5 billion in debt to Russia, introducing new strains to an already poisonous relationship.

title: Review: The Merry Wives of Windsor Goes for High Jinks and Low Comedy
description: I wish this were more of a mess.

title: East Village Condos in a Synagogue
description: You dont have to be Jewish to live inside a synagogue in the East Village. You only need to buy one of the three condominium apartments that have been carved out of the historic synagogue at 415 East Sixth Street, between First Avenue and Avenue A.

title: U.N. Says 60 Million People Have Been Forced to Flee War
description: GENEVA  The number of people forced to flee war is expected to far surpass 60 million in 2015, the United Nations said on Friday, warning that violence around the globe is likely to push a record number of asylum seekers even higher in the coming year.

title: A Review of Black-Eyed Sallys, in Hartford
description: Can it really be 20 years since James Varano, a restaurateur in Hartford, took a research trip down South and came back to open a Memphis- and New Orleans-inspired blues-and-barbecue joint?

title: N.F.L.s Deal Over Data Blurs a Line on Gambling
description: Last winter, the National Football League began lining up suitors to distribute what has become one of the hottest commodities in sports: live data from games.

title: JPMorgan to Pay $307 Million for Steering Clients to Own Funds
description: JPMorgan Chase has agreed to pay $307 million to settle accusations that it improperly steered clients to the companys in-house mutual funds and hedge funds.

title: Old Stove Pub, a Hamptons Haunt, Holds True to Its History
description: There are few things in the Hamptons more iconic than the road sign in Sagaponack that reads Old Stove Pub. It has sat on this stretch of Route 27 for nearly 50 years. Follow the signs red neon arrow and you drive up a long, worn path to a farmhouse that bears no resemblance to a pub. A flock of free range chickens comes around to have a look at you. The house is centuries old and poorly lit. You may wonder if youve stumbled upon a personal residence, and a haunted one at that.

title: Gender Reassignment
description: To the Editor:

title: Transparent Episodes 8 and 9: Berlin and Idyllwild
description: One of the best episodes from the first season of Transparent, called Best New Girl, was set almost entirely in the past; in it, we watched Mort become Maura for a long weekend at Camp Camellia, dancing the tango with the actress Michaela Watkins as they guzzled martinis and waxed dreamy about breaking down gender boundaries.

title: On Your Phone at Work
description: To the Editor:

title: Women May Pay More, but How Much? Take the Quiz
description: Test your shopping instincts with this quiz based on a study, from the New York City Department of Consumer Affairs, that found goods geared towards women here were priced 7 percent higher than comparable products marketed to men.

title: Ted Cruzs Immigration Advice to George W. Bush
description: As a policy aide on Mr. Bush's 2000 presidential campaign, Mr. Cruz struck a very different tone on immigration than he is offering today.

title: In 1999 Memo, Ted Cruz Took Milder Tone on Immigration
description: WASHINGTON  Senator Ted Cruz was emphatic on Thursday in Nevada when he summarized his immigration stance to reporters before a rally.

title: New York Revamps Safe Sex
description: In summer 2014, a 22-year-old black man who had recently been diagnosed with H.I.V. walked into a clinic at Mount Sinai Hospital where he was seen by Demetre Daskalakis, an infectious disease specialist, who would soon become the assistant commissioner of New York Citys H.I.V. and AIDS prevention unit. The patient was vigilant about his own care. He carried a container that looked like a slightly oversize cosmetics compact. It neatly held condoms issued by the city, lubricant and his H.I.V. medications.

title: Kenya Cholera Epidemic Hits Worlds Largest Refugee Camp
description: A cholera epidemic that has been spreading in Kenya for more than a year is threatening Dadaab, the worlds largest refugee camp complex, situated near the Somalia border, the medical charity Doctors Without Borders reported Friday.

title: New Novel From Jonathan Safran Foer Coming in September
description: In the book of Genesis, when God calls for Abraham to order him to sacrifice his son Isaac, Abraham replies obediently, Here I am.

title: Puerto Rico Utility and Bondholders Agree to Keep Working on a Deal
description: With a potential huge default on bonds looming and a new bankruptcy law for Puerto Rico to be weighed by Congress in the new year, bondholders have agreed to keep trying to reach a deal to restructure as much as an eighth of the islands $72 billion debt.

title: Sleater-Kinneys Five Nights in New York: The Art of a Set List
description: Sleater-Kinney started 2015 by returning to the road to support No Cities to Love, its first album in a decade, and ended the year with a unique live challenge: a run of five consecutive shows in New York, each in a different space, which concluded Wednesday. The bands drummer, Janet Weiss, described it as a shrinking tour  the Portland-based trio started big, with the Kings Theater in Flatbush, Brooklyn (capacity: nearly 4,000, where most fans had assigned seats) and played a subsequently smaller stage every night until it reached the recently revamped Market Hotel in Bushwick (capacity: approximately 300, where attendees were packed shoulder to shoulder, crammed into window frames and wrapped around pillars).

title: Review: The Humble Pie at Dough Artisan Pizzeria
description: Odd that a restaurant devoted to pizza should serve such a lovely roast chicken. As with most dishes at Dough Artisan Pizzeria in Caldwell, its preparation and provenance satisfies many contemporary preferences. The meat, roasted until its skin was a golden brown on the evening that I ordered it, comes from a chicken that has been pasture-raised without G.M.O.s (genetically modified organisms) or antibiotics.

title: In Developing World, Cancer Is a Very Different Disease
description: In the United States the median age at which colon cancer strikes is 69 for men and 73 for women. In Chad the average life expectancy at birth is about 50. Children who survive childbirth  and then malnutrition and diarrhea  are likely to die of pneumonia, tuberculosis, influenza, malaria, AIDS or even traffic accidents long before their cells accumulate the mutations that cause colon cancer.

title: The Art of Turning Around an Airplane
description: About 1,000 flights a day take off or land at Kennedy International Airport. For each one that lands, it takes dozens of workers to return it to the sky. Heres how Delta Air Lines did it.

title: At Munich Hotel, High Style and Low Cost
description: From 110 euros, or $116 at $1.05 to the euro.

title: Fantasy Football Playoffs, Week 15: Rankings and Matchups
description: Fantasy football analysis for N.F.L. Week 15 games. You can also follow the Sablich brothers on Twitter at @5thDownFantasy and see their complete Week 15 player rankings.

title: Wind Power Spreads Through Turbines for Lease
description: TULLY, N.Y.  Three years ago, Ed Doody and his brothers, Kevin and Rich, installed a wind turbine at the dairy farm they operate here, looking to cut electric bills. They were so happy with the results that each got a turbine for his home, visible from the farm, which overlooks rolling hills and orchards.

title: Syrias Treacherous Borderlands
description: There has been no easy way out for many of the more than four million Syrians who have fled their country since 2012.

title: E.U. to Extend Sanctions Against Russia, but Divisions Show
description: BRUSSELS  The European Union moved on Friday to extend economic sanctions against Russia for six more months for its annexation of Crimea and support for separatists in Ukraine, even as European leaders clashed on policy toward Russia with testy exchanges over a Russian gas pipeline project to Germany at the last scheduled summit meeting of a tumultuous year.

title: 36 Hours in Palermo, Sicily
description: Palazzi housing art and nightlife, dazzling churches and cozy osterias are highlights in this colorful port town.

title: Nepal Avalanche Carried Half the Force of an Atomic Bomb
description: NEW DELHI  The avalanche that buried the popular hiking village of Langtang in Nepal this past spring struck with about half the force of an atomic bomb, according to a study published this week in the journal Science.

title: Second Red Alert for Beijing: Air Pollution Worsens
description: Beijing issued its second-ever red alert for dangerously bad air quality on Friday morning, just a week after its first one. The current alert is for hazardous levels starting on Saturday and end at midnight on Tuesday.

title: The French Literati and the Arab World Do a Complicated Dance
description: Well before tensions between Frances Muslim and non-Muslim populations rose in response to the terrorist attacks last month, the Islamic world had been looming large in French literature this season  a sign of the powerful influence the Middle East and North Africa play in the nations cultural imagination.

title: Run, Hide, Fight Is Not How Our Brains Work
description: IN this age of terror, we struggle to figure out how to protect ourselves  especially, of late, from active shooters.

title: Fighting in Yemen After Cease-Fire Threatens Negotiations
description: AL MUKALLA, Yemen  Days after Yemens warring parties agreed to a cease-fire, fierce fighting in at least three provinces on Friday threatened negotiations underway in Switzerland to end the countrys nine-month civil war.

title: Requiem For Star Wars
description: Like any red-blooded American I have my ticket for Star Wars: The Force Awakens  Im seeing it tomorrow and Im confidently expecting it to be light-years better than the last three movies set in a galaxy far, far way. Yet in conversations with friends and on Twitter, Ive oftentreated the Eventwith jadedness and snark rather than full enthusiasm. Part of that reflects my assumption that J.J. Abrams, the director, is only really capable of doing homage, and so this movie is likely to stand in the same relationship to A New Hope that Super 8 stands to E.T. But theres something deeper at work in my tempered enthusiasmas well, and reading the end of David Edelsteins review of Awakens helped me put my finger on it:

title: A Japanese Beauty Haven, Hidden Away at Bergdorf
description: The beauty floor of Bergdorf Goodman, with its dozens of close-packed displays and bustle of shoppers, can be an overstimulating place. This month, a measure of tranquillity has arrived in the form of Espace Cl de Peau Beaut, the new counter  and treatment room  for Shiseidos prestige brand. The counter, an exercise in luxe minimalism with a Mondrian-style navy-and-white geometric facade, hides the 80-square-foot treatment room, which is closely modeled after the lines first treatment space in Tokyos Ginza district. (Creating the tucked-away haven for facial treatments required some architectural finagling: namely, removing an office and storage room on the beauty floor.) As in the Japanese space, clean lines dominate the room, with products, linens and robes stored away to keep the focus on the treatment chair  and the person in it. Guests can choose from a small menu of treatment options, including the brands signature eight-step Synactif intensive purifying & brightening facial ($100), which is designed to encourage lymphatic drainage and which makes use of Cl de Peau Beauts proprietary treatment machine. A custom-made sound-dampening curtain effectively blocks outside light, noise  and hubbub.

title: Whats Your Secret Ingredient?
description: Food entrepreneurs who share a warehouse kitchen space in Long Island City, Queens, talk about what makes their products special.

title: At Incubators, Chefs Aim to Turn Recipes Into Big Businesses
description: Inside a brick warehouse in Queens, Free Bread turns out gluten-free loaves for tables at Le Bernardin, Blue Hill at Stone Barns and the cafeteria at Facebooks headquarters just south of Union Square in Manhattan.

title: Bombs at Bangladeshi Mosques Wound Naval Personnel, Police Say
description: DHAKA, Bangladesh  Three powerful bombs exploded Friday in two mosques inside a naval base in a port city in southern Bangladesh, the police said.

title: Jazz 2015: In the Spotlight and the Cross Hairs
description: A bright blue sky stretched over Fort Adams State Park in Rhode Island on the afternoon this summer that I spoke with Jon Batiste. He and his band, Stay Human, had just performed at the Newport Jazz Festival, leaving several thousand people in a state of fizzy elation. Mr. Batiste, an irrepressible force on piano, melodica and vocals, was five weeks away from his new gig as bandleader for The Late Show With Stephen Colbert, where his brand of ecstatic stagecraft now reaches an average of 3.1 million people a night.

title: What I Love | Mark Barak
description: Mark Barak, the owner of La Pecora Bianca, a restaurant in Manhattan, lives in a one-bedroom apartment in a Greek Revival townhouse.

title: RestaurateurMark Baraks Home as an Elegant Scrapbook
description: Sitting in the living room of his apartment on West 16th Street, Mark Barak pointed out that the street is home to the Catholic Church of St. Francis Xavier, the Center for Jewish History and Yeshe Nyingpo NYC, a Tersar dharma center. Its a very spiritual block, he said.

title: Pictures of the Day: Greece and Elsewhere
description: Greece and Elsewhere: Pictures of the Day

title: Dec. 18, 2015  Pictures of the Day
description: Photos from Greece, the West Bank, England and Germany.

title: U.S. Bomber Mistakenly Flew Near Disputed Island in South China Sea
description: WASHINGTON  A United States B-52 bomber last week mistakenly flew within two nautical miles of a disputed artificial island built by China in the South China Sea, Pentagon officials said Friday.

title: Martin Shkreli: Arrested for the Wrong Crime?
description: To the Editor:

title: All Is Bright. Very, Very Bright
description: Tony Pampena used to go by the nickname Clark Griswold, after the holiday-obsessed character played by Chevy Chase in National Lampoons Christmas Vacation. But that was 15 years and several thousand strands of Christmas lights ago.

title: Security Council Draft Resolution
description: The United Nations Security Council approved a resolution calling for a cease-fire and political talks in Syria.

title: Prince Albert II of Monaco Charges Forth as Eco-Warrior
description: Immediately following the United Nations climate conference in Paris this month, Prince Albert II of Monaco flew to New York to receive an environmental award from Ban Ki-moon, the U.N.s secretary general. At a black-tie gala at Cipriani Wall Street, the prince was given an award by the United Nations Correspondents Association (previous recipients have included former President Bill Clinton and Sir Richard Branson) for his efforts on behalf of biodiversity and climate-change research.

title: Star Wars Visits the White House
description: These are not the White House aides youre looking for.

title: Garth Risk Hallberg, the Literary Wunderkind of 2015
description: Few authors, not even Joan Didion, have emerged on the literary scene as dramatically as did Garth Risk Hallberg in 2015.

title: Another Enthralling Earthrise View of the Home Planet
description: Just in case you missed it, I have to draw attention to a spectacular new image of the dynamic blue Earth set against the sterile lunar surface  a k a, an Earthrise, generated this time with data from theLunar Reconnaissance Orbiter.

title: University in Florida Seeks to Fire Newtown Conspiracy Theorist
description: A professor in southern Florida who has aggressively promoted false theories surrounding the 2012 massacre at Sandy Hook Elementary School is facing termination after the parents of a victim publicly accused him of harassment.

title: How Joseph Mizzi, President of Sciame Construction, Spends His Sundays
description: Joseph Mizzi, the president of Sciame, a construction company that specializes in architecturally sophisticated projects, is not your typical hard-hat-wearing tough guy. Hes a pescatarian, a patron of the arts and a co-founder of the 14 + Foundation, a nonprofit that builds schools in Africa. On Sundays Mr. Mizzi, 49, might slow his pace but hes always working, whether visiting a dormant construction site or an artists studio, or corresponding with Nchimunya Wulf, a co-founder of the foundation. He lives alone in a one-bedroom in a high-rise on the Upper West Side of Manhattan.

title: Next Step After the Climate Accord: A Carbon Tax
description: To the Editor:

title: Review: Annie and Elf: The Musical Stay Kid-Friendly
description: I think Im gonna like it here.

title: Evening Hours | Holiday Spirit
description: Music, dancing and merriment.

title: Review: Danish Piano Trio Shares Well-Loved Sounds and Little-Known Gems
description: The debut recording and debut recital of a chamber ensemble are often made up of the same music. Its only efficient, after all, to apply the hard work from the recording studio to the high-pressure environment of the concert hall. But when the impressive Danish Piano Trio gave its American debut at Carnegie Halls Weill Recital Hall on Thursday, the program contained only one of the little-known gems from its inaugural disc, Danish Romantic Piano Trios. Instead, the ensembles members, the pianist Katrine Gislinge, the violinist Lars Bjornkjaer and the cellist Toke Moldrup, took the opportunity to introduce themselves as players of wide-ranging interests in two contemporary works.

title: Review: Beach Slang Arrives From Philly, Prepared to Punch
description: For the Philadelphia band Beach Slang, every song is a manifesto: The declarations of an outcast saved by rock. I never fit. I never tried./I need the struggle to feel alive./All I want are records on my stereo, James Alex sang in Dirty Cigarettes as the band started its set at the Knitting Factory on Thursday night. He had just announced: Were Beach Slang. Were here to punch you right in the heart.

title: Review: Sung With Words, a Collaboration by a Pianist and a Poet
description: Sung With Words, a song cycle by the pianist Helen Sung and the poet Dana Gioia, starts from the premise that jazz and poetry are natural allies. This isnt a new or provocative idea, but it can still present a high degree of difficulty in performance. And in its premiere on Thursday night at the Jazz Gallery in Manhattan, Sung With Words didnt quite clear the bar, despite being well played and well intentioned, with an impressive concentration of musical talent.

title: Fiddler on the Roof Gets a Debated Update
description: The revival of Fiddler on the Roof that opens at the Broadway Theater on Sunday night includes all the cherished characters (Tevye, Golde, their five daughters, and their shtetl neighbors) and all the unforgettable language (Even a poor tailor is entitled to some happiness!).

title: What Were Reading
description: Get recommendations from New York Times reporters and editors, highlighting great stories from around the web. What Were Reading emails are sent twice a week. Sign up

title: A Cousin of Phillys Cheese Steak Gains Fans
description: Who doesnt like a Balboa? Anthony Russo asked on the phone.

title: Archdiocese of St. Paul Settles Civil Complaint on Child Sexual Abuse
description: ST. PAUL  The Roman Catholic archdiocese here has reached an agreement with prosecutors in a civil case accusing church officials of failing to protect children from sexual abuse.

title: Two Russian Tours, One Led by Evgeny Kissin, the Other by the American Symphony Orchestra
description: On paper, it looked like a well-planned mini-festival of Jewish composers over two nights at Carnegie Hall.

title: Your Friday Evening Briefing: Syria, Bernie Sanders, Star Wars
description: (Want to get this briefing by email? Heres the sign-up.)

title: Your Evening Briefing
description: Heres what you need to know at the end of the day.

title: Chuck Hagel Says About-Face on Syria Hurt Obamas Credibility
description: WASHINGTON  Former Defense Secretary Chuck Hagel has become the latest former member of President Obamas cabinet to fire a missile at his old boss, saying the presidents 2013 decision to ignore his own red line on Syrian military action hurt the credibility of Mr. Obamas word around the world.

title: Remember the Dutchmen
description: Joseph Swides photographs chronicling the Erasmus Hall teams season capture New York City high school football in all its urban glory, with the elevated F train as a backdrop to boot.

title: Joseph Swide Captures the Heartache of High School Football
description: This is high school football, New York City-style, where the clanking of the elevated F train and the booming of a 50 Cent song can drown out the quarterback in the huddle.

title: Backers of Marco Rubio Target Ted Cruz for Stance on Edward Snowden
description: A group run by supporters of Senator Marco Rubio sent a mailing to Iowa Republicans this week criticizing Senator Ted Cruz for not condemning Edward J. Snowden, the former National Security Agency contractor who leaked a trove of classified documents.

title: Jordan Deports Sudanese Asylum Seekers, Spurring Outcry
description: AMMAN, Jordan  The Jordanian authorities on Friday deported hundreds of Sudanese asylum seekers, most of them from the war-afflicted Darfur region, according to the United Nations and human rights groups.

title: Your Fill-in-the-______ Holiday Card Game
description: Have no time to write a holiday card this season? Not to worry! Play the game by picking a few of your favorite emojis, and well do the rest.

title: Sanders vs. Party: Why Voter Data Can Be So Important
description: The feud between Bernie Sanders and Democratic leaders this week was set off by a breach of computer records most voters never think about, the partys voter file.

title: War of Words Escalates in Chicago Over Laquan McDonald Shooting
description: CHICAGO  As Mayor Rahm Emanuel fends off critics calling for him to resign over his handling of the fatal police shooting of Laquan McDonald, he has not hesitated to condemn the officer who fired 16 bullets into the young man.

title: San Bernardino Massacre: How the Key Figures Converged
description: Investigators have released a new and detailed account of the relationship between Enrique Marquez and Syed Rishwan Farook, the county health inspector in San Bernardino, Calif., who, together with his wife, Tashfeen Malik, killed 14 people and wounded 22 others in a terrorist attack on Dec. 2.

title: Overdose Deaths Reached a New High in 2014
description: Fatal drug overdoses reached a new high in 2014, killing nearly 50,000 Americans, more than were killed in auto accidents, according to data from the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention. Twice as many Americans died from drug overdoses in 2014 as in 2000.

title: Regulators Tamp Down on Mergers of Hospitals
description: In the latest sign that federal regulators are uneasy about the flurry of proposed health care mergers taking place, the Federal Trade Commission said on Friday that it planned to block the combination of two large Illinois hospital groups.

title: New Jersey: Gay Conversion Therapy Group to Close
description: A counseling group in New Jersey that promised to help men overcome homosexual attractions through conversion therapy has agreed to shut down permanently in a settlement announced Friday. Earlier this year, a jury found that the claims of the group, Jonah, that homosexuality was a curable disorder amounted to consumer fraud. In the settlement, Jonah agreed to dissolve. Its founder, Arthur Goldberg and its chief counselor, Alan Downing, agreed never to offer the therapy in the state again, announced the Southern Poverty Law Center, which represented four men who said they were misled and harmed by the group and will receive undisclosed compensation for therapy and legal costs. Four states and the District of Columbia have banned the widely discredited therapy for minors.

title: U.S. Delivers Art to Iran That Had Been Impounded Since 1979
description: Fourteen pieces of American art purchased by Iran nearly four decades ago, but blocked for export from the United States because of the 1979 Iranian revolution and rupture in relations, have finally been delivered, both nations said Friday.

title: Congress Orders Defense Dept. to Study Combats Effects on Veteran Suicide Rates
description: Congress on Friday passed a bill requiring the Departments of Defense and Veterans Affairs to study the long-term effects of combat on the mental health of veterans  a dynamic that remains poorly understood despite concerns by lawmakers and the public over elevated veteran suicide rates in recent years.

title: Las Vegas Review-Journals Owners Told Reporters to Monitor Judges
description: The Las Vegas Review-Journal reported on Friday that in the weeks before Sheldon Adelson bought the paper, its journalists were asked to monitor three local judges. One of those judges is overseeing a case involving Mr. Adelson, a billionaire casino magnate.

title: Albany Trials Exposed the Power of a Real Estate Firm
description: The recent federal trials that ended in the quick convictions of Sheldon Silver and Dean G. Skelos laid bare a world of greed, flagrant corruption and abuse of power in Albany, with evidence showing payoffs taking a deceptively circular route from business interests to the elected officials whose help they sought.

title: North Carolina to Review Death Sentences Reduced Over Race
description: In a pair of decisions that sidestepped landmark questions about capital punishment in North Carolina, the State Supreme Court on Friday ordered a lower court to reconsider rulings that commuted the death sentences of four inmates who had challenged their punishments with claims that racial biases had tainted their trials.

title: Friday Night Music: Im With Her, Crossing Muddy Waters
description: Unfortunately I was overseas and had to miss what was reportedly a luminous performance at Bowery Ballroom. But heres a sample:

title: Martin Shkrelis Arrest Fuels Debate Over $1 Million Donation
description: When Hunter College High School announced in March that it had received a $1 million donation  the largest ever in its century-long history from a member of the Class of 2001, many graduates were stunned to learn who the young donor was: Martin Shkreli, a multimillionaire pharmaceuticals executive.

title: Cowboys Owner Jerry Jones Wows Those Gathered at the Fifty
description: ARLINGTON, Tex.  The offer to watch the Dallas Cowboys play from the owner Jerry Joness suite is extended during the summer, but the formal invitation is not sent until a week before the game.

title: Brazils Finance Minister Replaced
description: Finance Minister Joaquim Levy, who had been in charge of spearheading austerity measures and returning the country to fiscal and economic health, was replaced on Friday after a long-running battle with members of Congress and President Dilma Rousseffs own party over policy as the countrys economy continues to deteriorate. Nelson Barbosa, the countrys planning minister, stepped into the position, Brazils presidential palace said on its website. Ms. Rousseff said Mr. Levy had a fundamental role in the governments handling of the economic crisis. Since his first day on the job in January, Mr. Levy, a former bank executive and University of Chicago-trained economist, faced criticism from Ms. Rousseffs largely leftist base and even her predecessor and mentor, Luiz Incio Lula da Silva, who questioned the efficacy of fiscal austerity and sought to undermine him. Additionally, Congress gave him tepid support. Brazils economy contracted by 1.7 percent in the third quarter.

title: Chief Lost Influence Amid Criticism of Mayor de Blasios Policies on Homelessness
description: Mayor Bill de Blasio was facing one pointed question after another from those who work with homeless people. Why, more than a year into the new administration, was homelessness still so high?

title: Internet Firms Urged to Limit Work of Anwar al-Awlaki
description: In case after terrorism case, from the Fort Hood, Tex., shootings to the Boston Marathon bombing and now to the slaughter in San Bernardino, Calif., the inflammatory videos and bomb-making instructions of Anwar al-Awlaki, easily accessible on the Internet, have turned up as a powerful influence.

title: Saturdays Matchup: Jets (8-5) at Cowboys (4-9)
description: Saturday, 8:25 p.m. Eastern

title: How Martin Shkreli, the Teen Wolf of Wall Street, Thrived
description: PONDER for a moment the strange case of Martin Shkreli, the 32-year-old former hedge fund manager who was arrested by the Federal Bureau of Investigation at his Manhattan apartment before dawn on Dec. 17 and charged with securities and wire fraud. Even by the standards of the ego-driven, attention-grabbing, hedge fund industry, Mr. Shkrelis alleged depravity stands out for its audacity and for his ability to keep the con going long after it should have been stopped dead in its tracks.

title: Automation Claims Jobs of Phone Operators at New York Hotels
description: On Mad Men, the telephone operator for the Sterling Cooper advertising firm, Marge, is a vital part of the office. But that was decades ago. Today, the notion of women with headsets perched behind wire-laden switchboards feels as antiquated as the clattering of typewriters.

title: Baseball Has a New Policy on Netting, but Theres a Catch
description: Joe Nocera is the new sports business columnist for The New York Times. You can read more of his columns here.

title: The Feds Next Move
description: At least for the short run, the Federal Reserves interest rate increase has created one clear winner: the banks. When the Fed announced on Wednesday that it would raise its benchmark rate to a range of 0.25 to 0.5 percent, banks raised the rates they charge on many loans but not the rates they pay to depositors. That widening spread means higher bank profits.

title: New Yorks Humane Retreat From Solitary Confinement
description: The state of New York State took a big step toward a more humane prison policy this week when it agreed to new rules that would reduce the number of prison inmates sentenced to solitary confinement as well as the maximum time they could be held there.

title: Terry Backer, 61, Legislator Who Helped Clean Up Long Island Sound
description: Terry Backer, a 12-term Connecticut state representative, a third-generation commercial fisherman and an environmentalist who fought successfully for the preservation of Long Island Sound, died on Monday in Bridgeport, Conn. He was 61.

title: Latest Escape From New York Police Custody Draws Ire, but No Rethinking of Training
description: When a shoplifting suspect riding in the back of a squad car bound for a police station in Lower Manhattan started acting sick, the two officers who arrested him pulled over to see what was wrong.

title: Out of Prison, a Brooklyn Woman Hopes for a New Start
description: If not for the time she spent in prison, Dominique McWilliams may have never gone to college.

title: Licio Gelli, Italian Financier and Cabal Leader, Dies at 96
description: Licio Gelli, a buccaneering Italian financier and self-professed fascist who was implicated in terrorist crimes, scandals and a secret society that, with him as its grandmaster, was accused of plotting a right-wing coup, died on Tuesday at his villa in Arezzo, Italy. He was 96.

title: George Ortman, Artist Whose Works Presaged Minimalism, Dies at 89
description: George Ortman, whose constructed, collaged canvases of the late 1950s and early 60s, with their geometric shapes and signs, pointed a way past Abstract Expressionism and toward the austerities of Minimalism, died on Wednesday in Manhattan. He was 89.

title: Alden Amos, Whose Spinning Wheels Gave Craft a Brighter Fate, Dies at 77
description: Alden Amos, a Stradivari of spinning wheels who as a master wheelmaker, teacher and deliciously opinionated author helped spur the modern revival of the traditional craft of handspinning, died on Nov. 28 in Jackson, Calif. He was 77.

title: Better to Be Lucky Than Good? Sometimes Its True
description: Nearly eight years later, Mike Deane, the former Wagner basketball coach, can remember when Sacred Heart almost beat his team at the buzzer on Valentines Day 2008.

title: French Dip
description: SATURDAY PUZZLE  No one would argue that Saturday crossword puzzles are hard, but sometimes they are hard for different reasons. The clues are diabolically vague and point solvers in different directions. Some of the entries might be a bit on the obscure side, or there might be entries that linger just outside a solvers wheelhouse. Some may contain  and consider this your trigger warning  pop culture.

title: $5.45 Billion Deal for Stuyvesant Town Completed After Threatened Lawsuit
description: Amid the holiday season, SL Green Realty Corporation, New York Citys largest commercial landlord, dropped a bombshell: It told real estate executives and city officials last week that it would file a lawsuit to block the imminent $5.45 billion sale of Stuyvesant Town-Peter Cooper Village, Manhattans largest apartment complex.

title: Could Shipwrecks Lead the World to War?
description: London  ARCHAEOLOGY has long been exploited as a political tool. Hitler used artifacts and symbols to manufacture a narrative of Aryan racial superiority. The Islamic State proves its zealotry by destroying evidence of ancient history. Underwater archaeology  the world of shipwrecks and sunken cities  has mostly avoided these kinds of machinations, though. Since no one lives beneath the sea, leaders havent found many opportunities for political gains from archaeological sites there.

title: Whats the Matter With Iowa?
description: One of the great things about the American political system is the amount of time it gives us to think about corn.

title: Knicks Work Over N.B.A.s Punching Bag
description: PHILADELPHIA  The Knicks are embracing the soft underbelly of their schedule. On Friday, they showed up at Wells Fargo Center fully prepared to face a ragtag team dealing with change. The 76ers are not good, and the Knicks took advantage of an opportunity to inch back toward mediocrity with an easy 107-97 victory.

title: Accusations of Navy SEAL Brutality Against Afghan Prisoners
description: To the Editor:

title: Doubts About Saudi Arabias Antiterrorism Coalition
description: One of the greatest weaknesses in the American-led fight against the Islamic State is the lack of competent regional forces to join in defeating the militants, especially on the ground. Saudi Arabias plans to organize a military coalition of 34 Islamic nations against terrorism could be a breakthrough, though there are many reasons to doubt how effective the plan will be.

title: Attacker Convicted in Hate Crime on Transgender Woman in Brooklyn
description: A Brooklyn man was convicted of first-degree assault as a hate crime in connection with an attack on a transgender woman last year that left her with a traumatic brain injury, the authorities said on Friday.

title: Ted Cruz Hits Marco Rubio on Immigration in New Ad
description: Ratcheting up the volume in his rivalry with Senator Marco Rubio, Senator Ted Cruz has released a new ad suggesting that Mr. Rubios prior stance on immigration posed a threat to national security.

title: Legislator Questions San Bernardino Suspects Visa
description: The chairman of the House Judiciary Committee is raising new questions about the fianc visa granted to the Pakistani woman who with her husband carried out the massacre in San Bernardino, Calif., saying her application shows she may not have met a core requirement for the visa.

title: Isles Limit Alcohol Sales
description: After an incident between fans and Barclays Center security guards during Tuesdays 5-1 loss to the Florida Panthers, arena officials saidalcohol sales would be cut off after the second period of Islanders games. Sales had previously taken place until the 12-minute mark of the third period. Barclays Center also said it would enforce a limit of two drinks per purchase.

title: What to Watch Saturday
description: Relish a true-crime mystery? Check out Making a Murderer, which is as close to reading a book as streaming gets. On TV, worlds collide and tears flow in The Longest Ride, the latest from the Nicholas Sparks brand. And Tina Fey and Amy Poehler make like sisters on Saturday Night Live.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: His work has inspired countless plots and attacks. Its hate speech. It should come down, period. Like child porn, it should be expeditiously removed.

title: Corrections: December 19, 2015
description: FRONT PAGE

title: Syrias Christian Refugees: Four Wrong Assumptions
description: The debate concerning how best to provide asylum to Syrian refugees continues to polarize. It has been a relief to hear more thoughtful voices rising above the alarmist clamor. Prioritizing security is not incompatible with dispensing compassion, and the need to balance these two vital components inevitably makes any response more challenging, but why would we assume there could be simple responses to such complex problems?

title: President Obama Visits Families of San Bernardino Victims
description: SAN BERNARDINO, Calif.  President Obama met on Friday night with family members of those killed in the shooting massacre here this month, saying he had been moved by their conversations and inspired by the families determination that something positive come from the tragedy.

title: Bill Cunningham | Holiday Madness
description: A flurry of calm appears amid the abundance of Santa costumes and holiday window decorations.

title: 10 Unforgettable Marriage Proposals
description: While an aspiring groom in Bermuda went to great depths to find the most creative way to ask his girlfriend to marry him, the benchmark for memorable proposals submitted to The New York Times this year was set in Central Park.

title: The Fabulous (Instagram) Life of Derek Blasberg
description: Vanity Fair calls him its man on the street, but his feet often find red carpets or jetways, as his fingers post to Instagram.

title: Caitlyn Jenners Secret-Sharer
description: Sometime around the end of 2014, the publicist Alan Nierob received a call at his office at Rogers & Cowan in Los Angeles. The caller was a former client, Bruce Jenner, who explained that after years of gender dysphoria, he had begun the transition to become a woman and needed a representative.

title: Sandy and Joan Weill and the $20 Million Gift That Went Awry
description: If you take a tour of some of New Yorks most notable cultural and medical complexes, you are bound to encounter  and re-encounter  one prominent family name.

title: Jill Soloway of Transparent: A Daughters Story
description: When, at the age of 75 and after more than 40 years of marriage, a Chicago psychiatrist named Harry Soloway came out as transgender to his family, and said he would now be known as Carrie, his two grown daughters had very different reactions.

title: After The Big Short, Hedge Funders Lose Cultural Capital
description: Last decade, Turney Duff lived in a $9,300-a-month triplex in TriBeCa. He wore jeans to work and was able to do his job largely free of the red tape that could entangle those who worked in other parts of the financial sector. As a hedge fund guy, he had the sexiest job on Wall Street.

title: The Weinstein Brothers Have Oscar Gold. Now They Need Cash.
description: Harvey Weinstein was in motion.

title: Donald Trump Campaign Lags in Mobilizing Iowa Caucus Voters
description: DES MOINES  Donald J. Trump has dominated much of this political season, excited an often-ignored part of the electorate, filled huge arenas with followers and upended the rules of how modern campaigns are run.

title: The Week on Instagram
description: Photos posted this week on @nytimes took followers from the streets of Brooklyn to the sky over Kerman Province in Iran.

title: New York Jets at Dallas Cowboys Preview
description: 8:25 p.m. Eastern

title: On the Media and the [Landmark][Disastrous] Paris Climate Agreement
description: The public radio program On the Media sought me out this week to join host Brooke Gladstone and Jonathan M. Katz of The New Republic in a discussion of the many conflicting interpretations of the climate change agreement reached in Paris on December 12. (I laid out my views in a guest Opinion column last Sunday.)

title: In Bolivia, Legitimizing Child Labor
description: Bolivian legislation allowing children as young as 10 to work has created a rift between those who support it as Andean tradition and others who condemn it as exploitation.

title: Farhad and Mike Ruminate on the Peaks and Abysses of 2015
description: Each Saturday, Farhad Manjoo and Mike Isaac, technology reporters at The New York Times, review the weeks news, offering analysis and maybe a joke or two about the most important developments in the tech industry.

title: Kurt Masur, Conductor Who Transformed New York Philharmonic, Dies at 88
description: Kurt Masur, the music director emeritus of the New York Philharmonic, who was credited with transforming the orchestra from a sullen, lackluster ensemble into one of luminous renown, died on Saturday in Greenwich, Conn. He was 88.

title: In Democratic Debate, Hillary Clintons Focus Is on G.O.P.
description: Hillary Clinton largely looked past her Democratic rivals in Saturday nights debate, instead repeatedly assailing the Republican field, led by Donald J. Trump. She called Mr. Trump a threat to the nations safety, saying he was fast becoming ISIS best recruiter.

title: Recourse for Blacklisted Tenants
description: Ask Real Estate is a weekly column that answers questions from across the New York region. Submit yours to realestateqa@nytimes.com.

title: Still Assailing Donald Trump, Jeb Bush Calls Him a Jerk
description: CONTOOCOOK, N.H.  Jeb Bush was halfway through an early morning town-hall-style event here Saturday when he paused, announcing he had something he wanted to get off his chest.

title: How to Watch the Democratic Debate
description: The prospect of a Saturday night debate in December has stirred controversy within the Democratic Party, raising concern that Hillary Clintons lesser-known rivals will take the stage before a small television audience. It is the holiday season, after all, and there is also football to watch. But for those who do want to tune in to see Mrs. Clinton face off with Senator Bernie Sanders and Martin OMalley, there are several ways to catch the action.

title: Variety: Puns and Anagrams
description: VARIETY PUZZLE  Well, look whos branching out! Joel Fagliano, who assists Will Shortz in editing the crosswords and constructs the Mini crosswords, makes his debut today as a Puns and Anagrams constructor.

title: U.S. Airstrike Killed Iraqis by Accident, Officials Say
description: ABOARD THE U.S.S. KEARSARGE  An airstrike that mistakenly killed Iraqi troops on Friday was carried out by an American plane, United States officials said on Saturday.

title: Theranos Founder Faces a Test of Technology, and Reputation
description: It should have been Theranoss moment to shine.

title: Celtics Are on the Rise. The Problem: So Is the East.
description: Under Coach Brad Stevens, Boston has become the type of team that no one wants to play. The Celtics are not blessed with a true superstar, so they win with depth, strategy and execution.

title: Where Support for Assault Rifles Is All in Good, Clean Fun
description: SUNRISE, Fla.  As Eddie Pereira helped his 15-year-old nephew fire a semiautomatic assault rifle for the first time, Mr. Pereiras son, a more experienced shooter, snapped pictures of the rite with a phone.

title: Gandhi Family Vows to Fight Corruption Case Filed by Political Rival
description: NEW DELHI  India on Saturday witnessed the unusual spectacle of Sonia and Rahul Gandhi, the inheritors of a political dynasty that guided the country for five decades, appearing in court to apply for bail in a corruption case.

title: As Obama Checks Off List of Goals Met, a Nervous Nation Dwells on Terror
description: WASHINGTON  Determined to defy the stereotype of a weakened short-timer, President Obama is ending 2015 with a series of accomplishments, most notably a nuclear agreement with Iran, an international climate accord, a 12-nation Pacific trade pact, and long-stalled deals on the budget, education and transportation.

title: To Achieve Paris Climate Goals, U.S. Will Need New Laws
description: The climate agreement reached in Paris last weekend has been hailed as a landmark in the global effort to reduce greenhouse gas emissions, and it could well turn out to be one.

title: Looking Back at a Year of Haggling
description: With the New Year approaching, its time for the Hagglers annual look at the last 12 months of columns, to see what lessons have been learned, what consumer-friendly measures have been adopted  in short, what improvements have been spurred by expostulations in this space.

title: My Career Choice: All of the Above
description: Editors note: Heres one of our favorite stories from the archives, now being featured in our Smarter Living collection.

title: Pete Roses Ban, a Product of His Flaws, Highlights Others Faults
description: COOPERSTOWN, N.Y.  To walk through the National Baseball Hall of Fames museum is to realize that the old scamp Pete Rose is already in the house.

title: Syrian Peace Plan Offers Some Hope, but Has Plenty of Pitfalls
description: UNITED NATIONS  The self-congratulatory speeches that rang inside the Security Council chamber Friday celebrated the fact that, after four and a half years, bitterly divided world powers had finally agreed on a peace plan for Syria.

title: Bill Cunningham | Holiday Madness
description: The legendary Times fashion photographer Bill Cunningham spots and distills the latest trends from the runways of Paris to the colorful streets of New York.

title: No Justification for High Drug Prices
description: There is ample evidence that drug prices have been pushed to astronomical heights for no reason other than the desire of drug makers to maximize profits. Prices in many cases far exceed whats needed to cover the costs of research and clinical trials, and some companies have found ways to rake in profits even without shouldering the cost of drug development.

title: When Hospital Paperwork Crowds Out Hospital Care
description: A FRIEND was recently hospitalized after a bicycle accident. At one point a nursing student, together with a more senior nurse, rolled a computer on wheels into the room and asked my friend to rate her pain on a scale of 1 to 10.

title: How Diversity Plays Out on Campuses
description: Readers discuss Frank Brunis criticism of self-segregation on diverse campuses.

title: Paul Brown
description: Paul Brown is general manager of Santa Claus House in North Pole, Alaska, which by default receives millions of childrens letters addressed to Santa Claus. The red-and-white house in Alaskas interior is a family-run business conceived by Mr. Browns wifes grandparents in the 1950s and continues today as a popular tourist attraction.

title: The Fate of Obamacare
description: FOR the first six years of the Obama era, many Republicans made an apocalyptic case against the presidents health care law. It was unconstitutional, immoral, borderline tyrannical. It wouldnt just fail: It would fail disastrously, in a death spiral that would take down most of American health care as we know it.

title: Walmart Cant Escape Clutter. Can You?
description: TO the dismay of economists and retailers, the American consumer keeps holding back.

title: For Grieving Families, Each Gun Massacre Echoes the Last
description: NEWTOWN, Conn.  The nations latest gun rampage  the one in far-off California  had an immediate and devastating side effect here, compounding the trauma of grieving families who lost 20 children and six educators three years ago in the massacre at Sandy Hook Elementary School.

title: The Reproductive Rights Rollback of 2015
description: How many laws making it harder to get an abortion will pass before the Supreme Court sees them for what they are  part of a tireless, coordinated nationwide assault on the right of women to control what happens with their own bodies without the interference of politicians?

title: The Deer in My Sights
description: Bushkill, Pa.  IT was midmorning, and the sun was over my shoulder. A breeze rustled the dead leaves still clinging to the oaks, just enough to cover the sound as I fox-footed my way through the undergrowth.

title: Why Do I Have to Call This App Julie?
description: RECENTLY, I signed up for a virtual inbox assistant service. I gave the assistant, Julie, access to my email and calendar over the Internet.

title: Jane Austens Guide to Alzheimers
description: I CAME to Jane Austens Emma in my 50s, which is late for many Austen aficionados. The story of a wealthy 21-year-old woman who lives with her father and imagines herself a matchmaker hadnt caught my attention until then. At first, I was made uneasy by Emma as she imagines romance where it isnt and misses it where it is. But during a caregiving crisis in my life, I lost count of how many times I read or listened to Austens novel. I turned her words over in my mind like a piece of slowly melting hard candy.

title: The One Question You Should Ask About Every New Job
description: TWO years ago, a student of mine named Nicole was torn on where to start her career. While applying for jobs in finance, technology, consulting and marketing, she suddenly realized that her biggest concern wasnt what she did, but where she worked.

title: Political Party Meltdown
description: DURING the tumultuous wartime summer of 1944, President Franklin D. Roosevelt fielded an incredible proposal. His Republican opponent from 1940, Wendell Willkie, would quit his party and join the president in a new, liberal coalition.

title: Bright Lights, Big Predators
description: IT was tea break one afternoon this past May, in a business park in Mumbai, one of the worlds most crowded cities. The neighborhood was chockablock with new 35-story skyscrapers adorned with Greek temples on top. On the seventh-floor deck of one building, 20-something techies took turns playing foosball and studying the wooded hillside in back through a brass ship captains spyglass.

title: Being Smart About Your Childs Brain
description: PROBABLY no one tracks concussions among young athletes in the United States more closely than Dawn Comstock, and in many ways, shes encouraged by what she sees.

title: For Many, Faith Comes at a High Price
