title: A Global TV Tour via Streaming: England, Australia and New Zealand
description: The age of television abundance is also increasingly an age without geographic boundaries. Whereas TV viewers in the United States once were at the mercy of the importation whims of PBS, BBC America and a few other outlets, streaming services now make all sorts of worthy shows available.

title: Afghan Province Tucked in Mountains Lies Beyond Reach of Aid and Time
description: NURISTAN PROVINCE, Afghanistan  When the king of Afghanistan decided it was finally time, a bit over a century ago, to bring this forbidding mountainous eastern region to Islam by force, his soldiers faced a huge problem: There were no roads at all.

title: In Hong Kong, Fears for an Art Museum
description: HONG KONG  At the waterfront site destined for a vast new center for the arts here, the view across Victoria Harbor is one to marvel at  an urban jungle of high-rises that together make up the citys famous skyline.

title: Timothy Peake, British Astronaut, Dials Wrong Number From Space
description: He may have the right stuff, but he got the wrong digits.

title: Bidoun, an Influential Magazine of the Middle East, Extends Its Reach
description: Since its founding in 2004, the Middle Eastern art and culture magazine Bidoun has presented a distinctive, Technicolor vision of a complex region. It has given voice to important Arab feminists, analyzed Pakistani horror films, documented Egypts Tahrir Square uprising, and published interviews with the rapper M.I.A. and the gallerist Larry Gagosian. It even explored the influence of Star Wars on Saddam Husseins son Uday.

title: The Extreme Stunts of Point Break
description: A closer look at some of the action scenes in Point Break, coordinated and performed by extreme sports athletes.

title: Review: Point Break, an X-Games Remake
As Oil Money Melts, Alaska Mulls First Income Tax in 35 Years
description: ANCHORAGE  Oil money no longer pays the bills here.

title: In Betsy Podlachs Sensual Portraits, an Undercurrent of Love
description: In his poem As I Walked Out One Evening, W. H. Auden wrote: And down by the brimming river/ I heard a lover sing/ Under an arch of the railway:/ Love has no ending  .

title: An Artist of Bears, Caterpillars and Friends
description: In Eric Carles 2013 picture book Friends, the illustrator takes a little boy on a solo journey across a river, over a mountain, through a meadow, above the clouds and into forests to reconnect with a friend who moved away.

title: Final Note for Crossroads Music, a Local Hangout in Amagansett
description: On a recent Sunday afternoon in Amagansett, Roddy Thompson, a musician from Tupelo, Miss., strolled into Crossroads Music, an instrument store, school, and general music-lovers hangout. He sat on a bench in the sunny room, picked up a guitar and started to strum an original tune.

title: Soaking Up the Christmas Warmth
description: Short sleeves and ice cream cones were among the peculiar sights around New York City as springlike weather lingered on Christmas Day.

title: Warhol and Mapplethorpe: Exploring Gender as Disguise and Identity
description: On a small wall in Warhol & Mapplethorpe: Guise & Dolls, at the Wadsworth Atheneum Museum of Art in Hartford, a photographic portrait of Andy Warhol by Robert Mapplethorpe hangs beside a silk-screened portrait of Robert Mapplethorpe by Andy Warhol. Both are head shots; both men gaze directly at the viewer. Mapplethorpe placed Warhols face in the center of a cruciform frame and encircled his head with a saintly glow, while Warhol saturated Mapplethorpes image in a deep, devilish red.

title: Ted Cruzs Iowa Ad Offers Conservatives Red Meat on God and Guns
description: Increasing his presence on television screens in Iowa, Senator Ted Cruz released a new ad, titled Victories, portraying him as a successful fighter for conservative causes.

title: Kobe Bryant, Despite Struggles, Has Big Lead in All-Star Voting
description: Kobe Bryant, who plans to retire after the season, is the leading All-Star vote-getter by far, the N.B.A. said Friday in announcing the first returns.

title: Turkish President Erdogan Dissuades Man From Jumping Off Bridge
description: ISTANBUL  Turkeys president has often been described as a rhetorical tactician and man of the people who excels at rebuttals and rejoinders when challenged by critics on almost any issue. But on Friday, the president, Recep Tayyip Erdogan, used his skills of verbal persuasion to save a despondent man as he sought to jump off the Bosporus Bridge here.

title: Political Dark Money Just Got Darker
description: As untold millions of dollars pour into the shadowy campaign troughs of the presidential candidates, voters need to be reminded of the rosy assumptions of the Supreme Courts Citizens United decision that legitimized the new spending frenzy.

title: Put Reforms Into State Prison Guards Contract
description: In New York State, some prison guards may well feel free to beat prisoners nearly to death because their union contract, which expires at the end of March, protects even the worst of them from being fired, disciplined or moved into jobs where they could do less harm.

title: Candidates Children in the Peanut Gallery
description: Presidential candidates children and grandchildren are turning up once again. Ted Cruzs decision to cast his daughters in an attack ad and Hillary Clintons just like your abuela misfire make one wonder anew, Why do candidates seek advantage by shoving the next generations center stage while insisting that they remain politically off limits?

title: The 2-Year Law Education Fails to Take Off
description: A quicker, cheaper law degree  which got a major vote of confidence when President Obama, a lawyer and former law professor, unexpectedly endorsed it in August 2013  has been widely promoted  as an ideal way to slash growing student debt and give beginning lawyers a leg up in a difficult job market.

title: Protg of Clintons Targets U.S. Congressional Seat
description: A cluster of political donors gathered in the downtown Little Rock, Ark., office of Wesley K. Clark earlier this month, listening closely as the retired general praised a Democratic candidate for Congress in effusive terms.

title: Iran: Relatives Visit a Jailed Reporter
description: Jason Rezaian, the Washington Post correspondent who has been incarcerated in Iran since July 2014, was permitted an extended visit with his wife and mother on Friday in what appeared to be a Christmas gesture by the Iranian authorities. Mr. Rezaian, 39, a California native, has been accused of espionage and other hostile acts, charges that he and his supporters say are unfounded. His mother, Mary Rezaian, and his wife, Yeganeh Salehi, shared a home-cooked meal with him at Evin Prison in Tehran, according to an account Mrs. Rezaian relayed to her other son, Ali Rezaian, in the United States. It was the longest meeting with him since she arrived last December, Ali Rezaian said in an email. Martin Baron, The Posts executive editor, said in a statement that he welcomed the gesture but said Iran should release Mr. Rezaian and allow him a return to life as a free man who can spend time with his family where and whenever he pleases.

title: Iraq: Leading Cleric Urges Release of Kidnapped Qatari Hunters
description: Grand Ayatollah Ali al-Sistani, Iraqs most important Shiite cleric, on Friday called for the immediate release of a group of at least 26 Qatari hunters who were abducted while on a government-approved safari in southern Iraq more than a week ago. Ayatollah Sistanis statement, released through his representative, Ahmed al-Safi, in the holy city of Karbala, said that the central government must help to free all the abducted hunters and called the kidnapping wrong and bound to harm the countrys reputation. No group has claimed responsibility for the seizure of the Qataris, who included some members of Qatars royal family. The ayatollah, whose proclamations are influential among Iraqs Shiite majority, spoke a day after Arab League foreign ministers also called for the release of the captives. There has been speculation that Shiite militias in southern Iraq are responsible.

title: With Added Distance, Extra Points Become Less Than Automatic
description: When Jacksonville Jaguars kicker Jason Myers blasted a kickoff through the uprights, moments after missing his seventh extra-point attempt of the season in a Week 14 win over the Indianapolis Colts, the home crowd gave him a sarcastic ovation, prompting him to slam his helmet into an equipment bag.

title: 192 Days Later, Cavaliers Again Fall to Warriors
description: OAKLAND, Calif.  David Blatt, the coach of the Cleveland Cavaliers, was on the team bus heading to Oracle Arena on Friday morning when he had the strange sensation that he had just left this place. How long had it actually been since the Golden State Warriors ousted the Cavaliers in the N.B.A. finals? To Blatt, it felt like yesterday.

title: FedEx Is Hit With Delays After Storms Across South
description: Heavy demand and bad storms delayed some holiday deliveries at FedEx, forcing the carrier to add extra staffing on Christmas Day.

title: A Festival of Language for the Good of Yiddish
description: On a stretch of the East Village, New York Citys Christmas hush was interrupted by a peculiar melody. It was not a Bing Crosby croon or Mariah Careys melismatic whistle, but the faint hum of a clarinet playing along to Undzer Nigndl.

title: A Sailing Event Down Under Suddenly Gains a Global Reach
description: Before sailing in Australias great race, which started on Saturday in Sydney and will end in Hobart, the competitors and their yachts had to get to Sydney.

title: 11 Wins May Not Be Enough for a Playoff Spot, but 7 May Be
description: With 31 games remaining in the regular season, there about two billion ways the N.F.L. season could end. Which of those outcomes is best for your team? Such a question led us to buildour N.F.L. simulator, which can be found at nytimes.com/sports, allowing you to explore which games matter the most for your teams playoff chances.

title: City Hall, a Restaurant Hangout for Officials in TriBeCa, Is Closing
description: City Hall is closing  the restaurant at 131 Duane Street in TriBeCa in Manhattan, not City Hall, the seat of government a couple of blocks away.

title: Robert D. Douglas Jr., Eagle Scout Elder and Adventurer, Dies at 103
description: Robert Dick Douglas Jr., who joined the Boy Scouts on his 12th birthday in 1924 and by 17 had shot a lion on safari in Africa, hunted whales and grizzly bears in Alaska and written two books on his adventures, died on Wednesday in Greensboro, N.C. He was 103 and one of the nations oldest Eagle Scouts.

title: Alabama Declares State of Emergency as Flooding From Storms Continues
description: ATLANTA  Gov. Robert Bentley of Alabama declared a state of emergency on Friday as heavy rain and flooding paralyzed areas in the central and northern parts of the state.

title: Kiss of the Dragon
description: SATURDAY PUZZLE  Maybe its because its the holiday season, maybe Im just getting better at these Saturdays, but this one fell pretty quickly for me. Im betting that its because there was just enough pop culture in it to give me a leg up and make this puzzle by James Mulhern fun to solve.

title: Woman Draws From Her Own Struggles to Help Others Find Work
description: Boredom was a powerful motivator for Chanelle Williams.

title: Returning to His Bronx Neighborhood on Christmas Eve, a Teenager Is Fatally Shot
description: The young couple spent much of the evening on a porch, enjoying the warmth of a tropical December night, as the first hours of Christmas approached in the Bronx.

title: Meant as Homage, Bars Naming for Downtown Squatter Is Perceived as a Slight
description: Adam Purple was an opinionated, sometimes cantankerous, freethinker who lived as a squatter on the Lower East Side of Manhattan, avoided commerce and considered real estate development to be a scourge.

title: The Times Square Ball Drop, in Times Past
description: New York Times photographers documented the tension and release of the annual gathering.

title: New Years Eve, Times Square, Through the Years
description: Whats so special about New Years Eve? Plenty. For starters, photographs of the event rarely show happy families gathered together to celebrate. Its not that kind of occasion. Alone among American holidays, New Years is a time for family members to run to their separate corners: grown-ups to do stuff that might charitably be called childish, and children to try on the rituals of adults.

title: The Best-Selling Sports Books
description: The best-selling sports books in November 2015, according to the New York Times best-seller list:

description: Weve had it awfully good for a long time, and if we want to protect that, were going to have to make some hard choices.

title: Corrections: December 26, 2015
description: INTERNATIONAL

title: What to Watch Saturday
description: On this Boxing Day, you may still be at the house of friends or family. You may not be able to figure out how to use their remote control. So stream new additions to Netflix and use the last days of the year to watch Almost Famous and Zoolander before they are taken down on New Years Day.

title: Patricia Field Hangs Up Her Retail Wig
description: Do you mind if I have a cigarette? Patricia Field asked, though the deep gravel of her voice indicated that the question was rhetorical. She was sitting in the basement office of her eponymous boutique at 306 Bowery, wearing a black tank-top, dark capri pants and heavy blue mascara that complemented her trademark vermilion hair: a punk knockout at 73.

title: Breaking Up? Let an App Do It for You
description: Checklist for the holidays: Buy bejeweled 2016 eyeglasses and noisemakers from street vendor. Stock Champagne. Regift perfume and sweaters. Turn Christmas tree into mulch. And, oh yes, break up with significant other.

title: Going Cashless in Sweden
description: Few countries are tilting toward a cashless future as quickly as Sweden, where parishioners text tithes to their churches and street vendors carry card readers.

title: Jet.coms Strategy: Low Prices, Fast Delivery, Happy Workers
description: You cant accuse Jet.com of timidity.

title: In Sweden, a Cash-Free Future Nears
description: STOCKHOLM  Parishioners text tithes to their churches. Homeless street vendors carry mobile credit-card readers. Even the Abba Museum, despite being a shrine to the 1970s pop group that wrote Money, Money, Money, considers cash so last-century that it does not accept bills and coins.

title: The Week on Instagram
description: Photos posted on @nytimes this week took followers from Prague to the Division of Old Records in Surrogates Court in Lower Manhattan.

title: China Says It Will Expel French Journalist
description: HONG KONG  Chinas Foreign Ministry said Saturday that a French journalist would be expelled from the country for writing an article about ethnic violence in Chinas northwest, one that the government viewed as sympathetic to terrorism.

title: The Killing of Farkhunda
description: Farkhunda Malikzada, a 27-year-old Muslim woman falsely accused of burning a Quran, was killed by a mob in central Kabul as hundreds watched and filmed. This video contains scenes of graphic violence.

title: Flawed Justice After a Mob Killed an Afghan Woman
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  Farkhunda had one chance to escape the mob that wanted to kill her. Two Afghan police officers pulled her onto the roof of a low shed, above the angry crowd.

title: A Year of Grievances and Solutions
description: Ask Real Estate is a weekly column that answers questions from across the New York region. Submit yours to realestateqa@nytimes.com.

title: As Graduation Rates Rise, Experts Fear Diplomas Come Up Short
description: GREENVILLE, S.C.  A sign in a classroom here at Berea High School, northwest of downtown in the largest urban district in the state, sends this powerful message: Failure Is Not an Option. You Will Pass. You Will Learn. You Will Succeed.

title: Variety: A Determined Acrostic
description: VARIETY PUZZLE  For most people, the old tradition of making New Years resolutions is not filled with FESTIVITY. Who wants to think about having to be a better person than you already are, and then project that out over the course of an entire year at that? Its overwhelming.

title: Christie Spins His Version of Security Record on Trail
description: As a presidential candidate, Gov. Chris Christie has sought to differentiate himself by spotlighting his tenure as the United States attorney for New Jersey, framing it as a time when he spent his life protecting our country against terrorism. The message has begun to resonate: Mr. Christie, long an underdog in the Republican presidential field, has recently risen in the polls.

title: Man Kills Family and Then Shoots Himself in New Jersey
description: EDGEWATER, N.J.  By dinnertime on Christmas, Mellie Staskos uncle had grown worried.

title: A Janitor, Once an Addict, Cleans Up His Life
description: When Eric Gonzalez started working as a custodian on East 125th Street in Harlem for a local merchants association earlier this year, the hardest part was not hauling trash or sweeping gutters. It was dealing with the K2 addicts.

title: An Entrepreneur Juggles Six Companies and One Worker: Herself
description: One afternoon in early 2014, an employee of the Manhattan co-working space Coworkrs got behind the handlebars of a large tricycle and began pedaling it through the Flatiron district. The tricycle was outfitted with a small desk; the employee seemed to be sitting at her desk while cycling around the city.

title: Getting a Promotion, but Feeling Shortchanged by the Raise

title: After a Difficult Start, a Jets Receiver Prepares, Stays Alert and Rises
description: FLORHAM PARK, N.J.  Kenbrell Thompkins wakes up at 5 a.m. on weekdays. He dresses, reads some Bible passages and arrives at the Jets complex here by 5:45. When he enters the locker room, none of his teammates are inside, not even his fellow receiver Brandon Marshall, who was astounded to discover that someone could beat him there.

description: I HAVE a letter for you, my friend Kirsten tells me on the phone.

title: Charity and Justice
description: Reimagining philanthropy: Relieving suffering and injustice through social change.

title: Dont Abandon Puerto Rico
description: The leaders of Puerto Rico could soon have to choose between cutting essential services like the police, hospitals and education, and paying bondholders. To avoid this catastrophe, Congress needs to help the island, which is home to 3.5 million American citizens, by giving it the ability to restructure its debts in an orderly way.

title: The Real Victims of Victimhood
description: BACK in 1993, the misanthropic art critic Robert Hughes published a grumpy, entertaining book called Culture of Complaint, in which he predicted that America was doomed to become increasingly an infantilized culture of victimhood. It was a rant against what he saw as a grievance industry appearing all across the political spectrum.

title: A Fearful Congress Sits Out the War Against ISIS
description: The  omnibus spending bill Congress passed this month includes several explicit mentions of the military campaign against the Islamic State and a $58.7 billion budget line that will allow the Pentagon to continue fighting the terrorist group in Iraq and Syria with bombs and, increasingly, troops on the ground.

title: Cracks in the Liberal Order
description: IN the twenty-five years since the fall of the Berlin Wall, the architecture of liberal modernity has looked relatively stable. Not flawless or wonderful or ideal, to be sure; not free of discontents and decadence. But its been hard to imagine the basic liberal democratic capitalist order cracking up, let alone envision what might take its place.

title: New Minimum Wages in the New Year
description: In five states and nine cities  including California, New York, Oregon and Washington, D.C.  voters and lawmakers will consider proposals in 2016 to gradually raise minimum wages to $15 an hour.

description: LONDON  He was the youngest of the participants in the Paris terrorist attacks, a baby-faced 20-year-old whose attention had drifted from soccer, cigarettes and girls to the venomous messages of extremist Islam.

description: 8:30 p.m., NBC

description: 1 p.m., CBS

title: Doubling Down On W
description: As Ive said, its hard these days for liberals to look at the state of the Republican primary without feeling a lot of Trumpenfreude. But one downside of The Donalds turn in the spotlight is that the policy positions of the tonsorially conventional candidates are going largely unscrutinized, which is bad. For the fact is that the whole field has taken a hard right turn into fantasyland.

title: Kentucky Survives Close Call Against Louisville
description: LEXINGTON, Ky.  At one point in the second half, Kentucky Coach John Calipari was so animated after a failed offensive sequence that he tripped and fell backward into his bench.

title: Binary Code
description: SUNDAY PUZZLE  It seems like the year just flew by, doesnt it? Yet here we are, at the final Sunday crossword puzzle for 2015. Weve played with a lot of words this year, but today we get to break that down even further and play with some of the letters that make up those words.

title: Noboru Ando, 89, Mobster and Film Star in Japan, Dies
description: Noboru Ando, a yakuza, or mobster, who made a seamless transition from gang leader to movie star in dozens of Japanese crime films of the 1960s and 70s, died on Dec. 16 in Tokyo. He was 89.

title: Lewis M. Dabney, Who Devoted Lifes Work to Edmund Wilson, Dies at 83
description: Lewis M. Dabney, a literary scholar whose doctoral dissertation at Columbia steered his path to becoming perhaps the pre-eminent expert on the life and work of Edmund Wilson, died on Tuesday at his home in Easton, Md. He was 83.

title: South Carolina Faces the High Cost of Curating Historys Dustbin
description: COLUMBIA, S.C.  After decades of debate in South Carolina over the Confederate battle flag, it seemed the matter had been settled in July, when state officials stopped flying the flag on State House grounds and relegated it to a museum for appropriate display.

title: Chicago Police Fatally Shoot 2, Raising New Questions for a Force Under Scrutiny
description: CHICAGO  The police fatally shot a man and a woman on Chicagos West Side early Saturday, setting off a new flurry of questions about a department already under intense scrutiny.

title: ISIS, Facing Losses, Releases Recording Said to Be of Leader
description: BAGHDAD  The Islamic State on Saturday released an audio recording of a speech purportedly made by the organizations leader, Abu Bakr al-Baghdadi, in which he implored more Muslims to fight on behalf of his increasingly besieged group.

title: Robert Spitzer, 83, Dies; Psychiatrist Set Rigorous Standards for Diagnosis
description: Dr. Robert L. Spitzer, who gave psychiatry its first set of rigorous standards to describe mental disorders, providing a framework for diagnosis, research and legal judgments  as well as a lingua franca for the endless social debate over where to draw the line between normal and abnormal behavior  died on Friday in Seattle. He was 83.

title: Duke Wins at Yankee Stadium (Attendance Isnt Exactly Out of the Park)
description: Duke outlasted Indiana in overtime, 44-41, under leaden skies at Yankee Stadium on Saturday to win the sixth Pinstripe Bowl, but an eagerly awaited number of higher importance, at least to the baseball team that runs the show, was announced in the second quarter: 37,218.

title: Eight Dead as Tornadoes Strike the Dallas Area
description: At least eight people were killed in the Dallas area Saturday night when as many as 11 tornadoes swept North Texas, officials said.

title: Severe Weather Across the U.S.
description: Severe weather across the United States over the holiday weekend.

title: Drought Deepens South Africas Malaise
description: SETLAGOLE, South Africa  Under a midmorning sun that augured punishing heat later in the day, a handful of cows stood still inside a small pen, their ribs protruding. Too weak to reach the nearest grassy field some miles away, some munched on tall grass that their owner had cut from a strip of land along the highway, in a desperate attempt to save his cattle from the drought afflicting the land.

title: Schools Evaluate Threats, Questioning When to Shut Down
description: Mark Conrad, the superintendent of schools in Nashua, N.H., got the chilling news last Sunday morning. An email sent to a school board member threatened a lethal attack on multiple schools, naming the sites, how students would be harmed and the date, Dec. 21  the next day.

title: Veteran International Prosecutor Foresees War Crimes Trials for ISIS
description: THE HAGUE  Stephen J. Rapp, a veteran American lawyer and a familiar figure in international courts, was doing what he most favors  talking about war crimes. Not just citing conflicts that demand the worlds attention, but also discussing how to pursue top offenders.

title: David Hopmann, James Taul Jr.
description: David Edward Hopmann and James Wiley Taul Jr. were married Dec. 21 in the rotunda of San Franciscos City Hall by the Rev. Richard Wilmington, an Episcopal priest.

title: Shera Fingerman and Raimy Amasha: Prescribing Love for a Doctor
description: Shera Lynn Fingerman and Dr. Raimy Raymond Amasha are to be married Dec. 27 at BridgeStreet Gallery and Loft in Birmingham, Ala. Rabbi Barry Altmark is to officiate, with Cantor Kathy Bar, a cousin of the bride, taking part.

title: Lauren Levy, Simon Bangiyev
description: Dr. Lauren Lee Levy, a daughter of Denise A. Sofferman of Manhattan, was married on the evening of Dec. 26 to Dr. Simon Yakov Bangiyev, a son of Natalia S. Bangiyev and Dr. Yakov M. Bangiyev of Forest Hills, Queens. Rabbi Ari Isenberg-Grzeda officiated at Valbella, a restaurant in Manhattan.

title: Julia Nietsch, Stephan Kouris
description: Julia Nietsch, a daughter of Helene J. Nietsch of Newtown, Conn., and William W. Nietsch of New Milford, Conn., is to be married Dec. 27 to Stephan Peter Kouris, a son of Despina C. Kouris and Petros S. Kouris of Fresh Meadows, Queens. The Rev. Chrysostomos Gilbert is to perform the ceremony at the Greek Orthodox Archdiocesan Cathedral of the Holy Trinity in Manhattan.

title: Charlianne James, Adrien Albert
description: Charlianne Elizabeth James and Adrien Benjamin Albert were married Dec. 21 at the Manhattan Marriage Bureau. Angel L. Lopez, a staff member of the New York City Clerks office, officiated.

title: Riddhima Gandhi, Neil Mehta
description: Riddhima Gaurang Gandhi, the daughter of Shabnam A. Gandhi and Gaurang M. Gandhi of Mumbai, India, was married Dec. 24 in Udaipur, India, to Neil Kumar Mehta, a son of Raksha D. Mehta and Dinesh C. Mehta of Great Falls, Va. O. P. Bunkar, the marriage officer and additional district magistrate of Udaipur, officiated at the Leela Palace, a hotel there. Pandit Rajunikant Vyas led the Hindu religious ceremony that day, also at the Leela Palace, which is on Lake Pichola.

title: Elise Viebeck, Andrew Caplan
description: Elise Joy Viebeck and Andrew Laurence Caplan are to be married Dec. 27 at the Merchants Exchange Building in San Francisco. Elise S. Turen, an aunt of the groom who became a minister of American Marriage Ministries for the occasion, is to officiate.

title: Robert Marshall, Kurt Meister
description: Robert Charles Marshall and Kurt Christian Meister were married Dec. 22 at the Manhattan Marriage Bureau. Edwina M. Townes, a staff member of the New York City Clerks office, officiated.

title: Leigh Janiak, Ross Duffer
description: Leigh Anne Janiak and Ross Christensen Duffer were married Dec. 22 at Korakia Pensione, a resort in Palm Springs, Calif. Jennifer Knode, a friend of the couple who became a Universal Life minister for the event, officiated.

title: Redskins Claim N.F.C. East Title and End the Giants Playoff Chances
description: PHILADELPHIA  With the ball sitting at the Philadelphia 6-yard line with six seconds left in the first half and no timeouts remaining, Washington quarterback Kirk Cousins had options as he stood behind center.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: The goal is not just high school graduation. The goal is being truly college and career ready.

title: Corrections: December 27, 2015
description: NATIONAL

title: Anxiety Aside, New York Sees Drop in Crime
description: Homeless encampments proliferated. Two officers, confronting armed men, were shot and killed. And many New Yorkers said they felt less safe.

title: India Offers Atypical Video Challenges
description: MUMBAI  As the morning rain dripped in the garden outside, the yoga teacher Aparajita Jamwal got down on one knee, stretching the other leg behind her in a lunge known as the equestrian pose.

title: ISIS Influence on Web Prompts Second Thoughts on First Amendment
description: It is one of the most hallowed precepts in modern constitutional law: Freedom of speech may not be curbed unless it poses a clear and present danger  an actual, imminent threat, not the mere advocacy of harmful acts or ideas. But in response to the Islamic States success in grooming jihadists over the Internet, some legal scholars are asking whether it is time to reconsider that constitutional line.

title: Common Stock Ownership Spreads Among Start-Up Investors
description: When institutional investors put money into companies backed by venture capital, they typically end up owning a type of stock called preferred shares. Now, institutional investors are also becoming owners of a different class of start-up stock: common shares.

title: The Other Woman Who Snuggles My Daughter
description: On the weekend after Thanksgiving, my daughter met her: my former husbands new girlfriend.

title: State-Level Brawls Over Medicaid Reflect Divide in G.O.P.
description: WASHINGTON  John Thune of South Dakota, the No. 3 Republican in the Senate, voted earlier this month to repeal major provisions of the Affordable Care Act and to end its expansion of Medicaid, arguing that the health law was unpopular and unaffordable.

description: Rams (6-8) at Seahawks (9-5)
