description: SEATTLE  Robbie Bach has felt the highs and lows of the video game business.

title: White House to Host Justin Trudeau of Canada for State Dinner
description: The Obama White House knows political glamour when it sees it, and Justin Trudeau, Canadas new prime minister, certainly fits the bill. So it is not surprising that the White House announced on Monday that President and Mrs. Obama would host the worlds newest political celebrity and his wife, Sophie Grgoire-Trudeau, on March 10 for one of the final state dinners of Mr. Obamas presidency.

title: Ethan Couch, Affluenza Teenager, Had Last Party Before Fleeing, Officials Say
description: FORT WORTH  The Texas teenager was facing the prospect of a court hearing that could have sent him to jail, so he and his mother held a kind of farewell celebration with friends. Then they got into their black Ford pickup truck and disappeared.

title: Why Self-Identifying Is Different From Coming Out
description: By necessity, the folks officiating your sports are a relatively anonymous lot. You come to watch a game. They enforce its rules, and given the hell that keyed-up spectators can give an official, the maintenance of a kind of privacy makes sense. Anonymity does have its exceptions. Some are happy. Ed Hochuli, for instance, is known for both the work he does as an N.F.L. referee and the work he does on his body (hes ripped). Some exceptions are less happy. The Bill Kennedy situation is one of these.

title: The Primary That Disqualified the Qualified
description: Midway into a long Decembers day of campaigning throughout New Hampshire, the state on which he had pinned his flagging electoral hopes, the Republican presidential candidate John Kasich stood in the middle of a Greek restaurants banquet room and shared a few words of introduction. Then he told the small audience that he would be happy to take questions, adding, with an arid half-smile, But if the questions are about You Know Who, Im not interested in answering them.

title: The Imperiled Bloggers of Bangladesh
description: Until he was stabbed multiple times with a kitchen knife and forced to flee to Europe two years ago, Asif Mohiuddin was a leading member of Bangladeshs freethinker movement and the countrys best-known secular provocateur. We met last June at a cafe on a pedestrian promenade around the corner from his apartment, a sunlit space in a shabby-chic neighborhood in northern Germany. (He asked me not to name the city.) Mohiuddin, dressed that day in jeans and a green T-shirt that proclaimed American Atheists Convention, Memphis, April 2-5, 2015, was still getting used to the tranquillity of his new surroundings. Shortly after he secured a fellowship at a German institute and left Bangladesh, extremists serially murdered four of his friends  all secular bloggers who had criticized fundamentalist Islam and whose names appeared on hit lists assembled by hard-liners and disseminated on social media. Everybody is wondering who will be next, Mohiuddin told me while picking halfheartedly at the kiwi slices on his plate.

title: Concussion Report Highlights Field Maintenance
description: When St. Louis Rams quarterback Case Keenum sustained a concussion in a game in Baltimore last month, commentators focused on how he wobbled as he got up and questioned why he was not taken out of the game. Few mentioned that he had slammed his head on the turf.

description: Donald J. Trump seems aware that he has a fight on his hands in New Hampshire, and that he needs to battle to at least a draw.

description: Berlin  GERMANY is not lacking in right-wing sentiment these days, but most people are careful about how they deploy their anti-immigrant rhetoric. And then theres Bjrn Hcke.

description: The N.F.L.s new try rule has resulted in lots of missed kicks  as intended, the point-after attempt is no longer automatic. But deuces still arent wild.

title: Suicide Attack Targets Regional Government Office in Pakistan
description: PESHAWAR, Pakistan  A suicide bomber struck a regional branch of Pakistans National Database and Registration Authority in Mardan on Tuesday, killing at least 22 people and wounding more than 40, a police official said.

title: A Belgian Destination for Homewares and Curiosities
description: Located in a former solar-panel store on a back street in Antwerp, Atelier Solarshop has, over the last seven years, quietly become one of the citys most interesting boutiques. Since it opened  and without advertising or fanfare  the store has slowly built a reputation for well-made things.

title: In Portland, Thai Food Moves Beyond the Usual
description: When Andy Ricker opened Pok Pok in Portland, Ore., 10 years ago, he wanted to introduce Americans to Thai cuisine beyond the pad Thai and green curries they were used to  introducing the more-nuanced cuisine he had found in his travels around Thailand.

title: 1940: Roosevelt Seeks to Aid Britain
description: WASHINGTON  President Roosevelt tonight [Dec. 29] called upon the nation to put forth a mightier effort than it had been doing to increase the output of all implements of defense in order to become the arsenal of democracy. The emergency, he said, was as serious as war itself and called for the same sense of urgency and the same spirit of patriotism and sacrifice as though this country were at war. The President appealed to capital and labor, management and workers to put every ounce of effort into production. New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, Dec. 30, 1940

title: Moroccos Other Coast Emerges as a Destination
description: On a sandy curb, one dune away from the crashing Atlantic surf, a wiry vendor in a blue plastic chair with baskets of razor clams and oysters at his feet scissored open a spiky purple sea urchin, balancing a cardboard strip on his lap as a cutting board. He made a great show of washing a stainless steel spoon, which my husband and I shared to scoop out the creamy orange shellfish within.

title: 3 Museum Upgrades Worth Seeing in Paris
description: Last year brought not one but three new or updated cultural hubs to Paris.

title: French Artists Will Take Their Irreverence to the Grave
description: PARIS  Benot Delpine, a French film director, likes to stroll by his tomb occasionally to check on the neighbors and the new arrivals.

title: Daily Report: When Academia Nurtures Entrepreneurs
description: The foundational stories of successful tech companies  at least the ones people like to tell over and over again  always include an unlikely and humble place: The family garage, a rented garage, even a playground.

title: Big Bang Theory Is Accused of Stealing Soft Kitty Lyrics
description: The daughters of a New Hampshire poet say The Big Bang Theory stole their mothers verses about a soft kitty for a lullaby that has become a staple of the television show.

title: Breaking Up With Apple Music
description: Q. I signed up for the free trial of Apple Music and forgot I had it until I noticed I was getting billed for it. I looked in the app, but I cant figure out how to cancel the service. How does one resign from Apple Music?

title: What Science Fiction Movie or Novel Is Most Prescient Today?
1965: Johnson Starts Bid for Peace
description: WASHINGTON  President Johnson launched today [Dec. 29] an all-out  and possibly final  drive to get the war in Vietnam to the negotiating table. Moving behind a curtain of secrecy, he dispatched two of his most trusted aides on sudden missions to Europe to see if they can get peace talks under way. Mr. Johnsons roving ambassador, Averell Harriman, turned up unexpectedly in Warsaw to get across to the Communist world that North Vietnam must agree to talks. Almost simultaneously, Arthur Goldberg, U.S. ambassador to the United Nations, flew secretly into Rome to enlist the Pope in the effort to settle the war. New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, Dec. 30, 1965

title: A Kickback by Any Other Name, Stinks Just As Bad
description: When is a kickback not a kickback?

title: Hillary Clinton Ad in Iowa and New Hampshire Focuses on Wage Gap
description: Hillary Clintons campaign has begun airing a new ad in Iowa and in New Hampshire that was not announced publicly, a spot that focuses on ending the wage gap and criticizes Republicans who will let corporations write their own rules.

title: South Korean and Japanese Leaders Feel Backlash From Comfort Women Deal
description: TOKYO  The leaders of South Korea and Japan faced a barrage of criticism on Tuesday from nationalists upset about a landmark deal aimed at resolving a dispute over Korean women who had been pressed into sexual servitude in Japanese military brothels before and during World War II.

title: The Iran-Iraq War, by Pierre Razoux
description: The war between Saddam Husseins Iraq and Ruhollah Khomeinis Iran ended 27 years ago, before most of todays Iraqis and Iranians were alive. Many of todays Americans were pretty young then, too  certainly too young to remember the glee with which United States policy makers watched the war, an eight-year storm of steel that killed as many as a million people and exhausted two unsavory regimes. The most famous line about the war is also the most fatuous. Henry Kissinger is said to have remarked that it was a shame there can only be one loser. In fact, they both lost: Few modern wars have so thoroughly broken, traumatized and destroyed both sides, and few have turned out to have had such disfiguring effects on the region or on American foreign policy.

title: Celebrating Victory Over ISIS, Iraqi Leader Looks to Next Battles
description: BAGHDAD  Prime Minister Haider al-Abadi of Iraq flew to the western city of Ramadi on Tuesday to celebrate its liberation from the Islamic State, as jubilant, flag-waving Iraqis thronged the citys battle-scarred streets with cars and pickup trucks.

title: Black Box Thinking and Failure: Why Science Is So Successful
description: After more than a half-century of unraveling cognitive biases, the psychologist and Nobel laureate Daniel Kahneman feels deeply pessimistic about our ability to change our behavior. In a 2014 Guardian interview, Kahneman told the Harvard psychologist Steven Pinker that the idea of human nature with inherent flaws was consistent with a tragic view of the human condition, and its a part of being human that we have to live with that tragedy. Though acknowledging Kahnemans influence on his own work, Pinker countered with a diametrically opposed view of the same material. We have the means to overcome some of our limitations, through education, through institutions, through enlightenment. His optimism that rationality will overcome our baser instincts is the underlying argument of his 2011 book The Better Angels of Our Nature.

title: For the Wealthiest, a Private Tax System That Saves Them Billions
description: WASHINGTON  The hedge fund magnates Daniel S. Loeb, Louis Moore Bacon and Steven A. Cohen have much in common. They have managed billions of dollars in capital, earning vast fortunes. They have invested large sums in art  and millions more in political candidates.

title: New Yorks Chief Judge Leaving a Legacy of Reforms Inspired by Social Justice
description: A few weeks before he was to retire as chief judge of one of the nations most influential courts, Jonathan Lippman traveled to Brooklyn to open a small storefront office that offers legal advice to poor people in civil cases, like housing disputes and fights with creditors.

title: Kendrick Lamar on the Grammys, Black Lives Matter and His Big 2015
description: LOS ANGELES  On To Pimp a Butterfly, Kendrick Lamars overflowing post-fame album, he was, in his own words, a king, a hypocrite, a sinner and a prophet. Awash in black music, black pride and shame, he attempted to propel the ghosts of Nelson Mandela, Tupac Shakur, Huey Newton and Michael Jackson through the will of his conflicted rhymes. As I lead this army make room for mistakes and depression, he warned at the end. Heavy was the head.

title: Chilaquiles to Welcome the New Year
description: Sometimes I make green tomatillo salsa just to give me an excuse to make chilaquiles, the comforting Mexican dish made with fried tortillas and salsa. Throughout Mexico, you find both red and green versions of chilaquiles, as well as one made with pured black beans. But this salsa verde version has always been my favorite. I love the contrast of the tangy tomatillos against the earthy tortillas.

title: Goat Meat, Not Beef, Found in Home of Indian Killed Over Cow-Slaughter Rumors
description: JAIPUR, India  Three months after an angry mob beat to death a Muslim man in the state of Uttar Pradesh after rumors that he had slaughtered a cow and consumed its meat, a preliminary investigation has found that the meat retrieved from his home was goat.

title: Barclays to Pay $13.75 Million to Settle Case Over Mutual Funds
description: Barclays Capital failed to stop 6,100 unsuitable switches between mutual funds on behalf of its customers over a five-year period that ended in June, resulting in $8.6 million of customer harm, the Financial Industry Regulatory Authority said on Tuesday.

title: A Plan to Untangle Philadelphias Daunting Decay
description: PHILADELPHIA  To have any hope of reviving this citys many blighted streets, developers would have to purchase property like 1913 North 24th Street, an empty lot that is still officially owned by a man who died in 1969.

description: Will Dean is the co-founder of a company that holds elaborate endurance events all over the world. But his daily workout is simple.

description: This week, were sharing stories from children, teenagers and families about the charities that inspire them to give time, money and passion. Family Gateway in Dallas inspired Anne Johnson to write.

This just flies in the face of the facts. Three points:

title: How Facebook Helps Tortoise Traffickers  Until it Doesnt

description: A Republican state lawmaker from Virginia who stood up to Donald J. Trump is feeling the wrath of his angry supporters this week, facing a torrent of hectoring and death threats from people accusing him of being a Muslim terrorist.

title: Mauricio Macri, Argentine President, Is Cleared of Wiretapping Charges
description: INTENDENTE ALVEAR, Argentina  A federal judge threw out charges on Tuesday against Argentinas president, Mauricio Macri, in an illegal phone-tapping case that has hung over him for years. The judge, Sebastin Casanello, dismissed charges that Mr. Macri participated in a wiretapping scheme that date to his tenure as the mayor of Buenos Aires.

title: Letters: The Novels Evil Tongue
description: To the Editor:

title: The Year Ahead for Readers
description: If your resolution for 2016 is to read more, here are 16 possible places to start. At less than 300 pages, Don DeLillos Zero K (due in May) wont have the sheer bulk of Underworld or Libra, but it will feature his usual thematic ambition, this time dealing with a billionaire who invests in a project to delay death.

title: Field Peas, a Southern Good Luck Charm
description: SHORTER, Ala.  Eating a bowl of black-eyed peas on New Years Day is not the nations sexiest food ritual.

title: Jeb Bush Sprints to Escape Donald Trumps Low Energy Label
description: EXETER, N.H.  Jeb Bush practically shouted his stump speech here, slamming Donald J. Trump as a chaotic candidate who loves the chaos because its all about him. He knocked President Obama and Hillary Clinton for believing that containing ISIS is actually a strategy.

title: Syria and France Said to Be Deadliest for Journalists in 2015
description: At least 69 journalists were killed in the line of duty this year, and Islamic militant groups such as the Islamic State and Al Qaeda were responsible for 40 percent of the deaths, a press advocacy group reported Tuesday.

title: Mandate Memories
description: Sarah Kliff notes that the individual mandate in Obamacare is turning out to be essential  and its working, with the risk pool improving as the penalties kick in. What I wrote back in 2007, when Obama was campaigning against the mandate.

title: Where to Buy Field Peas
description: Dried black-eyed peas are perfectly serviceable for your soup bowl, and widely available in supermarkets around the country. But its worth it to seek out other varieties of cowpeas for a deeper range of flavor and more-pleasing texture.

title: Queen of the Night Will Play Last Performance on New Years Eve
description: Queen of the Night, the sensually interactive dinner theater spectacle, will close two years after its first performance at the Paramount Hotel.

title: In 2015 Obituaries, Distant Eras Were Evoked
description: Mary Keefe, to her great surprise, became an emblem of the American home front in World War II. A 19-year-old telephone operator in rural Vermont, she was the wholesome model for Norman Rockwells painting Rosie the Riveter, a can-do figure who rallied American women to show their patriotism not by taking up arms but by making them, in factories, for the fighting men overseas.

title: Oklahoma Players Punch Caught on Video, but Few Get to See It
description: In early September last year, about 40 members of the news media, many of whom covered the Oklahoma Sooners football team regularly, crowded into a nondescript room at the Norman Police Department.

title: Twitter Names Jeffrey Siminoff as New Diversity Chief
description: At the end of a year in which it was regularly criticized for a lack of diversity in its work force, Twitter, the social media service, has put a new executive in charge of dealing with the issue.

title: Tonya Pinkins to Depart From Mother Courage Off Broadway
description: Tonya Pinkins, who plays the title role in Bertolt Brechts Mother Courage and Her Children at Classic Stage Company, will leave the production on Jan. 5, a publicist for the theater said on Tuesday.

title: New York Police Commissioner and Predecessor Spar Over Accuracy of Crime Data
description: Police Commissioner William J. Bratton and his predecessor, Raymond W. Kelly, opened a war of words on Tuesday, engaging in a raw and apparently spontaneous dispute over the veracity of the New York Police Departments official tally of shootings and murders.

title: The Curious Incident Is on the Grid With a New Christopher
description: I see everything. Most other people are lazy. They never look at everything.

title: U.S. Says Airstrikes Killed Militants Tied to Paris Attacks
description: LONDON  Airstrikes by the American-led coalition assisting Iraqs armed forces have killed 10 Islamic State commanders in Iraq and Syria over the past month, including some linked to the Paris attacks, a United States military spokesman said on Tuesday.

title: A Taste Test of Chocolate Bars Made From Scratch
description: A tasting of bean-to-bar chocolates made in the United States reveal an impressive collection of confections.

title: Picking the Best in Bean-to-Bar Chocolate
description: In the long history of murder, war, slavery, theft and other crimes committed in the pursuit of cacao, the sale of other peoples chocolate under the Mast Brothers label is a tiny misdemeanor, the equivalent of double parking.

title: Book Says Zhou Enlai, Chinese Premier, May Have Been Gay
description: HONG KONG  He was a towering figure of the 20th century, instrumental in building the Chinese Communist Party from the battlefield to the halls of power. He worked alongside Mao Zedong for decades, and was revered for his rich intellect and even temperament.

title: Marco Rubio and Chris Christie Toil to Belittle Each Others Work Ethic
description: CLINTON, Iowa  Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey has a cutting message for Senator Marco Rubio of Florida: You dont work very hard at your job.

title: The Most Wanted Fugitives Still On the Run
description: Though the case of Ethan Couch has captured widespread attention, many fugitives from decades ago have faded from the headlines, and remain a concern for law enforcement officials.

title: Matt Damon: You Could Call Him Down to Earth
description: BEVERLY HILLS, CALIF.  In the 1997 film Good Will Hunting, Matt Damon faces an existential crisis: Stay in Southie and work construction with his pals  whats wrong with layin brick? he asks  or use his prodigious mathematical powers for, well, who knows what. His best friend, Ben Affleck, promises to kill him if he squanders his winnin lottery ticket and picks the bricks.

title: A Conversation With Jonathan H. Simon
description: Mr. Simon, 50, is the founder, chairman and chief executive of Simon Baron Development, which focuses largely on residential and mixed-use developments, particularly rentals. Among Simon Barons current projects is a condominium at 12 East 88th Street, a prewar building in Manhattan designed by Rosario Candela.

title: An Appraisal: Scott Rothkopf, Chief Curator at the Whitney, Recalls Ellsworth Kelly
description: Words like joy, delight and wonder dont have a lot of currency in serious contemporary art criticism, which tends to prize skepticism and anxiety over supposedly easier pleasures. But it was precisely those former feelings that overcame me when I first encountered Ellsworth Kellys work en masse as a college student at his staggering 1996 retrospective at the Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum. The artist filled Frank Lloyd Wrights signature rotunda with a confetti explosion of jaunty yellow ovals, crisp blue rectangles and vivid red curves, delivering an effervescent jolt that changed the course of my life and my interest in art. His paintings were strict yet somehow sprightly, and they tended to arouse emotions that one would be hard-pressed to ascribe to Mr. Kellys equally rigorous contemporaries in the field of abstraction.

title: Recent Commercial Real Estate Transactions
description: RECENT SALE

title: Holiday on Friday: New Years Day
description: GOVERNMENT OFFICES  Closed.

title: Review: Anomalisa Pairs Charlie Kaufman and Lonely Puppets
description: The sad and stingingly painful Anomalisa, a beautiful big-screen whatsit, features a throng of whiners, malcontents and depressives along with one bright soul who hasnt let disappointment break her. Theyre a funny, odd group. Some register as generically prickly, full of vinegar and spit (a few may just be tired after a days work); others sag, as if deflating one breath at a time under an unfathomable weight. And while some carry their burden quietly and alone, others insist on sharing it, like those people who take deep, accusatory sighs when you bump into them on the subway.

title: Pictures of the Day: Afghanistan and Elsewhere
description: Afghanistan and More  Pictures of the Day

title: Ai Weiweis Instagrams From Greece
description: The Chinese artist Ai Weiwei turned his Instagram account into a news feed during a visit to the Greek island of Lesbos this week.

title: Your Evening Briefing
description: Heres what you need to know at the end of the day.

title: All the Best Concerts, of What the Critics Have Seen
description: In the full portfolio of what musicians can and must do, concerts now take their place alongside digital-only recordings, long-form videos, limited-edition vinyl, intricately timed rollouts, interviews, tweets, public disagreements and various other kinds of life-as-performance. But the stage show is still where its possible to take the full measure of a performer, whether at a D.I.Y. party or an arena. Here, from the jazz and pop critics at The New York Times, are hundreds of 2015 concert experiences boiled down to 40. BEN RATLIFF

title: Dec. 29, 2015  Pictures of the Day
description: Photos from Afghanistan, Turkey, Spain and Yemen.

title: Your Tuesday Evening Briefing: Lemmy of Motrhead, Ethan Couch,George Pataki
description: (Want to get this briefing by email? Heres the sign-up.)

title: The Hateful Eight Tests 70-Millimeter Format
description: The reviews for Quentin Tarantinos The Hateful Eight were mixed, and so were reviews for projection of the film in 70 millimeter, a seldom-used format that requires special projection equipment run by knowledgeable technicians. By Monday, on forums like Twitter and Reddit, there were reports of problems with screenings from Tampa, Fla., to Vancouver, British Columbia.

title: Revisiting the Fervor of the Womens Suffrage Movement
description: The placards read like Twitter posts from the past. In large type, printed in bold against a plain backdrop, they deliver messages from womens suffrage activists to politicians in the 1912 election: The men of twelve States and Alaska have given women their ballot. Will you not be as fair as those men?

title: Use of Affluenza Didnt Begin With Ethan Couch Case
description: The story of Ethan Couch, the Texas teenager who received probation in 2013 for his role in a deadly drunken-driving crash, has helped lodge the term affluenza securely in the American lexicon.

title: George Pataki Leaves Presidential Race
description: George E. Pataki, the former three-term New York governor who undertook a long-shot presidential bid that failed to catch fire, withdrew from the presidential race on Tuesday, urging Republicans in a televised message to nominate another candidate who could bring the country together.

title: What Were Reading  The Years Great Reads
description: Get recommendations from New York Times reporters and editors, highlighting great stories from around the web. What Were Reading emails are sent twice a week. Sign up

title: Ai Weiweis Instagram Dispatches From Lesbos, Greek Island at Center of Migrant Crisis
description: The Chinese artist Ai Weiwei this week visited the Greek island of Lesbos, where thousands of migrants continue to arrive daily, hoping to find refuge in Europe from war and poverty in the Middle East, West Asia and North Africa.

title: Texas Urges Supreme Court to Reject Appeal on Obamas Immigration Program
description: WASHINGTON  Texas urged the Supreme Court on Tuesday not to consider an appeal on President Obamas immigration program, arguing that lower courts had properly rejected the administrations sweeping and unprecedented assertion of executive authority.

title: New York State Standardizes Its Oversight of Lawyers
description: Lawyers in New York State will be subject to a uniform disciplinary process under new rules Chief Judge Jonathan Lippman announced on Tuesday, a move that caps months of negotiations aimed at standardizing a system long hampered by regional differences.

title: A Timeline of George Patakis Presidential Campaign
description: Seven months after he declared his candidacy in New Hampshire, George E. Pataki is calling it quits. The moderate conservative policies that made him successful as the governor of New York failed to catch on in a 2016 Republican nominating contest that has been dominated by political outsiders and firebrands.

title: Clevelands Terrible Stain
description: Tamir Rice of Cleveland would be alive today had he been a white 12-year-old playing with a toy gun in just about any middle-class neighborhood in the country on the afternoon of Nov. 22, 2014.

title: Chip Kelly Is Fired by Philadelphia Eagles After Roster Moves Flop
description: Eagles Coach Chip Kelly, an offensive mastermind who was lured from the University of Oregon in January 2013 in a bid to see whether his innovative tactics would work in the N.F.L., was fired on Tuesday with the team assured of missing the playoffs for a second straight season.

title: Jocelyn Cooper Dies at 86; Helped Pave Way for First Black Congresswoman
description: Jocelyn Clopton Cooper, who helped shift New Yorks black political center of gravity from Harlem to Brooklyn and, with her husband, established an alternative voice in journalism, died on Dec. 21 in Brooklyn. She was 86.

title: Burkina Faso: First New Leader in Decades Is Sworn In
description: The first new leader of Burkina Faso in almost three decades was officially sworn in Tuesday as president, capping more than a year of political turbulence that began when the countrys longtime leader sought to extend his rule. The inauguration of Roch Marc Christian Kabor drew officials from eight other West African countries and thousands of supporters, news services reported. Mr. Kabor, a former prime minister, won an election last month that outside observers described as the first free and competitive vote in the country in decades. Burkina Fasos former leader Blaise Compaor was deposed in October 2014 after protests over his attempt to amend the Constitution and extend his 27 years in power. This month a military court in Burkina Faso issued an arrest warrant for Mr. Compaor, who lives in exile in Ivory Coast, in connection with the 1987 assassination of Capt. Thomas Sankara, the countrys revolutionary leader. Mr. Compaor has denied involvement in the killing.

title: Puerto Rico Debt Crisis Closes In on Jan. 1 Deadline
description: Running out of both time and money, debt-ridden Puerto Rico appears headed for default on at least some of the roughly $1 billion in bond payments that are due on Jan. 1.

title: Break Is Likely in Planned Parenthood Funding Battle
description: WASHINGTON  Congressional Republicans are planning to start the new year with another attempt to ban federal funds for Planned Parenthood. But after five years of fruitless legislative attacks, the House vote next week is likely to be the last, conservative activists say, until a Republican moves into the White House.

title: Suspect in Grisly Killing Met Victim in a Therapy Group, Officials Say
description: The man accused of killing and disemboweling a woman in October and dumping her body in a park met the victim while the two were getting mental health care at a hospital in Queens, the authorities said on Tuesday.

title: More Police Officers Facing Charges, but Few See Jail
description: What was once a rarity has now become increasingly common: police officers facing criminal charges in the deaths of civilians. In Albuquerque, two officers will stand trial in the death of a homeless man. In Cincinnati, a campus police officer has been charged in the fatal shooting of a man during a traffic stop. In Chicago, where a video captured the death of Laquan McDonald at the hands of the police, an officer was charged with murder.

title: Stein Eriksen, Olympic Ski Champion Who Heralded Freestyle, Dies at 88
description: Stein Eriksen, an Olympic ski champion whose competitive triumphs, elegant style and innovative acrobatics made him one of the sports first superstars, died on Sunday at his home in Park City, Utah. He was 88.

title: Egypt Shuts Arts Venues Amid Signs of Clampdown
description: CAIRO  Over the past two days, the Egyptian authorities have shut down an internationally respected art gallery and raided an independent publishing house in what free-speech advocates said Tuesday were the latest moves in an expanding crackdown on dissent that now includes cultural spaces popular with activists and artists. In the first raid, on Monday, government agents seized papers and computers at the Townhouse Gallery and the affiliated Rawabet Theater before suspending the organizations activities, according to Fatima Serag, the legal director for the Association of Free Thought and Expression, a group that monitors free speech in Egypt.

title: With Alabamas Offense in Need, Derrick Henry Has Taken the Ball and Run With It
description: ARLINGTON, Tex.  Alabamas offensive strategy is not exactly classified, but if its Cotton Bowl opponent, Michigan State, needed a reminder, the Crimson Tides table positions at the games media day on Tuesday seemed fitting.

title: Bringing Poetry to Rikers Island, Where They Cant Cage Your Mind
description: The inmates at Rikers Island were slumped in plastic chairs, their expressions suggesting boredom and doubt. They had been pried from their favorite television shows to attend  of all things  a poetry reading. Some nice people from the public library, they were told.

title: Argentina: Ex-Transportation Ministers Get Prison
description: Two former transportation ministers wereconvicted Tuesday, found responsible for a 2012 train crash in Buenos Aires that killed 51 people. Juan Pablo Schiavi, who held the post at the time, was given an eight-year sentence, convicted of causing the deaths. Ricardo Jaime, his predecessor, was given a six-year sentence,merged with punishment for a previous charge ofreceivingbribeswhile in government. Both were found guilty of fraudulentpractices that jeopardized the management of train lines andled to thetragedy, a four-judge panel said. Nineteen others wereconvicted, including the driver of the train and Sergio Claudio Cirigliano,whose company operated the commuter line. He was given a nine-year sentence for fraudulent practices that resulted in the crash. Victims families celebrated the ruling, for which the judges will provide a fullexplanation in March.

title: Giant Squid, Elusive Creature of the Deep, Gets a Vivid Close-Up
description: They can be bigger than a bus, and yet the elusive giant squid has hardly been spotted swimming alive in the ocean.

title: Finding Her Footing Once More After Slipping Off the Career Ladder
description: Praying that no one would see her, Christine Moore dropped to her hands and knees and crawled under the turnstile along the grimy subway station floor. She had no money to pay the fare.

title: Pint-Size Diplomacy at Play in U.N. Ambassadors Penthouse
description: The adults were doing their level best, but for a while, the evening seemed doomed to a stately pace. A family of Syrian refugees had been invited to dinner in a penthouse atop the Waldorf Towers, the official residence of the United States ambassador to the United Nations.

title: Ex-Ally Donald Trump Now Heaps Scorn on Bill Clinton
description: For years, President Bill Clinton was the best friend Donald J. Trump always hoped to have.

title: Sing Along With Wordplay
description: WEDNESDAY PUZZLE  Dont adjust your watches just yet. Its New Years Eve only in todays crossword. But lets take this opportunity to celebrate, as this is Wordplay and theres always a party going on.

title: Detective Killed in Afghanistan Is Recalled as a Man Dedicated to 2 Uniforms
description: WEST HARRISON, N.Y.  They stood on a cold, damp sidewalk, lined up by the dozens outside the church with the sloping red brick facade, waiting for the opportunity to pay their respects to the family of the New York City police detective killed in combat.

title: Donald Trump Announces Plan for TV Ads, With a Big Uncertainty
description: Donald J. Trump scored another first in the 2016 presidential race on Tuesday evening  he held a news conference aboard his private jet just before a rally in Iowa, to announce he is about to spend heavily on the campaign.

title: Swedish Players Increasingly Drawn to U.S. Colleges
description: HELSINKI, Finland  Forty years ago, Anders Carlsson was believed to be the first Swede to play college hockey in the United States when he suited up for Yale. Since then, there have been 111 Swedish hockey players in the N.C.A.A., and about 20 percent of them  23  are currently enrolled.

title: New York Officials Seek to Legalize Hoverboards
description: It is the holiday gift that makes people stop and stare. It is viewed as a nuisance, or worse, a safety hazard. And it is banned in New York City.

title: Aide to Kim Jong-un Dies in Car Accident, North Korean Media Says
description: SEOUL, South Korea  A senior North Korean governing party secretary and key foreign policy aide to the countrys young and relatively inexperienced leader, Kim Jong-un, has died in a car accident, the countrys official news media reported Wednesday.

title: Work in Progress Knicks Beat Pistons to End Another Four-Game Skid
description: The Knicks entered 2015 having been swept during a three-game West Coast trip, part of an eventual 16-game losing streak that would define their inept season, which they finished at 17-65.

title: Remembering a Marine
description: Tyler Schlagels death was the 14th suicide in his military unit  the Second Battalion, Seventh Marine Regiment  since the group returned from a tour in Afghanistan in 2008.

title: Suicide Claims 14th Marine From a Unit Battered by Loss
description: LONGMONT, Colo.  Tyler Schlagel slipped out of his parents house while they were asleep three weeks ago and drove through the wintry darkness to his favorite fishing lake high in the Rockies.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: We do have two different tax systems, one for normal wage-earners and another for those who can afford sophisticated tax advice.

title: Sidney Mintz, Father of Food Anthropology, Dies at 93
description: Sidney W. Mintz, a renowned cultural anthropologist who provocatively linked Britains insatiable sweet tooth with slavery, capitalism and imperialism, died on Dec. 27 in Plainsboro, N.J. He was 93.

title: What to Watch Wednesday
description: This evening serves up a cornucopia of entertainment, an embarrassment of television riches. Uncharted pathologies (Extreme Time Cheaters) compete for ratings with evenhanded evaluations of the human diet (In Defense of Food). The Lizzie McGuire Movie is suitable for the whole family, while the dystopian class-inequality theme of Snowpiercer may merit parental guidance.

title: Corrections: December 30, 2015
description: NATIONAL

title: Record Floods Affect Millions in the Midwest
description: FENTON, Mo.  Amid the worst flood this town has ever seen, Tammy Morgan took a break Wednesday from shoveling sand into the yellow bags she hoped would save her business and pointed to a line of treetops rising from the water. There, she said, a few hundred feet away, past streets and clapboard houses now submerged, is where the Meramec River should be  not lapping at the grass a few feet away.

title: For Black Marching Bands, Its About Rhythm, Precision and Flair
description: Jules Allen has been photographing African-American marching bands for 30 years. He was captivated by the pulse and beat of the bands. Then their intense discipline rubbed off on him.

title: For Black Marching Bands, Its About Rhythm, Precision and Flair
description: There is something about the spectacle of a marching band that has entranced Jules Allen. Sure, the sun gleaming off trumpets and the sound of drums echoing in the air are impressive. So, too, is the majestic sight of scores of musicians following a high-stepping, high-hatted drum major. But what gets to Mr. Allen is something deeper: the sights and sounds of victory.

title: No Indictment in Shooting of 12-Year-Old Tamir Rice

title: The Political Consultant Racket
description: Donald J. Trump is a nightmare for the political consulting industry. Not only has he insulted, among many others, Mexicans, Muslims, women, veterans and members of the media  behavior that would make any consultant cringe  but Mr. Trump has succeeded, so far, without much help from the professionals on whom other candidates rely.

title: Exporting Crude Oil
description: To the Editor:

title: Your Cells. Their Research. Your Permission?
description: JEFFREY GRAY, a professor at Des Moines University, recently instructed a room full of medical students to take out their phones. Unlock them, he said. Now pass them to the person behind you. They looked at him like, Are you nuts? They wanted to know, Why? What will they look at? How will they use that information?

title: The Juicy Subplots of 2016
description: In American politics, one narrative  one question  eclipses all others: Who will become the 45th president?

title: The Power of New Year's Resolutions
Songs of Transition
description: Have you ever been there when someone dies? people ask when they find out I play the harp and sing for dying patients. It is the same tone I hear when someone asks, Do you think you will have more children? They want to talk about it, but they worry that the answer might be a secret. When I tell them I have been there at the moment of death, though not as often as they might suppose, they ask, What is that like for you?

title: Nearing Triumph Over Ebola
description: Guinea had every reason to celebrate Tuesday. The country where the West African Ebola epidemic began had been declared free of virus transmission. That in effect meant that the three countries hardest hit by the disease  Guinea, Liberia and Sierra Leone  had broken the chain of infections that took 11,300 lives, jumped borders and spread panic around the world.

title: Coming to Terms on Japans Wartime Sex Slaves
description: The landmark accord announced Monday between Japan and South Korea over the use of sex slaves by Japans army before and during World War II is unlikely to end all debate over Japans horrific behavior at the time.

title: Shooting in Dagestan, Focus of ISIS Recruiters, Leaves One Dead
description: MOSCOW  One person was killed and 10 were wounded after at least one gunman opened fire at the ancient citadel in Derbent, a historic crossroads in the southern republic of Dagestan that has been a focus of recruiting by the Islamic State, Russias Investigative Committee said in a statement on Wednesday.

title: Solitude and Industry Collide Near Mumbai
description: An industrial zone for blue-chip multinationals is changing the landscape in western India. But three years after the biggest leaseholder signed on, some land once used for grazing still stands empty.

title: A Chinese Company in India, Stumbling Over a Culture
description: SHINDE, India  When a Chinese truck company wanted to open a factory in India, its president looked at sites that had a mountain in back and a river in front  especially auspicious locations in the traditional practice of feng shui.

title: How to Manage Your Curls in Winter
description: Winter is a particularly challenging season for curly hair, which tends to be drier than its straighter counterparts. Cold air, wind and indoor heating can leave curls parched and rough; raw, wet days can cause frizz.

title: Alarm Spreads in Brazil Over a Virus and a Surge in Malformed Infants
description: SO PAULO, Brazil  A little-known virus spread by mosquitoes is causing one of the most alarming health crises to hit Brazil in decades, officials here warn: thousands of cases of brain damage, in which babies are born with unusually small heads.

title: New Hampshire Independents May Control Fates of Trump and Sanders
description: ROCHESTER, N.H.  There are few titles in American democracy as privileged as undeclared New Hampshire voter.

title: Longing for the Old Penn Station? In the End, It Wasnt So Great
description: Pennsylvania Station was ruined long before it was wrecked.

title: Living in Dix Hills, N.Y.
description: The hamlet has no town center, but it does have large lots, good schools and a central location.

title: Dix Hills, N.Y.: Large Lots and Good Schools
description: Adam and Brenda Elberg of Melville, N.Y., are not planning to move to nearby Dix Hills until later this year  their new house there is still under construction. But theyve already gotten to know some of the other people moving in to their new neighborhood, Mr. Elberg said, meeting them during visits to the building site.

title: The Second Coming of Hyaluronic Acid
description: After spending hours on airplanes to help run her familys photography business, Sonia Deasy was desperate for a quick solution to her dehydrated skin. Im a mother of five, Ms. Deasy said. I dont have time for a fuss.

title: South Americas Culture of Graft
description: BUENOS AIRES  South America is a vast continent of light, yet it has a dark soul. Nestled in its political class, like a snake from the rain forest, corruption poisons the core of government.

title: 15 Ways to Be a Better Person
description: A years worth of tips from the Styles archive.

title: Michael Ian Blacks Navel Gazing
description: I am woeful but not yet wretched, the comedian Michael Ian Black writes in his new memoir, an honest, entertaining account of male middle age, when bellies begin to thicken and hair to thin. Black, whos now in his 40s, chronicles his efforts to stave off wretchedness, through fitful exercise and a steady supply of Propecia, and to reckon with the mounting evidence that he may not, in fact, be immortal.

title: The Blizzard, by Vladimir Sorokin
description: Russians have been trying, and failing, to make their way through blizzards for as long as they can remember, or at least as long as they have been writing. The perilous-voyage-through-the-snow novella might be the Russian corollary to the American road novel. Vladimir Sorokin, Russias most inventive contemporary author, has written one too, and called it The Blizzard. His book alludes to every Russian literary portrayal of snow-threatened travel, from Alexander Pushkins The Captains Daughter to Alexander Blok, who wrote dozens of poems starring blizzards, to the rock group Nol (Zero), which in 1991 sang heartbreakingly of a man and his cat waiting for a doctor struggling through the snow to bring them healing white powder.

title: Can Too Much Exercise Harm the Heart?
description: With many of us contemplating marathons or other prolonged endurance events in 2016, we, our spouses and other family members most likely have wondered whether such strenuous training could be harmful to our hearts. Could any of us, in making ambitious resolutions, exercise too much?

description: A BOSTON HOTEL WITH A FENWAY VIEW

description: Question:

title: New York Today: The Year That Was
description: Updated 8:51 a.m.

title: Your Wednesday Briefing
description: Heres what you need to know to start your day.

title: Looking Back at Donald Trumps 2015
description: In the six months since announcing his run for president, Donald J. Trump has defied political gravity, seeing his popularity among Republicans rise despite  or because of  a steady flow of provocative policies and barbs that would sink most traditional politicians. For the billionaire developer, what has not killed his candidacy has made it only stronger.

title: In Memoriam: The Campaigns They Lived
description: As the remaining candidates hunker down to plan their strategies for the new year, we take a moment to remember some of the candidates we lost along the way.

title: The Terrible Beauty of Brain Surgery
description: I arrived in Tirana, Albania, on a Sunday evening in late August, on a flight from Istanbul. The sun had set while the plane was midflight, and as we landed in the dark, images of fading light still filled my mind. The man next to me, a young, red-haired American wearing a straw hat, asked me if I knew how to get into town from the airport. I shook my head, put the book I had been reading into my backpack, got up, lifted my suitcase out of the overhead compartment and stood waiting in the aisle for the door up ahead to open.

title: Judge John Hodgman on Toilet-Paper Quotas
description: Michelle writes: My husband complains that I use too much toilet paper. (We measured. I use approximately 20 squares per sitting.) He claims it is a complete waste of money. I think its fine  and besides, his baby-wipe habit costs even more.

title: Sunday Performances Continue to Elude the Met
description: On various Sundays this month, Anna Netrebko sang in Verdis Giovanna dArco at the Teatro alla Scala in Milan, Jonas Kaufmann appeared in Berliozs La Damnation de Faust at the Paris Opera and Plcido Domingo played the title role in Verdis Macbeth in Valencia, Spain.

title: Oscars 2016: And the Nominees Should Be ...
description: Manohla Dargis, A. O. Scott and Stephen Holden offer up their own lists of Oscar-worthy films and performances from the past year.

title: Can the Turtleneck Ever Be Cool Again?
description: It was knit from gray lambs wool. It defined a gray area. On a stark set, amid the playback of a plaintive address to an ex, the hip-hop star Drake danced to the beat of his own drum machine in the video for Hotline Bling while bundled in a roomy sweater with a collar that rose to touch his resolute jaw. Designers have often praised the turtleneck for the way that it moves with the body, and that was its job here, to envelop and underline Drakes dancing  dancing that was objectively uncool, a choreography of private pleasure.

title: Is It O.K. to Go to Work While Sick and Sneezing?
description: I work for a company that doles out a paltry amount of sick days and paid time off. Because I was nearing the end of the year and had already put in a holiday vacation request and bought plane tickets, I hung on to one day to last the rest of the year.

title: Financial Markets Were Flat in 2015. Thank Goodness.
description: Name a financial asset  any financial asset. How did it do in 2015?

title: Goodbye, 2015, the Year Before the Campaign Storm
description: This year, there were 17 Republican presidential candidates, six Democrats, and a race that was upended by the presence of one flamboyant New York billionaire, Donald J. Trump.

title: An Open Mind
description: In August, the novelist Karl Ove Knausgaard traveled to Albania to observe an awake craniotomy, the surgical procedure by which brain tumors are removed from conscious patients.

title: Apple Settles Tax Dispute With Italian Authorities
description: Apple has reached a deal with Italian tax authorities over a dispute about how much tax the American technology company should have paid in the European country.

title: Release of 1985 Race Riots Memo Prompts Apology From Cameron Aide
description: LONDON  The annual release of 30-year-old government papers in Britain produced significant embarrassment on Wednesday for one of Prime Minister David Camerons most senior officials, who found himself facing calls to resign over comments he made in 1985 about the countrys black population.

title: Make Them Pay for Park Views
description: NEW YORKERS, and particularly Manhattanites, are wringing their hands about the two dozen or so supertall luxury towers sprouting along the southern edge of Central Park. The builders are charging up to $100 million for apartments that offer helicopter views of lush foliage, jagged skylines, soothing rivers and angelic clouds. They lure the superrich, many with suspect foreign assets, to sky-high mansions. They enrich themselves by exploiting weak zoning rules to pour hideous implants into Manhattan cavities.

title: Ts Best Fashion Imagery of 2015
description: From inside the house of Dior to a gothic scene on the Scottish moors, this year, fashion took a trip around the world. Here, the pictures that stood out.

title: Turkey Detains 2 ISIS Militants Planning New Years Eve Attack
description: ISTANBUL  Two Islamic State militants who were plotting a suicide attack on the Turkish capital, Ankara, on New Years Eve have been detained, Turkish officials said Wednesday.

title: Julius Baer Reaches Preliminary Tax Deal With U.S. Authorities
description: Julius Baer said on Wednesday that it had reached a preliminary agreement with the United States Justice Department over an investigation into whether it had helped wealthy American clients evade United States taxes.

title: Cleanthony Early of the Knicks Is Robbed and Shot in the Knee After Leaving a Queens Strip Club
description: A New York Knicks forward, Cleanthony Early, was shot in the knee early on Wednesday by masked men who swarmed an Uber car carrying him home from a strip club in Queens and stole several necklaces and gold caps for his teeth.

title: Mix of New and Old Enlivens Taos Ski Valley
description: For a long time Taos Ski Valley has suffered from its version of Yogi Berras Paradox: Everybody claims to love the place, yet nobody goes there anymore. I was one of those non-visitors. Id long meant to visit the northern New Mexico resort, with its remarkable steeps. But how often do you lug your skis south of Colorado? Today Taos sees about 60 percent of the skiers that it did 20 years ago. Even the management concedes that a sort of stagnation had set in.

title: A Hawaiian Island Where Everybody Knows Your Name
description: When you come to Molokai, dont try to change Molokai. Molokai will change you.

title: At a Santo Domingo Hair Salon, Rethinking an Ideal Look
description: On my first trip back to the Dominican Republic in 10 years, as I wandered down the streets of La Zona Colonial, I noticed how their names were weighted with history. Calle de las Damas, a street made specifically for the wives and daughters of noblemen from colonial times to walk down. Calle Jos Gabriel Garca, named for a Dominican historian and journalist, among other things, who shares a first and last name with my father and made me think of him while I was there. Calle Isabel La Catlica where I felt a connection to my paternal grandmother, Isabel Mireya Garcia. Born in Bani, she lived and died on the right side of Hispaniola and raised my father in Santo Domingo.

title: How to Stick to Your New Years Resolutions
description: We have always been impressed by how much Austin Frakt gets done. In September last year, he wrote a memorable article for his blog, The Incidental Economist, about how he does it. (We highly recommend it.) So we asked him for advice on sticking to a resolution. As we expected, he came up with a method that others may find useful.

title: What You Get for  $950,000
description: A cottage in Mississippi, a contemporary in Arizona and a bungalow in Texas

title: $950,000 Homes in Texas, Mississippi and Arizona
description: OXFORD, MISS.

title: Enter the Shoe Aisle, Feel Your Phone Buzz With a Personal Deal
description: During a preholiday shopping trip to New York, Lisa Libretto received an enticing alert on her iPhone: an offer for a $25 discount on a Vince Camuto handbag that she had coveted on the retailers website.

title: After Taliban Attack in Kabul, a Music Teacher Keeps Playing
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  When a Taliban suicide bomber infiltrated a play being staged in a high school attached to the French cultural institute here, it was not clear at first who the target was. The audience was packed with diplomats and prominent Afghans, and the bomber made his way to the front row, where he blew himself up next to a German spectator, killing him.

title: Central African Republic Elections, Long Delayed, Are Peaceful
description: BANGUI, Central African Republic  Citizens of the Central African Republic began casting ballots on Wednesday in long-delayed elections that represent the best hope of reuniting the country, one of the worlds poorest, after three years of sectarian violence that has displaced hundreds of thousands of people.

title: Daily Report: Twitter Hires a New Executive in Charge of Diversity
description: The tech industry is ending 2015 the way it began: With complaints that it is tone deaf to diversity issues.

title: Presidents and the Economy
description: After I put up my post comparing private-sector jobs under Obama and Bush, a number of people asked me whether I believe that presidents have a large effect on economic performance. My answer is no  but conservatives believe that they do, which is why this kind of comparison is useful.

title: Moving Photos from Android 6.0 to Windows 10
description: Q. I am trying to copy the photos on my new Android phone so I can edit them better in Windows 10. Even though I have Windows set to recognize the phone and import the pictures, nothing happens when I connect the two by USB. What might be wrong?

title: Meet the Man Whos Been Spoiling The Bachelor for Four Years
description: FRISCO, Tex.  A little more than a month ago, Ben Higgins, the warmly handsome star of the coming season of The Bachelor, got down on one knee at the Sandals Royal Plantation resort in Ocho Rios, Jamaica, and proposed marriage.

title: An Autumn of Terror
description: Dear Diary:

title: What Is the Biggest Challenge America Faces in 2016?
description: As the year draws to a close, we want to hear from you about whats ahead. Inspired in part by a readers question, we want to know: What do you think is the biggest challenge facing the United States in 2016?

title: Irans Missile Tests Remind the U.S. That Tensions Have Not Ended
description: WASHINGTON  After two recent Iranian ballistic missile tests made clear that Tehran had no intention of obeying a United Nations prohibition on such launches, Obama administration officials on Wednesday handed Congress a draft list of fresh sanctions they are preparing against Tehran  to be imposed even as separate nuclear-related sanctions are lifted in coming weeks.

title: Bill Cosby Charged in Sexual Assault Case
description: Bill Cosby, who has for decades been pursued by allegations of sexual misconduct, was charged with sexual assault in Pennsylvania on Wednesday in a case that many people, including women who had come forward publicly, long thought prosecutors would never bring.

title: Police Leaders Competing Claims Draw Focus to How New York Counts Crimes
description: The battle between the police commissioner and his predecessor over New Yorks crime statistics has opened a window on how the city counts crime, and how it could skew the numbers and perception of the citys safety.

title: Downton Abbey: Saying Farewell to All That
description: NEWBURY, ENGLAND  I just want to get over it, Lady Mary said. I mean, over him. I mean, over with. What do I mean? She burst out laughing and turned back into the actress Michelle Dockery, who plays Lady Mary on Downton Abbey. Allen Leech, who plays her brother-in-law, Tom Branson, stepped in to help, She wants to get it over with.

title: 1890: Great Fight at Wounded Knee
description: NEW YORK  A great fight has taken place with the Indians at Wounded [Knee] Creek, and there has been much loss of life. Big Foot, having declared that he was ill, surrendered with 150 of his braves to Major Whiteside and the Seventh Cavalry. Finding, however, that the remainder of the Indians were unwilling to give up their arms, the cavalry, which was five hundred strong, surrounded them and closed on them to within gun reach.

title: The Kitchen Announces Winter Season
description: For its winter season, the Kitchen  the performance and exhibition space in Chelsea  will present an ambitious, months-long show that traces the evolution of art-making for the past 50 years.

title: Investigators Blame Violent Weather for Yangtze Cruise Ship Disaster
description: BEIJING  A cruise ship disaster in central China this year that killed all but a dozen of the hundreds of people aboard was caused by violent weather, according to the findings of a government investigation released on Wednesday.

title: At St. Patricks, Sending Off a Fallen Detective, Soldier and Friend
description: It might have seemed incongruous, gathering in a cathedral where wreaths tied with red bows hung from the columns and a bounty of poinsettias had been laid before the altar to eulogize a father and police officer killed in war.

title: Ted Cruz Finds Support for His Opposition to Corn Subsidies
description: Sometimes, its as critical what your friends say as your enemies.

title: No-Recipe Cod Cakes and Other Joys
description: Sam Sifton emails readers of Cooking five days a week to talk about food and suggest recipes. That email also appears here. To receive it in your inbox, register here.

title: Turkeys Campaign Against Kurdish Militants Takes Toll on Civilians
description: ISTANBUL  A major Turkish military operation to eradicate Kurdish militants in Turkeys restive southeast has turned dozens of urban districts into bloody battlefields, displacing hundreds of thousands of civilians and shattering hopes of reviving peace as an old war reaches its deadliest level in two decades.

title: And Now for the Good News ... A 2015 Sampler.
description: The Islamic State. Shootings. Climate change. Refugee crisis. There was no shortage of bad news or horrifying dispatches from around the globe this year.

title: In The Big Short, Adam McKay Uses Absurdity as His Guide
description: Long before we get to the title card in The Big Short, the rollicking caper documenting the 2008 housing and banking crisis, we see how the nation arrived at the brink  with nary a dollar sign or a balance sheet in sight. Instead, the co-writer and director, Adam McKay, gives audiences a timeline of Wall Street from the raunchy 70s on. There are glimpses of nudity and of the products and personalities that obsessed Americans over the years, when they might otherwise have tuned in to an impending economic meltdown: Christie Brinkley, Top Gun, the first iMac, South Park. Faced with a potentially stultifying subject, Mr. McKay offers an unlikely comic stroll through financial malfeasance.

title: Ann Cairns of MasterCard: The Art and Science of Team Chemistry
description: This interview with Ann Cairns, president of international markets at MasterCard, was conducted and condensed by Adam Bryant.

title: 2015 Criminal Complaint Against Bill Cosby
description: The authorities in Montgomery County, Pa., announced on Wednesday that Mr. Cosby faced a felony charge of aggravated indecent assault stemming from a 2004 episode.

title: At a Murder Trial, Online and More: Readers Share How They Met Their Spouses
description: In response to the story, 10 Newlyweds Share the Unexpected Ways They Met, more than 400 readers posted how they met their spouses.

title: A Three-Bedroom Condominium With Sea Views in Singapore
description: On the seventh floor of the Seascape complex in the Sentosa Cove development, the unit is on the market for $5.5 million.

title: House Hunting in ... Singapore
description: A THREE-BEDROOM APARTMENT WITH SEA VIEWS IN SENTOSA COVE

title: Mozart in the Jungle: Where Classical Music Meets Soap Opera
description: Is it possible for Bernadette Peters to star in a TV show without ever singing? That was one of the pressing questions hovering over the first season of Mozart in the Jungle, the Amazon original series that was, rather unexpectedly, recently nominated for two Golden Globe Awards, including best musical or comedy.

title: Russia Expands Sanctions Against Turkey After Downing of Jet
description: MOSCOW  Russia broadened its sanctions against Turkey on Wednesday to bar new Turkish construction and curb tourism activities in Russia, an expansion of measures put in place last month after Turkey shot down a Russian warplane under disputed circumstances.

title: With Taps on the Wrist, Apple Watch Points to the Future
description: THERE was never any doubt that I would buy an Apple Watch on the day it was released. Im a White House correspondent for The New York Times, but Im also that early-adopter guy.

title: Icahn Wins Bidding War for Pep Boys
description: After a tug of war between the activist investor Carl C. Icahn and the Bridgestone Corporation, the auto-parts retailer Pep Boys on Wednesday officially picked its suitor.

title: Carrie Fisher Takes On Criticism of Her Looks in Star Wars: The Force Awakens
description: The actress Carrie Fisher, who reprised her role as Leia Organa, the intergalactic revolutionary princess turned general in Star Wars: The Force Awakens, is taking on Internet trolls who criticized her appearance. Please stop debating whether or not I aged well, the actress, 59, wrote on Tuesday via Twitter. Unfortunately it hurts all three of my feelings.

title: Steve Jobs: The Man in the Machine Tries for a Rich Portrait
description: Danny Boyles biopic about Steve Jobs received a fair amount of attention when it came out in October, mostly because of its poor showing at the box office. But another film about Jobs also had a theatrical run, though brief and limited, the month before: Alex Gibneys documentary Steve Jobs: The Man in the Machine. On Sunday, Jan. 3, CNN gives it a broader audience at 9 p.m.

title: In Key Change, Women in Prison Vent
description: Women behind bars were once a staple of exploitation films. Now in the age of Orange Is the New Black, they also evoke prestige television. But in the latest adaptation of an award-winning show from the Edinburgh Festival Fringe, Key Change presents a story of incarcerated women from their points of view. Created by women in Her Majestys Prison Low Newton, in London (with the help of the writer Catrina McHugh), this drama, which mixes physical theater abstraction with realistic dialogue, explores the lives of four prisoners with a sensitive eye to the pain of isolation, the challenge of surviving in jail and the pasts that led them to where they are.

title: Prototype Festival Shows Off Contemporary Chamber Operas
description: Why do provocative operas like Dog Days rarely reach New York? the critic Steve Smith wondered in The New York Times three years ago about this searing opera by David T. Little and the librettist Royce Vavrek. After that New Jersey premiere made it one of the most talked-about operas in recent years, Dog Days finally comes to Manhattans Skirball Center on Saturday, Jan. 9, part of the explosion of boundary-defying chamber opera that is the Prototype Festival. The 2016 program, at spaces across Brooklyn and Manhattan, includes the human-trafficking drama Angels Bone by the composer Du Yun and Mr. Vavrek; The Good Swimmer, billed as part Requiem, part lifesaving drill by the composer Heidi Rodewald and the librettist Donna Di Novelli; and The Last Hotel by Donnacha Dennehy and Enda Walsh. (Jan. 6-17, prototypefestival.org.)

title: Daniil Simkins Intensio Has Its New York Debut
description: Daniil Simkin, a mercurial star of American Ballet Theater, also directs Intensio, a troupe that presents new choreography and gifted dancers on intimate stages. For its New York debut, which starts Tuesday, Jan. 5, at the Joyce Theater, the participants include Isabella Boylston, Alexandre Hammoudi, Blaine Hoven, Calvin Royal III, Hee Seo, Cassandra Trenary and James Whiteside, all from Ballet Theater, and Cline Cassone, from Les Ballets Jazz de Montral.

title: For Pierogi, a Last Brooklyn Hurrah
description: Pierogi isnt leaving Williamsburg entirely; the gallery will continue to operate its second space there, the Boiler. But Pierogi itself is moving to the Lower East Side, with plans to open there at 155 Suffolk Street in February. Its final two shows in its current space open Friday, Jan. 8, with two artists  John Phillip Abbott, who works primarily with spray paint, taping off areas to create lines of text, and the multimedia artist Michael Ballou.

title: KaloBios Files for Chapter 11 Bankruptcy
description: KaloBios Pharmaceuticals, the troubled California biotechnology company that ousted Martin Shkreli this month, filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy on Tuesday.

title: Charlotte Ramplings Earlier Films to Screen
description: She has always provided a refined elegance and over time has developed true acting chops. What with all the buzz surrounding Charlotte Rampling and her performance in 45 Years  she may garner the first Oscar nomination of her 50-plus-year career  the IFC Center has had the good sense to program a sampling of Ms. Ramplings earlier work. Every weekend through March 6, the theater will screen one of eight films featuring an actress whom the camera has never stopped loving.

title: Tomeka Reid, a New Jazz Power Source
description: The cellist Tomeka Reid, from Chicago, has been one of the great energies of the past year in jazz: a melodic improviser with a natural, flowing sense of song and an experimenter who can create heat and grit with the texture of sound.

title: Michael Haneke to Make Film With Immigration Theme in Calais Region
description: The director Michael Haneke will shoot Happy End, a new movie that grapples with immigration issues, this spring in the Calais region of northern France, Agence France-Presse reported Wednesday.

title: Filling the Country With Drones
description: In the last few days, perhaps one million small drones were given as Christmas gifts. Many prototype commercial drones, however, have been flying largely unnoticed for almost a year, and are preparing for a big takeoff of their own.

title: A Shirley Collins Tribute and Other Projects
description: STRANGE DARLING

title: Reporters Notebook: Maritime Repo Men in Haiti
description: The last time I was in Haiti was to cover the 2010 earthquake. Obviously, the country was a disaster then. The suffering was acute and the tension palpable.

title: App Smart | 2016 Trends
description: Simplicity of design and clarity of purpose characterize the latest apps.

title: Video Feature: The Mood in 2016: Sleek and to the Point
description: MANY thousands of apps flicker before my eyes and dance beneath my fingers each year on the screens of my phones, tablets, smartwatch and TV. That gives me some insight into emerging trends in the apps world. Heres what I think will shape apps in 2016:

title: How Much Is This Old Thing Worth?
description: My mother said the book would be valuable one day. Her only regret was that over the years of reading it to me and my sister, she had been careless about pulling it off the shelf and had torn the delicate red leather of the spine. Still, it was a first English edition of Winnie-the-Pooh, dated 1926. Slim, soft and well loved, it was the copy she had had as a child and when she died, she left it to me.

title: Puerto Rico Says It Will Default on Some Bonds
description: Puerto Rico will default on nearly $174 million in principal and interest payments on bonds on Friday, the first day of 2016, the governor said on Wednesday, increasing the likelihood that the island will face lawsuits from an array of creditors.

title: Bill Clintons Former Friend to Host Fund-Raiser for John Kasich
description: John Kasich, the Ohio governor and Republican presidential candidate, will hold a campaign fund-raiser in California next month, co-hosted by the businessman Ron Burkle, a onetime friend, donor and business partner of former President Bill Clinton.

title: Brussels Police Investigate Reports of Police Orgy Amid Terror Alert
description: PARIS  In the six weeks since the Paris terrorist attacks, law enforcement agencies in Brussels, where most of the attackers lived or had ties, have been denounced as slow, unresponsive, disorganized and even incompetent.

title: How Russia-Turkey Relations Soured
description: After a Russian fighter jet was shot down on Nov. 24, relations between Turkey and Russia became heated. A look at how things deteriorated between the two countries.

title: Vivid Scenes From a Warm December
description: A collection of photos taken by Times readers from moments when it seemed like winter might never come.

title: Donald Weinstein, Influential Historian on the Renaissance, Dies at 89
description: Donald Weinstein, a historian whose 1970 study, Savonarola and Florence: Prophecy and Patriotism in the Renaissance, overturned long-held assumptions about 15th-century Florence and redrew the contours of Renaissance scholarship, died on Dec. 13 in Tucson. He was 89.

title: Millions of Voter Records Posted, and Some Fear Hacker Field Day
description: First and last names. Recent addresses and phone numbers. Party affiliation. Voting history and demographics.

title: Charities That Inspire Kids: North Shore Sheltering Program and Mommas House
description: This week, were sharing stories from children, teenagers and families about the charities that inspire them to give time, money and passion. Two programs for supporting the homeless in her community, North Shore Sheltering Program and Mommas House, inspired Lissa Harris to write.

title: Martin OMalley Urges Obama Administration to Rethink Immigration Raids
description: Martin OMalley, the former governor of Maryland who staked out early ground in the Democratic presidential race on the issue of reforming immigration laws, sent a letter to the Jeh Johnson, the secretary of the Department of Homeland Security, urging him to rethink planned raids of families who came over the border last year during a surge of crossings into the United States.

title: Popcast: Making Sense of 2015 in Music
description: Music critics for The New York Times talk about the themes, currents and big ideas that defined the year.

title: Where to Go in St. Petersburg
description: Rubinstein Street has seen a fresh wave of restaurants recently, adding to the traditional draw of its theaters.

title: Three Theater Stalwarts, Together at Last, Talk Mom
description: The Manhattan Theater Club, over which Lynne Meadow has presided for 43 years, has presented nine of Richard Greenbergs plays, but The Assembled Parties in 2013 was the first she directed herself.

title: World Leaders Agree to Extend Efforts to End Ukraine Conflict
description: MOSCOW  The leaders of Russia, Ukraine, France and Germany agreed Wednesday to extend efforts to end the conflict in eastern Ukraine, acknowledging that the terms of a complex cease-fire agreement will not be fully carried out by the Dec. 31 deadline.

title: 50 Comics Walk Into a Club. No, You Havent Heard This One.
description: Almost no one would buy a ticket to see 50 First Cavities, in which 50 dentists come onstage and fill their first teeth of the new year. Ditto 50 First Pedicures or 50 First Stock Trades. But the joke-writing profession is perfectly suited to a 50 First format. A group of New York comics found that out almost by accident a decade ago, and on Saturday 50 First Jokes NYC celebrates its 10th anniversary with a show at the Bell House in Gowanus, Brooklyn, that will no doubt generate lots of laughs and perhaps the occasional groan.

title: Playwright Dominique Morisseau Cant Forget the Motor City
description: A few years ago, the playwright Dominique Morisseau and her husband, the musician James Keys, traveled back home for a wedding. On their way into the reception, they saw a woman sitting in a car packed with possessions. When they left, she was still there. Knocking on her window, they asked if they could help. The woman accepted some money and told them shed be all right. Its a rough time right now, but Im going to get through it, Ms. Morisseau recalled her saying.

title: Comic Book Recalls Effort to Expose Mein Kampf
description: The 70-year copyright on Hitlers Mein Kampf expired on Thursday in Germany. And a comic book released last month sheds light on a legal battle over the book that occurred in America in 1939. The comic, The Book That Hitler Didnt Want You to Read, tells the story of how Alan Cranston  then a journalist, and years later a California senator  produced his own version of Hitlers book, only to be sued by Hitler.

title: Police Say Rome Airport Workers Ran Art-Theft Ring
description: The Italian police have exposed what they say is a scam at the Fiumicino airport in Rome, and charged two workers with stealing valuable paintings.

title: With Via, Sharing More Than Just a Ride
description: The back seat of a Via functions as Joanne Gamels mobile office. It is where Ms. Gamel, a New York real estate agent, checks email, calls clients and gets listings, all while being chauffeured to appointments in Manhattan.

title: For Big Dance Theater, the After-Party Is at Intermission
description: In tight metallic pants and voluminous 17th-century wigs, Aaron Mattocks and Elizabeth DeMent skipped toward each other, halted and let their arms swim up, reaching for the same point in space. The choreographer Annie-B Parson, perched in the risers, eyed their position on the stage of the Kitchen in Chelsea. It either needs to be center-center or very off-center, but it cant be a little off, she said.

title: Psychotherapy May Have Lasting Benefits for Irritable Bowel Syndrome
description: Psychotherapy is effective in easing the symptoms of irritable bowel syndrome, researchers have found, even after therapy has ended.

title: Reasons to Be Excited About 2016
description: The new year is here, and so, too, is the renewed sense that anything is possible  even the advent of sweater weather. Here, some sartorial ways to kick things off on a high note.

title: Seeking to Alter Jury Selection, Lawyer in Terror Case Cites Donald Trumps Muslim Remarks
description: For months, Donald J. Trump has used his role as a provocateur to attract attention and high poll numbers in the Republican presidential campaign. But now some of his statements are being used for another purpose: changing the jury selection process for a man accused in a terrorism case in New York.

title: Respectable Radicalism
description: Brad DeLong, riffing off Larry Summers, asks about what is driving the Fed  and argues that Larry has it wrong, that the Feds problem is not an excessive commitment to existing models. On the contrary, the Fed seems to hold beliefs that are very much at odds with Macroeconomics 101, whose basic Hicksian models do not at all support the Feds eagerness to hike rates.

title: Georgia Lawmakers Approve a New Prime Minister
description: MOSCOW  Lawmakers in the former Soviet republic of Georgia voted late Tuesday to approve former Foreign Minister Giorgi Kvirikashvili as the countrys new prime minister amid increasing public dissatisfaction with the government.

title: Popcast: Making Sense of 2015 in Music
description: Listen to this weeks podcast | Subscribe: iTunes | RSS | Stitcher| Audioboom

title: When Dog Owners Are Off the Leash
description: I dont identify with celebrities, especially ones with superstar husbands. But when Amber Heard, the actress, got caught last spring, I felt her pain. She has been ordered to appear in court next year, the BBC recently reported, for smuggling two Yorkshire terriers into Australia.

title: With College Football Playoff, ESPN Plans to Reinvent New Years Eve
description: In an ESPN promotional ad for the College Football Playoff, a gaggle of partyers led by Jimmy Kimmel and Robin Thicke sings, Yes, New Years Eve will be so awesome watching college football through confetti, to the tune of Auld Lang Syne. The singing and new lyrics arent great, but the message is clear: The national semifinal games are designed to alter the American ritual of New Years Eve celebrations.

title: The War on Alcohol, by Lisa McGirr
description: My great-grandfather Vincenzo negotiated Prohibition by fermenting two barrels of wine a year. It was perfectly legal, he insisted. Vincenzo was lucky to be a New Yorker. In her fine history of Prohibition, The War on Alcohol, Lisa McGirr, a professor of history at Harvard, shows us that a poor Italian in Illinois or a black man in Virginia might very well have been jailed, shot or sentenced to a chain gang.

title: Lisa McGirr Discusses The War on Alcohol and the Legacy of Prohibition
description: America has been awash in Prohibition-era nostalgia of late, with speakeasy-style bars, artisanal moonshine and bootlegger balls proliferating from New York to Cedar Rapids, Iowa, to Los Angeles, where revelers in period dress will pack that citys 1930s Union Station to ring in the New Year.

title: High Fashion Near Ground Zero
description: Brookfield Place, a luxury mall just steps away from the site of New Yorks greatest trauma, is an argument that capitalism heals all wounds.

title: Saying a Last Goodbye
description: Detective Joseph G. Lemm, a New York City police officer who was killed in Afghanistan, was eulogized at his funeral Wednesday at St. Patricks Cathedral.

title: Mike Condon Converts Chances, and Fans of a Hated Rival
