description: BELMONT, Mass.  Hanging in the athletic directors office at Belmont Hill School is a game-worn Montreal Canadiens sweater. There is also a red fold-down seat from the old Montreal Forum. Many students at this hockey-mad all-boys preparatory school, 10 miles northwest of Boston, now track every game played by the Canadiens, the Bruins north-of-the-border rival.

title: Shell Opens Natural Gas Wells Off Irish Coast
description: LONDON  Two decades after being discovered, natural gas began flowing on Wednesday from wells off Irelands northwest coast. Royal Dutch Shell, the oil company, said it had begun producing gas from undersea wells, part of an effort for Ireland to produce more of its own resources.

title: Mom Tattoos, for Those Who Still Live With Her
description: In a storefront parlor on Bergen Street in Boerum Hill, Brooklyn, a father of two sat in a chair one recent Saturday afternoon, his shirt hiked over his head to reveal an open expanse of shoulder to be tattooed.

title: Jeb Bushs Campaign Redeploys Staff Members, Aiming at Early States
description: Yet another shake-up to Jeb Bushs already beleaguered campaign Wednesday underscored the challenges Mr. Bush faces to revive his presidential bid just a month before the first votes are cast.

title: Pictures of the Day: Syria and Elsewhere
description: Syria and More  Pictures of the Day

title: Dec. 30, 2015  Pictures of the Day
description: Photos from Syria, Turkey, the United States and Scotland.

title: Shop the Pain Away
description: Like many people, I shop to forget.

title: The Partys in Sunset Park
description: Sunset Park, Brooklyn, has become the latest landing strip for seekers of concerts, raves, after parties and art shows.

title: Sunset Park, the Latest Party Spot in Brooklyn
description: It was 3 a.m. on a Sunday, and a 13,000-square-foot warehouse swirled with thousands of partygoers, lasers befitting an alien invasion and throbbing beats from Gesaffelstein, a French D.J. In the elevated V.I.P. section, night-life stalwarts like Kanye Wests consigliere Virgil Abloh, the R&B singer Ian Isiah and the fashion designer Alexander Wang lounged on couches.

title: Doug Atkins, a FearedHall of Fame Pass Rusher, Dies at 85
description: Doug Atkins, a towering Hall of Fame defensive end who manhandled offensive linemen and quarterbacks for 17 seasons in the National Football League, most famously with the Chicago Bears, died on Wednesday at his home in Knoxville, Tenn. He was 85.

title: Jamie Dimon of JPMorgan Still Strong After 10 Years as Chief
description: Jamie Dimon has generated his fair share of controversy as the boss of JPMorgan Chase. But he marks 10 years running the New York bank on Thursday having fashioned an institution with some of the leading results in the business  and in a strong position to outperform competitors for another decade.

title: Movies the Oscars Will Overlook, but Shouldnt
description: It happens every year. Some actor stands next to another performer or the president of the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences, and they take turns telling you whats up for an Oscar. Which means theyre also telling you whats not. And whats not tends to be as important as what is. And every year, Im left wondering whether months of punditry and daily forecasts of awards-season weather pollutes what was scarcely a pure process to begin with.

title: Some Quarterbacks Run an End-Around on Transfer Constraints
description: DALLAS  As college athletes and their advocates have intensified efforts to win greater rights in recent years, a small but high-profile segment of football players has divined a way to attain something that resembles free agency.

title: Galavant Goes Medieval for the Biggest Laughs
description: This might sound like an insult, but really its a compliment: The Emmy Awards need a new category, Outstanding Deliberately Mindless Comedy Series, and for 2015 the statuette should have gone to ABCs daffy Galavant. Also, judging from the first seven episodes of its second season, which begins Sunday, the show would have a good chance of being a repeat winner in 2016.

title: A Day Out With the Architect Moshe Safdie
description: Moshe Safdie threw over his conventional dress shirts long ago for a jauntier wardrobe of band-collared alternatives. The version he wore on a Monday morning as he headed north along a grassy stretch of the High Line lent him the look of a cleric, minus the priestly severity.

title: Muslims on Twitter Say They Have Better Things to Do Than Join ISIS
description: A plea by the leader of the Islamic State terrorist group for Muslims to fight on its behalf against disbelievers prompted many to respond online with defiance and sarcasm.

title: Donald Trump Laments Loss of Aerosol Sprays to Frame His Hair
description: Donald J. Trump appears to be more concerned about the quality of his hair than the quality of the air.

title: Marin Mazzie on Cancer and Songs in the Key of Life
description: Flash back to last New Years Eve, and there was the Broadway star Marin Mazzie in a form-fitting black ball gown, on her way to see The Merry Widow at the Metropolitan Opera. With thick blond tresses cascading past her shoulders, she was the picture of glamour, posing with her husband, the actor Jason Danieley, his arm around her waist.

title: As College Football Playoff Grows, It Doesnt Need to Be Super
description: FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla.  Last year at this time, Bill Hancock was confidently but nervously anticipating the first four-team playoff in big-time college football.

title: Six New Books, Including One by Christopher Buckley
description: By Michael Peppiatt

title: Review: In Megan Pughs America Dancing, a Focus on Where the Moves Came From
description: What makes a dance American? The question has been asked for more than a century. Today its shocking to find that John Martin  The New York Timess dance critic from 1927 to 1962  asserted in his book America Dancing (1936) that black and Native American art was not our art. Though he observed that America had behaved like an imperial power in conquering Native Americans and enslaving Africans, he argued that these nonwhite traditions should not be assimilated.

title: Ethan Couch, Affluenza Teenager, Granted Delay in Deportation
description: Federal marshals said Wednesday that it was uncertain when Ethan Couch, the Texas teenager known for using an affluenza defense in a fatal drunken-driving case, would be returned to the United States from Mexico to face charges of violating his parole.

title: Marco Rubio Helped Brother-in-Law Get Real Estate License After Prison Release, Report Says
description: When Senator Marco Rubio of Florida was the majority whip of the states House of Representatives, he used his influence to help his brother-in-law obtain a real estate license after hisrelease from prison, where he had been serving time for trafficking cocaine, according to report.

title: Fox News Holds Its Lead in a Year of Growth for Cable News
description: In a year that featured a number of prominent news stories  a presidential campaign upended by Donald Trump, civic unrest in Baltimore, Pope Franciss visit to the United States and deadly terrorist attacks in Paris and San Bernardino, Calif.  the number of people tuning in to the top 24-hour cable news channels went up, according to Nielsen.

title: Anselm Kiefer and His Hallmarks Have a Moment
description: PARIS  As Paris reeled in the weeks after the Nov. 13 attacks, the German artist Anselm Kiefer was finishing up an apocalyptic installation at the Pompidou Center.

title: Review: Bach at St. Pauls, and the Fictional Relative, P.D.Q., at Town Hall
description: For New York music lovers of a certain age, and undoubtedly many younger ones as well, Peter Schickeles concert P.D.Q. Bach: The Golden Anniversary at Town Hall on Monday evening was cause for giddy celebration. And for a listener who had already heard two programs of legitimate Bachiana on Monday, it all but made the head spin.

title: Review: The Philharmonic Hails Sibelius, and Offers Joshua Bell on a Mendelssohn
description: Timid conductors wary of programming new or challenging works sometimes fall into a trap that Alan Gilbert has called the Bolero effect. The idea is that the audience will come for a new piece, so long as the program ends with a crowd-pleaser like Ravels Bolero. The problem is that such a gambit suggests the conductor doesnt really believe in the challenging work.

title: Biding Time Until Chinas Outlook Clears
description: BEIJING  For many in Chinas capital, the smog that has obscured buildings and dimmed the sun into a pale disk this winter is a fitting metaphor for the uncertainty that has marked their year.

title: Your Wednesday Evening Briefing: Chicago, Bill Cosby, Missouri
description: (Want to get this briefing by email? Heres the sign-up.)

title: Your Evening Briefing
description: Heres what you need to know at the end of the day.

title: Cellphone Contacts in Paris Attacks Suggest Foreign Coordination
description: PARIS  The terrorists who killed 130 people in Paris in November were in contact by cellphone with at least one person in Belgium during their attacks, suggesting that they may have been coordinated or monitored from abroad while killing, according to French police reports on the investigation.

title: Marco Rubio Endorses Idea for Constitutional Amendment to Set Congressional Term Limits
description: Senator Marco Rubio of Florida, who is seeking to gain ground in Republican states dominated by conservatives, this week endorsed the idea of amending the Constitution to set term limits in Congress and the Supreme Court.

title: Rail Industry Again Given More Time to Install Safety System
description: WASHINGTON  When Congress in October gave railroads extra time to install a badly needed speed-control system, officials at the Federal Railroad Administration vowed to move aggressively to make sure the safety technology would be in place by the end of 2018, the new deadline.

title: Death of Man Found in Burning Bronx Home Is Ruled a Homicide
description: The death of a Bronx man has been ruled a homicide two months after emergency workers carried his lifeless body from his burning home, the authorities said on Wednesday.

title: Coachella Lands Two Big Reunions: Guns N Roses and LCD Soundsystem
description: Living up to its tradition as the premier forum for rock n roll reunions, the Coachella Valley Music and Arts Festival will host at least two of them in 2016: Guns N Roses  a gigantic get  and LCD Soundsystem.

title: Murray Weissman, Publicist With a Focus on Oscar Campaigning, Dies at 90
description: Murray Weissman, who helped lead a generation of Hollywood publicists in their transition from press agent to Oscar campaigner, died on Monday in Los Angeles. He was 90.

title: A Lively Little Girl Needs a Kidney Donor
description: The day that Edgar Campos brought his wife and newborn girl home from the hospital was bittersweet.

title: A Shift Toward Luxury Crops
description: Luxury crops are replacing staples on some California farms.

title: Farmers Try Political Force to Twist Open Californias Taps
description: FIVE POINTS, Calif.  The message that Maria L. Gutierrez gave legislators on Capitol Hill was anguished and blunt: Californias historic drought had not merely left farmland idle. It had destroyed Latino farm workers jobs, shuttered Latino businesses and thrown Latino families on the street. Yet Congress had turned a deaf ear to their pleas for more water to revive farming and farm labor.

title: Rex Ryan Looks to End Bills Failed Season on High Note
description: FLORHAM PARK, N.J.  The voice over the phone rang familiar, and then it did not. The longer Rex Ryan talked  that is to say, beyond his opening answer  the more dispirited, defeated and deflated he sounded.

title: Thanks, Obama: Highest Earners Tax Rates Rose Sharply in 2013
description: Data released by the I.R.S. on Wednesday shows that tax rates on the income of Americas 400 wealthiest taxpayers rose sharply to 22.9 percent in 2013, erasing a majority of the last two decades decline in their effective tax rate.

title: Ted Cruz Follows His Rise in Polls With a $20 Million Fund-Raising Surge
description: Senator Ted Cruz of Texas has raised nearly $20 million in the fourth quarter, his campaign said on Wednesday, an impressive haul that coincides with his rise in state and national polls in recent months.

title: As Home Births Grow in U.S., a New Study Examines the Risks
description: With a growing number of American women choosing to give birth at home or in birthing centers, debate is intensifying over an important question: How safe is it to have a baby outside a hospital?

title: Star of Mother Courage Quits in Creative Dispute
description: The lead actress said her perspective as a black woman was dismissed. The director blamed a clash of interpretations. The result: That actress, the Tony Award-winning Tonya Pinkins, has withdrawn from a production of Bertolt Brechts Mother Courage and Her Children set to open on Jan. 7 at Classic Stage Company.

title: In Wild Winter, Warm North Pole Storm Chills U.S. Forecast as Flooding Threatens Levees
description: What a season it has been for demonstrating how severe weather in the United States is shaped by, and shapes, conditions elsewhere around the planet. Of course, the main event is the still-growing El Nio warmup of the tropical Pacific Ocean, which has worldwide impacts  particularly in poor countries. For a primer, see this helpful explanatory video and article from The Times, and a great update from Capital Weather Gang.

title: Making Resolutions to Be a Better Parent, Every Day of Every Year
description: If I kept a journal  one of those five-year books, maybe, which allow you to look back at the same day in previous years (a service Facebook now provides, without the pesky introspection)  the entries might look something like this:

title: Excerpt From Bill Cosbys Deposition
description: Over the course of four days in 2005 and 2006, Bill Cosby answered questions posed to him by a lawyer for a woman who said Mr. Cosby had drugged and molested her.

title: A Clemson Juggernaut Is Led by a Star Wearing No. 4. That Figures.
description: Inside the Clemson locker room at Memorial Stadium, about 10 feet from quarterback Deshaun Watsons locker, is a shrine to the jersey number he wears. There, set up neatly in another locker, is a throwback helmet, a pair of uniform pants and a hanging No. 4 jersey. It is all encased in glass, like a museum exhibit recalling the glory days of Clemson football.

title: Edward Hugh, Economist Who Foresaw Eurozones Struggles, Dies at 67
description: Edward Hugh, a freethinking and wide-ranging British economist who gave early warnings about the European debt crisis from his adopted home in Barcelona, died on Tuesday, his birthday, in Girona, Spain. He was 67.

title: Farmers Try Political Force to Twist Open Californias Taps
description: Few in agriculture have shaped the debate over water more than the several hundred owners of an arid finger of farmland west of Fresno.

title: The More We Poll, the Less We Know
description: Polling of Republicans in the early-voting states of Iowa, New Hampshire and South Carolina has reached unprecedented levels, fueled by the number of candidates in the hunt and an obsession with the horse race rather than a meaningful debate over policy, a new Boston Globe study says.

title: Holiday on Friday New Years Day
description: NEW YORK

title: Mayor of Chicago Announces Measures to Curb Use of Deadly Force by the Police
description: CHICAGO  Under intense pressure to change the behavior of the police force, Mayor Rahm Emanuel on Wednesday announced a series of steps intended to rein in the use of deadly force, promising to buy hundreds of Tasers and to train officers to be less confrontational.

title: In Bill Cosby Case, 3 Pills, Sips of Wine and a Charge of Sexual Assault
description: He was her mentor and one of the most famous people to ever have attended Temple University, where she worked as a director of operations for the womens basketball program. One night in the winter of 2004 Bill Cosby called Andrea Constand on her cellphone and invited her to his home in Cheltenham, a leafy suburb just north of Philadelphia. The two chatted about her job and career prospects.

title: Donald Trump Renews Attacks on Bill Clinton
description: Days before he is set to campaign within miles of Bill Clinton, Donald J. Trump ratcheted up his attacks on the former president over scandals involving women before and during his presidency, calling him one of the great abusers of the world.

title: A Coney Island New Years Eve: Sword Swallowing. Fire Breathing. No Ball.
description: There is no challenging Times Squares pre-eminence on New Years Eve, with its traditional ball drop and its three-two-one countdown turning the area into the thrumming, jostling, rollicking center of the universe.

title: Egypt Officials Stop Facebook Program for Free Access to Internet
description: CAIRO  A program that provided more than three million Egyptians with free access to Internet services was abruptly shut down on Wednesday, according to Facebook, the social media company that provided the program in cooperation with an Egyptian cellphone company.

title: Unbrotherly Feelings in Philadelphia
description: PHILADELPHIA  As he listens to old men who lament, Im never going to live to see a Super Bowl, Bruce Graham, a playwright, has begun to wonder about himself.

title: Its Amazon and Also-Rans in Retailers Race for Online Sales
description: Two decades after Jeffrey P. Bezos started Amazon in his Bellevue, Wash., garage, his e-commerce juggernaut could be forgiven for letting up on its rapid growth.

title: Climate Chaos, Across the Map
description: What is going on with the weather?

title: Several Days After Christmas, Toys R Us Closes in Times Square
description: Jen Saibel took her place in front of a 60-foot-tall indoor Ferris wheel on Wednesday afternoon, raised her fists to her cheeks in a pantomime of crying and frowned theatrically for her mothers cellphone camera.

title: Odell Beckham Jr. Continues Apologizing in Return to Giants
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  Odell Beckham Jr. returned to Giants practice Wednesday for the first time since his one-game suspension and was once again apologetic for his reckless and dangerous play in a Dec. 20 game against the Carolina Panthers.

title: Connecticut Man Is Charged in 2011 Murder in Queens Over Double-Parked Car
description: There were plenty of witnesses to the deadly shooting on a Queens street corner in July 2011.

title: Trevon Pendleton Has Body for Big Blocks and Nose for Huge Plays
description: DALLAS  The Michigan State senior Aaron Burbridge caught 79 passes this season and was named the Big Tens receiver of the year. His teammate Trevon Pendleton, a fullback, pulled in only four, but even Burbridge might admit that they were some of the biggest ones of the Spartans season.

title: Frank Malzone, Star Fielder for Boston Red Sox, Dies at 85
description: Frank Malzone, a six-time All-Star third baseman whose steady presence in the Boston lineup tied together two of the citys baseball eras, linking Ted Williamss Red Sox with Carl Yastrzemskis, died on Tuesday at his home in Needham, Mass. He was 85.

title: Caetano Veloso Loves Israel, but Wont Be Going Back
description: For most Brazilians, the Israeli occupation of the West Bank is far from a pressing concern. But in recent months, one of Brazils most prominent figures, a revered singer, has found himself wrestling with a dilemma directly related to Israels continuing control over the territory, which is home to millions of Palestinians.

title: Round a Corner
description: Administrivial Jokes On Us! Alert! It turns out that Mr. Tausig has played a meta-joke on us. In addition to todays New York Times crossword, he also has a similarly-themed puzzle in three other venues: Buzzfeed, AVCX and Brendan Emmett Quigleys site. Kudos to Mr. Tausig for monopolizing our time. You can read more about it in The Observer.

title: Venezuelan Court Blocks 4 Lawmakers
description: CARACAS, Venezuela  The Supreme Court on Wednesday blocked four newly elected lawmakers from taking office, three from the opposition and one from the governing Socialist party.

title: Federal Grand Jury Indicts Friend in San Bernardino Massacre
description: Enrique Marquez, who supplied his longtime friend Syed Rizwan Farook with two assault rifles used to carry out the massacre in San Bernardino, Calif., was indicted by a federal grand juryon Wednesdayon five charges, including conspiring with Mr. Farook in an earlier, unrealized plot.

title: Britain: 2 Plotters Sentenced
description: A man and his former wife who were found guilty of plotting a terrorist attack in London on the 10th anniversary of the transit bombings in the British capital were sentenced to life in prison on Wednesday. The defendants, Mohammed Rehman, 25, and Sana Ahmed Khan, 24, were sentenced by Judge Jeremy Baker one day after their conviction in a trial known as the 7/7 bombers case, named for the date in 2005 when suicide bombers in the transit system killed 52 people in London. Under British law, Mr. Rehman must serve at least 27 years and Ms. Khan 25 years. Mr. Rehman, who had referred to himself as the Silent Bomber on social media, was arrested in May after having posted a message that asked: Westfield shopping centre or London underground? Any advice would be greatly appreciated. According to evidence and testimony presented in court, the police seized explosives and bomb-making chemicals from Mr. Rehmans house in the city of Reading, west of London. In sentencing the defendants, Judge Baker was quoted by the BBC as saying their intended actions included a suicide bombing, an act which envisaged martyrdom, a notion specifically resurrected by Islamic State in order to encourage this type of venture.

title: What to Watch Thursday
description: A dramatic evening of programming is set to welcome the New Year. One of Americas most ferocious rivalries plays out in Times Square between Ryan Seacrest and Carson Daly, the eminent presenters of seemingly anything televised. If you have reason to skip the festivities, you can instead laugh at Shaun of the Dead or become immersed in No Country for Old Men.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: As scientists, its a little humbling that weve kind of been saying this for 20 years now, and its not until people notice daffodils coming out in December that they start to say, Maybe theyre right.

title: George Lucas Criticizes Latest Star Wars Installment
description: George Lucas has criticized the latest installment of Star Wars, the series he created, in an interview with Charlie Rose, describing the film as too retro for his taste and jokingly comparing the Walt Disney Company, which bought the rights to the franchise in 2012, to white slavers who had bought his children.

title: At the Mummers Parade, Philadelphia Celebrates a New Years Ritual
description: Every New Years Day, throngs huddle along Broad Street in Center City Philadelphia to behold thousands of (mostly) men, flamboyantly dressed in satin, sequins and feathers, faces painted with bright colors, strutting down the street with parasols, instruments and other props. This is the annual Mummers Parade, a tradition dating back officially to the early 1900s, unofficially much further, to working-class northern European immigrants in the late 17th and early 18th centuries.

title: Searching for Hate
description: To the Editor:

title: Americas Bountiful Churn
description: GALLUP, N.M.  The main drag in Gallup runs along Historic Route 66, adjacent to the railroad. The Hotel El Rancho, where movie stars filming westerns once stayed, is still there. A host of trading posts sell Navajo jewelry, pottery and rugs, as well as artifacts made by the smaller Zuni Nation.

title: Test Your Savvy About 2016 With a Quiz
description: Will Trump, Cruz, Clinton or Sanders win the presidency? Will the refugee crisis improve? Heres a multiple-choice exam on whats to come.

title: Catchy Highway Signs
description: To the Editor:

title: Reducing the Stresses Students Face
description: To the Editor:

title: Mr. Obamas Trickle of Mercy
description: This month, President Obama announced the latest winners of the annual lottery otherwise known as the presidential clemency process.

title: Appreciating the Virtues of the Maligned Cassette
description: To the Editor:

title: What Should Chicago Celebrate?
description: Chicago  TODAY is the first Chi-Town Rising, a blowout New Years Eve party along the Chicago riverfront. It promises celebrity and musical guests, including, naturally, the band Chicago. As the countdown to 2016 begins, a 70-foot steel star will ascend 36 stories up the side of the Hyatt Regency, the celebration culminating in a fireworks show.

title: Debt and the Racial Wealth Gap
description: IF you are black, youre far more likely to see your electricity cut, more likely to be sued over a debt, and more likely to land in jail because of a parking ticket.

title: The Counterfeit High School Diploma
description: Teachers unions and other critics of federally required standardized tests have behaved in recent years as though killing the testing mandate would magically remedy everything that ails education in the United States. In reality, getting rid of the testing requirement in the early grades would make it impossible for the country to know what if anything children were learning from year to year.

title: Donald Trumps Strongest Supporters: A Certain Kind of Democrat
description: Donald Trump holds a dominant position in national polls in the Republican race in no small part because he is extremely strong among people on the periphery of the G.O.P. coalition.

title: China Frees 2 Brothers of U.S. Reporter for Radio Free Asia
description: HONG KONG  Two brothers of an American journalist who United States lawmakers say were jailed by China in retaliation for his reporting on ethnic tensions in the countrys Xinjiang region have been freed, the reporters employer said. Another brother remained in custody.

title: Soak. Wash. Rinse. Dry. No Tilt!
description: Patrons at the Sunshine Laundromat in Greenpoint, Brooklyn, can lounge at the bar or play several rounds of pinball while waiting for their clothes to wash and dry.

title: So You Think Your Sisters Boyfriend Is Gay
description: My sister has been dating her boyfriend for two years. They live together and seem mostly happy. And I am happy for them, except for one thing: I am about 99 percent sure he is gay. Now, I have no problem with homosexuality, but you can understand my concern. Also, I am not the only one who thinks this. Several male friends have told me that he has tried to kiss other men or grab their crotches. I would like to bring this up with my sister. How should I do it?

title: Cleaning Up at the Arcade
description: Laundry day at Sunshine Laundromat in Greenpoint, Brooklyn, has always been a little out of the ordinary. Droll portraits of dogs adorn the walls, and snack-size bags of potato chips are complimentary. More than 20 vintage pinball machines ding and ping. Lately, though, there have been some changes.

title: For a Better Commute, the Upper West Side
description: After several years of living in assorted New York shares, sublets and rentals, most recently in Manhattan, Wayne Gerard found himself with just a few days to land a new place to live. So he made a hasty move to an apartment in Astoria, Queens.

title: Alicia Vikander's Breakout Style
description: The star of The Danish Girl shows an easy assurance on the red carpet.

title: Single, and Surrounded by a Wall of Men
Facing Increase, Rent-Controlled Tenants Complain of Being Singled Out
description: At a time when rent-stabilized tenants in New York City are enjoying a freeze in their rents, another group of regulated tenants  the dwindling minority in rent-controlled apartments  is facing an increase of up to 9.6 percent over the next two years.

title: Belgium Arrests 6 and Holds 2 Longer Over New Years Eve Plot
description: LONDON  The authorities in Belgium announced the arrests of six men on Thursday, and a court prolonged the detention of two others, in connection with a plot to attack the capital, Brussels, on New Years Eve.

title: Corrections: December 31, 2015
description: BUSINESS DAY

title: 36 Hours in Tel Aviv
description: Young, modern Tel Aviv and ancient Jaffa pulse with energy and combine to offer bustling markets, night clubs and a beachside promenade just right for two wheels.

title: Ask Well: Should You Filter Your Water?
description: Question:

title: Your Thursday Briefing: Bill Cosby, Donald Trump, New Years Eve
description: (Want to get this briefing by email? Heres the sign-up.)

title: Your Thursday Briefing
description: Heres what you need to know to start the day.

title: New York Today: Making Resolutions
description: Updated 8:59 a.m.

title: Britain to Review How Airport Shops Collect Sales Tax
description: George Osborne, the British chancellor of the Exchequer, announced a review on Thursday of how retailers at major airports in Britain collect sales tax from their customers.

title: A Marine Ecologist Strives to Protect the Seas
description: In 2007, Enric Sala, a marine ecologist, quit his job in academia, saying he was tired of writing the obituary of ocean life. Only 1 percent of the ocean is currently protected, marine scientists say, and the rest is being disrupted by overfishing, pollution, climate change and species extinctions. Dr. Sala said he felt the need to take action.

title: Letter of Recommendation: Terro Liquid Ant Bait
description: Have you ever had an anxiety attack? One of those full-blown panic freakouts: Your hands are tingling, your head is swimming, your skin is crawling and  my God  you want to run away, but you cant, so you crumple wherever you are, even if that means at your desk, in front of your entire office. How long does it last? Hours, days. Maybe it dissipates for a time and then you bolt upright sweating at 3:17 a.m., gulping for air in the darkness. Eventually it retreats, but never completely. Somewhere in the recesses of your mind, anxiety is still tucked away, quietly at work, plotting its next strike.

title: Almost-Traditional Jewish Cooking
description: Living in New York, a spiritual homeland of the delicatessen, I have certain Pavlovian responses to the phrase Jewish food. I sniff around for the scent of fatty fish and smoke. I clutch my supply of Lipitor and fiend for a corned-beef sandwich bigger than my childs head. I assume everything that is yellowish and disc-shaped is a fried potato pancake until proved otherwise.

title: Ken Jeong Is Not Cracking Asian Jokes
description: You were a doctor for seven years before you switched to comedy and acting full time. Did your parents want you to do medicine first? Yeah, I always joke that I was Koreaned into doing medicine.

title: Brie Larson Finds a Hectic Life After Room
description: ARCADIA, CALIF.  Fortified by coffee and a Red Bull on the Sunday morning before Christmas, Brie Larson was hopscotching down a path at the Los Angeles County Arboretum and Botanic Garden here.

title: China Says It Is Building Its Second Aircraft Carrier
description: BEIJING  China is building a second aircraft carrier, the countrys Ministry of National Defense confirmed on Thursday. But unlike the first, this one will be produced entirely using Chinas own designs and technology, the ministry said.

title: New Years Eve Security Bolstered After Terrorist Attacks and Threats
description: New Years Eve is unfolding around the world in an atmosphere of heightened security, after recent terrorist attacks in Paris and San Bernardino, Calif., associated with or inspired by the Islamic State. The authorities in Turkey and Belgium announced this week that they had disrupted terrorist plots aimed at popular destinations in the capitals.

title: When Journalism Catches Hollywoods Eye
description: It is not every year that Hollywood produces two movies about journalism that are Oscar contenders, but 2015 appears to have been that year. First came Truth in October. Based on the memoir of a former 60 Minutes producer, Mary Mapes, it purports to tell the story of her gutsy 2004 investigation into George W. Bushs service in the National Guard when he was a young man. When it turned out that her story, which was broadcast on 60 Minutes II months before the presidents re-election, had unwittingly relied on falsified documents, the network suits turned against her and her famous correspondent, the CBS anchor Dan Rather, costing them their jobs.

title: Dance This Week: Ballerina Swan, Die Fledermaus and the Choreography of Merce Cunningham
description: Allegra Kents Ballerina Swan Onstage

title: Tessa Hadley: By the Book
description: The author, most recently, of The Past finds it frightening to think about the books that form us. Its not just Emma Bovary who makes her life decisions ... based on something that shes read.

title: Food Trends That Shaped 2015
description: Waste is becoming a dirty word in the world of high-end food. During Expo Milano 2015, the Michelin-starred chef Massimo Bottura oversaw  with help from Mario Batali, Alain Ducasse and Ren Redzepi  the Ambrosian Refectory, a pop-up dining hall in a disused theater, where meals were made using surplus from the estimated 400 tons of food that arrive at the culinary fair each day. Batali and Ducasse also worked at New Yorks wastED, a temporary restaurant at Dan Barbers Blue Hill in Greenwich Village, which involved a cast of rotating chefs addressing food waste in their menus.

title: Barge Set Loose in North Sea by Violent Weather Is Secured
description: LONDON  A 360-foot-long barge that was set loose by violent weather in the North Sea was secured on Thursday, after the oil companies BP and ConocoPhillips evacuated hundreds of workers from two oil platforms and temporarily halted production.

title: A Sons New Apartment
description: Dear Diary:

title: 1941: Ringing In the New Year, Underground
description: LONDON  In many different parts of England at the stroke of midnight the faint sound of laughter and singing could be heard issuing from deep in the earth. These waves of sound, vanishing and swelling in turn, came from thousands of people who, like their primitive ancestors, have taken to the caves of England for protection, warmth and human companionship.

title: Ben Carson Raises About $23 Million in Latest Quarter
description: Ben Carson collected roughly $23 million in the final fund-raising quarter of the year, a large haul at a moment when the candidate is trying to bolster his sagging poll numbers. Mr. Carsons campaign spokesman, Doug Watts, confirmed the figure, which was reported first by Politico.

title: 8 Handy Travel Tips From 2015
description: The New York Times Travel section publishes a lot of advice through the year. Here are a few favorites to put into practice in 2016.

title: Man Falls to His Death Climbing the Four Seasons Hotel
description: A 20-year-old man fell to his death as he and a friend tried to take photos of the skyline from a catwalk above the roof of the Four Seasons Hotel in Midtown Manhattan on Wednesday night, the authorities said.

title: Tamir Rice and the Color of Fear
description: A month ago, I was carrying groceries up my apartment-building steps when an old white woman, checking her mail in the lobby, watched me struggle with my bags. She froze at the sight of me, and while I fumbled for my keys, she didnt take a step toward the door to open it for me. When I finally stepped inside, she sighed and apologized. Im sorry I didnt get the door, she said, but I just didnt know you. I kept looking, and I didnt know you.

title: The Year in Illustration
description: A selection of notable art created for the Opinion section in 2015.

title: Spain Has Little Appetite for Truffles, but Plenty for the Truffle Trade
description: SARRIN, Spain  On Saturday nights, prospective buyers gather on the outskirts of this small village, in the darkness of a parking lot next to a semi-abandoned railway station. Using flashlights, they inspect the offerings local farmers have piled in the trunks of their vehicles, then haggle over price.

title: At the Mummers Parade, Philadelphia Celebrates an Old New Years Ritual
description: After they famously strut down Broad Street in Philadelphia, the Mummers go back to their gritty, blue-collar roots on South Second Street.

title: Golden State Warriors Routed? It Happens to the Best of Teams
description: The mighty Warriors lost on Wednesday night; all teams do. But Golden State did not just lose; it was trounced by 23 points at Dallas. And it played without its star, Stephen Curry.

title: Daily Report: A Happy Holiday for Amazon
description: Its not your imagination: Every recycling bin on your block really is filled with Amazon boxes.

title: Digging Deeper for Missing Mac Mail Messages
description: Q. I tried the Rebuild command to find missing messages in Mac Mail on the El Capitan version (OS X 10.11), but it didnt fix my problem. What else can I try?

title: Making a Murderer: Watched It All? Share Your Theories.
description: For armchair detectives, Netflixs Making a Murderer is delicious fodder: 10 hours of a true-crime documentary, smartly released by the streaming service over the holidays, when free time is abundant. After watching the story of Steven Avery, its difficult not to immediately postulate theories and throw things at your screen as you rage against the imperfections of the American justice system.

title: Trial of Chads Ex-President Brings Harrowing Accounts of Abuse
description: PARIS  The witness, a slight middle-aged woman, wanted to tell the court about something that had happened to her, something terrible that she said she had kept to herself for more than 30 years. As she faced the judges, she was just steps away from the man on trial, Hissne Habr, once Chads all-powerful and much-feared president.

title: Blake Bortless Huge Leap Bodes Well for the Jaguars
description: A year ago, Jacksonville Jaguars quarterback Blake Bortles had a nondescript rookie campaign. He finished well below average in most passing metrics and had the lowest passer rating in the N.F.L. among qualifying quarterbacks.

title: Paperback Row
description: CENSORS AT WORK: How States Shaped Literature, by Robert Darnton. (Norton, $17.95.) To understand the longstanding human predilection for censorship, Darnton examines three historical cases of political interference with literature: the monarchy in 18th-century France; British colonial rule in 19th-century India; and the 20th-century Communist dictatorship in East Germany. Exploring the various justifications governments have invoked in defense of censorship, the author draws inferences about its long-term cultural impact.

title: Editors Choice
description: BRIGHT SCYTHE: Selected Poems, by Tomas Transtromer. Translated by Patty Crane. (Sarabande Books, $17.95.) Until his death last year, the 2011 Nobelist was one of Europes greatest poets, producing work of austere beauty and mystery.

title: Keeping Up With Firefox Updates
description: Q. Why does the Firefox browser on my computer constantly update itself? Is there a way to see what is actually being changed?

title: Manila Social Club
description: Nostalgia suffuses the dishes at this Filipino restaurant in Williamsburg, Brooklyn.

title: At Manila Social Club in Williamsburg, Rambling Filipino Cuisine
description: Bjrn DelaCruz never learned the name of the dish he ate at a roadside shack under a narra tree, not far from his grandmothers orchid farm in Davao Oriental, the Philippines. It was simple, made with carabao (water buffalo) milk, chayote and fish likely caught in the river running alongside.

title: Inside the List
description: Be Prepared: If your New Years resolutions include acquiring the know-how to build your own stun gun, dispose of a body and trick facial-recognition technology  in other words, the usual  you might want to skip the advice list and head straight to the monthly espionage list, available online, where Clint Emersons 100 Deadly Skills was No.2 in December. Emerson is a former member of the Navy SEALs who served with Chris Kyle, of American Sniper fame, and now runs his own security consulting firm in the Dallas suburbs. Among the 100 lessons in his crisply illustrated manual are such handy pointers as how to turn a plastic water bottle into a gun silencer and, for bibliophiles, how to build a bulletproof vest out of duct tape and books. You have to learn from the predators, Emerson told Texas Monthly this fall, because your natural-born instinct wont be good enough.

title: A Strange Business, by James Hamilton
description: James Hamiltons A Strange Business  the title is taken from an observation about the art market made late in life by the brilliant British painter J. M. W. Turner  is every bit as quirky a book as you might expect from a onetime fellow at St. Antonys College, Oxford. It has 31 pages of endnotes; a 14-page index; and six pages of bibliography, in reduced type, including a section for primary source material, one for secondary source material and another for manuscripts consulted. There are also four tiny-type pages devoted to recounting for the befuddled reader the names of the 180 or so Dramatis Personae that get name-checked continually, from George Ackermann, the art dealer and publisher, to John Young, the engraver and curator.

title: After a Tumultuous Year for Investors, the Experts Look Ahead
description: The last year was a treacherous one for investors, including some top hedge fund and asset managers. Much of what happened in global markets can be traced to falling oil and commodity prices, which rippled through the economies and markets of most major oil-producing nations.

title: 21 Injured on Air Canada Flight After Sudden Turbulence
description: OTTAWA  Sudden and intense turbulence during an Air Canada flight on Wednesday threw passengers out of their seats, with some hitting the ceiling of the airplane, and resulted in numerous injuries.

title: Up Against the Night, by Justin Cartwright
description: In the 1830s, the Boer commander Pieter Mauritz Retief led part of the Great Trek out of the British-occupied Cape Colony, intending to settle in Zululand, only to be massacred by the Zulu kings warriors. Many years later, Retiefs legacy  a thorny mix of heroism, nationalism and racism  haunts his fictional descendant, Frank McAllister, the present-day narrator of Justin Cartwrights latest novel, Up Against the Night. The battle provides the only sound archival root for what becomes a gratifyingly unsound psychological odyssey.

title: One Out of Two, by Daniel Sada
description: The Mexican writer Daniel Sadas second novel to appear in English, One Out of Two, is a spry addition to the genre of spinster sister fiction. Sada, who died in 2011, was as prolific as he was mischievous. Between his birth in Mexicali in 1953 and his death at 58, he published 20 books of fiction and poetry, all of them consistently unpredictable. In One Out of Two, Sadas interest in spinster escapades is foremost in the opportunities they create for playing around with sexual tension and transgression.

title: Suspicious Minds, by Rob Brotherton
description: For all the talk of Donald Trumps unpresidential behavior, the Republican enfant terrible does share one notable trait with that paragon of presidentiality, George Washington: a fondness for conspiracy theories. Washington once wrote in a letter that he believed an Illuminati conspiracy was at work in America, while Trump is the figurehead of the birther movement, which claims Barack Obama is not a natural-born American citizen. The psychologist and science journalist Rob Brothertons new book, Suspicious Minds: Why We Believe Conspiracy Theories, helps explain why someone with such seemingly outlandish views can gain widespread public support. It turns out we are all conspiracy theorists.

title: Bird, by Noy Holland
description: After three widely praised story collections, Noy Hollands first novel, Bird, is a whirling and feverish illustration of how much time can be contained in the present moment. A master of the domestic, Holland takes us again into that sphere: into the life of Bird, a stay-at-home mother of two children, as she moves through the events of a single day. Bird readies her son for school, sees her husband out the door, takes a bath with the baby. An old friend calls, and they share stories about the past. Bird takes the baby for a walk, and they stop by a pond, enjoying some time on the grass. Returning home, she flips through a photo album, talks on the phone again and hangs up in time to share the last moments of sunlight with the baby before greeting her son at the school bus.

title: Martin John, byAnakana Schofield
description: Its not often you feel sympathetically disposed toward flashers, gropers, public masturbators or punchers of womens private parts, and in fairness, you dont often feel it while reading Martin John either  but you sometimes do, which makes Anakana Schofield either an extremely persuasive apologist for the sexually aberrant or a very fine novelist.

title: Abba Eban: A Biography, by Asaf Siniver
description: In December 1955, following Syrian harassment of Israeli fishermen on the Sea of Galilee, Israel carried out a large attack on Syrian military positions, killing 50 soldiers and capturing 30. Abba Eban, Israels eloquent and admired representative to the United Nations, thought the response was over the top and wrote a letter to Prime Minister David Ben-Gurion condemning the raid. At the United Nations, meanwhile, Eban defended the operation, assailing Syrias implacable hostility. Ben-Gurion wrote back to Eban saying he himself had had doubts about the retaliation but when I read the full text of your brilliant defense of our action in the Security Council, all my doubts were set to rest. You have convinced me that we were right after all.

title: The English and Their History, by Robert Tombs
description: Even in free countries it is sometimes necessary to alter the past to suit the present. For instance, I recall the day at my English boarding school in the early 1960s when our sober, patriotic old history books were gathered up and carted away to a storeroom. In their place we were handed bright, optimistic replacements, with a good deal less to say about the empire, the Protestant martyrs or what we had been taught without embarrassment to call the Glorious Revolution.

title: Infectious Madness, by Harriet A. Washington
description: One hundred and sixty odd years ago, Ignaz Semmelweis realized that physicians who didnt wash their hands were carrying tiny germs from bedside to bedside and causing the childbed fever that killed many women. After doctors began washing their hands, fewer women died. The series of realizations in the 19th century that germs  bacteria and viruses  caused diseases like cholera and tuberculosis and influenza ushered in modern medicine. Mortality rates declined; children lived longer. Germ theory had a dramatic clarity to it. It pushed medicine away from holistic conceptions of illness as imbalance toward conceptions of illness as a specific entity. You get the germ, you fall sick, you take antibiotics or fight it off (or die). Ironically, though, the tidiness of this relationship helped obscure cases where germs may have less direct but still devastating effects  a complex reality we are now beginning to understand better.

title: Thomas Perrys Forty Thieves, and More
description: Nick and Nora Charles theyre not. But while Sid and Veronica Abel may be lacking in urbanity, these private investigators are no less brainy and far better marksmen. Appearing for the first time in Thomas Perrys new thriller, FORTY THIEVES (Mysterious, $26), these former Los Angeles police detectives have been married for over 30 years and have children and grandchildren. That confers on them the wisdom of the ancients, along with the cloak of invisibility in a youth-obsessed society, which suits them just fine. (Do you have any idea what gray hair is worth in our business?)

title: BBC Websites Said to Be Target of Online Attack
description: The British Broadcasting Corporation said on Thursday that its digital services had been shut down temporarily in what its news operation described as a hacking attack.

title: 2 Sentenced to Death in Killing of Bangladeshi Activist in 2013
description: DHAKA, Bangladesh  A court in Bangladesh sentenced two people to death and six others to prison terms on Thursday for killing a secular blogger and activist in 2013, the first sentences in a series of  killings of bloggers in Bangladesh.

title: Food Memoir
description: HOW TO COOK A MOOSEA Culinary MemoirBy Kate Christensen292 pp. Islandport, $24.95.

title: Pentagon Curbs Use of Psychologists With Guantnamo Detainees
description: WASHINGTON  The United States military has sharply curtailed the use of psychologists at the prison at Guantnamo Bay, Cuba, in response to strict new professional ethics rules of the American Psychological Association, Pentagon officials said.

title: Ted Cruz Raises Almost $20 Million in Year-End Surge
description: Senator Ted Cruz raised significantly more money in the final three months of the year while Ben Carson maintained his pace in fund-raising during that period, according to numbers released by the Republican presidential hopefuls campaigns.

title: Inside The New York Times Book Review: You, New and Improved
description: This week, Heather Havrilesky talks about Amy Cuddys Presence and Shonda Rhimess Year of Yes, and Michael Ian Black discusses Navel Gazing. Pamela Paul is the host.

title: 1966 | We Could Not Move, We Could Not Take Cover
description: It took decades to forge the legend of the correspondent R.W. Apple Jr.  a man known for his Dickensian byline, Churchillian brio and Falstaffian appetites, according to Todd Purdum, a former Times reporter who wrote Mr. Apples obituary.

title: Fund-Raising Pleas Get Desperate as Year Winds Down
description: Senator Ted Cruz has nowhere else to turn. Jeb Bush is counting on you. Senator Marco Rubio needs you to hear this. Senator Rand Paul needs all hands on deck.

title: Chris Christies Punch Lines vs. Marco Rubios Polish on Iowa Campaign Trail
description: MUSCATINE, Iowa  It was the same question, on the same topic, asked on the same day to two different candidates: How, as president, would you hold down the crushing cost of a college education?

title: Manspreading, Vape and So: Hated Words for 2016
description: If you are still trying to decide on a New Years resolution, there are some people in Michigan who might be able to help: Promise never to use the word problematic again.

title: Polls Show Attacks on Bill Clinton May Only Help Hillary Clinton
description: Donald J. Trump made clear this week that nothing was off limits when it came to attacking the Clintons, dusting off names like Monica Lewinsky and Paula Jones while calling former President Bill Clinton one of the great abusers of the world. Sexual indiscretions of the past, he said, are fair game in an election year.

title: Soaking The Rich, Slightly
description: Good catch by Josh Barro. Its been clear for a while that taxes on top incomes went up significantly in 2013; but weve had to rely on estimates of the change, not actual numbers. Now the actual numbers on income taxes are in, and sure enough, fairly big hikes at the top.

title: Over 50 and Buying a First Home
description: Edith Shapiro was 36 when she and her husband, Nathan, moved in 1967 to a brand-new rental building at 200 East 62nd Street. Back then, $725 per month got them a four-bedroom duplex with four and a half baths.

title: The Red Tape of New Windows in New York
description: In many parts of the country, replacing old, drafty, noisy windows is as simple as selecting products at a home improvement store and scheduling a contractor to install them. But thats not the case in New York, where window replacement, like so many facets of home renovation, is governed by rules and procedures.

title: Fino Sherry, for the Undaunted
description: Stick your nose into a glass of fino sherry and you may be in for a shock. Years of enjoying the usual sorts of fruity reds and whites will not have prepared you for the wave (some may say assault) of aromas. Instead of the gentle sweetness that sherry novices may expect, what arises is bone dry, pungent and savory, almost the antithesis of sweet and fruity.

title: Your Next Lesson: Marsannay Burgundy
description: Next up, we visit what many consider the spiritual center for much that we worship about red wine: Burgundy.

title: Iran Denounces U.S. Sanctions Over Missiles, Saying It Will Build More
description: Irans president denounced the United States on Thursday for suggesting the possibility of new sanctions over Iranian missiles, and he ordered his Defense Ministry to respond by swiftly building more of them.

title: Top Ben Carson Aides Quit Amid Campaign Turmoil
description: New upheaval engulfed Ben Carsons troubled presidential campaign on Thursday as his campaign manager and his spokesman resigned abruptly after a deep rift with an outside adviser to the candidate.

title: The Selfish Side of Gratitude
description: THIS holiday season, there was something in the air that was even more inescapable than the scent of pumpkin spice: gratitude.

title: Seinfeld and Obama, Chatting in a Corvette
description: President Obama wears one brand of underwear, always the same color. He shaves before working out in the morning. And he picks out his own suit.

title: Murder Isnt Black or White
description: IT was the spring of 1991  more than two decades before Ferguson, Mo., would become a national symbol of racism  when my parents took my siblings and me to visit their hometown, St. Louis. We spent the week hanging out with our cousins, with whom we were close. I was 16, too young to tag along when, the night before we were supposed to return home to Maryland, my 19-year-old brother, Tom Cummins, and our cousins, Julie and Robin Kerry, were brutally attacked by four strangers. Julie was 20, Robin, 19.

title: Review: In Stories I Tell Myself, Life as Hunter S. Thompsons Son
description: Its not easy growing up a shy, sensitive, bullied, Dungeons & Dragons-playing child, the kind of friendless boy who hates sports, becomes a vegetarian and in college eats alone in the cafeteria, pretending to read a newspaper while dying inside.

title: Anatomy of a Scene | 45 Years
description: Andrew Haigh narrates a sequence from his film featuring Charlotte Rampling and Tom Courtenay.

title: Same Trail, Diverging Styles
description: Chris Christie and Marco Rubio showed strikingly different styles over two days of campaigning in Iowa.

title: Allen Lacy, a Professor Turned Gardening Columnist, Dies at 80
description: Allen Lacy, an accidental gardening columnist whose cramped backyard inspired practical advice on down-to-earth subjects like expunging crab grass and erudite cerebrations about far-flung fields like global warming, died last Sunday at his home in Linwood, N.J. He was 80.

title: You Can Now Call Him Sir Matthew (Bourne)
description: LONDON  The choreographer Matthew Bourne, the actress Imelda Staunton, the Blur frontman Damon Albarn, the ballerina Tamara Rojo and the choreographer Christopher Wheeldon are all on this years New Years Honors 2016, the list of awards announced by the British cabinet office to those who have distinguished themselves in a variety of professional or charitable fields. (These are wide-ranging, and this year include honorable services to snooker among many others.)

title: The Next Big Voting-Rights Fight
description: Over the past year, The New York Times Magazine has chronicled the long campaign that led to the Supreme Courts 2013 nullification of the Voting Rights Acts most powerful provision  its Section 5  and the consequences that decision has had for minority voters. As Ive written in our Disenfranchised series, the gutting of Section 5 facilitated an onslaught of restrictive new laws that made voting disproportionately harder for minorities across the country, marking the biggest setback to minority voting rights in the half-century since President Johnson signed the Voting Rights Act.

title: Fire Engulfs Luxury Dubai Hotel, Forcing Evacuation of New Years Crowd
description: DUBAI, United Arab Emirates  A luxury hotel skyscraper in Dubai was engulfed in flames after a fire broke out Thursday, causing an evacuation of a large crowd from the downtown area that had gathered for New Years Eve.

title: Andrew Haigh Narrates a Scene From 45 Years
description: A couple (Charlotte Rampling and Tom Courtenay) face a hurdle in their lengthy marriage in the drama 45 Years, written and directed by Andrew Haigh. The British filmmakers previous film, Weekend, looked at the the brief relationship between two men after a one-night stand. In a recent interview at The Times, Mr. Haigh discussed how those films were alike and his decision to follow up a gay-themed film with one on heterosexual characters. Here are excerpts from that conversation.

title: On the 101st Floor, Saying I Do
description: Haley Swindal, an actress, and Jack Tantleff, a theatrical agent, were married Dec. 12 high above Manhattan in One World Trade Center.

title: An Actress and an Agent: What Could Be a Better Match?
description: Ever since his divorce in 2008, Jack Tantleff, a theatrical agent in New York, had struggled to find someone to fill the role of partner in his life.

title: Video Review: The Scion iM Is Proud to Be a Hatchback
description: THEYVE been embraced by Europeans and shunned by Americans. Lately, this could pertain to any number of things, but right now Im describing hatchbacks.

title: Ants Can Change Their Roles, Study Finds
description: Among Florida carpenter ants there are the so-called majors, brawny soldiers that guard the colony, and the smaller minors that act as foragers. But membership in these castes is not set in stone, a new study found.

title: Gene Editing Offers Hope for Treating Duchenne Muscular Dystrophy, Studies Find
description: After decades of disappointingly slow progress, researchers have taken a substantial step toward a possible treatment for Duchenne muscular dystrophy with the help of a powerful new gene-editing technique.

title: Test Your Downton Abbey Drama Quotient
description: Downton Abbey ends its six-season run on Sunday. How well do you know the characters and their tortured pasts?

title: Russia Plans Survey in Crimea on Ukraine Electricity Contract
description: MOSCOW  In an echo of the referendum in 2014 on whether to join Russia, residents of Crimea are being asked if they want to reaffirm their choice.

title: Jeb Bush Courts Iowa Supporters at Rose Bowl in California
description: With most political eyes on Iowa right now, and most Iowa eyes on the Rose Bowl  where their beloved Hawkeyes are taking on Stanford on New Years Day  the super PAC supporting Jeb Bush is heading to Pasadena, Calif., where the big game will be held.

title: F.B.I. Is Asked to Investigate Chicago Police Shooting That Left 2 Dead
description: CHICAGO  The top county prosecutor hereThursdayasked the F.B.I. to investigate the fatal shooting of two people by a Chicago police officer over the weekend, and Mayor Rahm Emanuels administration separately released a trove of emails showing how City Hall aides scrambled for months to address an earlier police shooting that was captured on video.

title: Rochester Man Charged With Planning Attack on Behalf of ISIS
description: A 25-year-old man in Rochester has been arrested and charged with preparing to stage a New Years Eve machete attack on diners at a local restaurant on behalf of the Islamic State.

title: A Turbulent Year in the Music Business
description: For the music industry, 2015 was a year of huge hits, big battles behind the scenes and the continuing evolution of an industry that has been transformed by technology and the Internet.

title: The Last (and Most Expensive) Night of the Year
description: Vegas Dave knows what it costs to ring in the new year, Vegas Dave-style.

title: Jewish-Arab Love Story Excluded From Israeli Classrooms
description: JERUSALEM  Israels Ministry of Education has decided not to include a novel about a romance between an Israeli woman and a Palestinian man on the list of required reading for Hebrew high school literature classes, prompting a stormy debate over how Israeli society deals with its cultural divides.

title: Review: Metropolitan Museum Looks at Photos That May Last
description: It is contemporary photography roundup time in New York, with major exhibitions appearing concurrently at the Museum of Modern Art (Ocean of Images: New Photography 2015) and the Guggenheim (Photo-Poetics: An Anthology). The Mets contribution, Reconstructions: Recent Photographs and Video From the Met Collection, is not framed as a showcase of whats new, hot or trending, but it relates both subtly and significantly to these two exhibitions. The show includes 18 works by 15 artists acquired during the past seven years  work that Met curators think will endure historically.

title: The New Exponential Festival Opens in Brooklyn
description: Last spring, Theresa Buchheister, a founder of the experimental theater company Title: Point, and Eliza Bent, a playwright and performer, spent an evening lamenting all the shows theyd missed  friends plays that had overlapped with their own, short runs theyd discovered too late. These were shows that should happen again, Ms. Bent remembered insisting. But when? And where?

title: Review: Praying to the Heavens, Looking at the Stars and Revising a Service
description: Starting around the 1960s, radical revisions to the Christian liturgy have resulted in a more accessible service and a great deal of music for the Mass. But not much of it has been by significant composers.

title: This Weeks Movies | Jan. 1, 2016
description: The New York Times film critics review Concussion, Anomalisa and Daddys Home.

title: Review: Maest, Piecing Together Part of a Lost Legacy
description: Sometimes you dont know what you have until its gone. Thats a lesson viewers might take away from Maest: Gaddis Triptych Reunited, a tiny exhibition at the New-York Historical Society that inadvertently prompts thought about museums and their responsibilities.

title: A Recovering but Changed Auto Industry
description: United States automakers have emerged from their worst crisis in a generation, but they have lost much along the way.

title: Auto Industry Sales Explode in an Ever-Changing Market
description: DETROIT  Automakers have enjoyed an unequaled run of success in the United States because of pent-up consumer demand, cheap gas prices and low interest rates. But despite record sales, manufacturers must continue updating their vehicles and improving technology to keep the good times rolling.

title: Our Favorite Styles Photos of 2015
description: A look at some of the years most striking Styles section images.

title: In Reversal, Twitter to Let Politwoops Collect Politicians Deleted Tweets
description: Politwoops will once again be able to collect and publish the deleted tweets of American politicians after Twitter announced Thursday that it reached a deal with the organizations that run the website.

title: Bill Cunningham | Lush Colors
description: As we embark on the new year, the richness of colors, particularly pastels and flower patterns on winter coats, often reflects the hidden treasures of gemstones and of vegetables sliced open, revealing an intense color inside. A spectrum that ranged from amethyst to lavender was mirrored in cabbage roses. Blacks and grays remain a foundation of fashion for practical reasons.

title: Escaped Convicts in Argentina Shoot 2 Police Officers
description: INTENDENTE ALVEAR, Argentina  Three escaped convicts shot and wounded two traffic police officers on Thursday, officials said, after a prison break that set off a round of finger-pointing between feuding politicians.

title: Movie Review: Daddys Home
description: The Times critic Stephen Holden reviews Daddys Home.

title: New Years Day Offers Plenty of Free Chances at a Clean Slate
description: Whether youre hoping to improve your body or your mind  or even just add to your cocktail conversation repertory  this weekend has plenty of events for self-improvement that, while opening the door for commitment, ask for nothing upfront.

title: Friday File: When the Ball First Dropped on New Years Eve
description: The last newspaper printed before The New York Times left its building on Park Row appeared on New Years Day, 1905.

title: Spurs Get a Laugh Track to Go With Their Five Titles
description: Phil Jackson, or, rather, a coarsely animated version of him, is sitting in a hotel room, threatening Gregg Popovich, the San Antonio Spurs coach, and pressing him to join the Knicks with a big-city sales pitch.

title: Movie Review: Concussion
description: The Times critic Manohla Dargis reviews Concussion.

title: The Year in Weird Contentions
Movie Review: Anomalisa
description: The Times critic Manohla Dargis reviews Anomalisa.

title: Review: Squeak Carnwath Speaks With Her Varied Palette
description: Over the decades, Squeak Carnwath has cultivated a distinctive blend of disparate 1970s art movements, including New Image painting, Conceptual Art and above all Process Art. In her first solo show in New York in over a decade, her paintings fluently speak several languages at once. Areas of flat color are adrift with abstract and representational elements as well as writing  passing thoughts, the news, quips  often partly submerged in the shuffle of erasures and new additions. Everything contributes to the commentary. Tracts of cursive consider the income gap or light pollution, while little blocks of color allude to abstraction and a compass rose conjures cartography and sign painting.

title: Evening Hours | The Debutante Cotillion
description: A festive tradition continues.

title: Review: Rudolf Stingel at Nahmad Contemporary, Making Crowd-Sourced Art
description: By 2000, the Italian-born painter Rudolf Stingel had made what he called paintings by covering floors or walls with bright orange carpet, and had sold D.I.Y. abstract painting kits. He then began to adopt more traditional formats while maintaining his hands-off attitude. The results, as demonstrated by the 10 paintings from 2000 to 2003 in this exhibition, continue to startle, taunt and seduce.

title: N.F.L. Week 17 Previews and Picks
description: Vikings (10-5) at Packers (10-5)

title: Review: In The Himalayas, Two Climbers Form an Indelible Bond
description: The Himalayas is a broad comedy, a buddy movie, a mountain climbing adventure and a cornball weepie, not always in proportions that go well together. Inspired by a real-life mission to recover the bodies of mountaineering compatriots who died on Mount Everest in 2004, it spans roughly a dozen years in the lives of a team of South Korean climbers.

title: Dog Days Is Centerpiece of Prototype Festival
description: For new music, the main difficulty isnt getting a premiere. Its getting a second performance, and a third, and a fourth, the repetitions necessary for a piece really to enter the cultural bloodstream.

title: More Hillary Clinton Emails Are Released, but State Department Falls Short
description: WASHINGTON  The State Department fell short of a court order requiring the release of the vast bulk of former Secretary of State Hillary Clintons emails by the end of 2015, but promised on Thursday to catch up early in the new year.

title: Review: In Barb Choits Pronk, 1980s Shoes Are Back
Review: Only Yesterday, Isao Takahatas Time-Jumping Anime
description: Isao Takahata, an Academy Award nominee and one of the twin pillars of the anime giant Studio Ghibli, brings the cleareyed grace of his animation to the lovely memoiristic story of a 27-year-old woman in Only Yesterday. As the woman, Taeko, goes on a vacation in the country that brings back grade-school memories, Mr. Takahata finds a poignancy in milestones and ordinary moments alike, showing her sense of self deepening over time.

title: Review: Nathaniel Robinsons Sculptures Tease Perceptions
description: The remarkably inventive sculptor Nathaniel Robinson makes technically impressive, philosophically provocative works that play in the gap between perception and cognition  between what you see and what you understand.

title: Site of a Raging Fire in Downtown Dubai
description: A 63-story luxury hotel in Dubai caught on fire Thursday evening, interrupting New Years Eve celebrations.

title: Review: In Other Peoples Children, a Womans Pain and Search for Artistic Solace
description: Other Peoples Children, a painfully hackneyed first feature by the director Liz Hinlein, is doomed from the outset by its wearisome heroine, Sam (Diane Marshall-Green). Appearing in almost every scene, Sam  a filmmaker who has victim practically stenciled on her forehead  drifts vapidly through downtown Los Angeles, trying to untangle her feelings about her recently deceased father by engaging in mindless sex and binge drinking.

title: Making a Show From Found Videos, Both Unsettling and Lighthearted
description: Everyone knows the YouTube sensations, the most popular cats and kiddos. But Sean McElroy and Tei Blow, the avant-garde theater duo who make up Royal Osiris Karaoke Ensemble, were after the opposite: YouTube videos with almost no audience.

title: Spare Times for Children Listings for Jan. 1-7
description: Sometimes only a few days separate Christmas cheer from cabin fever. For families whove grown tired of staying at home, Brooklyn Botanic Garden offers a weekend event in which colorful paper and pungent pine have nothing to do with the holidays.

title: A Year of Mourning Steeped in African Tradition Leads to a Theater Piece
description: Kaneza Schaal was 25 when her father died of malaria in 2010. Her first impulse was to stay in New York, not fly to the funeral in Burundi, where he lived when he wasnt in the East Village. At the time, she was working with immigrant students at a school in Chelsea, and she saw no reason to interrupt that.

title: Review: In Yosemite, a Coming-of-Age Tale of 3 Boys in 1980s California
description: The young French-born filmmaker Gabrielle Demeestere can be an observant and resourceful simulator of lovely small moments. Theres a brief sequence in her debut feature, Yosemite (adapted in part from a couple of stories by its executive producer and co-star James Franco), in which a boy wakes up in the morning to find a spider walking up his bedroom curtain. He cups it in his hands, examines it, and some of his wonder and curiosity make their way off the screen.

title: BTG Pactual Sells Distressed Debt Unit to Itau Unibanco
description: RIO DE JANEIRO  Brazils largest private sector banking group said on Thursday that it had agreed to acquire the distressed debt unit of the troubled investment firm BTG Pactual for about 1.2 billion reais, or about $307 million.

title: A Desert Biennial Alongside Coachella Is in the Works
description: Ever since Ed Ruscha and friends threw a Royal typewriter out the window of a speeding Buick LeSabre near Los Angeles for his 1967 photographic book, Royal Road Test, the impact of the California desert has been visible in his work. Now, Mr. Ruscha is part of an effort to establish a biennial-like exhibition in the Palm Springs area that would be timed for February through April 2017 to overlap with Modernism Week and the Coachella Valley Music and Arts Festival, two big crowd-pleasers.

title: Review: Phish Settles In for Another New Years Run
description: Phish began its semi-regular New Years run at Madison Square Garden on Wednesday, the first of its four straight nights of shows there. The concerts are sold out. If you dont have a ticket and dont follow Phish, it means that youll see excitable, woodsy-looking men with beards in Midtown bars before 7:30 and after 11:30 p.m. The concerts will in no other way affect you. They do not intersect with contemporary aesthetics or dynamic social currents.

title: Response to Paris Attacks Points to Weaknesses in French Police Structure
description: PARIS  Since the devastating Nov. 13 attacks in Paris, the French police have offered only a fragmentary outline of their response and of how they deployed antiterror teams and other forces. The somberness and solidarity in the weeks since have muted public criticism. No review of the polices performance has been announced.

title: Review: For the Crawleys and Downton Abbey, the Beginning of the End
description: Downton Abbey  the country house, if not the wildly popular PBS drama  begins the shows final season on Sunday night in a depleted state. Servants are not being replaced, and Robert Crawley, the Earl of Grantham, is hinting that further reductions may be needed. Upstairs, both Tom Branson and Rose MacClare (now Lady Rose Aldridge) have sailed for America, taking with them some of the shows energy and audience good will. When the Granthams gather in the morning, its a sad showing, just Robert, Mary and Edith around a small table.

title: Review: Drips, Dropped: Pollock and His Impact
description: Any exhibition of older art drawn from a museums permanent collection is a palm held out for us to read, a snapshot of the museums sense of its role over time, its present ambitions and its view of art history. Place two such exhibitions side by side and an especially intense and revealing frisson can occur.

title: Comedy Listings for Jan. 1-7
description: For news about comedy, including critical commentary: nytimes.com/arts. A searchable guide to these and other shows is at nytimes.com/events.

title: Merkel Urges Germans to See Migrants as an Opportunity, Not a Threat
description: As Germans prepared to ring in 2016 alongside at least a million migrants who were registered as new residents in 2015, Chancellor Angela Merkel dedicated a New Years Eve address to what she said her nation could gain from the refugee crisis.

title: A Times Course for Young World Changers Asks, Sustain What?
description: Most visitors know I left full-time journalism in 2010 to teach courses on communication and environmental policy at Pace University. But you may not know that The Times, itself, is expanding its mission beyond traditional journalism and, with a partner, has launched The School of The New York Times, offering mini-courses on weekends to high school and older middle school students and courses for professionals in various fields. Therell soon be online classesand much more.

title: Spare Times for Jan. 1-7
description: Three Kings Day Parade (Wednesday) Also known as the Epiphany, this Christian holiday, as the name suggests, celebrates the day the three Magi visited the newborn Jesus and gave him gifts.Different countries have their traditions; in Spain and Latin America, the holiday usually comes with fanfare: colorful parades with tributes to camels and kings in the streets.

title: Subpoena Ordering Recipients Not to Disclose
description: An order by prosecutors not to disclose the existence of this subpoena was sharply rebuked by a federal judge. By law, recipients of subpoenas are free to tell anyone about them.

title: Winning Before God at Clemson
description: MIAMI GARDENS, Fla.  At the end of Clemson Coach Dabo Swinneys news conference on Wednesday, I asked him a theology-based question.

description: Reporters from The Times explored the answers to these questions and others in some of our most-read longer pieces of the year on the 2016 presidential campaign.

title: Its an Unobtrusive Assistant Whispering in Your Ear (Not Little Brother)
description: Google Glass, the augmented reality assistant in the form of an omnipresent glass eye, failed largely because of the anxiety it created. In San Francisco, Glass wearers were quickly mocked, and Google reluctantly went back to the drawing board.

title: Museum & Gallery Listings for Jan. 1-7
description: Museums and galleries are in Manhattan unless otherwise noted. Full reviews of recent art shows: nytimes.com/art. A searchable guide to these and many other art shows is at nytimes.com/events.

title: Pictures of the Day: South Korea and Elsewhere
description: South Korea and More  Pictures of the Day

title: Hostage at Bataclan Recalls Terrorists During Paris Attack
description: PARIS  He was one of a dozen-odd hostages captured by a group of terrorists as they finished their massacre in November at the Bataclan, living for over two hours in their grip in a narrow upstairs corridor at the Paris concert hall and then through the final assault of the police as bullets flew.

title: Dec. 31, 2015  Pictures of the Day
description: Photos from South Korea, Tokyo, Switzerland and Turkey.

title: Decrease in Homeless Veterans in New York Far Outpaces National Drop
description: The bedraggled veteran draped in a flag, begging for spare change, has been one of the most persistent images of homelessness in this country.

title: Television This Winter: 20 Shows to Keep on Your Radar Screen
description: AMERICAN CRIME, American Crime Story, The Americans  the winter season of new and returning television shows has a patriotic sound to it (setting aside that the shows in question are about rape, murder and Soviet espionage). And you can throw in a PBS drama actually set in America, Mercy Street; an alternate history of an American tragedy, 11.22.63; and the return of an American classic, The X-Files. Here are 20 shows to watch for during the next three months.

title: Microsoft to Notify Users of Government Hackings
description: SEATTLE  Microsoft says it will begin notifying users of its online services if they have been targets of suspected state-sponsored online attacks, joining a growing list of Internet companies stepping up their security policies with similar measures.

title: Gun-Friendly Texas Is Getting Even Friendlier
description: HOUSTON  Texas is so gun-friendly that it is easier to get into the Capitol in Austin with a firearm than without one  licensed, gun-carrying lawmakers and members of the public have their own no-wait security lane, and the unarmed masses have to stand in line and slog through the metal detectors.

title: Super PACs Supporting Ted Cruz Plan a $1 Million Advertising Buy
description: A string of allied super PACs supporting the presidential campaign of Senator Ted Cruz of Texas is planning a $1 million television, digital and radio advertising buy in the early voting states, with the heaviest spending in Iowa, a spokeswoman for the group said.

title: A Family in Transition Rebuilds Its Connections
description: When Karen Quinoness son Tristian was almost 3 years old, a New Jersey Transit driver stopped the bus in the middle of the Lincoln Tunnel and pleaded with her to stop her sons crying. He said the tantrum was so distracting that he could not drive.

title: Chief Justices Report Praises Limits on Litigants Access to Information
description: WASHINGTON  Calling for a change in our legal culture, Chief Justice John G. Roberts Jr. devoted his year-end report on the state of the federal judiciary to a plea that lawyers avoid antagonistic tactics, wasteful procedural maneuvers and teetering brinkmanship.

title: A Roller Coaster Year Ends With U.S. Markets Mostly Down
description: Investors may be disappointed with the lackluster performance of the United States stock market in 2015, but, given all that happened, it could have been worse.
